DOC.HEAD: Rhetoric Gets Hot in Texas, Nebraska, Michigan and Maine
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `Exon denied...' with 2 grafs to UPDATE with Daub and Kerrey comment. Picks up 5th graf pvs, `Tower left...'
DOC.TEXT: Texas GOP gubernatorial nominee Clayton Williams called Democrat Ann Richards a ``liar'' to her face Thursday, and former Sen. John Tower said Nebraska Democrat Jim Exon has a reputation as one of the ``biggest boozers in the Senate.'' Williams and Richards were making a rare joint appearance in Dallas. Tower, who is from Texas, was in Omaha to campaign on behalf of Exon's Republican opponent for the Senate seat, former Rep. Hal Daub. With less than a month to go before the Nov. 6 elections, rhetoric also heated up in gubernatorial races in Maine and Michigan. A supporter of GOP candidate John Engler Michigan Gov. James Blanchard's tactics to Hitler's. Maine Democrat Joseph Brennan deflected criticism of pardons he gave as governor, saying Republican Gov. John McKernan might have needed one. Exon denied Tower's accusations and said he would welcome a Senate investigation of his reputation. He urged Daub to renounce the allegations. At a news conference, Daub declined to do so. Nebraska's other senator, Democrat Bob Kerrey, called Tower's campaign activities ``wormlike.'' Tower left the Senate after the 1984 elections. Last year President Bush nominated him to be secretary of defense, but those aspirations were derailed by allegations of drinking and womanizing. Exon had opposed Tower's nomination. ``Sen. Exon bore down on me heavily on the drinking thing when he's got the reputation in Washington of being one of the two or three biggest boozers in the Senate,'' Tower said on Omaha radio station KKAR's program ``Talk of the Town.'' ``We're talking about reputation,'' Tower continued. ``We're talking about rumor. Specific comments that have been related to me by others. So I would have to say that I don't have firsthand knowledge. I would establish that because that is the fair way to do it.'' In Dallas, Richards and Williams were on a podium at a gathering of the Greater Dallas Crime Commission when Williams walked to Richards' side of the stage to greet supporters. Richards extended her hand, but Williams declined to shake it, saying, ``I'm here to call you a liar today.'' ``That's what you are. You've lied about me; you've lied about Mark White and you've lied about Jim Mattox. I'm going to finish this deal today.'' Richards defeated White and Mattox in a bitter Democratic primary. Williams' campaign has been punctuated by outspoken and sometimes outrageous remarks. Williams said he was angry that Richards was spreading rumors in an attempt to link him with a federal investigation into alleged drug money laundering. ``We think she stepped over the line. It is our intention that Ann Richards is no longer able to spread her venom. We want to make sure she is not able to destroy other people's careers and reputations,'' said campaign spoksman Bill Kenyon. Richards called Williams' comment ``unkind'' and said ``I think it's important that Clayton Williams tell the people of Texas exactly what kind of businessman he is.'' In Michigan, a supporter of Republican gubernatorial candidate John Engler on Tuesday said Gov. James Blanchard's tactics have ``been as effective as the Third Reich under Hitler.'' Richard Headlee, the leader of a statewide effort to cut property taxes, said Blanchard, a Democrat, misled voters to make them believe he supports property tax relief much as Adolf Hitler brainwashed the German people into supporting Nazism. Engler's campaign director backed away from the comment Wednesday, calling Headlee ``a little zealous.'' ``He was talking about the public relations machine. We don't share Dick's view on that,'' said Dan Pero, Engler's campaign director. ``Dick gets somewhat carried away and he used a poor analogy.'' In Maine's gubernatorial race, Rep. Joseph Brennan, a Democrat, called Republican Gov. John McKernan a hypocrite Tuesday for criticizing his record on pardons as governor. ``If John McKernan hadn't been lucky, if the police had knocked on the door one night and arrested him for possession of illegal drugs, he would have been in the exact same position of many of those I pardoned,'' said Brennan, who was governor from 1978-86. McKernan has admitted smoking marijuana in college; Brennan has said he never tried it. McKernan has accused Brennan of pardoning political friends.

DOC.HEAD: Massacres Said to Occur in Rwanda Tribal Fighting
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers massacred hundreds of Rwandan civilians belonging to the same tribe as the rebels who have invaded the central African nation, according to refugees who reached Uganda. But Rwanda's president denied the claim, and a diplomat familiar with the area said Thursday he doubted the reports were true. Rwandan President Juvenal Habyarimana told a news conference Wednesday that fourteen civilians had been killed in fighting between his troops and Rwandan exiles who invaded from Uganda on Sept. 30. Habyarimana also said 3,000 people had been arrested since the invasion. Many of the detainees belong to the minority Tutsi tribe. An exiled Tutsi is leading the rebel force that invaded Rwanda last month. The Hutus, who make up 85 percent of Rwanda's 8 million people, wrested control of the country from the Tutsi in 1959. Habyarimana denied reports from Rwandan exiles that his soldiers had indiscriminantly fired on civilians and killed more than 1,000 people in 10 villages on the border with Uganda. Some of the approximately 500 refugees who crossed into Uganaa on Tuesday made the charges, according to the British Broadcasting Corp. ``There was no way to escape because the soldiers cordoned off each village before opening fire,'' a 45-year-old man from Chonio village told the BBC. New Vision, a government-owned newspaper in the Ugandan capital of Kampala, quoted a refugee identified as Stephen Kabarega as saying soldiers were joined by civilians armed with knives, hoes and spears in an attack on Tutsi herdsmen. The refugees said the soldiers accused them of feeding and supporting Tutsi rebels. The Western diplomat in Kigali, the Rwandan capital, who spoke on condition he not be identified further, said it did not appear that government soldiers had reached the region of the alleged massacre. ``I don't think the massacre happened. I don't think there are any Tutsis or government soldiers in the area,'' he said in a telephone interview. ``It may be a rebel tactic.'' But he said the rebel incursion could easily degenerate into a tribal war. In 1963, the Hutu brutally put down a Tutsi uprising, killing more than 10,000 Tutsis. About 250,000 fled north to Uganda. The invaders, who call themselve the Rwandese Patriotic Front, spring from that refugee population. They accuse Habyarimana of failing to allow the repatriation of more than 1 million Rwandan refugees. The rebels are led by a former Ugandan army commander, Maj. Gen. Fred Rwigyema, a Rwandan of Tutsi origin. Meanwhile, the European Parliament in Strasbourg, France, endorsed intervention by French and Belgian troops in Rwanda but urged the troops be used only to protect French and Belgian citizens. Belgium has rejected Rwanda's appeals for military aid to fight the invaders. A Belgian statement Thursday accused the government of human rights violations. ``Belgium will put no troops and military equipment at the disposal of Rwanda,'' Foreign Minister Mark Eyskens said in Brussels. The government will remain neutral in what it considers an internal matter, he said. But Prime Minister Wilfried Martens said Belgian paratroopers already in Rwanda to help in evacuations might move toward the northeastern battle zone to protect other Belgians.

DOC.HEAD: U.S., PLO Tilt over U.N. Resolution to Condemn Israel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to bring up risk of U.S. veto of resolution, report of Bush call to Mitterrand; picks up 8th graf pvs, `But consultations ...; DELETES outdated material and trims; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. initiative in the Security Council to condemn Israel for using deadly force against Palestinians ran aground Thursday over PLO demands for a tougher resolution. The Security Council failed to reconcile the approach of the United States and Britain with that of the Palestine Liberation Organization and the non-aligned movement despite two days of intensive U.S. lobbying and marathon negotiations Wednesday night and Thursday morning. That put the United States at the risk of having to veto the PLO-backed resolution against Israel, a move that would infuriate the Arab nations President Bush has been trying so hard to cultivate in the gulf crisis. ``We have a couple of issues still to be settled,'' U.S. Ambassador Thomas R. Pickering had said as tired representatives ended their meetings at 4 a.m. Thursday. Sir David Hannay, the British U.N. ambassador and October president of the Security Council, said on NBC radio after leaving a meeting Thursday night with Pickering: ``I think if we fail to get an agreement tomorrow (Friday) that would be very, very unsatisfactory. I think tomorrow is the time when we must have to have a vote. . . . I think we've reached the end of a long negotiatiing process. We ought to be ready to make a decision tomorrow.'' Thursday afternoon, President Bush telephoned French President Francois Mitterand, whose government has said it is willing to vote for the PLO-backed resolution condemning Israel, The New York Times reported Friday. The Times, quoting administration officials, said Bush told Mitterrand the alliance against Iraq would be hurt if the United States had to veto the resolution. U.S. agreement to condemn Israel after Monday's killing of 19 Palestinian demonstrators by police in Jerusalem has been seen as a major shift in public policy toward Israel. The U.S. government commonly shields the Jewish state from condemnation by exercising its veto in the council. But consultations collapsed as compromise efforts failed. No formal meeting was held Thursday. More consultations were expected Friday, but it was not known if a vote would take place. The Security Council has debated the killings since Monday. But the 15 council members cannot agree on a common approach in a resolution of ondemnation that would be adopted unanimously, without a U.S. veto. The United States on Tuesday proposed that the council condemn Israel for using excessive force against Palestinians who stoned Jewish worshipers at the Western Wall, or Wailing Wall. America itself drafted the resolution, which it described as ``balanced.'' The U.S. decision to join the condemnation outraged Jewish groups, which flooded the U.S. Mission to the United Nations with phone calls. In contrast to a non-aligned draft, the U.S. resolution blamed Palestinian troublemakers as well as Israeli security forces. It regretted the attack on innocent worshipers and asked the U.N. secretary-general to send personal emissaries to investigate. But PLO envoys said the U.S. proposal was so weak and tepid they would be ``embarrassed'' to transmit it to their leadership in Tunis as a reasonable working document. They objected to apportioning blame and the reference to innocent Jewish worshpers, and complained that the U.S. resolution made it appear the Israeli police were merely incompetent and ill-trained. The PLO and others wanted the council itself involved in the situation in the Occupied Territories, captured by Israel in the 1967 Mideast War, and to send its own team to recommend how to protect Palestinians from Israeli mistreatment. The United States was reported ready to veto a draft resolution supported by the PLO and non-aligned nations as being too harsh, ignoring Palestinian violence and opening the way to council involvement and U.N. observers in the Occupied Territories. The council on Thursday worked on a British compromise draft. The five permanent council members - the United States, Britain, China, France and the Soviet Union - want to preserve the cohesion and unanimity that characterized most Security Council resolutions against Iraq. But the Palestinian problem has proved intractible so far. U.S. allies, the Soviet Union and China support elements in the U.S. draft but also were ready to vote for the nonaligned resolution. Differences centered on a U.N. investigation of the violence, whether it should emphasize protection of Palestinians and how much weight its recommendations should carry. The PLO originally sought an independent investigative team consisting of three Security Council members. Israel rejected that as infringing on its sovereignty. The PLO compromised and accepted a British proposal for the secretary-general to send his own emissaries to investigate. Israel has indicated it could accept such a mission. But the PLO wants to make sure that the report makes clear recommendations for protection of Palestinians, that it is made directly to the Security Council and that the council takes action.

DOC.HEAD: Weakening Storm Works Northward Along Florida Gulf Coast
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `Nearly 10 ...' to UPDATE with hurricane watch posted for North Carolina coast; SUBS grafs 10-12, `By 6 p.m. ...' with four grafs to UPDATE with latest positions of Marco and Lili. Pick up 13th graf, `Sheets said ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos SAX1, CH2
DOC.TEXT: Tropical storm Marco toppled trees and power lines as it swept Florida's Gulf Coast on Thursday and heavy rain streaming northward from the tropics washed out roads and dams in the Carolinas. The rain was blamed for at least five deaths in the Carolinas and may have led to a train derailment. Nearly 10 inches of rain fell in 24 hours in parts of South Carolina, with unofficial reports up to 11 inches, the National Weather Service said. A hurricane watch was posted for the North Carolina coast. Bermuda felt the effects of Hurricane Lili with rain, thunderstorms and gusty wind. But while the Southeast bore the brunt of the stormy weather Thursday, the entire East Coast also could suffer severe weather as several weather systems may converge, forecasters said. ``There's not only Marco, but Hurricane Lili, a cold front ... all converging on the East Coast in the next few days,'' said Bob Sheets, director of the National Hurricane Center in Coral Gables. He said Lili was moving west and ``the question is how fast it's going to recurve and approach the East Coast, possibly as early as tomorrow night,'' Sheets said. ``All the weather conditions that these are creating can produce heavy rain over the East Coast, and that's of some concern.'' Marco pelted Florida's central and southwest coast with wind up to 65 mph and dumped up to 5 inches of rain before it began weakening. It was downgraded to a tropical depression with 35 mph winds by 6 p.m. EDT. Schools were closed in Manatee and Sarasota counties, where wind gusts up to 80 mph toppled power lines, knocking out electricity to 50,000 people. At 10:30 p.m. EDT, Marco's center hit land near Cross City, which is about 40 miles west of Gainesville. The center was near latitude 29.6 north, longitude 83.2 west. It was moving north at 9 mph, but all tropical storm warnings had been dropped. At 10:30 p.m. EDT, Lili was centered about 620 miles southeast of Cape Hatteras, N.C., at 29.7 latitude north, longitude 67.3 west. The storm, with winds of 75 mph, headed west at 23 mph and was expected to slow slightly and turn to the northwest. A tropical storm warning for Bermuda was discontinued. Sheets said Lili possibly could hit land at the Outer Banks, off North Carolina, this weekend, but he expected to have a better idea by Friday. Forecasters expected Marco to continue its generally northward path. ``It's weakening ... but now the big problem is the rain,'' said Sheets. Rainfall amounts of 3 inches or more were expected across portions of north Florida and south Georgia. The hurricane center posted a tornado watch for portions of north Florida and southern Georgia through the evening. Local forecasters said a tornado touched down northeast of Florida's Lake City, throwing people into a lake, upending mobile homes and felling trees across railroad tracks, weather forecasters said. Another ripped through a housing development about 200 yards from a hospital near Crystal River, Fla., tearing a roof off a mobile home, knocking down trees and power lines and closing the southbound lanes of U.S. 19. The Carolinas had been drenched by the remnants of previous tropical weather. Three people were found drowned and a 9-year-old boy was missing in South Carolina after a dam failed late Wednesday, Kershaw County Coroner Thomas Horton said. The four were riding in a car that stalled in high water. Two North Carolina highway deaths were blamed on heavy rain. In South Carolina, the rain forced the evacuations of residents in Orangeburg and Kershaw counties. Also, dams overflowed in Kershaw County and two bridges were undermined in Kershaw and Chesterfield counties, the weather service reported. Heavier 24-hour rainfall totals for South Carolina included 9.50 inches at Honey Hill and Schulerville, with 6.50 inches at Cross and Bonneau, the weather service reported. Heavier totals in Georgia included 7.70 inches at Hinesville, 7.30 inches at Jesup and 6.60 inches at Statesboro. In North Carolina, a storm total of 5.70 inches of rain was reported at Kannapolis, and Wednesday's total of 4.10 inches at Charlotte was a record for the date, the weather service said. Fourteen cars of a CSX freight train jumped their tracks east of Marshville, N.C., early Thursday. Thirteen cars and one engine overturned, dumping 3,000 gallons of diesel fuel, officials said. No injuries were reported. ``The crew seems to think the ground gave way as they were passing over it,'' said Norman Going, a spokesman for CSX Transportation, based in Jacksonville, Fla. Officials of the Southwest Florida Water Management District officials said 3-5 inches of rain from Marco wasn't enough to end Florida's drought. ``It helps, but not as much as people think because the rain comes down hard and fast and tends to run off or sit on the surface,'' said spokeswoman Andrea Spadafora. But the rain doused the biggest part of a 40-day-old fire in the Okefenokee Swamp. Ignited by lightning, the fire has blackened more than 20,000 of the swamp's 438,000 acres. Officials at the Okefenokee National Wildlife Refuge said peat moss in the swamp is likely to continue smoldering until the swamp floods again. Tropical storms become hurricanes if their maximum sustained winds top 74 mph. With Marco, there have been 13 named storms this season, which began June 1 and ends Nov. 30. Six of those storms have been hurricanes.

DOC.HEAD: Rise of Fundamentalists Worries Algerian Women's Movement
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The women's rights organization Khalida Massaoudi leads is the largest in this Moslem nation - 400 members in a total population of 26 million. Ms. Massaoudi, 32, worries that the shift to democracy will do nothing to end tyranny for Algerian women. Her fears deepen with each political advance by the fundamentalist Islamic Salvation Front, known as the FIS. ``The biggest danger for us is if the FIS take power,'' said the soft-spoken teacher of high school mathematics. ``It will prolong the totalitarianism Algeria has already known too long.'' She said the Marxist revolutionaries who ruled Algeria unchallenged for 28 years had given the fundamentalists a ready-made framework for oppressing women under Islamic law. The National Liberation Front, or FLN, imposed one-party rule on Algeria after winning independence from France in 1962. Many FLN leaders were devout Moslems despite their Marxist phisosophy, and wrote into the constitution that Algeria would be an Islamic nation. Ms. Massaoudi said each member of her Independent Association for the Triumph of Women's Rights is a heroine in a society ``that has never made a gift to women.'' ``For the crushing majority of women in this country, the only world is the family,'' she said. Although barely 5 feet tall, Ms. Massaoudi stands out in her working-class neighborhood. She holds a job, lives alone, leaves her red hair uncovered and asks no man's permission to go out. Algeria's work force of 8 million includes only 380,000 women. Most of the rights leader's female neighbors cover themselves with long robes and scarves before leaving their houses, and nearly always are accompanied by another woman or a male relative. Women served in the National Liberation Front during the eight-year guerrilla war and Islamic tradition coexisted uneasily with Western concepts of women's rights during the first generation of independence. Women in Algiers and Oran wore skirts and trousers, but most rural women concealed themselves behind veils. Divided as it was between devout Moslems from rural areas and more secular leaders from the cities, the FLN sidestepped the issue of women's rights. Then, in 1984, the National Assembly passed the Family Law in response to pressure from Islamic fundamentalists. It was reformist in theory, restricting polygamy, giving women a say in educating their sons after age 10 and allowing women to initiate divorce proceedings. In practice, according to Ms. Massaoudi, law codified second-class status for women. One of its victims was a woman who would identify herself only as Keltoum. Her husband declared them divorced in January and threw Keltoum, 31, and their five children out of the house. He didn't need a court ruling. Under Islamic tradition guaranteed by the Family Law, Keltoum's husband divorced her simply by telling her the marriage was over. Had Keltoum sought a divorce, she would have had to prove in court that he had committed adultery or had not wanted children. ``I can't imagine saying such things before a judge,'' she said. ``No Algerian woman could.'' An electoral code passed in 1986 allows husbands to cast their wives' votes, which contributed to the sweeping municipal and regional election victory by fundamentalists in June. ``That law was the final stab in the back by the FLN,'' Ms. Massaoudi said. ``The FLN dug the grave for women and put them in it.'' The FLN has a women's wing, as do other parties, but they remain under the control of male hierarchies. President Chadli Bendjedid has proposed reforming the election law, but the fundamentalist Islamic Salvation Front accuses him of bending the rules to help the FLN. With solid support among Algeria's swollen ranks of unemployed young men, the fundamentalists have the strongest party as the spring parliamentary elections approach. Most followers of the fundamentalist party favor separate education for males and females. ``The woman is sacred,'' said Dilinjer Boualem, 55. ``We want them to learn, to do medicine, as the (Islamic) law says. But mixing, this we are against. It is forbidden for Moslem people.'' On rights to work, they are more vague. An article in the Salvation Front's newspapr said women should work ``when necessity arises.'' ``The woman who goes to work and preserves her honor, modesty and purity, who honorably fulfills her task, then comes home as clean as she left . . . should not, in our humble opinion, be considered as having disobeyed the commandments of God,'' it said. One test of modesty is whether a woman wears the hijab, a scarf covering the head and neck. Increasing numbers of women, even in Algiers, are doing so because of religious conviction, social pressure or reasons of fashion. Others refuse, even those who will not speak to a Western journalist without permission from a male relative. Rhodia Belkacem, a 21-year-old secretary who binds her long black hair with gold combs, said: ``I could never go out in a hijab. Nobody's threatened me, but I'll never wear it, even if they kill me.''

DOC.HEAD: Taylor Named Norfolk Correspondent
DOC.TEXT: Joe Taylor, a newsman in the Richmond bureau of The Associated Press, has been named correspondent in Norfolk. The appointment was announced Thursday by Virginia Chief of Bureau Dorothy Abernathy. Taylor, 42, joined the AP in Richmond in 1979. A Danville, Va., native, he received bachelor's and master's degrees from Virginia Polytechnic Institute.

DOC.HEAD: City Trying To Stave Off Big Mac Attack on Historic McDonald's
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: City officials fear an auto parts store might want to dismantle a prime example of the original McDonald's restaurant chain and are pushing for monument status for the classic ``Golden Arches.'' ``This is our most renowned landmark,'' said Mayor Roy Paul. ``I believe that it has historical significance and don't want to see it destroyed.'' The restaurant in question was franchised in 1953 by the McDonald brothers themselves. City officials fear the Pep Boys auto parts chain, the restaurant's landlord, will decline to renew the lease and tear down this fast-food relic that many say brings back memories sweeter than a strawberry shake. The restaurant, one of about a dozen franchised in the early 1950s by Dick and Mac (yes, Mac) McDonald, has two giant arches and a 40-foot sign featuring Speedy the cook, Ronald's predecessor, winking in neon. This city 10 miles southeast of Los Angeles has long had a soft spot for the McDonald's. The restaurant was even exempted from a sign ordinance. The City Council also is considering a new historic buildings ordinance that would require Pep Boys to state their case at a hearing if they want to evict Ronald and company. Action on the ordinance was tabled during this week's council meeting. A new debate date was not set. The save-the-McDonald's campaign is among the latest efforts in Southern California to preserve its fabulous '50s architecture. Studio City residents last year fought to keep a car wash and diner from becoming a mini-mall. But the effort came up short, and the car wash with its distinct 55-foot tower shaped like three boomerangs and the nearby diner are history. In Downey, the McDonald's has the support of not only the city, but the giant Oak Brook, Ill.,-based McDonald's Corp., with 11,000 affiliate and franchise restaurants and $17.3 billion in 1989 sales. The McDonald's Corp., which recently bought the Downey store from its independent operators, would like to spend $500,000 on a renovation project that will improve the store's facilities but keep its nostalgic look. But McDonald's doesn't want to lay out that kind of cash unless Pep Boys agrees to a long-term lease, said William Marble, regional vice president. ``We want to restart and bring it up to proud standards,'' said Marble. ``But if I can't get a longer lease, I have to walk away.'' Pep Boys, with 300 stores and $900 million in sales, won't say what it will do with the lease for the restaurant, which sits near a Pep Boys store. Company officials dismissed suggestions they only want McDonald's out of their lives. ``We have no intention to knock that thing down, and in fact right now are trying to negotiate a new lease,'' said Fred Stampone, senior vice president of administration. City officials say they suspect Pep Boys just wants to keep its options open. ``They don't want to have a situation where the city requires that they keep a hamburger stand there,'' said assistant City Manager Ken Farfsing. ``It's on a fairly busy corner, and they may want the ability of getting someone who will pay a higher rent.''

DOC.HEAD: Fossil Shows Oldest Known Tree-Dwelling Bird, Scientist Says
LaserPhoto CX4 of Oct. 11; LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: A sparrow-size creature of 135 million years ago appears to be the oldest known bird that lived in trees and flew with agility, a researcher says. The creature's feet showed that it lived in trees, while its wing bones, breastbone and short clump of tail bones suggest an ability for long-range agile flight, said Paul Sereno, who analyzed a fossil specimen of the bird. The bird, not yet officially named, followed a primitive bird called Archaeopteryx by about 10 million years. Archaeopteryx, which retained many dinosaur characteristics, was basically a ground-dwelling bird that probably could climb trees, jump and flap its wings to propel itself, Sereno said. But its flight may have been rather short-range, he said. The new study provides ``a really exciting picture of a transitional stage in the early stages of bird history,'' Sereno said. The findings challenge assertions by some scientists that birds essentially lived on the ground for 50 million to 100 million years after Archaeopteryx, he said. That idea was questioned two years ago with the report of a tree-dwelling bird from Spain that lived 125 million years ago, and now the new report pushes tree-dwelling back 10 million years more, Sereno said. Sereno, of the University of Chicago, was to present a reconstruction of the fossil bird today at the annual meeting of the Society of Vertebrate Paleontology in Lawrence, Kan. The specimen was found in 1987 in northeastern China. The Beijing Natural History Museum, which owns the fossil, asked Sereno for help in studying it. John Ostrom, curator of vertebrate paleontology at the Yale Peabody Museum of Nature History, said Sereno's interpretation of the fossil appears reasonable. ``I would be a little bit hesitant to say that the specimen demonstrates a tree-dwelling existence, but that's not outrageous. It's reasonable on the basis of what he sees in the specimen,'' he said. Ostrom said he has seen the reconstruction but not the specimen itself. ``It was very definitely an advanced-level bird'' for that period, showing that modern-day flying ability came about very early in the history of birds, he said. Sereno said the bird, long extinct, retained some dinosaur characteristics: movable fingers on the front edge of its wings, a lack of fusion of many of its bones, and a club-shaped end of the pubic bone that may have rested on the ground when the bird sat. Sereno said he suspects the bird had teeth, but none has been firmly identified. Judging from its size, the bird probably ate insects, probably catching them while it was flying, he said. It is not clear whether its appearance so soon after the more primitive Archaeopteryx means that modern bird characteristics evolved quickly, or that Archaeopteryx was hanging onto its more primitive form while other birds, not yet discovered, evolved more modern characteristics, Sereno said.

DOC.HEAD: Politicians Lining Up Behind Drive to Limits Terms in Office
DOC.TEXT: Elected officials trying to get in step with discontented voters are joining the drive to limit politicians' terms in office. At least five candidates for governor this year are backing term limits in an effort to tap voter resentment of politicians. And President Bush, under pressure from his party to join the boomlet, says he's not opposed to the idea and might sign up, too. ``I haven't decided exactly,'' Bush said this week. ``But I think people want a change against the incumbents up there on the (Capitol) Hill.'' Voters in Oklahoma endorsed a ballot referendum last month setting a 12-year limit on terms for state House and Senate members, the first real victory in this anti-establishment drive. Polls and some primary election results suggest voters are angry at politicians in general - even if they're content to re-elect their own particular legislators and congressmen. Backing term limits is ``the most accessible device now available to try to establish you're anti-establishment,'' said Thomas E. Mann, director of governmental studies at the Brookings Institution, a liberal Washington think tank. ``That's why political candidates are jumping on the bandwagon with it,'' Mann said. ``It's gotten a lot of attention. It seems to be anti-legislature, anti-government, so it seems to be in tune with public sentiment.'' Similar referendums are on the ballot this year in Colorado and in California. No doubt more are coming. Colorado's proposal would apply to members of Congress as well as to state offices, although it's uncertain whether that would be constitutional. Most of the incumbents or candidates backing the idea are Republicans. That's no surprise, since they tend to be the legislative outsiders, hoping to become insiders. Many of the proponents are challenging entrenched Democratic incumbents. In fact, the drive has been pushed in large part by Eddie Mahe, a Republican campaign consultant in Washington. The group Americans to Limit Congressional Terms operates out of his office. The Republican Party platform has called for limits on terms since 1984, though hardly anyone pays any attention to party platforms. But the idea has some supporters among Democrats, too. In Massachusetts, both nominees for governor have backed versions of the idea. John Silber, who upset the party establishment to win the Democratic nomination, wants to limit legislators to six years and the governor to eight. Republican rival William Weld - trying to show he's an outsider as well despite his Boston Brahmin upbringing - supports eight-year limits for legislators. Among others backing term limits are California Sen. Pete Wilson, the GOP nominee for governor; Kansas Gov. Mike Hayden, a Republican who's in a tough re-election fight; and Florida Gov. Bob Martinez, another Republican facing a stiff re-election challenge. Wilson's opponent, Democrat Dianne Feinstein, countered that limits would change little. There's no limit on longevity for lobbyists or bureaucrats, she said. The rush to embrace the idea leaves some open to charges of hypocrisy, or at least opportunism. Wilson, critics note, has held political office of one sort or another steadily since 1967, though no one office for more than 12 years. And depending on how it's implemented, such limits may or may not have much effect. The Oklahoma version would allow a state House member to serve 12 years in that chamber, then 12 more in the Senate. Still, opponents say, limits would needlessly purge government of experienced and capable politicians. Eight-year limits have been in effect for presidents since Harry Truman, however, and many states apply limits to governors. Legislators, who make the laws, haven't been inclined to set limits on themselves. But the ballot initiative approach may change that. ``I have no doubt that it will spread like contagion now,'' said Mann. ``It's likely to pass in both California and Colorado.'' And other states will follow, he said. Comedian Jay Leno provided his commentary on NBC-TV's ``Tonight'' show, citing Vice President Dan Quayle's support for it. ``He's been campaigning for shorter terms for politicians,'' Leno said. ``Boy, if there's anybody who can convince people that's a good idea, it's Dan Quayle.''

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Demands Kuwaitis in Italy Register With Them
DOC.TEXT: The Iraqi Embassy has ordered all Kuwaitis living in Italy to register with the embassy and get Iraqi identity cards, the Italian news agency ANSA reports. The agency said the Kuwaiti Embassy, which is loyal to the exiled Kuwaiti monarchy, said that it ``rejected in every way'' Wednesday's Iraqi order. The embassy statement said the registration was part of a census being conducted of Kuwaitis residing overseas, ANSA said, and Kuwaiti officials said it was the first case they knew of in which Iraq had sought to force Kuwaitis overseas to register as Iraqis. About 60 Kuwaitis live in Italy, including diplomats, a spokesman for the Kuwaiti Embassy was quoted by ANSA as saying. ``None of them however would ever accept an Iraqi identity card,'' said the spokesman, who was not identified by name. Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 and annexed the oil-rich nation two weeks later.

DOC.HEAD: Ferre and Fendi Cross Fashion Lines
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos MIL3, NY6 sent Oct. 10.
By DANIELA PETROFF
DOC.TEXT: Gianfranco Ferre and Karl Lagerfeld have crossed the formidable French-Italian fashion frontier, keeping a foot on each runway. The result is exhausting for the designers and a mixed bag of the best and the not-so-great of both worlds for the consumer. Ferre creates his own label out of Milan and in Paris designs ready-to-wear and couture for Christian Dior, one of the capital's oldest and most respected fashion houses. Paris-based Lagerfeld covers a big chunk of French fashion, designing for himself and for Chanel, Dior's traditional rival. In Italy he is the creative genius behind Fendi's ready-to-wear collections and its luxurious furs. Tuesday evening their shows were back-to-back on the Milan runway, where the Italian spring-summer 1991 ready-to-wear collections are being presented this week. Lagerfeld has few problems adapting French coquetry to the sensible lines of tailored Italian fashion. Ferre, on the other hand, seems to be struggling to reconcile the purity of his sculpted fashion with the more daring Parisian look. Beautiful Ferre signature blouses in crisp organza with wide collar and turned up French cuff find themselves paired with slick patent leather hot pants. Well-tailored leather trousers are toughened by combat belts and goggle glasses, reminiscent of the more aggressive Parisian leather look. Big bows are a Ferre specialty, but this season he decorates them with jewel encrusted floral bouquets. Taken seperately they are lovely adornments, but together they are excessive. When Ferre stuck to his Milanese guns the collection was stunning, as in the white and ivory striped pant suits, the white crochet shift dresses, the chocolate brown leather perforated pants, or the floor length gowns with cut out embroidery. True to the latest trend in Milanese fashion, Ferre presented a series of colorful prints, which reached their fashion peak in rich jewel encrusted evening jackets. The main reason why Lagerfeld finds it so easy to spice Italian designs with French frivolity is that he is designing for the inventive Roman Fendi sisters. For the spring-summer 1991, Lagerfeld prints zodiac signs on T-shirts, catsuits and swim apparel. The central item of the collection is the blouse - loose and often pleated at the back. True to the latest trends, the Fendi collection is full of pretty dresses in linen and silk, more often than not in demure navy blue, perfect for a Gigi revival. If Lagerfeld followed some directions of the Milanese pack, the bathing line was all his and all French. Based on the corset in shiny stretch fabric, Lagerfeld paraded 30 versions down the runway all accessoried by thigh stockings and high heels for those slow to get the Folies Bergere point.

DOC.HEAD: Toddlers Have Mastered the Video Recorder
DOC.TEXT: The typical British toddler of the 90s reaches a chubby hand to the video recorder to select a favorite program, then regales mom with the foul language he's learned from it. Down in the nursery there's more interest in television than in teddy bears these days, according to a survey on toddler lifestyles for the woman's magazine Options. Fifty-two percent of British children under 5 record and watch their favorite programs without any help from their parents, according to the poll. Among 4-year-olds, 72 percent have unlocked the mysteries of fast-forward, freeze-frame, rewind and pause, researchers found. Jokes about the youngest member of the family being the only one who can use the VCR may have some basis in fact, it seems: a full fifth of kids under 2 are capable of operating a video recorder. ``My two boys are 9 and 4, and they certainly know how to work our two videos,'' Jacqueline Mace of Witney in Oxfordshire county told researchers from Market and Opinions Research International, which did the polling. ``My husband doesn't know how, but they do.'' Ninety-seven percent of children under 5 watch television or videotapes for at least a half hour a day, the survey said. Other toddler trends include a tendency to swear, the researchers said. Forty-four percent percent of mothers reported that their 2- to 4-year-olds use bad language. But some things haven't changed, the survey found. Twenty-five percent of British toddlers still won't go to bed without their teddy, or ``a bear of some description,'' according to the poll. The pollsters interviewed 634 mothers across Britain between June 30 and July 10. No margin of error was given.

DOC.HEAD: If Bush Can't Make Up His Mind, How Will Congress?
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: If President Bush can't make up his mind on taxes, the 535 members of Congress - many of them up for re-election this fall - may have an even harder time. After leading the charge for the past four months on a $500 billion, five-year deficit-reduction package, the White House left the playing field Wednesday. ``Let Congress clear it up,'' Bush shrugged as he campaigned in the South for Republican candidates. His comment, coming a day after his apparent flip-flop on whether to seek a compromise containing higher tax rates for affluent Americans, only sowed more confusion in an already convoluted budget situation. Democratic leaders seized on the opportunity to portray the president as indecisive. Progress on a budget agreement once again appeared to be grinding to a halt because of the White House's mixed signals. Should lawmakers heed Bush's statement - made at a White House news conference Tuesday morning - that he would accept higher taxes on the wealthiest Americans ``at some level'' in exchange for a lower capital gains tax rate? Or should they believe Republicans, including Sen. Bob Packwood, R-Ore., who say Bush later buckled under pressure from GOP senators and withdrew his support for such a deal? Or should they believe Wednesday's claim by Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., suggesting Bush had not ruled out a tax increase? Bush and his aides did little to clarify the matter - or to hint where his spinning compass might point when it finally comes to a rest. The president deflected questions with wisecracks. He was asked as he jogged during a break in St. Petersburg, Fla., if he would care to clear up the confusion. ``Confusion?'' he responded. Was he giving up on a lower capital gains tax? ``Read my hips,'' he said as he jogged by, pointing at his buttocks. Bush's chief spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, was equally cryptic. ``I want to bob and weave on this today because we want Congress to come up with a package and we don't want to signal on any particular position,'' Fitzwater said. Fitzwater also appeared to dispute Packwood's characterization that Bush agreed Tuesday to drop the issue of higher taxes on the wealthy and a cut in capital gains rates. He said the president listened but did not voice an opinion. However, accounts by other administration officials tended to back up Packwood's description of the meeting. And a senior administration official aboard Air Force One with the president Wednesday night said Bush still is ``open'' on the tax issue, despite suggestions to the contrary. The president just doesn't want to go any further out on a limb and invite more pot shots from Democrats, the official said. ``He took water by saying revenues (higher taxes). He had a package and he lost. Now he figures it's up to Congress,'' the official said, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``Why should he show his behind before others?'' Bush dropped his 1988 ``no new taxes'' campaign pledge early in the search for a budget compromise - a move that deeply divided Republicans in Congress. Over the past months, that statement came to be interpreted as meaning that Bush would consider certain kinds of new taxes, like excise taxes, but not higher income tax rates. The budget package put together by the White House and congressional leaders - and rejected last week by the House - did propose higher taxes on gasoline, cigarettes, alcohol and certain luxury items, but not on income. Thus, when Bush declared Tuesday that he might consider raising the tax bracket for the wealthiest Americans - now 28 percent - it sent new shudders through the already-battered GOP minorities in the House and the Senate. It also raised red flags with conservative White House staffers, including chief of staff John Sununu, sources said. Increasing the tax rate on the wealthy to 33 percent - as proposed by some Democratic leaders - would represent a significant boost. It could far overshadow the benefit from the capital gains tax cut that would be the other part of such a deal. Thus, Bush likely would be giving up more than he got in agreeing to such a swap - a point sources said was driven home to him at Tuesday's meeting. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Tom Raum covers the White House for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: New Hampshire Lawmakers Remember Sununu's Bullying Well
LaserPhoto CR1
DOC.TEXT: White House chief of staff John Sununu's reputation as ``big, bad John'' on Capitol Hill comes as no surprise to former associates in New Hampshire who say his persistence as governor sometimes turned into belligerence. But even some bruised in the legislative give-and-take during his six years as the state's chief executive admire his ability to get things done. ``They're so used to being treated with such deference in Washington,'' House Democratic Leader Mary Chambers said Wednesday. ``They go home and everybody bows and scrapes and wants to shake their hand. They get pretty arrogant and self-satisfied. ``Someone like John Sununu comes along and doesn't care who they are. The mission of getting the job done, that's his driving thing. It amuses me to read what they say about him.'' Sununu bullied some, yelled at others. He tried logic, humor. Some recall telephone calls every 15 minutes with additional points he wanted to make to win their support. ``If I had to use one word to describe his tactics, it would be `effective,' '' said Senate Republican Leader Edward Dupont. ``He was capable of doing whatever he needed to get the job done.'' Dupont said no one who ever worked with Sununu would ``see him as a kind and gentle man,'' but neither could they call him mean-spirited. ``I can't classify him as a bully because whenever he pushed, it wasn't for the satisfaction of bullying someone, but to get something done,'' Dupont said. Chambers differed often with Sununu over issues, particularly Sununu's steadfast support for licensing of the Seabrook nuclear plant. But she said he has the ability to ``get in and stir things up'' to end legislative deadlocks. Joan Dolloff, president of the State Employees Association, also butted heads with Sununu, who was George Bush's campaign manager in 1988. ``When that man took over, all I heard was about his arrogance, but I and my issues were treated with respect,'' she said. ``Half of those postures he makes as a stand. If someone had the fortitude to come back at him, he'd sit down with them,'' she said. ``If people can be turned away by what they perceive as John Sununu's arrogant attitude, they have no business playing the game.'' Dolloff recalls an angry phone call from Sununu during George Bush's campaign when the union's executive director accused Sununu of grandstanding over a child-care program. ``I said, `Yes, he did say that and I concur with him,' '' Dolloff said. ``There was a flurry of negative language. I held the phone out. He said, `Consider yourself out of the loop.' Well, I didn't know I was in the loop.'' Sununu continued to return her calls as if the conversation had never taken place, she said. Former state GOP chairwoman Donna Sytek, a state representative from Sununu's hometown of Salem, clashed with him over party policy. Sununu told her he didn't think an elected official should be party head, then backed another state representative for the post. ``I knew I could win, but it would be a hollow victory, so I didn't run,'' she said. Yet, Sytek said she'd support him for governor again in an instant. ``Our philosophies are so compatible,'' she said. Legislators and associates who worked with Sununu developed a respect for his hands-on knowledge of government, particularly the state budget. ``He always took everything from the minute detail and worked up from that,'' Dupont said. That lent credibility to solutions he proposed, he said. Sytek said there's no question Sununu ``bullied to get through his program, a program very thought-out and driven by ideology.'' But she said, ``It wasn't so much to build up power for himself or the office, but to make government function.'' He also was charming. At a dinner not long before he went to Washington, he left the stage to greet Chambers in the audience. Chambers asked if she'd get into see him if she came to Washington. ``He said, `The minute you arrive I'll be sure the tall, skinny man gets out of my office and see you,' '' Chambers said. ``I said, `John, you've got it backwards.' ''

DOC.HEAD: Study: Stressful Jobs Not Hazardous to Pregnant Women
DOC.TEXT: Despite their 70-hour work weeks, late nights and grinding stress, doctors who become pregnant during residency training face a low risk of giving birth prematurely, a study today shows. The study casts doubt on the widely held belief that women who work in demanding, stressful jobs are more likely to deliver too early. The researchers based their conclusions on a sample of young doctors in training at hospitals across the United States. They noted that it would be hard to find a group of women who worked longer hours, got by on less sleep or were under more stress. They surveyed 4,412 women doctors and compared their pregnancies to those among 4,236 wives of male residents. They found that 989 of the women doctors gave birth to a single child during residency; 1,238 of the residents' wives gave birth to a single child. Although the women residents worked about twice as many hours as the wives, about 6 percent of both groups delivered prematurely, an unusually low rate. The risk of having especially small babies was also about the same for both groups. Only when women worked more than 100 hours a week did they seem to raise their risk of premature delivery. The work, by Dr. Mark A. Klebanoff of the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development, was published in the New England Journal of Medicine. Earlier research has found that pregnant women who work nights, put in long hours or stand a lot are more likely to have premature deliveries. The latest report suggests that these difficult pregnancies result because such women are often poor, not because of their work. During the first three months of pregnancy, the doctors worked an average of 74 hours a week, while the wives worked 38. By the third trimester, the doctors were working 64 hours and the wives 35 hours. Half the residents worked until the day of delivery, compared with one-quarter of the wives. ``These results call into question the association between stressful occupations requiring long hours of physical activity and the incidence of pre-term delivery,'' the researchers wrote. However, they said their research suggests that new rules in New York state that limit medical residents to 80-hour work weeks are a good idea.

DOC.HEAD: Clean Air Compromise Gains Ground
DOC.TEXT: Congressional negotiators are edging closer to agreement on a clean air bill with a compromise on auto emission controls, an issue that stalled the talks for several weeks. The tentative accord reached Wednesday on emissions removed a major obstacle to working out legislation that can be sent to the White House before Congress adjourns later this month. ``It's a major breakthrough,'' said Sen. Max Baucus, D-Mont., head of the Senate negotiating team. The legislation, which represents the first tightening of air pollution laws since 1977, also would impose new requirements on utilities, factories and thousands of small businesses to reduce urban smog, toxic chemical releases and pollution that causes acid rain. The new requirements are expected to cost the economy from $21 billion to $25 billion a year when all the provisions take effect toward the end of the decade, according to White House estimates. Members of the House and Senate negotiating teams said they hoped to complete work on the section on toxic industrial pollution within the next day or two and turn to the section on acid rain this weekend. Congressional leaders have set a goal of completing the bill by midnight Sunday. Baucus said he hoped the final wording of the completed legislation might be approved Monday by the House and Senate conferees, who have met since July 13 to combine clean air bills passed by the two chambers. The motor vehicle compromise, reached after sometimes around-the-clock staff negotiations, calls for 30 percent to 60 percent cuts in various smog-causing tailpipe emissions. It also provides for a limited phase-in of alternative-fuel cars - mostly for fleet use - and cleaner burning fuels in cities with the worst smog problems. In some cases, the compromise was weaker than proposals passed by either the House or Senate earlier this year because implementation of many of the tougher standards were postponed by several years. The White House argued for some of the delays, claiming, for example, that a requirement for cleaner fuels could lead to supply shortages almost immediately. In the compromise, the requirement for cleaner gasoline blends in cities with the worst smog would not go into effect until 1995, instead of next year. Some of the fleet provisions, requiring the use of vehicles that run on a fuel other than gasoline, also would be moved back from the mid-1990s to 1998. ``It's a very ambitious program, but a program that is not going to have much of an impact until the late 1990s or early in the 21st century,'' said Daniel Weiss, who has followed the clean air debate for the Sierra Club, an environmental organization. A dispute over state enforcement of auto pollution requirements, which had occupied the negotiations for more than a week, was resolved by allowing states to enforce their own standards as long as they aren't tougher than rules set by California or the federal government. Senators from some states, including New York, had balked at an earlier proposal they said would have kept states from enforcing tougher auto emission controls such as the California standards. Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., who heads the House negotiators, had insisted on a provision that would safeguard automakers from having to meet myriad pollution requirements in various states. By resolving the motor vehicle section of the bill, the House and Senate negotiators resolved ``the toughest obstacle to final passage'' of the legislation, Baucus said late Wednesday. He said he now was increasingly optimistic that a final bill could be approved this session. Dingell was less enthusiastic, saying only that the conferees ``are well over halfway toward (the) goal'' of getting a bill enacted this year. The conferees reached agreement earlier on three other sections of the bill: new pollution controls on factories and businesses to reduce urban smog; a phaseout of chemicals that cause a depletion of the atmospheric ozone layer; and rules on timetables for cities to meet federal air quality standards.

DOC.HEAD: Good News for Coffee Lovers: It Won't Hurt the Heart
DOC.TEXT: Coffee drinkers, delight. A good cup of joe, or two, or three, won't hurt the heart, Harvard researchers reported today. In fact, coffee with caffeine, the often maligned chemical that gives the brew its kick, may turn out to be easier on the heart than the decaffeinated variety. ``It's amazing how coffee has a bad name, when the harder one looks at health hazards, the more difficult it is to find adverse effects,'' says Dr. Walter Willett of the Harvard School of Public Health. His research, part of a huge study of healthy people, shows that those who drink several cups of ordinary caffeinated coffee every day do not raise their risk of heart attacks. ``This is a very reassuring study for something that people enjoy day in and day out,'' said Dr. Harvey Wolinsky of Mt. Sinai Hospital in New York, an adviser to the National Coffee Association. The research was based on a survey of the coffee-drinking habits o 45,589 men. It was published in today's New England Journal of Medicine. Those who suspected coffee was bad for the heart usually assumed caffeine was to blame. But the new research suggests just the opposite: Those who drink more than four cups of decaf a day have about a 60 percent higher risk of heart disease than do those who never drink it. The researchers cautioned that the link between decaf and heart trouble is statistically weak and it's too soon to conclude decaf is harmful. ``There is no particular reason to switch from caffeinated to decaffeinated coffee from the point of view of preventing heart disease,'' he said. Another recent study also raised doubts about decaffeinated coffee. Researchers at Stanford University found that people who switch from regular coffee to decaf increased their levels of low-density lipoprotein - the so-called bad cholesterol - an average of 7 percent. No one knows why decaffeinated coffee might do this. Some speculate it could result from differences in the type of beans used to make decaf or in the way they are processed. Caffeine might trigger heart palpitations in some people, but Dr. Peter Wilson of the Framingham Heart Study said there is no good proof of this either. ``The Marcus Welby theories are reasonable, but there isn't a lot of proof to back them up - that you should be drinking decaf because it's better for your heart,'' Wilson said. Robert Young, who played Dr. Welby in a TV series, made commercials for a brand of decaffeinated coffee. Wilson added that if people believe they have fewer palpitations by switching, ``it's very reasonable, and they shouldn't toss the decaf down the sink.'' While the wisdom of very high coffee consumption is questionable, several experts agreed that three or four cups a day of typical American coffee are safe for virtually everybody, even those with heart disease. Participants in the Harvard study, all doctors, dentists and other health professionals, filled out questionnaires about their coffee habits. After two years, 221 of them had suffered heart attacks or died of heart disease, while 136 had undergone coronary bypass surgery or angioplasty. The risk among those who drank four or more cups of all kinds of coffee or just caffeinated coffee was about the same as for non-users. ``This study means that if there is a hazard with drinking caffeinated coffee, it's going to be very small, and there may be none at all,'' said Willett.

DOC.HEAD: Reserves Callup Nearly as Big as During Vietnam, Korean Wars
DOC.TEXT: More than 33,000 military reservists have been called to active duty in support of the U.S. buildup in the Persian Gulf area - nearly as many as were activated during crises in Vietnam and Korea in 1968. The Army today activated 12 National Guard and 24 Army Reserve units from 24 states and Puerto Rico, for a total of 4,846 troops. Meanwhile, the Marine Corps said Wednesday it was calling up about 160 reservists. Those actions brought to 33,252 the number of reservists from all services activated since Aug. 22 when President Bush authorized their use in support of Operation Desert Shield. None of the reserves called so far are from combat units; all are performing combat support or combat service functions such as cargo handling, air, sea and ground transportation, water purification, intelligence and security. The 160 Marine reservists are the first from that service branch to get the call in the current crisis. The Pentagon said in late August that it expected to call up nearly 50,000 reserves by Oct. 1, but officials recently said the immediate need had been overestimated. Still, the total ordered to active duty so far is approaching the 35,280 called up in 1968 following the Tet offensive in Vietnam and the seizure by North Korea of the U.S. surveillance ship Pueblo. Those were the most recent uses of military reserves, other than a brief callup during the 1970 postal workers' strike. The Marine reservists called up Wednesday are forming a combat service support detachment to replace active duty Marines at Kaneohe Bay, Hawaii, who already have been sent to the gulf area. The Army reserves being placed on active duty today are mainly from transportation, maintenance and combat engineering units. Here are the Army units, by state: -Arizona: 348th Transportation Co. of the Army Reserve at Phoenix. -Arkansas: 299th Engineer Co. of the Army Reserve at Pine Bluff. -Florida: 743rd Combat Support Co. of the National Guard at Fort Lauderdale; 1083rd Transportation Co. of the National Guard at Jonesville. -Maine: 619th Transportation Co. of the Army Reserve at Auburn. -Michigan: 180th Transportation Co. of the Army Reserve at Grand Rapids. -Minnesota: 109th Combat Support Co. of the National Guard at Duluth. -Mississippi: 173rd Quartermaster Co. of the Army Reserve at Greenwood; DOC.HEAD: Prospects of Referendum Bill Passing Seem Dim
DOC.TEXT: Chances seem dim that legislation authorizing a referendum on the status of Puerto Rico will pass Congress this year, despite approval of the bill by the House and the support of President Bush. Sen. Bennett Johnston, D-La., who is handling the Senate version of the bill, said Wednesday that time has run out. ``With probably only 10 days remaining in this Congress and absent a lame-duck session, it has become clear that enactment of a Puerto Rico referendum bill is not possible,'' said Johnston. ``There are substantial differences between the House and Senate approaches to this issue - differences which cannot be resolved within the very limited amount of time remaining in this Congress,'' he said. The House, by voice vote, approved a bill Wednesday that authorizes $13.5 million for a referendum to determine whether Puerto Rico should become a state, become independent or have enhanced commonwealth status. In order for the money to be spent, however, an appropriations measure also would have to be approved. ``The bill has the potential to open up a path that in time will bring to an indisputable end the United States' imputed colonialistic rule of Puerto Rico,'' said Jaime Fuster, the island's nonvoting resident commissioner in Congress. Delegate Ron de Lugo, D-V.I., who sponsored the bill, said it would ``establish the necessary process at a time when self-determination is spreading through the world.'' Bush, in a letter to de Lugo, said: ``I would urge the entire Congress to act affirmatively and rapidly on whatever responsible measure comes before them to call for a referendum on Puerto Rico's political status. I stand ready to sign such legislation when it reaches my desk.'' Rep. Jose Serrano, D-N.Y., who was born in Puerto Rico, said he hoped Johnston could be persuaded to change his mind and move forward during the remaining days of the session. ``I very much fear that to lose our momentum now could end prospects of a Puerto Rican referendum for years,'' said Serrano. Johnston said he would meet with Puerto Rican leaders next month to consider steps to be taken in the next session of Congress. ``If there is a determination to continue this effort, then I expect to resume consideration of the Senate legislation where we have left off, and complete Senate action early next year, which would still allow for a referendum in 1991, or early 1992 - well before the scheduled fall 1992 local elections,'' he said. The House bill calls for the referendum to be held Sept. 16, 1991, or later if agreed to by a majority of Puerto Rico's three political parties. The three parties represent the three choices of status that would be on the ballot. Once the referendum is held, Congress would be required to enact further legislation to implement the decision of the referendum, to be ratified by Puerto Ricans in a second round of balloting. Under the Senate bill, the referendum would automatically change Puerto Rico's political status. It has been approved by two committees, but still needs action by a third before going to the full Senate for a vote. There was no dissent in the House during debate on the referendum bill. Status has been an obsession in Puerto Rico since it was ruled by Spain. After more than 400 years as a colony, the island won autonomy and full representation in the Spanish parliament in 1897. The next year, it lost all self-determination when the United States took possession through the Treaty of Paris. In 1917, Puerto Ricans were made U.S. citizens. The island is a commonwealth of the United States, but that status does not bestow upon Puerto Ricans all the privileges of other Americans. For example, they do not get the same welfare benefits as residents of the states and the District of Columbia. They also do not have full voting representation in Congress. Neither do they pay federal income tax.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Seeks to Improve Benefits for Reserves Activated in Gulf Crisis
DOC.TEXT: Congress is considering a boost in benefits for the military reserves activated in the Persian Gulf buildup. ``I believe that all of our military personnel in the Persian Gulf deserve a tangible expression of our support,'' said Sen. John Glenn, D-Ohio. House and Senate versions of the 1991 defense bill would provide an immediate housing allowance for reservists called to active duty to support Operation Desert Shield - a total of 33,252 as of Wednesday. Generally, once members of the National Guard or reserves are called to active duty for more than 30 days, they receive the same pay and benefits as their active duty counterparts. Salary is based on the active duty pay scale for grade and length of service. All of the reservists called up by President Bush are on an initial 90-day assignment. ``The dependents of such a reservist are also entitled to medical care, commissary, exchange and other morale, welfare and recreation benefits on the same basis as the dependents of any other active duty member,'' said the Congressional Research Service in a briefing paper. The two major exceptions to the benefits for reserves are dental care and housing. Military personnel must serve at least two years of active duty service for dependents to receive non-emergency dental care, and the House and Senate bills do not change that policy. The Variable Housing Allowance, based on local housing costs and paid to personnel who do not live in government housing, requires a call to active duty of at least 140 days. In Senate legislation, reservists called to active duty would be exempted from the 140-day requirement to qualify for the housing allowance. The bill also would exempt reservists from limits on payment of unused leave. Glenn and Sen. John McCain, R-Ariz., members of the Senate Armed Services Committee, are seeking to add those benefits for reservists called to active duty - along with income tax relief and a savings program for all military personnel - to the defense bill for the fiscal year that began Oct. 1. The House defense bill makes a similar change in the housing allowance requirement. It also would allow reserve medical and dental officers to receive the same pay as their active duty counterparts. In both the House and Senate legislation, lawmakers called for providing ``imminent danger pay'' of $110 a month to all service personnel in the Persian Gulf region. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney already has acted on that matter, though, approving the imminent danger pay on Sept. 20, retroactive to Sept. 1.

DOC.HEAD: NTSB Draws Up List of 18 `Most Wanted' Safety Improvements
DOC.TEXT: Safety watchdogs, frustrated by alleged bureaucratic foot-dragging, are calling for action on 18 ``most wanted'' improvements in air, sea and land transportation. But Transportation Department officials say progress is being made on many of the issues raised by the National Transportation Safety Board and that some recommendations either have been implemented or soon will be. The proposals by the NTSB, an independent federal agency, range from development of an effective air collision-avoidance system to adoption of state laws permitting police to confiscate licenses on the spot from suspected drunken drivers. They address safety conditions on fishing vssels and giant passenger liners, seek new systems to keep railroad trains from colliding into each other, call for the identification of pilots with drug and alcohol problems and seek to identify links between fatigue and transportation accidents. Safety recommendations also are made for school buses, heavy commercial trucks and passenger cars. Each of the 18 recommendations stemmed from the NTSB's investigation of an actual accident, many of them involving multiple deaths. The board's most-wanted list seeks to speed action by regulatory agencies, industry and state and local governments. ``It's a call to action,'' said NTSB Chairman James L. Kolstad. ``Our most-wanted list of recommendations represents some of the biggest areas for lifesaving. ``I think on some issues there has been foot-dragging,'' he said, noting that federal rule-making procedures can delay implementation for five years or more. The safety board has no actual enforcement power. It can only identify possible safety improvements and recommend they be implemented. Ed O'Hara, a Transportation Department spokesman, said that is being done in many cases. On the screening of commercial pilots for drug and alcohol abuse, O'Hara said: ``I believe we are doing essentially what this recommendation is proposing. The Federal Aviation Administration adopted a new regulation in July to identify and ground pilots involved in alcohol or drug-related motor vehicle offenses that result in convictions or administrative offenses, FAA spokesman Bob Buckhorn noted. After Nov. 29, he said, pilots must notify the FAA within 60 days of such actions and face revocation of their medical certificates, ``which you need to fly,'' if they fail to do so. Kolstad said he believes the highest-priority item on the list is the recommendation for the passage of laws in all states to permit police officers to seize licenses of drivers who fail or refuse to take alcohol tests. ``That is the single most important way to get drunk drivers off the road,'' he said. Air accidents can be reduced, the safety board said, by requiring an airborne collision avoidance system - a recommendation first made in 1969 - and by installing systems to avoid collisions on the ground. The NTSB's other most-wanted safety improvements include: -Legislation to allow alcohol testing if an operator of a recreational boat is suspected of being intoxicated. -A requirement that commuter aircraft to carry ground proximity warning devices. -Sweeping improvements in fishing vessel safety, including legislative authority to require the licensing of captains and the installation of basic lifesaving gear. -Adjustable seat belts in new cars to make them suitable and safe for children. -New standards to incorporate materials in new school buses that will slow the spread of fire. -Improved fire safety standards on passenger vessels, including automatic devices to close doors when smoke detectors are activated. -Uniform regulations for drug and alcohol testing of all transportation employees responsible for operations and safety. -Safety improvements in commercial trucking by detecting and preventing drug and alcohol abuse, imposing medical standards and dealing with driver fatigue. The safety board has made 8,200 accident-prevention recommendations since it was founded in 1968. Kolstad said 81 percent have been adopted, but 1,800, including some of the most troublesome safety issues before the board, have not.

DOC.HEAD: Kennedy Aides Question State Department Withholding of Data
DOC.TEXT: Nine former Kennedy administration officials are disputing the government's refusal to release about 700 documents from the Cuban missile crisis. In papers filed in U.S. District Court, the ex-officials said the government has failed to justify keeping information on the 1962 crisis secret. The withheld material includes memos written by the nine officials themselves. They include Kennedy administration Under Secretary of State George Ball, Treasury Secretary C. Douglas Dillon and Theodore Sorensen, special counsel to the president. All three served on the National Security Council's executive committee which dealt with the crisis. Philip Brenner, a professor at American University, is suing the State Department in an effort to get the documents on the superpower confrontation. The Soviet installation of missiles in Cuba pushed the United States and the Soviet Union to the brink of nuclear war. The Soviets eventually agreed to remove the missiles. The State Department is invoking national security concerns in refusing to release the documents. The agency provided ``insufficient information'' about many of the documents, Ball said in a court affidavit. An affidavit by Sorensen noted that it is ``28 years after the events in question'' and ``neither the principal figures or principal issues of that crisis are still with us.'' The State Department ``fails to provide sufficient information regarding withheld documents and the reasons for their nondisclosure,'' Sorensen added. Brenner's attorneys, the law firm of Crowell & Moring, got the affidavits as part of Brenner's motion demanding a detailed State Department explanation of the documents. The case is before U.S. District Judge Norma Holloway Johnson. The affidavits highlight the State Department's inconsistent and improper over classification of documents, said the National Security Archive, a nonprofit group that is doing legal work in the case. The withheld material concerns communications between the United States and the Soviet Union and cable and letter exchanges between President Kennedy and Soviet leader Nikita Khrushchev. It also relates to meetings of high-ranking Kennedy administration officials and anticipated covert actions in Cuba and communications from U.S. embassies. Thousands of other documents on the crisis already have been released. Under the Freedom of Information Act, the government in most cases must identify the documents it is withholding and detail the reason. But the government has failed to do this, say the former Kennedy administration officials. The State Department withheld one document which it described as ``analysis regarding Cuba.'' There were many documents fitting that description ``which I either authored or received during this time period,'' said Edwin Martin, former assistant secretary of state for inter-American affairs. It is impossible from the description to evaluate the decision to withhold the document on national security grounds, Martin said in an affidavit. The other Kennedy-era officials who filed affidavits in the case were U. Alexis Johnson, deputy under secretary of state; Harlan Cleveland, assistant secretary of state; Roger Hilsman, director of the State Department's bureau of intelligence and research; Leonard Meeker, assistant legal adviser; and Raymond Garthoff, adviser to the bureau of politico-military affairs. The government also said some of the material is exempt from public release because it relates to the deliberative process within a federal agency.

DOC.HEAD: Helen Hayes Takes Another Bow on 90th Birthday
DOC.TEXT: Nearly 20 years after retiring from the theater, Helen Hayes stood before an appreciative audience, listened to the applause and took a bow. She was 90 years old. The veteran of years of Broadway and motion pictures danced the night away at a black-tie gala party in her honor Wednesday night, an event that raised money for the Helen Hayes Awards. For more than 300 guests, the evening was a tribute to a grand old friend. ``I just hate to leave this event and go to, ah, heaven,'' Miss Hayes told the audience of family members and friends. Miss Hayes was toasted by her son, actor James MacArthur, who hugged her and said, ``I thank you, mom, I love you, mom - now and forever.'' Friends who joined in singing ``Happy Birthday'' included actress Arlene Dahl, singer Nancy Sinatra, Sen. Ernest Hollings, D-S.C., and the British ambassador to the United States, Sir Antony Acland. The honorary chairwoman of the birthday party for the first lady of American theater was another first lady, Barbara Bush. Reflecting on her 90 years, Miss Hayes said, ``Just think what I've lived through since 1900. The first automobile ride, the first telephone call, everything was exploding in wonder.'' Asked about her phenomenal success in show business, she told reporters, ``I think I was darn lucky. I just don't know how good I was ... I don't have any system. I just drift along.'' Miss Dahl, a longtime friend, said, ``She's a walking miracle of wit and wisdom, talent and beauty.'' Miss Hayes, born in an upstairs bedroom just blocks from the Georgetown hotel that was the site of her 90th birthday party, made her stage debut in Washington in 1906. Her first appearance on Broadway came three years later, and in 1920 her name first went up in lights in ``Bab,'' which had been written for her. She retired from the theater in 1971 with a Washington performance of ``Long Day's Journey Into Night,'' but continued to be active in motion pictures, television, radio and as an author. She recently finished writing a murder mystery whose heroine is a great lady of the stage. Miss Hayes was presented with a Helen Hayes Award of her own. The awards are given annually by the Washington Theater Awards Society for achievement in local theater production and performance. It was the latest in a lifetime of honors for the actress, whose film career began in 1931 with ``The Sin of Madelon Claudet,'' for which she won an Academy Award. She won another Oscar in ``Airport'' in 1970. Her life in the theater is the subject of a film currently in production for the PBS series, ``American Masters.'' Asked about her greatest role, she cited the play, ``Victoria Regina.'' She said it included a scene where a crowd said, ```go to it, old girl. You've done well.' I like that. I'm going to have it on my tombstone.''

DOC.HEAD: Engler Distances Itself from Headlee's Hitler Remark
DOC.TEXT: Gov. James Blanchard's tactics have ``been as effective as the Third Reich under Hitler,'' says a supporter of Republican gubernatorial candidate John Engler. Richard Headlee, the leader of a statewide property tax cut effort, made the comment at a news conference, and Engler's campaign later backed away from it. ``I think Dick got a little zealous with that,'' said Dan Pero, Engler's campaign director. ``He was talking about the public relations machine. We don't share Dick's view on that. Dick gets somewhat carried away and he used a poor analogy.'' Claims that Blanchard uses state resources to promote himself have been a consistent theme of Engler's campaign. But Pero said the alleged abuses do not compare to Hitler's tactics. Headlee, the 1982 GOP gubernatorial candidate, said he was not comparing Blanchard with Hitler. He said he was accusing Democrat Blanchard of dispensing misleading information to convince voters he supports property tax relief as Hitler's machine brainwashed the German people to support the Nazi programs.
DOC.HEAD: Failed Candidate Complains Of Post-Election Lie From Winner's Campaign
DOC.TEXT: A former Ohio congressman whose comeback hopes were dashed in a rancorous Republican primary accused the winning campaign of spreading a post-election lie about him.
