Thomas Kindness said Wednesday that congressional nominee John Boehner was trying to ``drag me into this campaign,'' and demanded in a letter to reporters that Boehner fire his campaign manager. ``Boehner's spokesman claims that I asked for Boehner's help in paying off my primary campaign debt and was told to `get lost,''' Kindness wrote. ``That never happened.'' Boehner said he doesn't intend to fire his manager and hasn't talked with Kindness but has received an indirect communication about the Kindness campaign's lingering debt. ``A former Kindness campaign staffer called our pollster in Washington and wanted to pass the message on to us as to whether we would consider helping to retire his debt,'' Boehner said. Campaign manager Barry ackson ``made it clear that Tom had never conceded (the race) ... and we just wouldn't consider it unless he wanted to call himself,'' Boehner said. Kindness never called, and as of July 1 his primary campaign was $19,000 in the red.
DOC.HEAD: Feinstein Calls on Wilson To Name His Intended U.S. Senate Successor
DOC.TEXT: Gubernatorial candidate Dianne Feinstein is demanding that opponent Pete Wilson name the person he would choose to fill his U.S. Senate seat if he wins the governor's race. ``That successor is important,'' the Democrat Feinstein said at a news conference. ``Will that successor be pro-life or pro-choice? Will that successor be pro-Medicare or (for) more cuts in Medicare? Will that successor be pro-Social Security or not?'' The Republican Wilson has declined to name his preferred successor or outline in detail his criteria for selection. A victorious Wilson would be allowed to pick his heir because federal and state election law gives a state governor the power to fill a vacant U.S. Senate seat, according to the California Secretary of State's office.

DOC.HEAD: Bill Clears Senate Committee
DOC.TEXT: A $15.3 billion foreign aid bill that would forgive Egypt's military debt to the United States and sharply restrict aid to El Salvador has cleared the Senate Appropriations Committee. The action came Wednesday on a routine voice vote even though President Bush has threatened to veto the measure because of its El Salvador provisions. The measure is certain to spark a spirited fight when it goes before the full Senate, perhaps as early as Friday. The measure is almost identical to one approved a week ago by the panel's foreign aid subcommittee. The primary exception was the addition of $306 million to the bill's economic aid accounts to conform to Congress' budget agreement with the White House. Efforts are expected later to strike from the bill the forgiveness of $6.7 billion in past military debts owed by Egypt. Bush wants to erase the debt as a reward for Egypt's leadership in marshaling Arab action against Iraq in the Persian Gulf crisis. The committee avoided a fight over the El Salvador provisions, delaying that battle for the full Senate. As it stands, the bill would cut the country's $85 million in military aid in half. The administration wants the bill to restore all aid unless the rebels agree to a cease-fire within 60 days, a move opponents say would undercut talks going on at the United Nations.

DOC.HEAD: DOT Finishes Work on New Side Crash Standards
DOC.TEXT:
The Transportation Department has sent a draft of new auto side impact standards to the White House. White House spokesman Bob Marks confirmed the development Wednesday night, but said he had no details on the standards. NBC News reported that changes in door manufacture called for in the draft standards could cost an average of $50 per car when fully in effect in 1996. The current side impact standard requires that doors be made with guard beams inside, but requires no test. The proposed standard would requires a test for side impact. Cars now must pass a frontal barrier impact test, scored according to notional ``injuries'' received by test dummies in the front seat.
---
DOC.HEAD: Energy Department Selects Successful Bidders in Reserve Test
DOC.TEXT:
The government says it got no takers for almost a fifth of the nearly 5 million barrels of crude oil offered from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve. The Energy Department said Wednesday it has selected 11 companies for the purchase of a little less than 4 million barrels of oil from the reserve under the test drawdown order given by President Bush last month. The department said the amount was short of what had been expected to be sold because there were no bids for more than 800,000 barrels of high-sulfur ``sour'' crude that were offered. The sour crude was one of six types of oil offered from the reserve stocks in salt domes along the Texas and Louisiana coasts. Buyers will take 1.35 million barrels of other kinds of sour crude. Some refineries cannot process high-sulfur crude because it corrodes their equipment. The lack of interest in the sour crude was attributed to an expected increase in the amount of similar oil from Alaska's North Slope at Gulf Coast ports next month. Successful bids ranged from $32.64 to $39.06 per barrel. The department will be able to adjust those prices somewhat to reflect changes in the oil market before delivery.
---
DOC.HEAD: Old Servel Gas Refrigerators Recalled
DOC.TEXT:
Old gas refrigerators sometimes used in hunting cabins, vacation cottages and other remote areas are being recalled because they have killed at least 14 people in the United States by carbon monoxide poisoning in the past decade. The Consumer Product Safety Commission said it has arranged for consumers to receive $100 in exchange for the Servel refrigerators, which were manufactured between 1933 and 1957. The commission said gas burners in the refrigerators can be fouled by dust, rust or other obstructions and produce deadly carbon monoxide, especially if the refrigerator has not been used for some time. In addition to their use in recreational cabins, the refrigerators continue to be used in remote areas where there is no electricity or where propane gas is a preferred energy source, the commission said. In Ontario, Canada, about 60 fatalities associated with the refrigerators have been reported in the past 20 years, it said. Owners of gas refrigerators may get information on the recall at 1-800-782-7431.
---
DOC.HEAD: Senate OKs German Unification Pact
DOC.TEXT: The Senate has overwhelmingly approved a treaty formally ending the post-World War II division of Germany. ``We welcome the German people, as a whole, back to the fraternity of civilized nations,'' said Sen. John Heinz, R-Pa. Voting Wednesday a week after unification, senators made clear that nothing in the treaty's ratification should be construed as tacit U.S. acceptance of the Soviet Union's postwar annexation of the Baltic nations of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania. The treaty, signed in Moscow Sept. 12 by Britain, France, the Soviet Union, the United States and East and West Germany, now goes to President Bush for his signature. It relinquishes all American rights and responsibilities over Germany and lifts Soviet, French and British controls over the country as well. ``A unified Germany is something I look at with some concern,'' said Sen. Rudy Boschwitz, R-Minn., who fled Berlin during his childhood. ``I intend to vote for this resolution. Nothin should stand in its way. But a sense of the history of Central Europe and a sense of the history of the world should be stated on the Senate floor ... so that Germany will remember that we will be watchful.'' ``The millennium has not yet come,'' said Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., echoing several senators' statements of concern about the peaceful intentions of a unified Germany. ``We must now focus our attention and our energy on the challenges of the future, not the legacy of the past,'' said Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine. Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., said the treaty ``does not exact the price of German sovereignty for German unification. ... All freedom-loving people of the world have won.'' The treaty was approved 98-0, with Sens. Mark Hatfield, R-Ore., and Pete Wilson, R-Calif., not voting.

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Issues Racism in Europe Report
DOC.TEXT: A European Parliament report says racism is on the rise in Europe, with tens of thousands of bias attacks occurring annually in Britain alone and most Germans believing immigrants exploit their charity. But the 518-member assembly only half-heartedly endorsed the document on Wednesday, partly because of a recommendation to give immigrants the right to vote in local elections after five years of residency. After some intense political wrangling, the parliament agreed to simply pass the report - which took a year to be completed by a special committee of inquiry - on to the 12 European Community governments without comment. The vote was 181-to-146 with 18 abstentions. The 176-page report offered a detailed summary of racist incidents and the activities of right-wing political groups in Europe in recent years. It said racism is worsening in Europe largely because of rising immigration. But it also cites political changes in Eastern Europe that have allowed many long-festering ethnic disputes to break out into the open. Among those voting against the report were the parliament's 17 extreme right-wingers, who argued that it overstated racism. Liberals and Christian Democrats also voted against. The report was written by a special panel of inquiry. It followed a similar study in the mid-1980s which was found last year to have shortcomings for ignoring the effect of the EC's single market project on race relations. Among other things, the new report says: - One in three citizens of EC countries believe there are too many people of other nationalities in their countries. - In the United Kingdom, a country plagued by an especially ``high level of racial harassment and violence,'' as many as 70,000 racial attacks occur annually. In recent years Britain's neo-nazi ``skinhead'' movement has spread to other European nations, especially Germany, Belgium and the Netherlands. - Right-wing political parties with pronounced racist views have won seats in national parliaments in France, Germany, the Netherlands and Belgium. - Almost 70 percent of Germans believe immigrants unfairly exploit their social welfare system. - France has been gripped recently by a growing number of racially motivated killings, bombings and vandalism. - In Greece, Moslems are often harassed and denied building permits and drivers' licences. In all, the report made 77 recommendations aimed at improving conditions for the estimated 12 to 14 million immigrants in the European Community and to encourage racial tolerance. ``Our aim should be that there be no second-class citizens within the EC after the creation of the single market of 1992,'' said Glyn Ford, a British Socialist and the author of the report. Among the most far-reaching recommendations was one urging the EC executive Commission to draft a `` European Residents' Charter'' that would allow non-EC nationals, legally resident in one EC nation, the same freedom of movement within the 12-nation bloc as EC citizens. The report also urged the European Commission to send more money to poorer areas with high immigrant populations and to adopt a common policy on refugee and visa issues. The European Community comprises Britain, France, The Netherlands, Belgium, Germany, Spain, Portugal, Italy, Luxembourg, Denmark, Ireland and Greece.

DOC.HEAD: Flight of Evacuees Arrives In Britain; Air Force Jet Crashes in Gulf
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with plane arriving in Britain. Picks up 5th pvs, `Officials in...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto DHA3, LaserColor DHA103
DOC.TEXT: A planeload of Americans and other foreigners held in Kuwait and Iraq arrived in Britain Thursday on a flight to freedom in America. Earlier, an Air Force jet crashed in Saudi Arabia, killing both crewmen. About 320 people were on the Iraqi Airways Boeing 747, most of them Americans left stranded in Kuwait by the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion. It was the first U.S.-chartered evacuation flight since Sept. 22. Diplomats in Basra, Iraq, had put the number leaving as about 400 - including about 350 Americans, 25 Britons and some Canadians and Japanese. An airport official at London's Gatwick airport said the plane left the Iraqi capital Baghdad around midnight and arrived Thursday morning at Gatwick Airport outside London. Officials in North Carolina said the State Department told them the Americans would fly into Raleigh-Durham International Airport on Friday. The evacuees were taken by bus to Basra to begin the air journey home. As in previous evacuation flights, arrangements called for Westerners on board to be limited to women and children and to Americans of Arab ancestry. The jet crash Wednesday was the fourth U.S. military air accident since the United States began deploying forces in the Persian Gulf region following Iraq's invasion. Two helicopters also disappeared during a training flight. In all, 24 servicemen have died and eight are missing. Meanwhile, the 10-week-old crisis brought more bad news for the U.S. economy. Oil prices rose to a record $41.15 a barrel on the New York Exchange before closing at $38.69, tumbling on an erroneous rumor Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein had been killed. On Tuesday, oil closed at $40.40. Traders said prices were pushed higher in part by the slayings of 19 Palestinians in a clash with police in Jerusalem on Monday, and by Saddam's threat to retaliate against Israel. On the New York Stock Exchange, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 37.62 points to 2,407.92, its lowest since May 1989. Saddam said Tuesday that Iraq had added another missile to its arsenal that could be launched ``against the targets of evil when the day of reckoning comes.'' He made it clear he was referring to Israel and the U.S.-led forces sent to Saudi Arabia after Kuwait was captured. About 170,000 U.S. forces are deployed in Saudi Arabia and on warships in the gulf region. Saddam has repeatedly tried to link the status of Palestinians in the Israeli-occupied territories with Kuwait, indicating he might withdraw from the emirate if Israel quits Arab lands seized in 1967. In Washington, families of seven U.S. service personnel in the crisis area; two congressmen - Reps. Jim Moody and Gerald Kleczka, both Wisconsin Democrats -and religious leaders expressed their concern at a news conference about the military deployment in Saudi Arabia. The families wrote in an open letter to Bush, ``The Persian Gulf crisis is not just a constitutional, a military or an economic crisis. It is a family crisis. All across the country families are facing the possible death of loved ones in a military offensive they do not support.'' They urged Bush to pledge no offensive action and to make the U.S. forces part of a ``truly multinational and purely defensive peacekeeping force'' under U.N. leadership. Alex Molnar of Milwaukee, father of a Marine in the gulf area, said the families want a response from Bush and Congress. ``Isn't it time we got an answer? Our voices must be heard,'' he said. The United States has so far taken no military action in the gulf, but at least two dozen servicemen have died in training or other accidents, the Pentagon said Wednesday. On Wednesday, an F-111 fighter plane crashed in the southern Arabian peninsula on a training mission, U.S. military spokesman Lt. Cmdr. J.D. van Sickle said, adding that an investigation was under way. The Air Force identified the victims as Capt. Fredrick A. Reid of Harrisburg, Pa., the pilot, and Capt. Thomas R. Caldwell of Columbus, Ohio, the weapons systems officer. The Navy said it found no survivors of the crash of two helicopters over the northern Arabian Sea on Monday and was suspending the search. An Air Force F-4 reconnaissance jet also went down Monday, killing both crew members. In addition, 13 other Air Force personnel were killed Aug. 29 in a crash of a C-5 jet cargo plane in Germany. The C-5 was ferrying supplies and equipment to the Saudi peninsula. The remaining military personnel died in ground accidents, and one soldier died of self-inflicted wounds, the Pentagon said. Up to Thursday, freedom flights had transported about 1,900 Americans out of Iraq and Kuwait. Recent State Department estimates indicated more than 600 Americans were stranded in Kuwait and more than 300 in Iraq. American and other Western men are being held in Iraq and Kuwait, many at strategic Iraqi installations to deter any attack by multinational forces. In Washington, Kuwait's ambassador to the United States said Iraqi soldiers in occupied Kuwait were torturing and summarily executing Kuwaitis suspected of sympahizing with the emirate's exiled leadership. Saud Nasir Al-Sabah also told a hearing of the House Human Rights Caucus that Iraqi soldiers are looting food from Kuwaiti homes and are barring citizens from hospitals, restricting medical care to military personnel.

DOC.HEAD: Saudi Navy Short Of Manpower, Computerizes And Seeks To Lure Recruits
DOC.DATELINE: ABOARD HMS TABUK IN THE PERSIAN GULF (AP)
DOC.TEXT: The Saudi navy, founded 20 years ago in a country more comfortable with sand than the sea, is trying to recruit enough sailors to field larger ships, officers say. The navy hopes to double its recruit from about 3,000 per year so it can staff frigate-class warships as part of an ambitious expansion campaign, they say. ``As we get bigger ships, we find it difficult to man some of them fully,'' Cmdr. Faraj Al-Gathian, one of four squadron leaders in the Eastern Fleet that patrols the Persian Gulf, said Wednesday. The navy has taken a number of steps to overcome the problem, including heavy computerization on board ships to pare the number of personnel needed, an advertising campaign that emphasizes the navy as a career, pay incentives and special attention to family needs while men are at sea. ``If you have a country with long shores, to have the shores protected you need a powerful navy,'' said Capt. Ibrahim Al-Maghlouth, commanding officer of this Corvette-class ship named after one of the 7th century battles of Islam's Prophet Mohammed. The officers spoke while giving the Western press its first extensive tour of Saudi naval facilities since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Much of the tour was spent aboard the Tabuk, watching exercises 70 miles off the coast. The larger ships in the Saudi navy, up to 10,000 tons, are stationed at naval bases along the western Red Sea coast. In all, the Saudi navy has 7,200 men, including 1,200 marines. It has eight frigates, 13 patrol and combat ships and four minesweepers. Its air wing consists of 24 helicopters, most French-made Dauphin II attack craft and Super Puma transports. ``The Saudi navy has the capability to defend the coast in this region, we have good defensive equipment,'' said Capt. Ibrahim Aqqad, flotilla commander and acting commander of the Abdul Aziz Naval Base in Jubail, opened 11 years ago. The Saudi navy has not been involved in the interdiction and boarding of ships heading to and from Iraq, but is monitoring traffic, he said. Ships suspected of violating the U.N.-ordered embargo on trade with Iraq have been stopped by Western warships and boarded. The Saudi navy has never fired a shot in anger, even during the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq war in which dozens of ships were attacked. It is one of the youngest of the navies in the gulf and faces the daunting task of recruiting sailors in a largely Bedouin society with no tradition of seafaring. ``People were not familiar with the sea, especially the desert people,'' said Al-Gathian. ``They feared the sea. They thought it was dangerous.'' The 37-year-old officer had to fight family opposition when he joined 17 years ago, an experience echoed by many crew members. The navy has tried to make it easier for families to accept having their man at sea. Women cannot drive in Saudi Arabia, so the navy has set up services on its bases so provisions are available without leaving home. Buses shuttle children to schools through high school level on base, and women can pick up the telephone and order groceries delivered from stores. Frequent newspaper advertisements emphasize that the navy is a career, an incentive in a country that cannot find jobs for all its university graduates. ``Join the navy for a better future,'' is one current slogan. Study in the United States for officers is another incentive. Navy salaries are five to 10 percent higher than those in other forces, with new recruits starting at $1,000 per month and getting automatic annual raises of about $100 a month during their years in training, officers said. The navy is also trying to cut its manpower needs by stressing computers. One computer links all the radar system tracking surface, air and underwater threats to the Tabuk, for example. The computer operator can fire all the weapons systems from the war room, including ship-to-ship Harpoon missiles, anti-aircraft missiles, a rapid-fire machine gun and a 76-millimeter gun. The chief mechanic can watch all the engine room functions with a computer. As a consequence, a ship like the Tabuk can be staffed with a crew of 75 instead of the normal complement of 150, said Al-Gathian. But the navy needs as many men as it can because it wants to beef up its forces with more frigates as well as destroyers, he said, a 10-year-old campaign made more critical by the Iraqi invasion. ``This area has been in crisis for a long time and the navy is trying to catch up with the other armed forces,'' Al-Gathian said.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyer: Mom-For-Hire May Have Wanted White Baby for Keeps
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Hearing is scheduled to resume at 11:30 a.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: A lawyer in a custody dispute over a baby born to a surrogate mother suggested the woman never intended to turn the boy over to his genetic parents because she coveted a white child. Anna Johnson, the woman hired for $10,000 to bear the child, denied the racial allegation Wednesday, testifying that she grew attached to the baby as it developed in her womb. ``There's no way you can prevent your emotions from taking over, and those instincts come out naturally,'' she said on the second day of a Superior Court hearing to determine custody of the 3-week-old boy. Mark and Crispina Calvert, the couple who hired Ms. Johnson to carry a test-tube embryo created from their egg and sperm, have custody of the baby in the meantime. The hearing was to resume today. The case is the first in which a surrogate is seeking custody of a genetically unrelated child. In the Baby M case in New Jersey, the surrogate mother was also the genetic one. Christian Van Deusen, the Calverts' attorney, raised the issue of race. Ms. Johnson, 29, has Indian, white and black ancestry; Mark Calvert, 34, is white and his wife, 36, is Filipino. ``Have you ever told anyone that you always wanted to have a white baby?'' Van Deusen asked Ms. Johnson, who firmly replied, ``No.'' ``Have you ever discussed it with ... your former roommate?'' he asked. Ms. Johnson again responded no. Van Deusen also questioned Ms. Johnson about her claims that the Calverts were late in making installment payments of the $10,000 as stipulated in the contract. He produced canceled checks, and Ms. Johnson agreed that at least one payment was actually made early. Ms. Johnson, a single mother of a 3-year-old girl, testified she changed her mind in June about giving up the baby after Mark Calvert refused to give her a ride to the hospital during a medical emergency. In a July 23 letter introduced as evidence, Ms. Johnson told the Calverts to give her the final $5,000 installment or ``you can forget about helping me out, calling it a breach of contract, and not get the baby.'' Harold LaFlamme, the child's court-appointed attorney, asked, ``Aren't you telling them in this letter ... if they don't cough up the money, they won't get their baby?'' Ms. Johnson denied that, saying she was anxious and confused at the time because of money and housing worries. She had also just learned of a welfare fraud investigation, which led to her conviction on a misdemeanor charge.

DOC.HEAD: Old Nation Gets Five New Governments In Sunday Election
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To CORRECT that Stolpe a Social Democrat, SUB 6th graf, `Kohl's Christian ...' Picks up 7th, `Of the ...' ^An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: One candidate is a muscular 38-year-old lawyer with movie-star looks, a law-and-order type who pumps iron at home and talks tough on the road. His name seems to turn up everywhere. Unfortunately for Peter-Michael Diestel, it's often in nasty slogans painted on subway tunnels and the wall around his handsome house. The other candidate is a popular preacher, a laid-back liberal considered the spiritual shepherd of the peaceful revolt that toppled East Germany's Communists a year ago. Unfortunately for the Rev. Manfred Stolpe, he's not just facing an unpopular politician, but a powerful political party led by the chancellor of a united Germany, Helmut Kohl. Stolpe and Diestel are the main combatants for governor of Brandenburg state, one of five states that East Germany became last week when it acceded to West Germany. Kohl's Christian Democrats are favored in the other four states in Sunday's balloting, Mecklenburg-Lower Pomerania, Saxony, Saxony-Anhalt and Thuringia. The left-leaning Social Democrats, Stolpe's party, are their main opposition. Of the 10 top candidates for governor, four are from what was West Germany, another indication that people from the west are poised to assume control of the east. East Germans endured four decades without a free election. On Sunday, they'll be voting in their third in eight months, with another one less than two months away. ``The people are fed up with elections,'' said Diestel, who was interior minister in the East Germany government that ceased to exist last week. Although a light turnout is predicted, electing governors and state legislatures will help give the old nation a new regional identity and greater political voice. The elections also will advance the process of forming a federalist system to replace the centralized bureacracy left by the East German Communists. The states will have to quickly assume regional responsibility for schools, police services, transportation and social services. Simultaneous with the East German elections will be the race in Bavaria, the largest of the 11 states on West German territory. The winner will likely be the reigning Christian Social Union, an arch-conservative sister party of the Christian Democrats. The Christian Democrats won East Germany's first free elections in March, dominated the May local elections and are favorites to win the Germany-wide national elections slated for Dec. 2. But if the Social Democrats can win anywhere Sunday, it is Brandenburg, where they had their best showing in the March balloting, finishing less than 4 percentage points behind their rivals. Brandenburg surrounds but does not include Berlin. The Social Democrats, who advocate more government control of the economy and broader social programs, are relying much on the eastern territory's economic problems to boost their chances. Stolpe and Diestel have basically reflected the views of their parties. Both have been running quiet campaigns, with Stolpe avoiding the easy grabbag of Diestel controversies. ``We're both refraining from personal insults,'' Stolpe said during a campaign stop Tuesday in the city of Kylritz, about 70 miles northwest of Berlin. ``We have a young democracy with many economic problems, and I'm focusing on the differences between us and the conservative party.'' Diestel was chosen as interior minister by Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere in April and has been in hot water since. The complaint that has energized activists is the number of former Communist ``Stasi'' secret police agents he kept on the ministry payroll. So strong are the emotions that Diestel put up a security wall around the home he recently bought outside Berlin, a lavish villa that once belonged to the former Communist regime. He tore the wall down a few weeks later because it suddenly became a new canvas for the graffiti artists who have adopted him as their favorite target. Diestel, however, is a personable, popular figure among many conservative East Germans. A dashing body-builder and former lifeguard, he is considered something of a sex symbol. ``It's been reported that not only was I a Stasi member, but also worked with the Israeli secret service and the Russian KGB,'' he said recently. ``Perhaps I'm also Mielke's illegitimate son,'' he added, referring to Erich Mielke, the now-imprisoned former Stasi chief. Stolpe was head of the Evangelical Church in Berlin and for years acted as mediator between dissidents and the hard-line Communist government. Even though a new poll gave Stolpe an approval rating almost twice as high as Diestel's, the race is considered virtually even. A Stolpe aide said the problem is not so much Diestel as Kohl, whose party may be popular enough to overcome Diestel's controversies.

DOC.HEAD: Kasparov Beats Karpov in Second Game
With PM-Chess Notation, PM-Chess Algebraic
DOC.TEXT: Defending champion Garry Kasparov goes into the third game of the world chess championship with a 1-point lead over Anatoly Karpov after defeating the challenger in the second game. Karpov resigned on his 44th move Wednesday night about five hours after the game started. Kasparov now leads 1{ points to { point in the best-of-24-game match. The third game is Friday. Kasparov, 27, who is the highest-rated player in the history of chess, had the white pieces and the slight advantage of having the first move Wednesday night against arch-rival Karpov. Kasparov, known for his bold, attacking style, and Karpov, 39, who favors methodical, defense-minded strategies, opened their long-awaited match Monday night. After five hours and 30 moves apiece, their first game ended in a draw. Kasparov and Karpov last met for the championship in 1987. It ended in a tie, allowing Kasparov to retain the title he had snatched from Karpov in 1985. This year's tournament will feature 12 games in New York and 12 in Lyon, France. The winner will receive $1.7 million and the loser $1.3 million.

DOC.HEAD: California Supreme Court Won't Hear Keating Appeal
DOC.TEXT: The California Supreme Court has refused to consider a bid by financier Charles H. Keating Jr. to get his $5 million bail lowered. The court denied the request Wednesday. The 66-year-old developer blamed for the nation's biggest thrift collapse has been jailed since last month on charges of defrauding investors who bought junk bonds through his Lincoln Savings & Loan. Keating contends he is broke and can't adequately defend himself against the charges while imprisoned. District Attorney Ira Reiner has acknowledged the $5 million bail is unusually high but said Keating might otherwise flee prosecution. Federal regulators took over Lincoln last year, a bailout expected to cost taxpayers $2 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Leading West German Counterspy Arrested; Officials Say He Worked For East
DOC.TEXT: A leading West German counterintelligence agent accused of spying for East Germany has turned himself in, prompting the arrests of eight more people in an ever-widening espionage scandal. Officials said Wednesday that the KGB had offered the agent, Klaus Kuron, asylum in the Soviet Union at the last minute but that Kuron declined. The 54-year-old Kuron, who surrendered over the weekend, is believed to have supplied large amounts of information about West Germany's spy-fighting efforts to East Germany over the past eight years. He is reported to have been one of the most trusted officials at the Constitutional Protection Office, West Germany's main spy-fighting unit. On Wednesday night, the Federal Prosector's office said eight other people had been arrested based on information handed over by Kuron. The eight, who were not identified, are suspected of spying on behalf of what was Communist East Germany until Oct. 3. Chief Federal Prosecutor Alexander von Stahl described the Kuron's espionage activity as ``a very serious betrayal.'' According von Stahl, Kuron agreed to spy for East Germany in 1982 and received a monthly fee of about $2,600. The Interior Ministry said the suspect received about that much as his normal monthly salary. Interior Ministry spokesman Willi Hausmann said Kuron was offered entry into the Soviet Union by the KGB just before surrending, but the Soviets ``offer did not appear lucrative to him,'' so he turned himself in instead. Hausmann gave no further details. On Tuesday, justice officials announced the Sept. 30 arrest of a 47-year-old woman working for the German Intelligence Service, which is also responsible for foreign intelligence work. The woman, identified as Gabriele G., is suspected of having passed intelligence documents prepared for Kohl on to the East German secret police. Justice officials have said they are worried that former East German agents may now offer their services - and important information - to the KGB. Chief government spokesman Hans Klein on Wednesday urged all former East German agents - spies without a country - to turn themselves in rather then seek refuge elsewhere. Dozens of East German agents have surrendered over the past few months. More than 60 others have been arrested, but others are still on the loose.

DOC.HEAD: Former Kent State President Dies at 81
DOC.TEXT: Robert L. White, who was president of Kent State University when National Guardsmen shot to death four students and wounded nine during a protest against the Vietnam War, has died. He was 81. White died Wednesday at Robinson Memorial Hospital in Ravenna. His career at the university spanned 44 years. White was president of the school from 1963 to 1971. He retired in 1975. During an anti-war protest on May 4, 1970, Guardsmen called in by Mayor Leroy Satrom opened fire on demonstrators. The deaths stunned the nation and touched off a wave of protests at college campuses around the nation. White appealed for calm and urged President Nixon to appoint a national panel to look into the causes of unrest at Kent State and other colleges. Nixon did so a month later.

DOC.HEAD: Swedish Academy to Award Nobel Literature Prize
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To CORRECT that Bei Dao did not play a direct role in the pro-democracy movement, SUB 2 grafs for grafs 11-12 pvs, `After an ... in Denmark. Picks up 13 pvs, `Sources say ...' Prize to be announced at 8 a.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: An exiled Chinese poet was the focus of the literary world today amid speculation the Swedish Academy would award the Nobel Prize to a Chinese writer for the first time in its 89-year history. The academy was to make its final choice in a vote this morning and make the announcement at the stroke of 1 p.m. (8 a.m. EDT). Bei Dao, whose somber short stories and poems have been praised for their depiction of personal dramas entwined in the political vicissitudes of Communist China, was said to be a strong candidates for the $700,000 prize. Others said to be in the running were Gaelic novelist Seamus Heaney, U.S. novelist Joyce Carol Oates, Mexican poet Octavio Paz, Brazilian novelist Jorge Amado, West Indians V.S. Naipaul and Derek Walcott, Turkey's Yasar Kemal, Margaret Atwood of Canada, South African writer Nadine Gordimer and Japanese novelist Masuji Ibuse. The academy long has been criticized for ignoring China's 3,000-year-old literary tradition and giving short shrift to Asia as a whole. There have only been two Asian winners in the history of the prize, first given in 1901. Indian poet Rabindranath Tagore won the Nobel in 1913 and Japanese writer Yasunaro Kawabata was chosen in 1968. Sweden, by comparison, has had six laureates. The addition of Chinese language professor Goran Malmqvist to the 18-member academy in 1985 has put the board in a position to assess original writings from the Chinese. Bei Dao was born in 1949, the year the Communists came to power in China. He entered adulthood during the Cultural Revolution, which lasted from 1966 to 1976, and Bei's interpreters say the feeling of terror that pervades much of his poetry can be linked to the violence of this period. Bei was a guiding voice for young Chinese writers during a period of greater democracy in China from 1976-79. In February 1989, he helped organize a petition seeking the release of political prisoners. He left China for a conference two months later, just as the pro-democracy movement began in Beijing. Bei never returned and currently teaches Chinese at the University of Aarhus in Denmark. Sources say Bei was a strong candidate for the prize last year. But some writers have been rumored to be on the ``short list'' for years. Female writers have rarely been awarded the prize. German-Swedish poet Nelly Sachs, the last woman laureate, in 1966, was only the sixth woman to win the prize. The prize was established in the 1896 will of Alfred Nobel, the Swedish philanthropist and inventor of dynamite.

DOC.HEAD: Gainesville Slaying Suspect Convicted of Grandmother-Beating
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf pvs, `Prosecutors said ...' to ADD grandmother's injuries.
DOC.TEXT: A suspect in the slayings of five college students has been convicted of beating up his grandmother, despite her testimony that her injuries came from a fall. Edward Lewis Humphrey, 19, was found guilty Wednesday of battery on a person over 65. Under state guidelines, he could get nearly two years in prison at sentencing Nov. 8. Humphrey has been identified by police as a prime suspect in the August serial slayings of five students in Gainesville, including four students at the University of Florida, where he was a freshman. Humphey, who is being held on $1 million bail, is not charged in the Gainesville killings. No arrests have been made in that case. Prosecutors said Humphrey pummeled 79-year-old Elna Hlavaty on Aug. 30. Her face was bruised and one eye was swollen shut. The arresting officer testified that Mrs. Hlavaty identified her grandson as her attacker. But Mrs. Hlavaty testified that she lost her balance and fell on a fireplace while reaching for a light switch. ``I am heartbroken that I have a crippled grandson that is being railroaded in hell until they find the Gainesville murderer,'' she said. Prosecutors said Humphrey pounded Mrs. Hlavaty like a boxer. ``He wasn't in a fight with Mike Tyson. He wasn't in a fight with Muhammad Ali. ... He was beating his grandmother,'' said Assistant State Attorney Philip Williams. Humphrey also faces unrelated charges of attempted rape and assault.

DOC.HEAD: Third Political Party Fights for Respect and Survival
DOC.TEXT: There aren't many political parties like the Illinois Solidarity Party. The gubernatorial candidate doesn't care if she wins. A congressional candidate wants to switch every electrical system in America to direct current. The candidate for University of Illinois trustee is counting on big Election Day turnout among Indians. And the 4-year-old organization is fighting for its survival. Unless one of Solidarity's statewide candidates captures at least 5 percent of the vote this year, the party no longer will be considered an established party automatically entitled to a spot on the ballot. The party's biggest vote-getter in 1988, trustee candidate Martin Ortega, received 98,000 votes, less than 1 percent of the ballots cast in an 11-person field. Illinois Solidarity, whose current leaders say they want to create an alternative to the two traditional parties, was founded by one of the most prominent members of the state's political establishment, Democrat Adlai Stevenson III. When Stevenson won the Democratic nomination for governor in 1986, followers of extremist Lyndon LaRouche were nominated for lieutenant governor and secretary of state. Stevenson refused to have anything to do with them and resigned from the ticket. To keep his gubernatorial hopes alive, Stevenson collected signatures, gathered running mates and created his own party, Illinois Solidarity. ``The party was formed just for that purpose, with the intent of killing it after the election,'' said Terry Stephan, Stevenson's deputy press secretary in the 1986 race. Plenty of groups have formed third parties in Illinois, but none was led by an established politician like Stevenson. The party won enough votes to be listed on state ballots for the next four years, but it didn't help Stevenson avoid a sound defeat. Then Gov. James R. Thompson - ``motivated by nothing but a desire for mischief,'' Stephan said - vetoed a bill that would have killed the party by merging it with the Democratic Party. Thompson, a Republican, said the bill was unconstitutional. Since then, the party has stood, abandoned by Stevenson but open to anyone who wants to call himself an Illinois Solidarity candidate. In 1987, for instance, ex-Democrat, later-Republican Ed Vrdolyak ran unsuccessfully for mayor of Chicago under the Solidarity banner. But since 1988, Solidarity has been ``a black-led, pro-gay, pro-socialist'' coalition, according to gubernatorial candidate Dr. Jessie Fields, a Chicago physician. ``I'm not expecting to win the election,'' she said. ``This is about much more than winning some high office.'' The group's goal is to include more people and more opinions in a political process they see as riddled with problems brought on by the influence of money. ``These things aren't going to respond to anything but a dose of grass-roots democracy,'' said Solidarity activist Alan Port. He is running a write-in campaign for the congressional seat that includes Peoria. Port runs on a platform calling for reducing the military to a purely defensive force with no personnel overseas. He also wants to change all electrical systems so people can draw power from special hydrogen generators he says have been invented. The handful of Solidarity candidates try to spread the word on shoestring budgets and time limited by jobs as doctors, veterinarians, night watchmen. They stand on street corners giving pamphlets to passers-by. They speak to student groups and community organizations. Other than that, their campaign is invisible - no posters, no TV commercials, no debate appearances. Her exclusion from the League of Women Voters' debates irks Fields. She said she's caught in a trap: Debates don't include her because few people know about her, and people don't get to know her without the exposure of debates. But the candidates predict they'll do well just by offering an alternative. ``We may not be much,'' Port said. ``But we're all they've got at this point.''

DOC.HEAD: Highway Patrol Officer Looks For Dummies
DOC.TEXT: Well-dressed mannequins don't fool him. Nor does iced champagne disguised as a baby. Highway Patrol Officer Alvin Yamaguchi watches the car-pool lanes in Los Angeles, searching for people trying to beat the two-to-a-car minimum. ``People will try anything to fool us,'' Yamaguchi said. Take the woman driving a Mercedes-Benz. She used a department store mannequin with $100 sunglasses, makeup and stylish clothes. Then there was the man with a baby seat covered by a blanket. ``I pointed at him to take it off,'' he said. ``When he did there was a bottle of champagne on ice.'' Others pose mannequins in a sleeping posture. Then there are the drivers who pretend to have lively discussions with their inanimate passengers. Nearly 9,000 people were cited for car-pool lane violations on Los Angeles freeways last year, despite fines that jump to $613.50 for people caught three times within two years. Once caught, some commuters resort to logic. Their logic. Pregnant women have argued to no avail they were carrying a second passenger. One undertaker thought the dead body in the back would qualify. He lost, too. Motorists delight in pointing out violators to the patrol. ``They love it when we pull (violators) over,'' Yamaguchi said. ``They'll honk then, too, and wave and smile.'' Yamaguchi's favorite is the driver seated beside a German shepherd secured by a safety belt. ``This guy told me that he shouldn't get cited because the dog was a family member,'' Yamaguchi said.

DOC.HEAD: Professors Say Motion-Sensitive Light Switches Have Them Jumpy
DOC.TEXT: New motion-sensitive light switches installed at a university are keeping professors on their toes. Traditional toggle switches were replaced by the energy-saving devices in 180 offices at California State University at Northridge. Professors say it was a dimwitted idea. ``There was a woman across the hall engaging in all sorts of gymnastics in her office to keep the light on,'' said Professor Max Lupal, who had the device removed because it observed only a wall and didn't pick up movement. His colleague James Sefton complained he had to get up from his chair 10 times in three hours and wave to convince the switch he was there. University engineer Alan McDonald said the $110 switches were part of a $1.1 million energy-saving project. The entire cost of the Watt Watcher switches was $20,000. University manager Martin Holzman said the switches are expected to pay for themselves in about six years. English Professor Marvin Klotz said it would have been cheaper to keep the old-fashioned switches. He and his colleagues are entirely capable of remembering to turn off the lights when they leave, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Propose Solution to Nuclear Plant Problem
DOC.TEXT: State officials have come up with a plan to remove and store two highly radioactive uranium fuel assemblies dangling precariously inside the Indian Point 3 nuclear reactor. The 14-foot, 1,200-pound assemblies were accidentally pulled from the core of the reactor during refueling last week and became snagged. They are far too radioactive for workers to try to fix the problem and put them back in place. Officials are worried the assemblies could drop back into the core, damaging equipment and releasing radioactive gases inside the plant. The New York Power Authority, which owns and operates the plant, wants to move the assemblies to special steel baskets in a storage area next the reactor, and eventually transfer them to the plant's spent fuel rod storage pool, spokesman Carl Patrick said Wednesday. The agency planned to present the proposal to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission today or Friday for approval, said another authority spokesman, Todd Forte. Both assemblies consist of 204 thin metal rods and hold hundreds of ceramic uranium pellets. They are dangling in water from a heavy metal plate suspended from a crane. NRC spokesman Karl Abraham has said radiation wouldn't escape the plant if the assemblies fell. The 14-year-old plant was removed from service Sept. 15 for refueling and maintenance. Other work in the containment building has been suspended until the problem is solved. Forte said it isn't clear how long the problem would delay electricity production, which was supposed to resume by Thanksgiving weekend. Indian Point 3, a 600-megawatt reactor, is about 35 miles north of New York City.

DOC.HEAD: Communists Announce New Party Name And Symbol To Reverse Electoral Losses
DOC.TEXT: In an attempt to win back voters, the leaders of Italy's Communist Party have decided to abandon communism - in name and philosophy - and become a more mainstream leftist party. The leadership on Wednesday backed Party Secretary Achille Occhetto's proposal that the largest Communist organization in the West and the second-largest political group in Italy be named ``Democratic Party of the Left.'' The final vote comes at a special party congress in January and Occhetto commands a majority in the party. The leadership's decision was more than a year in the making. It was aimed at keeping pace with the changes sweeping Europe, reversing an electoral slide and ending the stigma that has kept the party out of national government for 43 years. In a speech Wednesday to party members, Occhetto modified the party's emblem - a hammer, sickle and star. In the new symbol, the emblem would be smaller and depicted beneath a tree symbolizing liberty, strong roots and love of nature, Occhetto said. A small group of hard-liners burned a copy of the proposed symbol outside party headquarters, the Italian news agency AGI reported. In his speech, Occhetto criticized the Communist model of rigid centralized economies while calling for regulation to protect the poor and the environment. He appealed to the party to embrace the interests of workers, feminists, environmentalists, pacifists and leftist Catholics, and called on the Socialists, Italy's No. 3 party, to unite to form a government. The Socialists have been lukewarm to Occhetto's proposals and indicated the party would still not be welcome in the non-communist Socialist International. The Socialists, who have been coalition partners with the conservative Christian Democrats in the last decade, hope to surpass the Communists and become de facto leaders of the Italian left. Occhetto presented the proposed name change at a meeting of his party leadership, taking personal responsibility for the radical turn. He said the new symbol would include the hammer and sickle to represent ``the historical function of the workers' movement.'' In recent elections, the Communists have held on to their No. 2 position but have dropped from the 34 percent of the vote received in 1976, when they came to the brink of power, to around 27 percent. It has been even lower in some local elections. Still, in a Europe that has seen ruling Communist parties toppled in the East and the once powerful French party reduced to less than 7 percent of the vote, Italy's Communists stand out as major vote-getters. Occhetto won support for radical change at a special party congress in March but at the price of a split with hard-line Communists. His plan won 66 percent of the vote, with 34 percent of the delegates known as the ``no front'' opposed. The party split surfaced again in August on a parliamentary vote on Italy's participation in the multinational naval task force in the Persian Gulf. Occhetto and his mainline allies abstained on the vote while the ``no front'' voted against. The Italian Communist Party was formed in 1921 in a breakway from the Socialists. It went underground during Fascism, played a major role in the Resistance and briefly served in coalition governments after World War II. But it has been locked out of the central government since 1947, although it holds many key posts in the country. The Italian Communists long ago proclaimed their independence from Moscow when an international Communist front was seen as a threat to the West. They have also supported Italy's membership in NATO, although the U.S. government has been wary of their stand on strategic issues.

DOC.HEAD: Magellan Finds Sand Dunes on Venus
With PM-Space Shuttle, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Magellan spacecraft has found sand dunes on Venus despite low wind and little loose sediment on the planet. ``They look a lot like sand dunes on Earth,'' said Ray Arvidson, a geologist from Washington University in St. Louis and a Magellan scientist at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. ``This is a fairly rare occurrence on Venus,'' he said Wednesday. ``This area just had a beautiful supply of sediment to be reworked into dunes.'' Magellan's pictures revealed the dune field in an area of Los Angeles-sized meteorite craters. The field is 30 to 40 miles long, and each dune is hundreds of yards wide, Arvidson said. Magellan hasn't determined their height. Magellan's images have shown Venus has very little loose sediment. That's because the planet lacks water to erode rock. Surface winds on Venus measure only a few miles per hour, but the atmosphere is so dense that even such light winds can lift sediment, he said. Atmospheric pressure on Venus' surface is 90 times the pressure at sea level on Earth. Arvidson said the sediment that was blown around to form the dunes may have stemmed from a meteorite impact that shattered or melted rock. Another possibility is that the meteorite was a water-rich comet, he added. Magellan bounces radar off Venus to make pictures and maps of the planet, which can't be photographed with optical cameras because of its thick cloud cover. The pictures have shown numerous volcanoes, volcanic collapse craters, long rivers of solidified lava, extensive faults, deep valleys and towering ridges. Magellan began orbiting Venus on Aug. 10 after a roundabout trip from Earth of 948 million miles. The spacecraft was launched from the shuttle Atlantis in May 1989. Magellan and Venus were 158.6 million miles from Earth on Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Rinfret Unveils Dial-a-Message Promotion
DOC.TEXT: Republican Pierre Rinfret is asking voters to support his underdog campaign for governor by calling a 1-900 number - at $9.95 a call - to hear a recorded message from him. The number is being promoted in a 60-second TV commercial in which Rinfret calls on voters to ``get rid of'' Democratic Gov. Mario Cuomo because he opposes the death penalty. The ad was to begin airing today on WWOR. Rinfret's cash-strapped campaign paid $25,000 to have the ad run nine times over three days, said John Denny, deputy campaign manager. Each call will bring the campaign $8. ``It's not a sign of trouble. Don't be silly!'' Rinfret said at a news conference. ``It's a sign of innovation. Why do I have to do everything the old way?'' Rinfret's campaign also spent $26,000 to promote a 1-900 number in radio and newspaper ads nd direct mailings. That number is cheaper - it costs $5, of which $3 will go to the campaign - but its message is the same. Denny said 53 radio spots will run on five or six stations. Last week, Rinfret, who is trailing badly in the polls and is given practically no chance of beating Cuomo, reported that his campaign had less than $94,000 in the bank. He also reported $188,571 in unpaid bills. Cuomo reported having almost $6.1 million in his campaign account.

DOC.HEAD: GAO Says Nuclear Storage Tanks More Dangerous Than Previously Thought
DOC.TEXT: Energy Secretary James Watkins has ordered a new assessment of nuclear waste storage dangers at Hanford in response to a federal report warning that an explosion could give nearby residents cancer. The report on storage tanks at the government's nuclear weapons complex was released Wednesday by the General Accounting Office. It contradicted a 1987 study that suggested a tank explosion would pose little risk to area residents. Watkins ordered a new environmental impact statement to replace the 1987 study, which was prepared by Battelle Pacific Northwest Laboratory, a Hanford contractor. Watkins said the 1987 study greatly underestimated the consequences of a cyanide explosion in underground tanks. The GAO report agreed with previous Energy Department assessments that the actual risk of an explosion is low. But it cautioned that not enough is known to rule the possibility out. A cyanide explosion would blast a hole through a tank's roof, and people living near the 560-square-mile Hanford reservation in south-central Washington could receive enough radiation to cause cancer, the GAO said. ``If an explosion did occur, our review indicates that it would be a major accident, with potentially more damaging effects than those described in the (1987) Hanford EIS,'' the GAO said. Rep. Mike Synar, D-Okla., requested the report as part of a House Government Operations Committee investigation of nuclear waste handling practices. The GAO is the investigative arm of Congress. Hanford has 177 underground storage tanks. Of those, 22 are single-shell tanks that contain a chemical called ferrocyanide added in the 1950s to separate radioactive substances from liquids so the liquids could be pumped out. No new wastes have been added to those tanks for years. A 1984 study concluded tanks containing ferrocyanide carried an explosion risk, but that report was suppressed by DOE until last year. Hanford was created during the Manhattan Project of the early 1940s and since then has processed plutonium for weapons. Some plutonium processing continues, but much of the work at Hanford now involves cleaning up decades of nuclear waste.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Refuses to Carry Ads for Movies With New NC-17 Rating
DOC.TEXT: The president of the Motion Picture Association of America says an Alabama newspaper that rejected advertising for the first movie released with the new NC-17 rating is living in the Stone Age. The Birmingham News, an afternoon newspaper with a circulation of 180,000, became the first newspaper in the country to take such action. The newspaper, which previously banned ads for X-rated movies, said it would refuse ad copy for the Universal Pictures release ``Henry & June'' and for all subsequent NC-17 films. ``I can't tell the publisher how to do his business, but ... the reasonable, sane and fair way to do things is to find out what the picture is before you decide to ban its (advertising),'' said Jack Valenti, president of the motion picture association. ``That's what The New York Times and all intelligent newspapers are doing. If a newspaper wants to live in the Stone Age, I can't do anything about it,'' he said. Universal spokesman Allan Sutton said the Alabama newspaper was the first and only newspper to ban NC-17 ads. The ban came on the eve of the movie's Friday opening at Birmingham's Colonnade, part of the Columbus, Ga.-based Carmike theater chain. Universal said it is heavily advertising the movie on radio. Featuring two lesbian sex scenes and a shot of an erotic drawing, ``Henry & June'' is based on the diaries of Anais Nin and chronicles her affairs with writer Henry Miller and his wife. The association's new rating excludes anyone under 18 and replaces the X-rating. The X designation was long considered box office poison by the studios because of its association with hard-core sex and the inability to place media ads. In a Sunday editorial, the Birmingham News said ``smut was still smut'' and the NC-17 rating could lead to more violent or erotic fare, ``drawing audiences that might have been turned off by the stigma of an X rating.'' The New York Times and the Los Angeles Times didn't accept X-rated movie ads but have decided to permit ads for NC-17-rated films. ``Henry & June'' opened to sellout audiences in its first weekend of limited release. It took in $868,000 in 76 theaters for a robust $11,427 per-screen average. Last week in Dedham, Mass., the Showcase Cinema canceled a showing of ``Henry & June'' after two town selectmen claimed the NC-17 rating essentially meant the film was X-rated. ``These are isolated cases in my judgment,'' Valenti said. ``I'm not concerned. I just think in time, sensibility and sanity will prevail, and the First Amendment will live, hallelujah!''

DOC.HEAD: State Investigating `Slap Bracelets' After Girl's Injury
DOC.TEXT: A 4-year-old girl's cut finger prompted state officials to begin investigating the safety of a type of ``slap bracelet.'' Walgreens pulled a Taiwan-made brand of the popular toys from 16 Connecticut stores after the girl's father complained. The toy consists of a 9-inch strip of metal encased in cloth. When the strip is slapped against the wrist, it wraps itself around a wearer's arm. When Nicole Tomaso wrapped the bracelet she got at Walgreens around her wrist Tuesday, a piece of metal popped out of the cloth and she cut her finger, said her father, Joseph Tomaso. Nicole's bracelet was a copy of Slap Wraps, which are made by Main Street Toy in Simsbury and have become a fad with children. Slap Wraps sell for $2.49; the imitations cost 99 cents. The state Department of Consumer Protection on Wednesday began investigating the Taiwan-made bracelets for possibly dangerous sharp edges, said Joan Jordan, the department's product safety supervisor. The Slap Wrap brand isn't included in the investigation, she said. The state could recall the toy if it is found to violate the state's Child Protection Act, which bars non-functional sharp edges on toys sold to children 8 years old and youngerr, Jordan said. Elementary school officials in Pelham, N.Y., banned the wraps last week because of concerns about children cutting themselves. Main Street Toy maintains its bracelets, made with stainless steel, are safe, but says imitations are made from cheaper steel that will rust and break. ``We presented our item to Walgreens in July or August, but they turned us down because the other item was cheaper,'' said Deb Baker, marketing vice president for Main Street Toy.

DOC.HEAD: More Americans Flown Out Of Iraq; Kuwaiti Envoy Says Sanctions Will Fail
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 15 grafs to UPDATE with quotes from passengers, new details on figures. Picks up 16th pvs, `Until today...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY12
DOC.TEXT: An Iraqi Airways jetliner with more than 350 Western evacuees from Iraq and Kuwait landed in Britain today in the first such flight in nearly three weeks. Most of the passengers were Americans and many were children. Ten weeks after Iraqi troops overran his country, Kuwait's ambassador to the United States predicted that the U.N.-ordered embargo on trade with Baghdad will fail to force an Iraqi withdrawal. Saddam Hussein's forces are tightening their grip on oil-rich Kuwait, said the ambassador, Saud Nasir al-Sabah, and are confident they can outlast the U.S.-led multinational force arrayed against them in Saudi Arabia. Speaking in Washington on Wednesday, al-Sabah did not, however, go as far as to urge that the United States take military action against Iraq. ``You can reach your own conclusions,'' he said. The Persian Gulf crisis continued to wear on the U.S. economy. Oil prices briefly hit a record $41.15 a barrel on the New York Exchange on Wednesday before closing at $38.69, tumbling on an erroneous rumor that Saddam had been killed. On the New York Stock Exchange, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 37.62 points to 2,407.92, its lowest level since May 1989. The U.S.-chartered Boeing 747 from Iraq landed at Gatwick Airport outside London this morning after leaving Baghdad earlier in the day. It was the first such evacuation flight since Sept. 22. The British Foreign Office said about 360 passengers were on the flight. U.S. Embassy spokeswoman Nola Day said there were ``quite a few less than expected on board. A lot can happen between Kuwait and Baghdad.'' The embassy had expected close to 400 passengers. Mohammad Issa, a language teacher from Bridgeport, Conn. with dual U.S. and Jordanian nationality, said conditions in Kuwait were ``miserable, with people having to stand in line for bread, for gas, for everything.'' Robbie Faddah of Houston, clutching her daughter, Laila, also told reporters food supplies were very low, Iraqi troops were spread throughout the city, and many cars and trucks were being bombed, probably by the Kuwaiti resistance. Her husband, Hani Faddah, an electronics engineer who also has dual U.S. and Jordanian nationality, said: ``People are getting scared now. It has become like Lebanon. It is descending into a civil war.'' The Americans and Canadians on the flight were to leave Friday from London on a chartered flight for Raleigh-Durham International Airport in North Carolina, said Andrew Varney, Gatwick airport's director of public affairs. Until today, freedom flights had transported about 1,900 Americans out of Iraq and Kuwait. Recent State Department estimates indicated more than 600 Americans were stranded in Kuwait and more than 300 in Iraq. American and other Western men are being held in Iraq and Kuwait, many at strategic Iraqi installations to deter any possible attack. In Washington, the Kuwaiti ambassador al-Sabah said international sanctions imposed on Iraq after its Aug. 2 invasion will fail because Saddam's economy is self-sufficient in food. ``I don't believe Iraq in the short or long run will be adversely affected by the sanctions,'' he told a hearing of the House Human Rights Caucus, a loose organization of U.S. lawmakers interested in human rights issues. Iraq's border with Jordan also remains open to truck traffic, and aircraft still land in Amman and transfer their cargo to trucks that then poke holes in the embargo, the ambassador said. ``Sanctions will not bring Iraq down to its knees and force it out of Kuwait,'' al-Saban said. He said the embargo was being further undermined by the central banks in other countries who are providing credit lines to Iraq, although he declined to name the countries. ``Saddam Hussein's policy now is to sit tight ... to strengthen his grip on Kuwait and to outlast the patience of the multinational forces,'' Al-Sabah said. ``He hopes to break the alliance, and he believes time is on his side.'' It is generally agreed, however, that the U.N. embargo has all but suceeded in preventing Iraq from exporting the oil that had been its leading foreign currency earner. Saddam seized Kuwait in a dispute over oil, money and land, and in so doing boosted his share of world crude reserves to 20 percent. The Iraqis have moved an estimated 460,000 troops into the captive kingdom. More than 200,000 U.S. soldiers are stationed across the border in Saudi Arabia and aboard warships in the region. Thousands of Arab and European troops also have been deployed in the multinational force standing up to Saddam.

DOC.HEAD: Chiles Declares Pro-Choice Stance
DOC.TEXT: Democrat Lawton Chiles, in a move that could make abortion a major issue in Florida's gubernatorial campaign, has come down squarely on the pro-choice side. His opponent, Republican Gov. Bob Martinez, is fiercely anti-abortion. Chiles, a former U.S. senator, staked out his position on the anniversary of Martinez's failed attempt to push through restrictions on abortion. As a senator, Chiles voted against additional spending on abortions and voted for a constitutional amendment taking away the guaranteed right to an abortion. But he said Wednesday his position has changed and that he wanted to clear up any confusion over his views. ``I am not pro-abortion. I've always been opposed to abortion,'' Chiles said. ``But when it comes down to who makes that decision, I think we want the woman to be able to make it.'' Chiles has pledged to veto any legislation restricting a woman's right to choose. But he admitted he had trouble with the label ``pro-choice'' until recently because it was ``equated with ... that we don't care about life.'' He said that if elected, he would try to reduce the number of abortions by increasing spending on family planning, sex education and school health services and to improve pre-natal care. Chiles made his comments during a pro-choice forum at the Capitol, where a year ago thousands demonstrated while lawmakers shot down Martinez's proposals to limit abortions. The session was the first in the nation after the U.S. Supreme Court's Webster ruling gave states greater authority on the abortion question. Abortion so far hasn't been a major campaign issue. ``If abortion is an issue, I would say the governor made that an issue when he called a special session last year,'' Chiles said. ``I don't think any one issue will decide the campaign.'' Martinez has repeatedly said he felt compelled to call the session after the Webster ruling because of his deep personal opposition to abortion. J.M. ``Mac'' Stipanovich, Martinez's campaign manager, said, ``It's an interesting contrast between the governor's principles on this issue and Lawton Chiles' prostitution of it.'' The National Abortion Rights Action League took out full-page ads Wednesday in several newspapers with the headline ``We remember, Governor Martinez,'' urging people to vote against Martinez on Nov. 6.

DOC.HEAD: Revolt Under Way at Main Communist Party Newspaper
DOC.TEXT: The editor of the Communist Party newspaper Pravda says he has survived a mutiny by reporters who say they want to raise plummeting circulation by replacing rambling speech text with readable copy. Pravda today published an unsigned denial of reports that the newspaper's Communist Party organization called last week for the resignation of Ivan Frolov, who was appointed editor one year ago. The notice, buried on page eight, acknowledged that the newspaper's party organization had ``sharp, sometimes tough'' discussions during two days of meetings and that ``criticism of the leadership was expressed.'' But, it said, the meetings ``did not adopt a no-confidence resolution in the chief editor.'' Frolov said at an unusual news conference on Wednesday that ``these people thought they could organize a mini-coup.'' Outside in the hallway, Pravda writers held what they called a ``parallel'' news conference about their efforts to unseat Frolov. They said they sought to improve the newspaper, officially described as the ``organ of the Central Committee of the Communist Party.'' Pravda satirist Vladislav Yegorov told reporters leaving the Frolov news conference that the party organization at the newspaper had passed a resolution asking the Central Committee to ``review the question of the editorial board.'' He said that 140 workers at Pravda who are members of the Communist Party cell had considered calling for Frolov's resignation but dropped the idea as too provocative. Last year Pravda's circulation dropped by 3 million, to about 7 million, and it appears to be falling further during a subscription drive now under way, Yegorov said. He said readers were bored by the format of Pravda, which this week has devoted its pages to the full texts of speeches from a two-day meeting of the Communist Party's Central Committee - a body of diminishing relevance in Soviet politics. ``Our readers don't want that,'' said Yegorov. ``The most important thing is to make it a newspaper that is interesting to readers.'' The Supreme Soviet parliament has erased limits on the circulation of periodicals, but subscribers must sign up this fall for publications they wish to receive next year. Yegorov told reporters that subscribers in one ``central Russian town,'' which he declined to identify, had fallen from 9,000 to 240 in the current subscription drive. Frolov said the Central Committee told him he could keep his job. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev appointed him to replace Viktor Afanasyev who had run the paper under longtime Soviet leader Leonid Brezhnev. ``The Central Committee will examine what has been happening and what we will do next,'' Frolov told reporters in a rambling hourlong discourse. He said that ``all Soviet newspapers will feel a shock'' from the 1991 circulation figures. Tamara Hlyupova, secretary to Pravda's editorial board, said the 1991 figures were not available, but acknowledged the subscription drive ``is going very badly indeed.''

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd item of PM-Deaths to CORRECT date of primary to last year, sted this year.'
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Boggs Sigmund, the daughter of two members of Congress who as Princeton mayor lost last year's Democratic gubernatorial primary, died Wednesday at home of cancer. She was 51. After the loss of her left eye in 1982, Mrs. Sigmund made a trademark of her collection of fashionable eye patches, which were always coordinated with the color of her outfits or of holiday symbols. Mrs. Sigmund was the daughter of U.S. Rep. Lindy Boggs, a Democrat from New Orleans, and the late Hale Boggs, who was the House majority leader and had been slated to become speaker when he was killed in a 1972 plane crash. She ran unsuccessfully for the U.S. Senate in 1982 and was elected mayor of Princeton in 1984.

DOC.HEAD: Security Council Snagged On Last-Minute PLO Demands
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To ADD PLO comment, INSERT 2 grafs after 11th graf, `The United ... occupied territories.' Picks up 12th pvs, `The United ...' ^By PETER JAMES SPIELMANN
DOC.TEXT: After 18 hours of wrangling, the Security Council was deadlocked early today over last-minute PLO demands on a resolution condemning Israel for ``excessive'' use of force in the Temple Mount killings. ``We have a couple of issues still to be settled,'' U.S. Ambassador Thomas R. Pickering said as weary representatives broke up a series of meetings at 4 a.m. Exiting Palestine Liberation Organization officials declined to comment. The PLO had suddenly insisted that the United Nations assume some responsibility for the safety and welfare of Palestinians in the West Bank, Gaza Strip and east Jerusalem, which Israel seized in the 1967 Middle East war. ``That's not a resolution we can support in there, you all know that,'' Pickering said during the bargaining. The United States' earlier decision to join in denouncing Israel - its traditionally close Middle East ally - had already outraged Jewish groups, which flooded the U.S. Mission to the United Nations with phone calls. Agreement on the Temple Mount resolution had appeared at hand late Wednesday after U.S. diplomats agreed to temper criticism of Palestinians involved in the confrontation that led to Monday's killings. Nineteen Palestinians were killed and 140 wounded by Israeli forces that opened fire on Arabs who were pelting Jewish worshipers with stones. More than 20 Israelis were injured. As part of the agreement, the PLO and its non-aligned allies gave up their demand that the Security Council send three members to Jerusalem to investigate. Instead, it was agreed that Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar would send his own emissaries. Israel has rejected any Security Council mission as infringing on its sovereignty - but has accepted personal emissaries of the secretary-general in the past. But as the council was being called into formal session early today, the PLO registered new objections. It said it wanted Perez de Cuellar's emissaries to recommend a course of action, not just present ``conclusions,'' as the draft resolution states. The United States objected, saying that the Fourth Geneva Convention on the welfare of civilians in areas under military occupation makes it clear that Israel is responsible for those in the occupied territories. Later today, the PLO representative to the United Nations was asked why his organization was driving such a hard bargain in the Security Council. ``We would like to see the U.N. going back to what the U.N. was established for, namely that there should be a united United Nations against agression and mass murder,'' Zuhdi Terzi told ABC News. The United States normally shields Israel from rebuke in the Security Council and has not supported condemnation of Israel in the body since the Jewish state's 1982 invasion of Lebanon. But a U.S. veto of a Temple Mount resolution would drive a wedge between the United States and moderate Arabs who have banded together to isolate Iraq for its Aug. 2 invasion and occupation of Kuwait. The original U.S. draft resolution marked the first time the United States sponsored a council resolution condemning the Jewish state. It criticized Israel for using ``excessive'' force against Palestinian rioters. The New York-based Conference of Presidents of Major Jewish Organizations denounced the U.S.-supported draft resolution as harsh and hypocritical. At the Simon Wiesenthal Center in Los Angeles, Rabbi Marvin Hier accused Washington of giving Iraqi President Saddam Hussein and PLO Chairman Yasser Arafat a diplomatic victory in ``an attempt to curry favor with the Arabs.'' Egypt, Saudi Arabia, Morocco and other Arab states, including Kuwait's government in exile, say Israel's occupation of Gaza and the West Bank is just as offensive as Saddam's invasion of Kuwait. Saddam has been trying to link the withdrawal of his Iraqi troops from Kuwait with an Israeli withdrawal from the occupied territories. The last time the United States supported criticism of Israel in the Security Council was in January 1988, when it endorsed a resolution urging Israel to halt deportations of activists in the Palestinian uprising. The most dramatic instances of U.S. condemnation of Israel were in 1982 over the invasion of Lebanon to force out the PLO, and 1981 over Israel's destruction of an Iraqi nuclear reactor.

DOC.HEAD: Rain Falls in East Coast; Snow in Wyoming
DOC.TEXT: Rain fell over much of the East Coast and parts of the Great Lakes region early today, and cold weather turned rain into snow in Wyoming. Dry and partly cloudy skies prevailed over much of the Midwest and Great Plains early today. In the West, skies were mostly dry and fair. A thunderstorm developed over Charleston, S.C., early today, and the Deep South west of the Appalachians had mostly dry weather. Today's forecast called for thunderstorms and showers along a stationary front that was to stretch between the Appalachians and the Eastern seabord. Flooding was possible in the foothills and northern mountains of North Carolina. Tropical Storm Marco was expected to crash ashore along Florida's Gulf Coast. Its winds were not expected to reach the hurricane threshold, but flooding and beach erosion was likely. The nation's high on Wednesday was 99 degrees at Monrovia, Calif.
