DOC.HEAD: Six Bombs Explode In Northwest Spain, Three Killed In Disco Blast
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with higher injury count, officials now saying Galician separatists claiming all but disco bombing. ADDS details. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Six bombs exploded in several cities in the northwestern Galicia region before dawn today, including one in a discotheque that killed three people and injured 46, police said. A seventh bomb was defused. Officials said the three killed in the Santiago de Compostela disco bombing were believed to have been planting the device when it went off. No one was injured in the five bombings, which targeted businesses in another province, Pontevedra, its Civil Govrnor Jorge Parada told reporters. Civil Governor Ramon Berra of La Coruna province, which includes Santiago de Compostela, told Spanish National Radio that police were investigating whether drug traffickers might be behind the disco blast. A Galician separatist group claimed responsibility for the Pontevedra bombings, said Parada, which hit a clothing boutique, a car dealership, a canning factory, a bar and a bank office. Parada said police bomb experts defused a bomb at a bank in the Pontevedra province town of Villa Garcia after a telephoned bomb threat by the same group. The group, the Guerrilla Army of the Free Galician People, seeks independence from Spain for the four-province northwestern region of Galicia, but has been relatively inactive recently, Parada said. A police spokesman earlier said a caller claimed the club blast also was the work of Galician separatists, but the spokesman later denied it. He said drug traffickers as well as the separatists were suspected. The disco blast killed a man and two women believed to have been handling the bomb when it went off behind a stack of speakers, a police spokesman said on condition of anonymity. Earlier, police reported that three women had died. The five other bombs exploded afterward in Villagarcia de Arosa, Villanueva de Arosa, Cambados and the provincial capital of Pontevedra, police said. They damaged businesses owned by or linked to alleged Galician cocaine traffickers, police said. The owners of the businesses included five alleged traffickers of Colombian cocaine who were among the more than 30 people jailed in June during the country's largest police anti-drug operation. That operation focused on longtime Galician smugglers of contraband U.S. tobacco along Galicia's long, jagged coast who have become prime distributors in Europe of Colombian cocaine. Parada said the Galician separatist group's attacks against property linked to drug traffickers could be an attempt to gain public favor.

DOC.HEAD: Stanford Approves Student Housing for Homosexuals
DOC.TEXT: Stanford University officials will monitor a new policy that gives unmarried couples, including homosexuals, benefits usually given to the legally married. ``The impact is impossible to predict at this point,'' said Norm Robinson, the school's acting dean of student affairs. The university Board of Trustees decision announced Tuesday gives same-sex and unmarried couples the same rights as legally married students, entitling ``domestic partners'' to housing and university services such as access to library and athletic facilities. Robinson said the policy would prevent students from having to choose between Stanford and their love interest. ``The change also affirms Stanford's policy of not discriminating against students on a variety of factors, including sexual orientation,'' Robinson said in a statement. Homosexual men and women will be eligible to rent one-bedroom campus apartments in a complex previously reserved for legally married couples. ``This is a significant stepping stone in recognizing the legitimacy of all relationships,'' said Steven Petrow, director of public affairs for National Gay Rights Advocates, a San Francisco-based group that works for the equal treatment of homosexual couples.

DOC.HEAD: Northrop Behind Schedule on B-2 Flight Testing, Air Force Official Says
DOC.TEXT: Northrop Corp. is running nine months behind schedule in flight-testing its second B-2 bomber, a top Air Force official said in an interview published today. ``We would like to get more productivity and results sooner in the test program,'' Assistant Air Force Secretary John J. Welch told the Los Angeles Times. ``Frankly, we had hoped to have both of these vehicles in the air by now.'' While saying that testing of the second bomber is nine months behind schedule, Welch added that ``all the test results we have had to date are very encouraging.'' The first B-2 made its first flight on July 17, 1989, about 18 months behind schedule. It has flown 15 times in 15 months. The second B-2 originally was scheduled to fly last spring. Neither the Air Force nor Northrop have released scheduling information in Northrop's contract to build the planes. Northrop spokesman Tony Cantafio contended the company is only one month behind schedule. He attributed the delays to deferred disbursements of federal funding and a strike by workers at subcontractor Boeing Corp. The strike resulted in a contract change that shifted the secon bomber's flight date to late summer, Cantafio said. The B-2 can carry nuclear or conventional weapons and is intended to replace the nation's aging B-52 strategic bomber fleet. Its stealth technology is designed to foil enemy radar. The B-2 program has been attacked by some members of Congress for its projected cost of up to $75.4 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Nearly Flawless Discovery Mission Leaves NASA Beaming
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to CORRECT that Ulysses is not speeding toward sun, although sun is its ultimate destination; pick up 2nd graf, `We showed ...' Also drops erroneous reference in editor's note to noon EDT news conference
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto HT1
DOC.TEXT: NASA pronounced an end to its losing streak after Discovery completed a nearly trouble-free mission that sent a probe on a mission to explore the sun. ``We showed the world that the shuttle and NASA is reliable and can meet their commitments,'' said Aaron Cohen, director of the Johnson Space Center. The shuttle and its five astronauts swooped out of orbit and glided to a landing at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif., on Wednesday after a four-day flight. It was NASA's first shuttle mission in six months. Only a few problems were reported from blastoff to touchdown, including a computer programming error discovered after takeoff that was considered serious but no threat to the shuttle or crew, said Milt Heflin, lead flight director. ``Well, today the losing streak is over,'' Discovery commander Richard N. Richards said. ``If you criticize our mistakes, then you must also acknowledge our successes,'' shuttle director and former astronaut Robert Crippen said. NASA had been unable to fly a shuttle since April, when the Hubble Space Telescope was put into orbit. Later, scientists found the $1.5 billion telescope had a flawed mirror. Hydrogen leaks have grounded shuttles Columbia and Atlantis for months. Although Atlantis is set for launch in early November on a secret military flight, Columbia's troubles have not been resolved. ``The fact that (Discovery) flew and they had such a textbook mission really makes us feel good,'' said Conrad Nagel, a NASA official in charge of Atlantis' prelaunch operations. Atlantis' mission will be the fifth and final shuttle flight for 1990 - four fewer than planned - unless Columbia's leaks can be repaired in time for a late November or December launch. Discovery's launch ended the longest gap between shuttle missions since flights resumed following the 1986 Challenger accident. The shuttle blasted into orbit from Cape Canaveral, Fla., on Saturday. Several hours later, the crew sent the $250 million Ulysses probe on a 1.86-billion-mile journey to explore the sun's poles. Racing along at more than 25,000 mph, Ulysses was 3.1 million miles from Earth on Wednesday, NASA said. The spacecraft will swing past Jupiter in 1992 and use the planet's gravity to sling it back toward the sun. Discovery's computer error was made before launch but was discovered when the astronauts were converting the shuttle's five computers from launch operations to orbital operations, Heflin said. Automatic safeguards on Discovery would have prevented any problem even if the crew hadn't discovered the error, Heflin said. But the mistake was serious because ``if we erred in some procedures on the ground, why did we not catch it?'' The problem involved computer No. 4, used for ``housekeeping'' tasks, including monitoring Discovery's propulsion, electrical and life-support systems. When the astronauts called up a computerized display of instructions for the computer, they found the screen had been incorrectly loaded with instructions intended for computer No. 2, Heflin said. Discovery touched down on pavement in the second such test to determine if shuttles can land at Cape Canaveral. Crippen said the brakes apparently performed well, but he won't decide until spring when to have shuttles touch down in Florida.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Orders End to Racist Telephone Recordings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `The messages ..., to CORRECT spelling of Pittsburgh; pick up5th graf, `A group ...
DOC.TEXT: The Missouri Knights of the Ku Klux Klan must stop playing racist telephone recordings that imitate the ``Mister Rogers'' children's television show, a federal judge has ruled. U.S. District Judge Howard F. Sachs on Wednesday also ordered the Klan and three of its alleged members to turn over tape recordings and other materials that lawyers for the program say infringe on its trademarks and copyrights. Sachs issued the temporary restraining order one day after Fred M. Rogers and his Family Communications Inc. sued to stop the Klan's use of the recording. The message imitates the sound effects and song of the ``Mister Rogers'' television show and Rogers' voice and speech patterns. ``The messages are of racism, white supremacy and bigotry - the antithesis of everything Rogers and Family Communications Inc. stand for,'' said Cynthia E. Kernick, a lawyer for Rogers from Pittsburgh. A group of civil rights, community and religious leaders complained last week that the number for a telephone in Independence that played the racist message had been circulated among elementary and middle school students in the metropolitan area. The same phone number was used earlier this year to promote the philosophy of the Missouri Knights of the Klan. The lawsuit names the Klan and Adam Troy Mercer of Independence; Michael Brooks, also known as M.B. Madison, of Kansas City; and Edward E. Stephens, also of Kansas City. Attempts to reach Mercer, Madison and Stephens were unsuccessful. The judge set a hearing on a preliminary injunction for Oct. 20. Sachs declined to issue a civil search warrant allowing U.S. marshals to search for the tapes at the defendants' residences.

DOC.HEAD: Engineer: Environmental Officer Fired For `Political Problems'
DOC.TEXT: Mobil tried to protect its upper management by having its environmental auditors fudge their reports on federal violations, a former environmental manager for the oil giant says. Philip Olson made his claim Wednesday at a trial in U.S. District Court, where Valcar Bowman is suing Mobil Oil Corp. Bowman, a former Mobil environmental officer, says the company fired him in 1986 for opposing a coverup of environmental problems at a California plant. Bowman wants his job back as well as back pay and reimbursement for legal fees. Olson testified in the five-week-old trial that Bowman was fired for having ``political problems with upper management.'' Mobil denies Bowman's claims. The company says Bowman was let go for insubordination and disobedience and as part of a cost-cutting effort at its Mobil Chemical Corp. subsidiary. In testimony Wednesday, Olson said inspectors spoke candidly with Mobil managers but were careful in their notes and reports not to leave a paper trail that investigators could trace to higher executives. Olson said he saw environmental violations at the refineries he audited. He used an analogy to illustrate how Mobil wanted reports made. ``Let's say the speed limit is 55, and we saw a company vehicle go in excess of 55,'' he testified. ``We'd say we saw it going in excess of 50.'' Mobil has argued that self-policing eliminated the need for government oversight of plant inspections and audits. Bowman was fired after a Los Angeles County district attorney made an unannounced search of Mobil's oil refinery in Torrance, Calif., and confiscated documents detailing alleged air pollution violations. After that, the company ordered certain company records from the Mobil Chemical plant in Bakersfield, Cal., be brought to its outside lawyer. Bowman's staff was ordered to move the documents. Charles Lindberg, Mobil's chief in-house lawyer, said this was done in the belief that attorney-client privilege would keep the documents confidential and out of investigators' hands. Bowman says he opposed transferring the documents as unethical and immoral and that Mobil knew an inspection of the plant was imminent.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Waite to be Released in 48 Hours
DOC.TEXT: A newspaper reported that Anglican Church envoy Terry Waite will be freed by Saturday from 44 months of captivity in Lebanon. The short unattributed report in the Al-Anwar newspaper today said ``most of the British hostages also could be freed in a step that would set the stage for the release of all the (Western) hostages.'' The front-page report said an official Iranian delegation was due to arrive in the Syrian capital of Damascus today to prepare the agenda for a visit by Iranian Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati. Velayati, the report said, was to discuss the hostage issue with Syrian officials, among other topics. Four Britons, six Americans, two Germans and an Italian missing in Lebanon are believed to have been kidnapped by pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem factions affiliated with Hezbollah, or the Party of God. Waite, who was the personal emissary of Archbishop of Canterbury Robert Runcie, disappeared in west Beirut on Jan. 20, 1987, after leaving his hotel for a meeting with hostage-holders. No group has claimed responsibility. Former Irish hostage Brian Keenan, who was released in August, said he was held with the Anglican envoy in the same house for a while. Al-Anwar, which said Waite would be freed within 48 hours, is a conservative newspaper based in Christian east Beirut. It is known for serious reporting, although it is not noted for insight on the Western hostages. Al-Anwar's report was the latest in a series that followed an agreement between Iran and Britain late in September to restore diplomatic relations after an interruption of 18 months. The other missing Britons are journalist John McCarthy, World War II flier Jack Mann and writer Alec Collett. McCarthy, 33, of Barnet in north London, was kidnapped on April 17, 1986 while driving to Beirut airport to catch a flight to London. Mann, 76, was kidnapped in west Beirut on May 12, 1989. Collet, a New York-based writer, was kidnapped on March 25, 1985, while on an assignment in Lebanon for the U.N. Relief and Works Agency to aid Palestinian refugees. The Revolutionary Organization of Socialist Moslems, which is believed to be linked to Palestinian terrorist mastermind Abu Nidal, claimed four years ago that it hanged Collett in retaliation for British support for the U.S. air raids on Libya earlier that month. The group released a videotape purportedly showing Collett dangling from a scaffold. No body has been produced, but British officials believe Collett is dead. The longest held Western hostage is Terry A. Anderson, 42, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Octavio Paz: A Writer Who Defined His Nation
With PM-Nobel-Literature, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: It was in his grandfather's huge private library that the young Octavio Paz first read the literature, mythology and philosophy that helped him build his sensuous poetry, political commitment and essays on Mexican culture. Paz, perhaps Mexico's South African author Nadine Gordimer and Japanese novelist Masuji Ibuse. The prize, worth $700,000, is one of five awarded in October under terms of the will of Alfred Nobel, the Swedish inventor of dynamite, who died in 1896. Two American doctors who pioneered human organ, cell and bone marrow transplants, won the Nobel Prize in medicine Monday. Joseph E. Murray, 71, made the first successful organ transplant, in 1954. E. Donnall Thomas, 70, carried out the first bone marrow transplant, leading to a cure for leukemia and other diseases. The Nobel Peace Prize will be awarded Monday in Oslo, Norway. The Nobel Prizes in chemistry and physics will be awarded in Stockholm Oct. 17. The Central Bank of Sweden endowed the Nobel Prize in Economic Science in 1969 and it will be awarded on Oct. 16.

DOC.SECOND: PM-AP Arts: Gangster Films, 1st Ld - Writethru, a0412,1266
DOC.HEAD: SILVER TONGUES AND DEADLY BULLETS: A Look at Gangster Films
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 13th graf, `No one...', to CORRECT spelling of Musketeers.
DOC.TEXT: Also in Thursday AMs report.

The violence of ``GoodFellas'' and other current mob movies hasn't rattled those who crusade against rap and heavy metal. But in the early 1930s, police and concerned citizens agreed something had to be done about the ``too live crew'' of gangster films. The New York Patrolman's Benefit Association passed a resolution calling for a ban on films that ``glorify the lives of gangsters, gunmen and racketeers.'' The Better Films Committee of Montclair, N.J., blamed the death of a 12-year-old boy on a gangster movie the murderer had seen. The main culprits were ``Little Caesar'' and ``The Public Enemy.'' No matter that stars Edward G. Robinson and James Cagney got theirs in the end; who could possibly root for the coppers when the bad guys were played by better actors (with better wardrobes)? Hollywood tried. Cagney insisted he was ``sick of carrying guns and beating up women. Movies should be entertaining, not bloodbaths.'' And when ``Scarface: The Shame of the Nation,'' was released in 1932, a grim warning was placed at the beginning of the film: ``This picture is an indictment of gang rule in America and of thecallous indifference of the government to this increasing menace to our safety and our liberty. ... What are YOU going to do about it?'' But director Howard Hawks undermined the message; the thugs stole the show. None of the speechmaking by the film's police commissioner was as effective as watching George Raft coolly clip paper dolls or Paul Muni gun down fellow mobster Boris Karloff at a bowling alley, a bullet knocking down the 10th pin. ``Being a gangster was better than being president of the United States,'' Ray Liotta boasts as gangster Henry Hill in the current ``GoodFellas.'' Muni's Tony Camonte felt the same way as he stared outside his apartment at a neon sign that read ``The World Is Yours.'' Gangsters really weren't that different from the old Hollywood bosses. They talked tough, wore fancy clothes, cut million-dollar deals. They grew up poor and had little education, but made it to the top through hard work, ruthlessness and a strong belief in free enterprise. Death was inevitable - taxes were not. ``Because they ennoble energy and because they are low born, cocky, and self-sufficient, they demonstrate what one can accomplish against all the odds outside the traditions,'' film critic Neil Gabler wrote in ``An Empire of Their Own,'' his book about Hollywood. Current mob movies include ``Miller's Crossing,'' starring Gabriel Byrne as an Irish mobster with conflicting loyalties; ``State of Grace,'' another story about Irish mobsters, this one set in New York's Hell's Kitchen and starring Sean Penn, Gary Oldman and Ed Harris; and Martin Scorsese's ``GoodFellas.'' The highly publicized ``The Godfather: Part III,'' again directed by Francis Ford Coppola, is due in November. ``The Godfather,'' released in 1972, won the Academy Award for best picture and ``The Godfather Part II'' did the same two years later. No one can really identify the first gangster film, but D.W. Griffith's ``Musketeers of Pig Alley,'' released in 1912, contained some of the classic elements: a young couple trapped in a war between rival gangs, a saloon, a dance hall, crooked cops and gunmen with nervous hands. ``The Gangsters'' and ``The Making of Crooks,'' released during the next few years, included such devices as a policeman working undercover (a major part of the 1949 classic ``White Heat'') and a pool hall where crooks and aspiring crooks gathered. By the late 1920s, all a Hollywood producer had to do was pick up the newspaper to get inspiration. ``Torn From Today's Headlines'' was how one publicity department described the gangster films. ``Scarface,'' for instance, has a plot similar to the notorious St. Valentine's Day massacre. Al Capone (nicknamed ``Scarface'') was feuding for control of Chicago's bootlegging operations. On the morning of Feb. 14, 1929, four men - two dressed as police officers, raided rival George ``Bugs'' Moran's garage headquarters. They lined up the men against a wall feigning a routine frisk, but instead shattered their bodies with bullets. ``More and more is the realization growing that pictures can and do play an all-important part in the cultural and educational development of the world,'' said Jack Warner, the studio chief at Warner Bros., which produced most of the gangster films. ``I do not mean we should strive for so-called intellectual films, but we should strive for pictures that provide something more than a mere idle hour or two of entertainment.'' This was tabloid moviemaking, 90 minutes (or less) of screaming headlines, random violence and sex as gentle as a grapefruit in the kisser. Asked how Camonte (Muni) got the scar on his face, an associate snapped, ``In a war - with a blonde in a Brooklyn speakeasy.'' Darryl Zanuck, the young production chief at Warner's, was the mastermind behind many of the best gangster films, including ``Little Caesar'' and ``Doorway to Hell.'' Of Cagney's character in ``The Public Enemy,'' he boasted: ``Every other underworld picture has had a thug with a little bit of good in him. He reforms before the fade-out. This guy is no good at all. It'll go big.'' Warner's churned out product like a machine gun spitting bullets. Films were often completed in less than three weeks, with directors rushing from set to set and writers at times working on 10 projects at the same time. Cagney once made six pictures in a span of 40 weeks. Some of Hollywood's biggest stars began as tough guys and ``molls.'' Spencer Tracy appeared in a series of gangster films, notably ``Quick Millions,'' when he was under contract to Fox in the early 1930s. At MGM, Clark Gable was a gangster in several films, edging just slightly toward the right side of the law as he became more famous. Jean Harlow had a supporting role in ``The Public Enemy,'' Bette Davis appeared opposite Tracy in ``20,000 Years in Sing Sing'' and Cagney in ``Jimmy the Gent,'' and Barbara Stanwyck was no angel as the star of ``Baby Face.'' But by 1933, the first run of gangster films was soon over. In 1933, the repeal of Prohibition ended the bootlegging wars and the following year the Hays Office's production code called for the violence to be toned down and demanded a stop to all the ``passions that stimulate the baser emotions.'' Gangsters remained on the screen, but soon the best films were often parodies (``A Slight Case of Murder''), reflections on aging (``High Sierra'') or chronicles of a time (``The Roaring Twenties'') when silver tongues and deadly bullets gave small-time hustlers the chance to be big shots. ``Out of this mix of energy, suspicion, gloom, iconoclasm and liberalism came not only a distinctive kind of film, but also a distinctive vision of America - particularly urban America,'' Gabler wrote. ``It was a . . . world where one's only hope and only meaning lay not in higher morals, not in love, not in family, not in sacrifice, but in action leavened by a sense of honor.'' Camonte, with a reassuring pat to his coat pocket, put it another way: ``In this business, there's only one law you gotta follow to keep out of trouble.''

DOC.HEAD: Defense Secretary to Visit Moscow, London, Paris
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney will visit Moscow next week for talks with his Soviet Defense Minister Dmitriy Yazov, other senior Soviet government officials and prominent private citizens, the Pentagon said today. The visit Tuesday through Friday will be part of a 10-day trip in which Cheney also will meet with British Defense Secretary Tom King in London Oct. 13-16 and French Defense Minister Jean-Pierre Chevenement in Paris Oct. 19-22. Cheney is expected to discuss the U.S.-led international military buildup in the Persian Gulf area as well as other regional and global issues.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Seize Newborn From Mom Charged in the Death of Her 5-Year-Old
DOC.TEXT: State officials have taken custody of a baby girl born to a woman charged with letting her 5-year-old son die after he drank about 10 ounces of bourbon. District Court Judge Scott Moore on Tuesday granted the Texas Department of Human Services' request for temporary custody of Patricia Griffin's newborn after health workers said the child demonstrated signs of cocaine withdrawal. The girl will remain in the state's care pending a hearing next Wednesday to determine permanent custody, authoriities said today. A state caseworker's affidavit said the baby is jittery, irritable, easily startled and has a ``high-pitched cry which is indicative of cocaine-fed babies.'' Rachel Taylor weighed only 4 pounds, 2 ounces when she was born about two weeks ago, even though Ms. Griffin's pregnancy went past term. Ms. Griffin's son Raymond ``Tinkie'' Griffin died in February after allegedly being urged to drink bourbon at a party. Ms. Griffin, 32, and Anthony Jimerson, 21, will be tried together next week in the boy's death. Both face maximum life sentences.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Bush Endorses Higher Tax on Wealthy Coupled With Capital Gains Cuts
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with new Bush plan
DOC.TEXT: President Bush has decided to accept higher income tax rates on the wealthy in exchange for a deep cut in capital gains taxes as part of an overall deficit reduction package, Republican lawmakers said today. Rep. Bill Archer, R-Texas, a senior Republican on the tax-writing House Ways and Means Committee, emerged from a White House meeting announcing that the president was ready to end two days of confusion over his position on taxes. Bush made his decision as lawmakers struggled against an Oct. 19 deadline to come up with a $500 billion package of spending cuts and tax increases to get the deficit under control. Archer said Bush will support raising the marginal tax rate on the wealthiest Americans from 28 percent to 31 percent, but only if Congress lowers the capital gains rate to 15 percent. Capital gains - profits from the sale of stocks, real estate and other assets - are currently taxed at the same rate as other income. Now, even though the wealthiest taxpayers pay a 28 percent tax, those making less can pay 33 percent. Archer said that the new proposal would seek to eliminate this apparent inequity. MORE

DOC.HEAD: Text of Nobel Prize Citation for Octavio Paz
DOC.TEXT: Here is the text of the Swedish Academy's announcement awarding Octavio Paz the Nobel Prize in literature.
DOC.HEAD: The Announcement:
DOC.TEXT: This year the Nobel Prize for literature goes to the Mexican writer, poet and essayist Octavio Paz, honoring the writer of Spanish with a wide international perspective.
DOC.HEAD: The Citation:
DOC.TEXT: For impassioned writing with wide horizons, characterized by sensuous intelligence and humanistic integrity.
DOC.HEAD: The Text:
DOC.TEXT: Paz published his first collection of poems while still in his teens. Today, in his 76th year, he remains active as a writer and a critic. In ``A Draft of Shadows,'' from 1975, there is a line which provides the key to much of Paz's production: ``Seeing the world is spelling it.'' His poetry consists, in other words, to a very great extent, of writing both with and about words. In Paz's surrealistically inspired thought, the words are endowed in this way with new, changeable, and richer meanings. The power of the poetic vocation - often asserted by Brodsky, Walcott and others - gives the words a form of otherwise unattainable content. ``We never say/ the words of the poem/ The poem tells us'' (from ``Return,'' 1969). In a poem to Roman Jakobson in 1976, he articulates his stance: ``Between what I see and what I say,/ between what I say and what I keep silent,/ between what I keep silent and what I dream,/ between what I dream and what I forget:/ poetry.'' Paz's poetry and essays evolve from an intractable but fruitful union of cultures: pre-Columbian Indian, the Spanish conquistadors and Western modernism. Experiences from India and other areas are included as well. All of this has, in shifting configurations, been reflected in his work. His own identity, Mexican and, in its broader meaning, Latin American, has already been explored decisively in ``The Labyrinth of Solitude'' (1950). The poet himself embodies this union of cultures - it is in his blood. His mother's family was Spanish, from Andalusia. On his father's side the Indian and the Spanish are combined. One of the high points of Paz's poetry is the long poem ``Sun Stone'' (1957). This was inspired by a magnificent calendar stone, which still stands as an heirloom from the Aztecs, whose calendar was based on the conjunctions of Venus and the sun. The 584 days of this cycle are matched by the 584 lines of the poem. This suggestive work with its many layers of meaning seems to incorporate, interpret and reconstrue major existential questions: death, time, love, and reality. As a publisher of magazines, ``Vuelta'' (``Return'') being the latest, Paz has been a lodestar in the tide of opinion. Others have quite simply been obliged to state their position in relation to his. He has pursued his humanistic course with unique integrity, which is also recorded in the prize citation. In his book ``Sor Juana: or The Traps of Faith'' (1982) he applies literary history and the history of ideas in depicting Juana Ines de la Cruz, a remarkable 17th century woman. This erudite poet and dramatist, a lady-in-waiting who later became a nun, is the subject of a penetrating analysis against the background of the culture and society of her day. The work takes the form of a portrait, one which bears the signature of a great humanist. Paz has written exquisite love poetry, at the same time sensuous and visual. ``Woman:/ fountain in the night./ I am bound to her quiet flowing.'' In his latest collection of poems, ``A Tree Within'' (1987), we are confronted with a series of reflections on death. Paz turns inwards on himself in a new way. Paz is a poet and essayist. His poetry, with one of its points of departure in surrealism, which, however, he has developed and broadened under the influence of pre-Columbian culture and the Buddhist philosophy of India and Japan, can be found, apart from his first volume from 1933, in the ``Poemas 1935-1975'' (1981) and the bilingual ``Collected Poems 1957-1987'' (1987). His collections of essays, amounting to about 30, deal to a great extent with social subjects. Not the least important of these are, of course, Mexican history and culture, together with art and literature, in particular the essence and diction of poetry.

DOC.HEAD: Holdup Note Written on Robber's Deposit Slip
DOC.TEXT: Authorities didn't have to look too hard for the man who robbed a Canada Trust branch. Craig MacNaughton, 31, of nearby Kelowna wrote the holdup note on one of his deposit slips. MacNaughton pleaded guilty to robbery in provincial court Wednesday and was sentenced to three years in jail. On Aug. 25, MacNaughton handed a teller a note, produced a large knife and said, ``Give me your money, I need it,'' prosecutor Vern Frolick told the court. The teller gave MacNaughton $1,296 and he fled the bank in this south-central British Columbia city. When the Royal Canadian Mounted Police examined the robbery note, they saw it was written on the back of a Canada Trust deposit slip, with MacNaughton's branch and account number filled in, Frolick said. Defense attorney Brian Adams said the robbery was a cry for help. ``I think what we're dealing with is a person of some diminished capacity,'' Adams said. MacNaughton has a criminal record that includes theft and break-and-entry charges dating from 1975, the court was told.

DOC.HEAD: Pennsylvania Man Plans To Claim Ohio Lottery's $50 Million
DOC.TEXT: An Erie, Pa., man who claims to hold a winning $50 million Super Lotto ticket boarded a limousine this morning for the ride to Cleveland, where he planned to claim his prize. Ohio Lottery spokeswoman Anne Bloomberg said the lottery couldn't confirm the winner's identity until a formal claim was made and validated at an Ohio Lottery office. The ticket is the second-most valuable in the history of U.S. lotteries. Florida's lottery had a $55.2 million winning ticket on Sept. 3, 1988. There have been larger lottery prizes, but they were split among multiple ticketholders. The lone winning ticket is worth $1,923,077 a year for 26 years, before taxes, and was purchased in Conneaut, a small city at Ohio's northeast tip near Pennsylvania, lottery officials said. Richard Hovis, 37, told television station WSEE in Erie he was the winner. ``We saw the ticket and the numbers on it. It was a little bit crumpled, but the numbers were there,'' Pierre Bellicini of WSEE said. Hovis told the station in an interview: ``I'm going to take care of the folks first, pay some debts, then redo my bathroom and maybe Bondo my Pinto.'' Bondo is a substance used to patch rust holes. Hovis, a warehouse manager at Erie Manufacturing & Supply Co., told co-workers today he had the winning ticket and submitted a two-week notice of resignation, said Dan Wlodarczyk, the company's purchasing and sales manager. Company president Cy Wellman said he arranged for Hovis to travel to Cleveland to validate the ticket. ``It's crazy,'' Wellman said. ``It's our 100th anniversary as a company Nov. 1. We decided the best way to celebrate was to have one of our employees win $50 million. I feel fortunate. Rick is a wonderful guy and you have to feel terrific for any individual who wins $50 million.'' The high jackpot created long lines at Ohio Lottery sales outlets Wednesday. The lottery sold $15,299,601 worth of tickets for Wednesday night's televised drawing. The winning numbers were 3, 17, 28, 41, 46 and 49.

DOC.HEAD: Britain: Give Saddam an Ultimatum
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd said today that Iraq must be told that force will be used unless President Saddam Hussein withdraws from Kuwait. ``Day by day we must build in the minds of the Iraqis the certainty that they have to leave Kuwait - if not peacefully, then forced out by military action,'' Hurd said. He spoke during the annual conference of the governing Conservative Party. Hurd warned that the world will revert to anarchy if the international coalition against Iraq collapses. ``If it does not (hold), then despite the coalition, despite the leadership of the United States, despite the cooperation of the Soviet Union - then we shall be back in a world of anarchy punctuated by explosions of force. ``The clouds would have extinguished the light. We cannot allow this to happen,'' he said. Hurd made only passing reference to the killing this week by Israelis of 19 Arabs at a riot in Jerusalem, and said that ending Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait must take precedence over attempts to solve the Arab-Israeli conflict. Hurd addressed the conference as Britain battled in the U.N. Security Council in New York to find a means of censuring Israel that goes far enough for outraged Arab nations but that the United States will also accept. Earlier, Chancellor of the Exchequer John Major pledged that Britain will fight plans for European economic union despite the linking the pound this week to other European Community currencies. Major, in his keynote address to the conference, also promised Britain's 10.6 percent inflation rate - the major failure of 11 years of conservative rule - will fall sharply next year. ``Joining the Exchange Rate Mechanism does not mean that we are now on a road leading inexorably to a single currency,'' he said to cheers from the 5,000 delegates. The chancellor reiterated that Britain still will not accept a radical plan for a single currency and central banking system for the 12-nation European Economic Community.

DOC.HEAD: Police Break Up March, Army Warns on Curfew Violations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 7th pvs, `Christian leaders...' to CORRECT identification of cleric. Pickup 8th, `Today's demonstrations...'
DOC.TEXT: Police fired tear gas in Jerusalem's Old City today to break up a march by about 150 Palestinians to the Temple Mount, where 19 Arabs were killed by police gunfire earlier this week. ``World, listen to us. We are people who will never submit,'' the marchers chanted before being blocked from entering the Mount by riot police armed with machine guns. Meanwhile, several hundred Arabs who had entered the Mount earlier in the day marched around the Dome of the Rock Mosque carrying outlawed Palestinian flags. They chanted the Moslem battle cry, ``Allahu Akbar!'' or ``God is Great!'' and ``We will redeem our martyrs!'' One of the flags was draped over a symbolic coffin. Israeli police guarding the gates to the Mount watched the demonstration but did not intervene. Another protest against the killings was held at the Church of the Holy Sepulchre, where 70 Palestinians, many of them women dressed in black, staged a sit-down strike. Christian leaders marched from the church to the Temple Mount to join Moslem clerics in prayer. They included Samir Kafity, the Anglican bishop of Jerusalem, and Lutfi Laham, the Greek Catholic patriarch. Today's demonstrations were the latest in a series of protests following the clash Monday on the Mount, the third holiest site in Islam. Arab hospitals in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip said at least 14 Palestinians were shot and wounded by soldiers in scattered clashes Wednesday. More than a million Palestinians remained under army curfews in the occupied territories, confined to their homes under army orders. The underground leadership of the nearly 3-year-old Palestinian uprising had urged Gaza residents to violate the curfews starting today. But residents said few people came out of their homes after army units drove through Gaza towns early today warning through loudspeakers that ``anybody who defies the curfew will be severely punished.'' Monday's rioting at the Temple Mount began when Palestinians threw stones at Jewish worshipers at the adjacent Western Wall. The stoning was apparently triggered by rumors Jewish zealots were going to march to the Moslem-controlled Mount to reclaim it for Judaism. About 30 worshipers and police were injured by the stones, and police then charged onto the Temple Mount, first firing tear gas and then live ammunition. The rioting, in which 140 Arabs were wounded, was the bloodiest of the Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation that began in December, 1987. In the uprising, at least 758 Palestinians have been slain by Israelis and another 278 Arabs have been killed by other Arabs as alleged collaborators with the enemy. Fifty-two Israelis and foreigners have also died in the violence. Moslems venerate the Temple Mount as Haram es-Sharif, or the Noble Enclosure, and believe it is where the Prophet Mohammed ascended to heaven. Its two mosques, dating to the 7th and 8th centuries, are Islam's third holiest site. The Western Wall, also known as the Wailing Wall, is the last remnant of the ancient Jewish temple destroyed by the Romans in the year 70. It is Judaism's holiest place.

DOC.HEAD: Moderates Win Sweeping Victory In Lopsided Elections
DOC.TEXT: Iranian moderates allied with President Hashemi Rafsanjani's government on Thursday won nearly all seats on a constitutional body in elections in which many of their radical opponents were excluded. The official Islamic Republic News Agency, monitored in Nicosia, said only 1.8 million people voted in Tehran, the Iranian capital, which has a population of more than 10 million. This confirmed earlier reports from diplomatic sources in Tehran that Monday's poll was largely boycotted despite government exhortations urging all Iranians over 15 to vote. Rafsanjani, leader of Iran's so-called pragmatists, was among the key members elected to the 83-member Assembly of Experts, whose main task is to elect the nation's spiritual leader and interpret the constitution. Among others elected to the 15 seats contested in Tehran were Ahmad Khomeini, son of the late revolutionary leader Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini; Mohammad Reyshahri, the former prosecutor-general; and Ayatollah Ali Meshkini, who headed the last assembly. The three are among only a handful of Rafsanjani's radical rivals whose names were allowed on the ballot as part of the president's campaign to squeeze the hard-liners out of key power centers. Most of the radicals were prevented from running after the government said they had had to sit a test on their Islamic credentials, in an apparent effort by Ayatollah ali Khamenei, the current spiritual leader, and Rafsanjani to reduce the radicals' influence. Most of the radicals who agreed to take the examamination flunked. Before the 12-member Council of Guardians decreed the new rule, candidates for the assembly were approved by three senior clerics in the holy city of Qom. The conflict over the balloting has heightened tension between th rival factions and brought the long-running power struggle in Tehran's hierarchy more prominently into the open. Since the death of Khomeini in June 1989, the anti-Western radicals have feared a purge by Rafsanjani. He is seeking to rebuild bridges with the West and attract investment to revive the sluggish economy devastated by the 1980-88 war with Iraq. His opponents say close ties with the West are contrary to Khomeini's teachings. The radicals, who constitute a majority in the 270-member parliament, have accused Khamenei, Rafsanjani's political ally, of colluding with him in rigging the elections. The voting was conducted amid tight security, after the radicals had threatened to stage protests, diplomatic sources in Tehran said. But no incidents were reported. In an apparent move to appease the radicals, Khamenei on Thursday called on mosques throughout the nation to mourn the slaying of 19 Palestinians by Israeli forces in Jerusalem Monday. The killings have particularly enraged the radicals, who consider Israel and the United States the greatest enemies of Islam. They have repeatedly pledged to destroy Israel and ``humilate the Great Satan,'' its closest ally. The Majlis, or parliament, Wednesday called for a jihad, or holy war, to liberate the Palestinian homeland. The broadcast, monitored in Nicosia, said Rafsanjani declared Friday a national day of mourning.

DOC.HEAD: New Paris Bridge Named For De Gaulle
DOC.TEXT: A new bridge across the Seine River will be named for Gen. Charles de Gaulle to mark this year's anniversary of his birth, death and appeal to France to resist Nazi occupation. Mayor Jacques Chirac announced Thursday that work on the new bridge linking Rue Van Gogh to the Austerlitz train station will begin before year's end and be completed in 1993. Chirac said the bridge will ``pay solemn and durable homage to the man who most marked the history of ou country during the course of this century.'' France has celebrated this year as the 100th anniversary of de Gaulle's birth, the 20th of his death, and the 50th of his speech from London urging France to resist the Nazis shortly after the country fell to German troops in World War II.

DOC.HEAD: Chess Set Collection Featured at World Championship in New York
LaserPhoto NY28
DOC.TEXT: In the foyer of a New York theater where the world chess championship opened this week, 100 exotic chess sets shine inside a row of illuminated cases. Half belong to David Hafler, a suburban Philadelphia man whose collection has been called among the finest in the world. Collected over 30 years, Hafler's 230 sets from 40 countries feature figures of jade, porcelain, glass, ivory, wood, gold, silver and a variety of semiprecious stones. ``There's an aesthetic value in the sets themselves and in the art related to it,'' said Hafler. ``Most people don't realize what variety there is and what beauty is available. It's something that can be appreciated even by people who don't play chess.'' The first 12 games between world champion Garri Kasparov and his challenger Anatoly Karpov are being played at the Hudson Theater in New York. Kasparov won the second game, Wednesday night; the first game ended in a draw. The match will move to Lyon, France, for the concluding 12 games of a 10-week face-off. The collection will not move with the competition. Hafler, 71, began collecting sets in 1960 after he bought a set for a friend's son at a New York department store. He returned later with his wife, Gertrude, to buy a set for himself. ``Gert looked up and said, `Let's get this one, too,''' he said. ``I said, `We don't need another set.' She said, `Well, you like that one; I like this one.' So we got another set and that was the start - once you get more than one of something that you don't really need, you've become a collector,'' he said. Hafler later asked U.S. embassies to help him locate dealers. The designer of specialized audio equipment also scheduled overseas business trips to coincide with auctions. Hafler's oldest complete set is a 15th- or 16th-century French set of topaz and crystal. He has a Faberge original, a set Napoleon supposedly presented to one of his generals, and an amber set once owned by Russian Empress Catherine the Great. A Soviet set made in the 1930s features capitalist pawns in chains. ``Hafler's collection is reputedly the best in the world,'' said Larry Parr, a former editor of the U.S. magazine Chess Life and Review. ``It is certainly first among equals.'' The 50 other sets on display in New York belong to George Dean, a doctor from Birmingham, Mich., who formed Chess Collectors International in 1984. Although Hafler occasionally plays chess, he said few collectors do. ``In fact, some of them don't even know how to set up the pieces.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Throws Ethics Amendment Off Missouri's Ballot
DOC.TEXT: A state judge today threw an ethics initiative off Missouri's Nov. 6 ballot, ruling that several parts of it were unconstitutional. Cole County Circuit Judge James F. McHenry said the measure wrongly dealt with too many subjects and that its ballot title was insufficient. McHenry said the initiative, Amendment 5, ``is not in compliance with the procedural requirements of the Constitution of Missouri ... and it is therefore not to be printed'' on the ballot. Amendment 5, placed on the ballot through a petition campaign, would create a state ethics commission and force big changes in the Legislature, including reducing the size of the 163-member House to 103 by 2003. State Attorney General William Webster said he would appeal McHenry's ruling to the Missouri Supreme Court. Willard Reine, president of Missourians to Protect the Initiative Process, which legally challenged the measure, said: ``I'm very pleased. I think the judge interpreted the law right. The initiative process is important to have, but it's got to be done right.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Endorses Tax Deal, Then Aide Casts New Doubt on Chances
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; editing thruout to tighten; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: The White House said today President Bush would accept higher taxes on the wealthiest Americans in a trade for a deep cut in capital gains rates. Bush's decision was disclosed after two days of confusion over his position on taxes, and came as Congress struggled to cement a $500 billion deficit reduction package of tax increases and spending cuts. Rep. William Archer, R-Texas, said that under the plan, the top income tax rate would be raised for about 500,000 of the nation's wealthiest taxpayers. The rate would be lowered for about 4.5 million who earn slightly less, he said. The tax on capital gains would be cut for all who make profits on the sale of stocks, real estate and other investments. Bush's new tax policy faced an uncertain reception in Congress, where many Republicans philosophically oppose any increase in tax rates, and some Democrats are reluctant cut the capital gains tax. There was no immediate reaction from Democratic leaders. But within an hour of Bush's decision being made public, the White House sought to lower expectations for such a deal - and suggest that the Democrats would never go along. Richard Darman, White House budget director, said Republicans had proposed a hike in tax rates for the wealthy during budget negotiations last month, but said it was rejected by the Democrats. Under the proposal, the the marginal tax rate on the wealthiest Americans would be raised from 28 percent to 31 percent, but only if Congress lowers the capital gains rate to 15 percent. Capital gains - profits from the sale of stocks, real estate and other assets - are currently taxed at the same rate as other income. The White House statement said that Bush had authorized his budget negotiators to explore such an option more than a month ago - even though today was the first time it has surfaced publically. The statement said that, while Bush still supported the plan, he was afraid that its formal presentation at this time could actually lead to Democratic action to raise the top tax rates to 33 percent. ``I will not tolerate ... raising rates to 33 percent,'' Bush was quoted by Fitzwater as saying. ``I cannot accept that.'' The statement said that the plan for a 31 percent top rate was originally opposed not only by Democrats but ``also by some of the same Republicans who now favor it.'' Archer said roughly 500,000 people will get a rate increase under the proposal. ``Those will be at the very highest income levels,'' he said. Archer said about 4.5 million people would get a rate reduction under the proposal - presumably those now paying a 33 percent rate. The plan would bring a relatively modest $6 billion in increased tax revenues to the Treasury over five years, Archer said. Participants at the morning meeting said the new proposal would, in essence, do away with the current 33 percent top rate - now paid by upper middle-class taxpayers. In essence, GOP lawmakers said, Bush's proposal would flatten out the so-called ``bubble'' in the tax code, the anomaly under which tax rates on additional income are now lower for the wealthiest Americans than they are for some who are less wealthy. Instead, there would be three distinct tax brackets. The 15 percent bracket for lower-income Americans would remain. Then, above a certain income level, the taxes for additional income would jump to 28 percent; and finally, move to 31 percent. Bush earlier in the week had indicated that he was open to a compromise trading higher taxes on the wealthy for a lower capital-gains rate. However, he then appeared to back away under pressure from GOP senators. The confusion created by Bush's apparent wavering on the issue slowed down congressional consideration of a budget compromise and led Democratic leaders to accuse Bush of indecision. ``He said, without equivocation, this is what we wanted to do,'' Archer said in comments echoed by other Republicans who attended the morning meeting. House Republican Leader Bob Michel, R-Ill., said that Bush was ``inflexible'' on the new 31 percent rate ``as I understand it, as of this morning.'' Michel said, ``The president wanted to clearly stake out where he was on that issue.'' Earlier, Senate leaders reported progress in efforts to agree on a deficit-reduction plan after the House Ways and Means Committee approved a $144 billion bill to raise taxes on gasoline, tobacco, alcohol and the earnings of higher-income Americans. ``What we are trying to do is see if we can develop a comprehensive package that is acceptable to a majority of Democratic and Republican members,'' Senate Majority Leader George J. Mitchell, D-Maine, told reporters. ``We believe we have made progress,'' he said after meeting with Republican Leader Bob Dole of Kansas and leaders of the Finance Committee. The House bill approved by the Ways and Means Committee bill eliminates a proposed tax on heating oil; lessens an increase in the tax on gasoline; drops $12 billion in tax incentives for investors in small corporations and reduces the proposed increase in premiums that retirees pay for Medicare coverage of doctors' bills. The Medicare premium, now $28.60 a month, would rise gradually to $46.50. The annual $75 deductible that beneficiaries pay for hospital care before Medicare starts paying would be raised to $100 next year and to $125 in 1992. Overall, the new plan would mean a 2.4 percent tax increase on people with incomes of $200,000 or more, compared with 1.7 percent in the earlier version. For those with incomes from $30,000 to $40,000, the new plan would raise taxes by 3 percent, compared with 2.9 percent in the earlier plan. People with incomes under $10,000 would face a 6.9 percent overall tax increase under the Ways and Means bill, down from 7.6 percent in the earlier bill.

DOC.HEAD: Tropical Storm Closes Schools, Knocks Out Power, Shuts Down Bridge
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with conditions at noon, picking up 6th graf, `It was ...; SUBS last graf to CORRECT number of hurricanes to seven sted six.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto staffing
DOC.TEXT: Tropical Storm Marco buffeted Florida's Gulf Coast with 65 mph winds and up to 5 inches of rain this morning before starting to weaken as it hugged land in the Tampa Bay area. On its way it it cut power to at least 14,000 people, closed schools and shut down a bridge. Bermuda, meanwhile, braced for Hurricane Lili, upgraded from tropical storm status Wednesday as its winds neared 75 mph. At noon, Lili was centered about 145 miles southeast of Bermuda. Forecasters said Bermuda began feeling the effects of Lili this morning with rain showers, thunderstorms and gusty winds. Hurricane conditions on the island were possible later today, according to the hurricane center. At noon EDT, Marco's center was located about five miles north of Clearwater and moving north at 9 mph. Its sustained winds had dropped to 45 mph, from 65 mph earlier in the day. Storm-force winds extended outward 150 miles over open Gulf waters and 50 miles east of the center, mostly over land. Forecasters said the sweep of winds over land would gradually weaken the storm. ``It was a difficult night but I think we came out better than we expected,'' Chris Eversole of Sarasota Emergency Management Preparedness said at daybreak. ``It looks like the worst may be over. The winds are calming and the rain is subsiding.'' The 150-foot Sunshine Skyway Bridge over Tampa Bay was shut down by the winds, The Sunshine Skyway Bridge, the Florida Highway Patrol said. Power lines were toppled and schools were closed in Manatee and Sarasota counties because of heavy rain and winds, authorities said. Emergency management officials said 14,000 Sarasota County residents were without power early today, but by 7 a.m. it had been restored to all but 4,600. Scattered outages also were reported in the Bradenton area. In Manatee County, 35,000 residents lost power overnight. By late morning 10,000 customers were still out. A motorist in Sarasota was seriously hurt when a tree fell on his car. Marco was expected to push tides 1 to 3 feet above normal, scour the sandy beaches and dump 3 or more inches of rain in some sections. All Red Cross chapters on the Gulf Coast from the Keys to the Panhandle were on alert and ready to open shelters, state disaster specialist Karen Wescott said. Two shelters opened in Bradenton for voluntary evacuees. In the Keys, trucks and vans were advised to stay off bridges because of strong gusts. Myton Ireland, owner of a marina on the barrier island Sanibel, hauled nine boats, all 40 feet or longer, onto land Wednesday. ``We're prepared, as prepared as we're going to be,'' Ireland said. ``If we wait too late and then it blows hard, we're in trouble.'' While potentially damaging, Marco also could give the state some relief from a drought, Case said. ``We've got tap on the tropics,'' he said. ``We've got a mechanism here where we can bring tropical air up over the southeastern United States and have the mechanism squeeze it like you would a sponge.'' Jimmy Brooks, a water manager in Inverness, said residents still will need to conserve. ``Every drop helps, but we didn't get into this situation overnight and one storm will not bring us out of this drought situation,'' he said. In North Carolina, rains attributed to Marco flooded roads and were blamed for two highway deaths. They may also have caused a freight train to jump its tracks, officials said. The deluge was welcome in at least one place. The more than four inches of rain that drenched the Florida peninsula also doused the biggest part of a 40-day-old fire in the Okefenokee Swamp. Ignited by lightning, the fire has blackened more than 20,000 of the swamp's 438,000 acres. Officials at the Okefenokee National Wildlife Refuge said today that peat moss in the swamp is likely to continue smoldering, however. ``The fire essentially has gone underground,'' said Dorn Whitmore, a refuge spokesman. ``The peat will smolder till the swamp floods. But the fire won't advance anymore.'' Marco is the 13th named storm of Atlantic season, which runs from June through November. Seven have become hurricanes. Tropical storms have maximum sustained winds of at least 39 mph.

DOC.HEAD: Earthquake Reported in Do-hican Xewublic
DOC.TEXT: WASHINGTON AP) - A strong earthquake ... in the Dominican Republic today, the U.S. ... Survey said. The tremor, with magnitude of 5.2 on the Richter scale, struck about 40 miles northeast of the capital, Santo Domingo, at about 11:15 a.m. EDT, officials said. There were no immediate reports of damage or injuries, but the quake was felt in the eastern half of the country as well as in some parts of Puerto Rico. A quake rated between .0 and 6.0 on the scale can cause considerable damage. The Richter Scale measures the strength of a quake based on ground motion and each increase of one whole number6indicates 10 times more force.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Withdraws From Race Against Husband
DOC.TEXT: Brenda Selinger is pulling out of the race for state's attorney in Slope County. That should be a relief for the incumbent - her husband, Bruce. The Selingers lived happily under one roof while both ran for the job. Selinger said it was never a grudge match between the two lawyers. Mrs. Selinger even admitted her husband was doing a fine job as prosecutor. ``We couldn't decide which of us wanted the job, so we both took out petitions,'' Selinger said. Mrs. Selinger, with a 2-year-old child at home and a full-time job in Dickinson, wanted her husband's job because of the part-time hours. But she has since arranged to work part-time. Selinger got 205 votes in June's primary to his wife's 133. Though Mrs. Selinger is quitting the race her name will appear along with her husband's on the Nov. 6 ballot. ``There were a lot of questions on people's faces,'' Mrs. Selinger said of the months she and her husband were political opponents. ``We just laughed and said we were trying to keep things interesting in Slope County.''

DOC.HEAD: Sony to Unveil JumboTron Screen in Times Square
DOC.TEXT: The bright lights of Times Square will get a little brighter in November after the unveiling of what is being called the largest permanent outdoor color video screen in the United States. The 23{-by-32-foot screen, attached to One Times Square, is the work of Sony Corp. Company officials announced plans for the JumboTron screen Wednesday. The screen will replace the old Sony panels that have been in Times Square for 20 years. It will serve as a marketing and promotional tool for Sony-owned CBS Records and Columbia Pictures. ``The Sony Video 1 Network'' also will provide news, holiday messages, public service messages and other programming. ``CBS Records is excited to have this new large scale medium available to increase awareness of our roster of talented artists,'' said Bob Altshuler, senior vice president.

DOC.HEAD: Outburst Interrupts Racial Attack Trial
DOC.TEXT: A juror began shouting in open court today at the father of murder victim Yusuf Hawkins, interrupting deliberations in the trial of a white man charged in the black teen-ager's death. The defense moved for a mistrial based on the juror's profanity-laced antagonism, but Justice Thaddeus Owens ruled that the proceedings would go on. The exchange occurred shortly before noon as the jury sat in the courtroom listening to a reading of testimony by the defendant, Charles Stressler. He is one of several whites charged in Hawkins' August 1989 death in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn. Hawkins' father, Moses Stewart, watched from the spectator seats. Suddenly one of the jurors, Lydia Bermudez, yelled at Stewart: ``You've been doing that to me every day. You know what I'm talking about. You've been doing it every ... day.'' The juror did not say what she meant, but Stewart said later he took her to be objecting to being looked at. ``If she can't stand the father of the victim looking at her, get her ... out of here,'' he said. ``I look at everybody on the jury. I don't care who she is, I look at everybody on the jury.'' After the outburst, Owens called the juror and lawyers to chambers, where Stressler's lawyer, Jacob B. Evseroff, moved for dismissal of the indictment, mistrial or Stewart's exclusion from the courtroom. Owens denied all three motions. Bermudez had indicated to the judge that she felt intimidated by Stewart and asserted: ``I don't need this aggravation from this freaking low-life ...'' The jury received the case Wednesday evening after hearing the defense argue that Stressler, 22, was little more than a bystander while prosecutors said he waqs guilty of murder for acting in concert with other members of the white mob. In earlier trials, Joey Fama, 19, was convicted of murdering Hawkins, and Keith Mondello, also 19, was acquitted of murder and manslaughter, but was convicted on several lesser charges. John Vento was convicted of menacing and unlawful imprisonment. His jury deadlocked on murder and riot counts and he is awaiting retrial. Four other young white men will be tried later for their alleged roles in the attack.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Bush Endorses Tax Deal, Then Casts New Doubt
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with Bush comments; picks up 4th graf pvs, Bush's new...
DOC.TEXT: The White House said today President Bush would accept higher taxes on the wealthiest Americans in exchange for a deep cut in capital gains rates, but prefers a deficit-cutting agreement that omits both elements. Caught in another day of budget confusion, Bush said he would not pursue the tax trade in negotiations with the House and Senate over a package of spending cuts and tax increases totalling $500 billion over five years. ``I think it's a waste of time because I just don't think it can get through both houses of Congress,'' Bush said of the proposal. There was no immediate reaction from congressional Democrats. The developments seemed to complicate efforts to draft the budget accord before Oct. 19, when the government faces the prospect of a shutdown in non-essential services. Bush held a morning session at the White House with GOP lawmakers. Rep. Bill Archer, R-Texas, emerging from the meeting, suggested Bush had decided on a strategy of seeking a package of capital gains tax cuts combined with a modest boost in income tax rates for the wealthy. Bush had floated that very idea at a news conference Tuesday but then appeared to back away under pressure from Republican senators. Today, Archer said Bush expressed unequivocal support for the package again. But then the White House made clear that the plan touted by Archer was not the one that Bush would pursue. Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Bush recognizes that he cannot get a good deal from Congress on capital gains and income taxes. He said Bush would prefer a budget package that omits both elements. Fitzwater offered a candid explanation for the confusion of the past two days. ``One of the phenomenons of group meetings (between the president and lawmakers) is people hear what they want to hear.'' The press spokesman apologized for letting confusion reign for the past two days. ``I think we just made a mistake'' in not clearing things up. Under the plan advocated by Archer, the top income tax rate would be raised for about 500,000 of the nation's wealthiest taxpayers. The rate would be lowered for about 4.5 million who earn slightly less, he said. The tax on capital gains would be cut for all who make profits on the sale of stocks, real estate and other investments.
DOC.HEAD: Bush's new: 4th graf
Drive to End Maine's Blue Law Pits Big Retailers Against Mom-and-Pop Stores
DOC.TEXT: The mom-and-pop stores that dot this rural state are fighting a ballot measure abolishing Maine's tough blue laws, which force most big retailers to close on Sundays. While most states allow local communities the option to restrict Sunday business, Maine and North Dakota are the only two with statewide blue laws. Maine outlaws Sunday shopping at all but small retailers, but exempts sporting goods stores - most notably L.L. Bean Inc., which is open 24 hours, seven days a week. On Nov. 6, voters in Maine will decide whether to revoke the 28-year-old state blue law and grant themselves the right to shop anywhere they want seven days a week. Supporters led by Citizens for Choice on Sunday, a political action group backed by large retailers, contend the blue law restricts business competition. The Retail Federation of Maine, a coalition of large stores, began campaigning to change the law several years ago. It collected enough signatures last year to force the referendum in November. The leading opposition group, Save Our Sundays, representing mostly mom-and-pop stores, argues that abolishing the law would disrupt family life, force some parents to work on Sundays, and drive many small businesses into bankruptcy. Hugh Holmes, the owner of Maine Pride Markets in Farmingdale, says he does 25 percent of his business on Sundays. ``We're a really small grocery store and Sunday is a really big thing for us,'' Holmes said. ``When the major stores are closed, it's very important to us because we do a lot of volume.'' Craig Burgess, owner of Burgess Market in Bath, says abolishing the blue law would be ``very detrimental'' to his business. ``I think the small independent grocers are kind of a dying breed and I don't want to be part of that trend,'' Burgess said. ``The fact is our way of life is going to change,'' said Robert Reny Sr., a leading opponent and president and chief executive officer of the Maine department store chain of R.H. Reny and Co. ``It's going to be dog eat dog seven days a week.'' But Aretas Stearns, president of Porteous, Mitchell & Braun Co. department stores and a competitor of Reny's, said that ``the quality of life issue that's being raised by the opposition is a smokescreen. I think givingpeople a choice enhances their quality of life.'' Stearns and officials from other large companies contend the current law unfairly prohibits most retail stores with more than 5,000 square feet of floor space from opening on Sundays except for the period between Thanksgiving and Christmas when they may open from noon until 5 p.m. Stearns says exemptions such as the one allowing L.L. Bean to operate on Sundays illustrate the inequity of the law. ``This thing is a patchwork of self-interested restrictions that serve to keep about 12 major chains closed on Sundays and restricts consumers' ability to shop when they want to,'' Stearns says. ``It is absolutely driven by self-interest on the part of some merchants who have a monopoly on Sunday sales.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviets' Most Advanced Booster Rocket Explodes Over Launch Pad
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union's most advanced booster rocket, which an American specialist believed was carrying a spy satellite, exploded seconds after liftoff last week. The blast nearly destroyed the launch pad and may complicate Soviet efforts to sell space hardware to the West. The official Soviet news agency Tass reported for the first time Thursday that a Zenit booster ``broke up'' at the Baikonur space port in the Central Asian republic of Kazakhstan on Oct. 4. Tass said no one was hurt and that a commission is investigating the accident. The three-sentence dispatch did not identify the payload or give any other details. It also did not say why the explosion was not reported for a week. James Oberg, an American aerospace engineer and expert on the Soviet space program, said he believes the payload was a satellite the Soviet military hoped to use for electronic intelligence gathering. A spokesman for the Soviet space agency Glavkosmos told The Associated Press one of two launch pads the Zenit uses was ``nearly totally destroyed'' and that the satellite was ruined. Nikolai Semyonov, head of Glavkosmos' international department, did not say how the satellite, which he said was in the Kosmos series, was to be used. He said further Zenit launches have been put on hold. ``I don't think any new launching will be attempted until the reasons for the accident are properly analyzed and the destroyed pad is restored,'' Semyonov said in a telephone interview. He said the rocket ``exploded in the air right over the pad'' but that no one was hurt because the launch was highly automated. Vladimir Utkin, chief designer of the Yuzhnoye plant that builds Zenit, told the Red Army newspaper Red Star in August that no people are on the launch pad for Zenit blastoffs. The Soviet space program has suffered several setbacks in the past two years, including the loss of two Mars probes, malfunction of an exit hatch on the orbiting manned station Mir and equipment problems that plagued the landings of several cosmonaut crews. The program recently has been faced with spending cuts and close scrutiny by legislators trying to trim a budget deficit. Last week's explosion comes as the Soviets' biggest space competitor, the United States, tries to correct problems that have delayed launches of U.S. space shuttles and marred the performance of the Hubble space telescope. Soviet space officials have been trying to make up for spending cuts by wooing foreign customers for their launch services, and the Zenit rocket was their showcase to the West. They face stiff competition from the Americans and Europeans, who are also offering launch services and satellites. President Bush opened the way in August for a U.S. company to help build a space port in Australia to launch Zenit rockets. The Soviets want to supply $308 million worth of rockets and technology over the next 10 years for launches of American-built satellites at the new center. Oberg said the Zenit contained the Soviet Union's most advanced propulsion system and was its ``showcase rocket'' for luring foreign customers. ``They were counting on it to make some money. This is a blow to their space commercialization effort, but one that they'll probably overcome,'' Oberg said in a telephone interview from his home in Galveston county, Texas. The Soviets rarely report accidents involving military space payloads. Oberg, who has written a book on Soviet space disasters, said he believes disclosure of last week's explosion was prompted by commercial considerations. ``If it's realized they're telling the truth on it, they'll probably emerge stronger, continuing to earn the trust of customers by being straight with them,'' Oberg said. He noted that the French are continuing to sell the services of their Ariane rocket booster, and the Americans continue to peddle their Centaur and Delta rockets despite explosions. Semyonov also attempted to minimize long-range implications of the explosion. ``Of course the consequences are heavy, but we shouldn't over-dramatize it. Such accidents do happen from time to time everywhere else in the world, including in the USA, Japan and other countries,'' he said. According to Oberg, the Soviets usually claim Kosmos satellites are for ``scientific research'' but that the term is a camouflage for military use. Last week's explosion is the first of a Zenit rocket, which went into service in mid-1985 and was last launched in May. It burns a kerosene-oxygen mixture in a high-pressure engine and can carry a 12-ton payload.

DOC.HEAD: FCC Proposes Finders-Keepers Systems For Scarce Airwaves
DOC.TEXT: Federal regulators Thursday proposed a finders-keepers licensing system to encourage business radio users to ferret out underutilized or vacant channels on the nation's crowded airwaves. Those who locate such channels in the ``private land mobile radio services'' would be rewarded with a license to the channels, as long as the finders meet minimum eligibility requirements and provided that the channels could be utilized on an exclusive, rather than shared, basis, the Federal Communications Commission said. The commission also proposed to speed the reassignment of unused or underused channels in private land mobile, whose users include public safety and government agencies, doctors, hospitals, public utilities, railroads and taxicabs. It does not include cellular or broadcast radio. Taxicab companies, since they share channels, would not be affected by the finders' preference proposal. The commission, in voting 5-0 to consider the proposals, said ``private land mobile frequencies have become congested and extremely scarce in many areas, making it difficult for new applicants to obtain licenses and for existing licensees to expand their systems.'' In other action, the FCC voted 5-0 to: -Give more channels, increased power and streamlined licensing procedures to the wireless (microwave) cable TV systems that provide cable programming to apartment buildings and remote areas not served by wired cable. The wireless systems would be able to lease some unused instructional TV channels. -Define cable systems as those using only cable, wire or other physically closed or shielded transmission paths to provide service to subscribers. The definition effectively excludes wireless cable and direct broadcast satellite systems from having to obtain licenses from local authorities and could be important if and when Congress decides to reregulate cable system prices and business procedures. -Consider changing international maritime distress communications equipment from Morse code and manual operations to automated or semi-automated communications systems using satellite and digital technologies. The proposals would affect all ships over 300 gross tons moving internationally or passenger ships carrying 12 or more passengers. It would not affect fishing and recreational yachts. The finders' preference system was proposed by the business radio industry and would replace the existing system that awards unused or underused channels on a first-come, first-serve basis through private industry groups that coordinate frequency allocation. Ralph Haller, chief of the FCC's private radio bureau, said he did not think the new system would encourage ``bounty hunters'' who would try to gain licenses to unused channels and then auction them off to the highest bidder. The commission said it would ``closely monitor for any signs of abuse'' and was seeking comment on whether applicants seeking preference should first certify that they have not compensated the previous licensee. The commission also proposed to streamline private mobile licensing procedures and to cancel licenses automatically one year after such a licensee discontinues operations. Haller said some discontinued radio operations can go unnoticed for as long as five years - until license renewal time.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi-Americans to Visit Iraq in Hope of Starting Talks
DOC.TEXT: A delegation of Iraqi-Americans will leave for Baghdad on Friday for talks they hope will lead to a dialogue between the leadership of the United States and Iraq. ``The problem in the Middle East between the U.S. and Iraq is like a problem between a married couple,'' said Riadh Khadhiri, a business professor at Mississippi State University and leader of the delegation. ``Like any problem between couples, we have to talk to each other and solve one problem at a time so we can both live a long, happy life.'' Khadhiri, 57, said he and the five other Iraqi-Americans were invited by the Iraqi Foreign Ministry, but did not know if they would meet with President Saddam Hussein. While the purpose of the week-long visit is to lay groundwork for Iraq and the United States to begin communicating, Khadhiri said he hopes to pull off perhaps an even bigger coup. ``I am also hoping to bring some of the hostages back,'' he said. Khadhiri, a U.S. citizen, has been on the faculties of several U.S. universities and colleges. Before joining Mississippi State, he was involved in an import-export business with contacts in Saudi Arabia, Iraq and Turkey. As a vice president of the recently formed American Iraqi Foundation, Khadhiri was among a group of Arab-Americans who met with President Bush on Sept. 24.

DOC.HEAD: Identical Twins on Wheeling Park Homecoming Court
DOC.TEXT: Picking the Wheeling Park High School homecoming queen may take a second look. Two of the 10 candidates are identical twins. The contest is the first head-to-head battle for 17-year-old seniors Amy and Elizabeth McKinley. ``We don't care who gets it,'' Amy said. ``As a matter of fact, we don't feel like we are competing against each other.'' The winner will be named during halftime at Friday's football game with Oak Glen at Wheeling Island Stadium. The twins said they have grown to look more like each other as they near adulthood. ``We can't get away with switching places at home,'' Elizabeth said. ``We usually don't trick many people in person, but we can confuse them with our voices.'' The two tried switching classes in the fifth grade, but the trick failed when they began laughing uncontrollably. Both are interested in politics. Their father is state Delegate David B. McKinley, the state Republican Party chairman. Elizabeth wants a career in math and Amy is interested in communications, physical therapy and interior design.

DOC.HEAD: Report Warns Of Increasing Danger From Space Debris
DOC.TEXT: A congressional report warns that shuttle flights and other space activity could become too risky within the next 20-30 years if nations continue to litter the most traveled paths.
