Already, the Hubble Space Telescope - which has enough problems of its own because of faulty optics - has been given a one-in-100 chance of being severely damaged by space debris during its 17-year lifetime, said the Office of Technology Assessment. `Even small debris particles can produce high levels of damage,'' said Ray Williamson, who directed the study. ``The average collision velocity in low earth orbit is about 10 kilometers (6.2 miles) a second.'' At such speed, an object having one-thirty-fifth the weight of an aspirin tablet would have the impact of a 30-06 bullet, he said. NASA is incorporating shielding for critical elements as it designs the space station and is looking into possible collision avoidance maneuvers for the shuttle, according to the OTA report. Don Kessler, NASA's debris expert at the Johnson Space Center in Houston, said the agency is warned about once every shuttle mission by Air Force trackers that objects are in the path. About once every five missions, he said - when the object is in an approaching ``box'' a mile high, a mile wide and three miles long - NASA is advised to change course slightly. Such a maneuver has never been made, he said, because even within that box the chances of a collision are estimated at one in 100,000. In the only documented collision, a tiny paint chip damaged the windshield of space shuttle Challenger in 1983 to the extent that it had to be replaced. That chip would have punctured the pressurized suit of a spacewalking astronaut had it struck him, OTA said. As of last week, the U.S. Space Command was tracking 6,645 artificial objects orbiting Earth, each larger than a softball and weighing a total of about 4.5 million pounds. Only six percent were operating satellites; the rest was debris and some experts think there may be another 30,000 to 70,000 bits of junk too small to track. Half the debris comes from rockets that drift in orbit after boosting their spacecraft above the atmosphere. Other debris comes from satellites, particulates from solid rocket motors and paint chips that have flaked off. ``As you increase levels of space activity, unless we do something to reduce the generation of debris, it will increase,'' Williamson told a news conference. He said estimates are the junk will increase by 240 pieces a year, or more as space activities are stepped up. ``That debris can collide with both active and inactive satellites, damaging the active satellites and maybe rendering them inoperative, and producing more debris from both types,'' Williamson said. Debris also is becoming a problem at the 22,300-mile altitude where communications satellites operate. The report said international action will be needed to minimize production of new debris and to cope with that already in orbit. It suggested boosters and spacecraft could be designed not to explode or break up; batteries could be protected from explosion; and spent upper stages of rockets could be removed by reducing their altitude so atmospheric drag will bring them down. Although the OTA study doesn't mention it, nature is helping remove space debris. An increase in solar activity has resulted in the expansion of the atmosphere which, in turn, slows low-flying objects and forces them to fall to Earth - burning up in the process. Not long ago, the Space Command was tracking 7,200 objects. The Japanese and European space agencies are doing their share to reduce debris and OTA said discussions with the Soviets have proven fruitful. In the past, the Soviet Union made it a practice to fragment certain reconnaissance satellites after their useful life, presumably to prevent them from being recovered by the United States. Recently, they have exploded these satellites in low orbits so that the debris quickly enters Earth's atmosphere.

DOC.HEAD: Fundamentalist Christians Protest Female Troops in Mideast
DOC.TEXT: Two dozen fundamentalist Christians marched to protest the dispatch of female troops - especially married women with children - to the Middle East. The protesters, in town for the American Coalition of Unregistered Churches, carried signs Wednesday outside the downtown Armed Forces Recruiting Center. ``It is against nature for women to be in combat uniforms,'' one sign read. Others said: ``I would rather have men protecting me, not weaker women,'' and ``Mama needs a mop and a broom, not an M-16.'' The protest leader was the Rev. W.N. Otwell, an independent Baptist pastor from Fort Worth, Texas. He called women in the military ``a perversion of women's role.'' Otwell lost a bid for the Republican nomination for Texas governor in March. The Bible mandates that women submit to their husbands, not a military leader, Otwell said. ``How can a man be the head of his wife if Uncle Sam is telling her what to do?'' Bill Sanders, a passer-by on his lunch hour, told Otwell his stand was ``bigotry and uncalled for.''

DOC.HEAD: Earthquake Hits the Dominican Republic, No Injuries Reported
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake downed telephone poles and sent people fleeing into the streets Thursday, but there were no reports of injuries or serious damage. The tremor, with magnitude of 5.2 on the Richter scale, struck about 40 miles northeast of the capital, Santo Domingo, at about 11:15 a.m. EDT, according to the U.S. Geological Survey in Washington. Dominican Civil Defense officials said telephone poles were downed in the southeastern province of San Pedro de Macoris, but there were no other reports of damage. In the capital, office workers rushed from buildings. Officials said the the quake was felt throughout the Dominican Republic and in parts of Puerto Rico, about 100 miles to the east. A quake of a magnitude between 5 and 6 on the scale can cause considerable damage. The Richter scale measures the strength of a quake based on ground motion and each increase of one number indicates 10 times more force.

DOC.HEAD: Eight More Suicides in Student Protests Over Job Policy
DOC.TEXT: Eight more students, one of them 13 years old, killed themselves Thursday to protest a government plan to reserve jobs for low-caste Hinuds, news reports said. The deaths raised to at least 56 the number of students who have committed suicide in the last month to force Prime Minister V.P. Singh to withdraw the job quota policy. More than 50 more people have been killed by police trying to quell the unrest that engulfed northern India, where the caste system is strongest. One student, Sanjeev Kumar, hanged himself in his home, setting off widespread riots and sabotage in Jalandhar in northern Punjab state. Police imposed a curfew on Jalandhar, 210 miles north of New Delhi, the agencies reported. Thirteen-year-old Ajay Kumar, who had doused his body with kerosine and set himself alight, died in the hospital in Chandighar in Uttar Pradesh state, the reports said. The wave of suicides and protests continued unabated despite an Oct. 1 Supreme Court injunction ordering the government to take no further action on the plan until the court decides its legality later this year. Singh announced in August he was adopting a 10-year-old commission report and reserving 27 percent of government jobs for low-caste Hindus. Another 22.5 percent previously were set aside for the lowest strata in the religious hierarchy, the outcasts and tribal communities. Upper caste students say they will lose out on prized jobs to less qualified candidates.

DOC.HEAD: Bush To Visit Mexico, South America
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will make state visits to Mexico next month and to five South American countries in December, the White House announced Thursday. Bush will visit Monterrey, Mexico, on Nov. 26-27 at the invitation of Mexican President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. Bush will also travel to Brazil, Uruguay, Argentina, Chile and Venezuela on Dec. 2-8 on his second trip to South America as president. The president will also meet in Honolulu on Oct. 27 with leaders of 13 Pacific island states of Micronesia, Melanesia and Polynesia. The meeting in Hawaii with the Pacific island leaders will take place during a five-day political campaign swing that will also take Bush to New Mexico, Arizona, California and Oklahoma. The five-nation South American trip originally had been planned for mid-September, but was postponed due to the Persian Gulf crisis and domestic budget problems. Bush went to Colombia for a one-day drug summit with Latin leaders last Feb. 15. Bush also has rescheduled a New England campaign trip postponed from earlier this month to Oct. 23, when he will travel to Burlington, Vt., Manchester, N.H., Waterbury, Conn., and Stamford, Conn. for various Republican candidates. On Oct. 25 he will fly to Albuquerque, N.M., then to Phoenix and Irvine, Calif., for other GOP candidates. He will spend that night in Irvine and attend events on Oct. 26 in Irvine, Los Angeles and Honolulu. Bush and the Pacific island leaders will discuss global and regional issues at the Oct. 27 meeting, Fitzwater said. The White House said the following leaders have been invited to the Honolulu summit: Prime Minister Geoffrey A. Henry, Cook Islands; Prime Minister Ratu Sir Kamisese Mara, Fiji; President Ieremia T. Tabai, Kiribati; President Amata Kabua, Republic of the Marshall Islands; President John R. Haglelgam, Federated States of Micronesia; President Bernard Dowiyogo, Nauru; Premier Sir Robert Rex, Niue; Prime Minister Rabbie Namaliu, Papua New Guinea; Prime Minister Solomon Mamaloni, Solomon Islands; King Taufa'ahau Tupou IV, Tonga; Prime Minister Bikenibeu Paeniu, Tuvalu; Prime Minister Walter Hayde Lini, Vanuatu, and Prime Minister Tofilau Eti Alesana, Western Samoa. Bush will fly to San Francisco on Oct. 28 and will attend GOP events in San Francisco and Oklahoma City on Oct. 29 before returning to Washington. The White House has said Bush also plans to spend several more days campaigning before the Nov. 6 elections.

DOC.HEAD: Mexican Writer Octavio Paz Wins Nobel Prize in Literature
LaserPhoto MAD5, NY30
DOC.TEXT: Octavio Paz, who explored the Mexican character and the universal themes of love, death and loneliness in lyrical poetry and impassioned essays, won the Nobel Prize in literature Thursday. The Swedish Academy awarded Paz the prize for his ``exquisite love poetry, at the same time sensuous and visual,'' and for his wide international perspective. It also cited Paz for his essays on Mexican society, calling him ``a lodestar in the tide of opinion.'' Paz's views have angered the left and the right in his homeland, and he was dumped by leftists who felt he turned on their cause. Paz, 76, said he was ``very, very surprised'' at being selected. ``Poetry is not a very popular art form these days, but it's an essential part of human life,'' Paz said in New York, where he is inaugurating a Mexican art exhibit at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. ``Poetry is the memory of a country, of language.'' ``The prize is a sign that the Spanish and Latin American literature is in good health,'' he added. Paz is the fifth Nobel laureate from Latin America. The last previous was Gabriel Garcia Marquez of Colombia, in 1982. ``It's also a great triumph for the glorious Spanish language,'' said 1989 laureate Camilo Jose Cela of Spain. Cela spoke in Madrid. Peruvian writer Mario Vargas Llosa, one of Latin America's leading authors, said in Washington, ``Octavio is one of the greatest poets that the Spanish-language world has produced and, at the same time, a great humanist.'' But Swedish Academy spokesman Sture Allen said the prize was meant to honor writers, not a language. The academy pointedly praised Paz's ``wide international perspective,'' gained during a 25-year diplomatic career. ``Paz's poetry and essays evolve from an intractable but fruitful union of cultures, pre-Columbian Indian, the Spanish Conquistadors, and Western modernism,'' the academy said. The academy said one of the high points of his work was the 1957 poem ``Sun Stone,'' which was inspired by a huge Aztec calendar stone. ``This suggestive work with its many layers of meaning seems to incorporate, interpet and reconstrue major existential questions, death, time, love and reality,'' the academy said. In a Swedish radio interview, Paz recommended his essay, ``The Labyrinth of Solitude,'' and his poetry, to those who have not read his work. The academy said Paz's ``own identity, Mexican and, in its broader meaning, Latin American, has been explored decisively'' in ``Labyrinth.'' The essay deeply affected how Mexican society was viewed at home and abroad, and was denounced by the left and the right. The academy said Paz himself embodies a ``union of cultures - it is in his blood. His mother's family was Spanish, from Andalusia. On his father's side the Indian and the Spanish are combined.'' He was born March 31, 1914, and, thanks to his grandfather's extensive library, Paz developed a love for literature at an early age. He earned a law degree and entered the diplomatic service. But he resigned as ambassador to India in 1968 and ended his diplomatic career when the Mexican army fired on anti-government student protesters, killing at least 300. He considers himself a socialist and a democrat, but has been ostracized for criticizing the left. ``I think that if there is one profoundly reactionary sector in Latin America, it is the leftist intellectual,'' he said in an interview in 1979. ``They are people without memory. I have never heard any one of them admit he made a mistake.'' Paz has many times criticized Mexico's governing party for six decades, the Institutional Revolutionary Party. But Mexican President Carlos Salinas de Gortari said Thursday, ``He is a poet and writer of whom we Mexicans feel proud. He has a universal stature.'' The academy said Paz's open-mindedness allowed him to remain a strong influence on contemporary literature. He still publishes the journal ``Vuelta,'' or ``Return,'' which he founded in 1976. He received an honorary doctorate in 1980 from Harvard University, where he lectures. Paz won the most important award in the Spanish-speaking world, the Cervantes prize, in 1981, and the American Neustadt Prize in 1982. Paz's Swedish publisher, Adam Bromberg, said the author had been on the academy's ``short list'' of top literature candidates for 15 years. Others said to be in the running included Chinese poet Bei Dao, Irish poet Seamus Heaney, American novelist Joyce Carol Oates, Brazilian novelist Jorge Amado, novelist Margaret Atwood of Canada, South African author Nadine Gordimer and Japanese novelist Masuji Ibuse. The prize, worth about $700,000, is one of five awarded in October under terms of the will of Alfred Nobel, the Swedish inventor of dynamite, who died in 1896. Two American doctors who pioneered human organ, cell and bone marrow transplants, Joseph E. Murray, 71, and E. Donnall Thomas, 70, won the Nobel Prize in medicine Monday. The Nobel Peace Prize will be awarded next Monday in Oslo, Norway. The Nobel Prizes in chemistry and physics will be awarded in Stockholm on Oct. 17. The Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science, established by the Central Bank of Sweden in 1969, will be awarded Oct. 16.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A 6 p.m. EDT embargo for first item has been broken
DOC.TEXT: Teen-age actress Kellie Martin, of the ABC series ``Life Goes On,'' says playing opposite an actor who has Down's syndrome has ``opened my mind and made me a better person.'' The 14-year-old Martin, who portrays Becca in the weekly series, told Parade magazine for this Sunday's issue that before she met actor Christopher Burke she was uncomfortable around disabled people. ``When I first knew that there was going to be a boy playing Corky who really had Down's syndrome, I was very afraid. I was thinking, `Gosh, I wish they had an actor playing him. This is going to be very hard. ``But once you've gotten to know someone like Chris, who is such a normal person and so great, everything changes.'' Because of her relationship with Burke, she said, ``I've gotten to the point where I would go up and talk to someone else who was `different.' I've gotten to understand that you can be friends with someone who is like this. ``The past year has just opened my mind and made me a better person.'' --- CHICAGO (AP) - Sophia Loren will receive a lifetime achievement award Friday at the Chicago International Film Festival just in time for the world premiere of her movie, ``Saturday, Sunday and Monday.'' Miss Loren estimated she has made about 100 pictures in her native Italy and in the United States since her debut 39 years ago as a teen-age extra playing a slave in ``Quo Vadis.'' Her other works include ``Two Women,'' ``Marriage Italian Style'' and ``The Cassandra Crossing.'' Not every film makes her proud, but she said she has no regrets. ``You believe in the project, you believe in the story, you believe in the director, and it's always done in very good faith. ... Each, for me, was a wonderful experience,'' she said. Her newest film, set in 1930s Naples, is about a simple woman whose philosophy of life revolves around her cooking. Speaking from her home outside Los Angeles, the 56-year-old actress said she never thinks about age. ``For me, aging is not a problem. It's something that comes very naturally. It's what you can accomplish in life that really counts,'' she said. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Kurt Masur will raise his baton for the New York Philharmonic ahead of schedule when he steps in for ailing maestro Leonard Bernstein in December. Masur was named music director of the Philharmonic last April and will take over next fall. He will appear for Bernstein on Dec. 18, 20, 21 and 22 in Philharmonic performances of Mendelssohn's ``Elijah.'' On Tuesday, Bernstein, laureate conductor of the orchestra, announced his retirement from conducting for health reasons. To make the New York dates, Masur postponed recording sessions with his present orchestra, the Gewandhaus of Leipzig and rearranged a commitment with the Bavarian Radio Symphony. --- ROCHESTER, N.Y. (AP) - Maurice Sendak has devoted his talents to entertaining youngsters. But parents, too, are often entertained by the children's book author and illustrator. On Friday, Sendak, who has written and illustrated 20 books and illustrated more than 60, will get something back: the first Empire State Award for Excellence in Literature for Young People. Presenting the award will be the Youth Services Section of The New York Library Association. ``I've had a mad love affair with a form called the picture book,'' he said. ``It is language and pictures working together. It is about making it so tight and making it your own. In order to do that you have to write, write, pare down, pare down.'' Sendak, 62, shrugs off criticism that his books can be frightening. ``I've always done what I wanted to do,'' he said. ``You see, there were no ground rules when I started in the 1950s. We just made it up. Children's art, children's books, children were less important then.'' --- KNOXVILLE, Tenn. (AP) - In the world designed by Italian opera star Luciano Pavarotti there are no smoky rooms or steps to climb off stage. The decor is in jewel tones and there is a king-size bed, a large television screen, a videocassette recorder and Italian movie tapes. Those are among the particulars the famously particular tenor made with his reservations at The Blakely Hotel, where he will stay while here for a peformance Sunday. That's not all his musical heart desires. Pavarotti also wants humidifiers in his room to keep his voice clear, large chairs with footstools in his dressing room - and at a dinner in his honor, and an electric golf cart to take him from the plane to the limousine and his dressing room. Pavarotti chose The Blakely from photographs his secretary made last summer.

DOC.HEAD: Excerpts of Poems by Paz
With AM-Nobel Literature, Bjt
DOC.TEXT:
The following are excerpts from the poem ``Sun Stone'' by Octavio Paz, who won the Nobel Prize for literature on Thursday. It is followed by a short poem in its entirety, ``With Eyes Closed.'' The poems are included in ``Selected Poems,'' published by New Directions Books in 1984. --- ``Sun Stone''
willow of crystal, a poplar of water, a pillar of fountain by the wind drawn over, tree that is firmly rooted and that dances, turning course of a river that goes curving, advances and retreats, goes roundabout, arriving forever: the calm course of a star or the spring, appearing without urgency, water behind a stillness of closed eyelids flowing all night and pouring out prophecies, a single presence in the procession of waves, wave over wave until all is overlapped, in a green sovereignty without decline a bright hallucination of many wings when they all open at the height of the sky ... the sun has forced an entrance through my forehead, has opened my eyelids at last that were kept closed, unfastened my being of its swaddling clothes, has rooted me out of my self, and separated me from my animal sleep centuries of stone and the magic of reflections resurrects willow of crystal, a poplar of water, a pillar of fountain by the wind drawn over, tree that is firmly rooted and that dances, turning course of a river that goes curving, advances and retreats, goes roundabout, arriving forever:
---
``With Eyes Closed''
With eyes closed you light up within you are blind stone
Night after night I carve you with eyes closed you are frank stone
We have become enormous just knowing each other with eyes closed

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Army Patrol Exchanges Fire Across Jordanian Border
With AM-Israel, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: An Israeli army patrol on Thursday was shot at from across the Jordanian border and returned fire, the army said. There were no reports of injuries. The soldiers were riding in a jeep along the border fence near the town of Ashdod Yaacov, about six miles south of the Sea of Galilee, when they heard shots, said an army official on condition of anonymity. ``The patrol returned fire, and then searched the area, but nothing was found,'' the official said. ``It looks like the Jordanians also conducted searches.'' Israel and Jordan, although officially in a state of war, have a tacit agreement to keep their joint border quiet. Jordan tries to block guerrilla infiltration attempts into Israel, and earlier this year returned unharmed two Israeli teen-agers who sneaked across the frontier as part of a dare. Earlier in the year, however, there were several incidents of Jordanian soldiers crossing the border and firing on Israeli patrols.

DOC.HEAD: Consumer Group: Nuclear Plant Shutdowns May Force Taxpayer Bailout
DOC.TEXT: A private consumer group charged Thursday that electric utilities are underestimating the cost of shutting down nuclear power plants and could force taxpayers into another multi-billion bailout in the years to come. The charge immediately was denounced by the electric utility industry, whose spokesmen said adequate funds for the shutdown - or decommissioning - of atomic power plants are being established under the scrutiny of both the Nuclear Regulatory Commission and state regulators. But a report by Public Citizen, a Washington-based consumer and environmental group, alleged that industry estimates of how much it will cost to close plants is far too low and that federal and state officials have been lax in requiring adequate shutdown funds. ``We could find ourselves in a situation of having another massive bailout,'' said Joan Claybrook, president of Public Citizen. ``Tomorrow's electric users are going to pay.'' Under federal regulations, atomic power plants are considered to have a life expectancy of 30 years after which many of them likely will have to be closed and decontaminated. There has never been a ``decommissioning'' of a major operating atomic power plant because none is that old. The nuclear industry as well as utilities and environmentalists agree that there are many uncertainties in trying to determine how much such shutdowns will cost. The report by Public Citizen said that industry estimates of $25.6 billion for shutting and decontaminating 124 plants is based on too many optimistic assumptions and that the total more likely will be between $50 billion and $100 billion. ``For some reactors, the cost to decommission the plants will rival their initial construction costs'' Ms. Claybrook said at a news conference. But industry spokesmen disavowed even the $25.6 billion figure, much less the $100 billion estimate suggested by Public Citizen as an upper range. ``I've never heard of this (figure). I don't know where they got this,'' said Ronald Clements of the Edison Electric Institute. He said that by law, utilities must establish segregated trust funds for the eventual shutdown of atomic power plants. But actual estimates of shutdown costs can only be made incrementally as plants become older, he said. ``You don't want to overcollect funds in the first years (of a plant's operation).'' But Daniel Borson, author of the Public Citizen report, said a detailed analysis of industry and government documents as well as interviews with utility executives indicates that the industry is not adequately preparing for what the eventual shutdown costs will be. Utility cost estimates often underestimate what it will cost to dispose of highly radioactive spent fuel and radioactive wastes as well as the decontamination of plants, Borson said. While many nuclear plants have exceeded a third of their expected operating lives, so far only about $3.5 billion has been allocated for shutdown activities and some of those funds could be threatened if a utility faces serious financial problems in the future. Clements, the industry official, disagreed. He said that new NRC rules now being phased in will require that all cleanup funds be in separate accounts independent of a utility's other corporate funds. The Council for Energy Awareness, an umbrella group representing the views of the atomic power industry, criticized the Public Citizen report, saying the consumer group ``lacks the comprehensive financial and technical knowledge needed to produce valid (cost) estimates.''

DOC.HEAD: Ulysses Fires Thrusters; Discovery in `Excellent Condition'
DOC.TEXT: Ulysses started firing its thrusters Thursday to point its main antenna toward Earth, and the shuttle that launched the probe was in fine shape after a 1.7-million-mile flight, NASA said. The space agency, meanwhile, formed a team to investigate why the shuttle Discovery lifted off Saturday with incorrect instructions for how it should operate some of its computer programs, said shuttle project engineer Chris Fairey. Discovery landed early Wednesday after sending Ulysses on a five-year, 1.86-billion-mile journey to study the sun's poles. ``The vehicle is in excellent condition,'' said shuttle processing manager Tip Talone. He said only 10 to 15 of Discovery's heat-shield tiles need to be replaced. Debris that hit the shuttle during its launch and landing caused 13 ``dings'' larger than one inch, and about 50 saller ones. ``That's a very low number,'' Talone said. ``Every time we come back, we seem to learn more about how to fly and land the thing without taking a lot of hits.'' Ulysses' maneuvering, which will end Friday, was designed to let the spacecraft communicate with controllers more quickly by using its high-gain antenna, a 5.4-foot-wide dish, said Franklin O'Donnell, a spokesman for NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. ``Ulysses began firing its thrusters to start a complex series of maneuvers to turn itself around nearly 180 degrees to point the big dish toward Earth,'' O'Donnell said by phone from the Pasadena laboratory. The solar explorer has been communicating with its controllers through one of its smaller antennas, limiting the rate at which information is transmitted, he added. The $250 million Ulysses spacecraft is the centerpiece of a $750 million joint mission by the European Space Agency and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Six hours after Discovery was launched Saturday from Cape Canaveral, Fla., Ulysses was deployed from the shuttle's cargo bay. Then three rocket stages hurled it out of Earth orbit at a record escape speed of about 34,000 mph. Ulysses was 3.68 million miles from Earth on Thursday, zipping toward a 1992 flight past Jupiter at 25,372 mph, O'Donnell said. It will use Jupiter as a ``gravity slingshot'' to become the first spacecraft to fly perpendicular to the plane in which the planets orbit the sun. That will allow Ulysses to fly over the sun's south pole in 1994 and north pole in 1995. However, it will never get closer to the sun that it was when it was launched. To study the sun's poles, Ulysses doesn't need to get close to the sun, only leave the plane of the planets. Fairey said the incorrect instructions were loaded into one of Discovery's computers last Thursday after that computer was used to update some of the programs on Ulysses, which was sitting inside the shuttle's cargo bay at the time. The investigators will recommend steps to prevent such an error from happening again, he added. The incorrect instructions were noticed and fixed by Discovery's five astronauts about an hour after the shuttle was launched and never posed a danger to the shuttle or its crew - even if the error hadn't been detected, said Milt Heflin, lead flight director at Johnson Space Center in Houston. Heflin had said NASA considered the problem serious because it went undetected before Discovery was launched. Fairey called it ``really minor,'' but said it ``did point out a minor deficiency in the way we code our software.'' The incorrect instructions were among those that tell each of Discovery's five computers which onboard devices they should operate during the shuttle's flight. Talone said shuttle maintenance was proceeding smoothly, so Discovery should be ready for a one-day flight back to Cape Canaveral on Monday, riding piggyback on a modified jumbo jetliner. Discovery's new carbon brakes, which have been tested on only one previous flight, are in such great shape that ``you could fly those brakes today as they are,'' he said. Nevertheless, they were removed and sent to B.F. Goodrich, the manufacturer in Ohio, for detailed analysis. O'Donnell said Ulysses will fire its thrusters again Monday and Tuesday to adjust its trajectory toward Jupiter.

DOC.HEAD: Iran's Abadan Oil Refinery to Resume Full Operations
DOC.TEXT: Iran's Abadan oil refinery, once the largest in the world but crippled in the eight-year war with Iraq, will resume full operations in about six months, Tehran radio reported Thursday. The refinery's capacity will rise to 300,000 barrels a day, more than twice the current production, the radio quoted Oil Minister Gholamreza Aqazadeh as saying. The refinery, which was repeatedly bombed by Iraqi planes in the 1980-88 gulf war, started partial operation in April 1989. An army of engineers and technicians have been working on the complex around the clock since the August 1988 cease-fire. Oil exports account for more than 90 percent of Iran's hard currency earnings. The broadcast, monitored in Nicosia, quoted Aqazadeh as saying there were plans to link the refinery to a pipeline, and transport its products nationwide. Iran, the third-largest oil exporter within the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, has benefitted from high oil prices brought on by the Persian Gulf crisis, which was triggered by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The halt in Kuwaiti production, and a United Nations-imposed embargo on Iraqi oil, cut 4 million barrels a day from international markets, boosting prices to a record $41 a barrel.

DOC.HEAD: Stomach Disorders in India Kill 100
DOC.TEXT: Water-born stomach diseases have killed 100 people in three weeks in eastern India, where floods have inundated thousands of villages, officials said Thursday. Another 16 people were reported killed in landslides or by drowning from the weeklong torrent in the far east states of Assam and Meghalaya, Press Trust of India reported. Roads were submerged and cut off in both states, it said. Gastroenteritis from affected water supplies spread through four districts of West Bengal, the agency quoted health officials as saying.

DOC.HEAD: Computer Virus Infects Governor's Speech
DOC.TEXT: A computer virus named ``Stoned'' made its way into copies of the governor's speech on the future of the British colony, adding a little spice to the dour commentary. Copies of the speech delivered to newspapers in the colony on computer floppy disks contained the virus, a government spokesman said hursday. The virus, which attaches itself to the internal memory of personal computers, freezes the keyboard at a prescribed time and flashes the message: ``Your PC is now stoned. Legalize marijuana.'' Sir David Wilson gave his speech Wednesday, reading from a prepared text. In the speech, he painted a somber picture of Hong Kong's future, warning of belt-tightening and rising inflation. The spokesman said technical personnel will investigate where the virus originated. A computer virus is a type of program designed as a high-tech practical joke. Some simply flash harmless messages on a computer screen while others can destroy information files contained throughout large computer networks. The ``Stoned'' virus is considered relatively harmless.

DOC.HEAD: New Transportation Department Spokeswoman Appointed
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Friday said he will name Marion Clifton Blakey as spokeswoman for the Transportation Department, succeeding David Prosperi. Blakey, whose title would be assistant secretary of Transportation for public affairs, is public affairs director for the Commerce Department. She previously served as a deputy assistant to President Bush in the White House public affairs and communications department.

DOC.HEAD: `Little People' Toys Called a Choking Threat
DOC.TEXT: The Consumer Product Safety Commission should change its standards to prevent children from choking on the popular ``Little People'' toys, the New York state attorney general said Thursday. Attorney General Robert Abrams sent a letter to the commission Thursday, asking it to alert parents to potential choking hazards of Little People and increase the size of its small-parts standard for toys. Carol Blackley, a spokeswoman for Fisher-Price toys, which makes Little People, said she was puzzled that Abrams had singled out the line of miniature figures. She called the toys ``among the safest things you'll find in a child's environment.'' In response to pressure from Abrams, Fisher-Price agreed in June to toughen the language of safety warnings on Little People packages, Blackley said. The Chicago-based company, a division of Quaker Oats Co., also paid New York state $25,000. In his letter to the commission, Abrams cited the recent deaths of two 6-month-old boys who choked on Little People. But Blackley noted that the Little People package clearly states the toys are intended for children aged 2 to 6. In the 30 years Fisher-Price has been making Little People, five children have choked to death on the figures, she said. All but one of those children were below the recommended age range, she said. David Thome, a spokesman for CPSC, said a commission study found that between 1980 and 1989, 146 children died after choking on toys. Of those, 70 percent were caused by balloons, marbles or small balls. However, he said, the CPSC staff is still concerned about the potential danger posed by what he called ``small human'' toys and is looking at alternatives.

DOC.HEAD: Emigre Sued by Fellow Ethiopian Claiming Police Torture
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 12th graf, `Ms. Abebe-Jira, ...' to include hometown; Note contents of 4th graf
DOC.TEXT: Kelbessa Negewo said he was just a ``simple man'' trying to raise his children, pursue a hotel management degree and forget being tortured in an Ethiopian prison when the past came back to haunt him. Another expatriate is suing him for $25 million, alleging he was the police official who tortured her in interrogation in December 1978 and January 1979 during the ``Red Terror,'' a period of government intimidation in Ethiopia. The suit claims that during one eight-hour interrogation in January 1979, Negewo and several others tied up Hirute Abebe-Jira and whipped her with wire. ``A stocking soaked with blood and vomit was stuffed in her mouth,'' the suit said. ``She was told she would be killed )f she did not reveal the location of a certain gun, about which she knew nothing. ``He (Negewo) directed his subordinates who participated in the interrogation and torture and he personally interrogated and tortured Abebe-Jira.'' Negewo, who now works in an Atlanta hotel, denies having anything to do with that. ``She doesn't know me, I don't know her,'' he said in halting English. ``I was a civil servant all my life. I was never in the police.'' Although Negewo refuses to answer many questions about his past, he said he can prove that he spent the months mentioned in the lawsuit attending school in Europe and in prison. He says he also was tortured by agents of Soviet-backed President Mengistu Haile Mariam in the period of government violence known as the Red Terror. The lawsuit alleges that Negewo was chairman of the Higher Zone 9, a police jurisdiction in the capital Addis Ababa. Ethiopian diplomatic sources said a Kelbessa Negewo was chairman of Higher Zone 9 during the Red Terror. The sources could not, however, say whether that man was in Addis Ababa at the time Ms. Abebe-Jira said she was imprisoned and tortured. Ms. Abebe-Jira has declined to be interviewed, according to her attorneys, but her lawsuit said she was imprisoned when she was an 18-year-old clerk-accountant for a business. Ms. Abebe-Jira, now living in Gloucester, Ontario, filed the lawsuit under the Alien Tort Claims Act, which allows aliens to seek relief for human rights violations in other countries. She said she learned of Negewo's whereabouts in May after a friend spotted him working at the Colony Square Hotel in Atlanta. Last week, Negewo filed a petition pleading indigency and asking for a court-appointed attorney. The suit is pending until a judge decides the petition, said Laurel Lucey, one of the attorneys handling the case for the Center for Constitutional Rights. An attorney is not required for civil cases. Negewo said he also has applied for help from the American Civil Liberties Union in case his petition is denied. Negewo said he left Ethiopia for Bulgaria on June 2, 1978, to attend a political institution called the Party School. He returned to Ethiopia on March 9, 1979, ``and when I reached the international airport at Addis Ababa they took me to jail directly,'' Negewo said. ``They said I was talking to Russians in Bulgaria,'' he said. ``They hit my legs, my soles, and I was in a dark house, dark jail for two months.'' Negewo wouldn't say why he was imprisoned by the Soviet-backed government for talking to Russians. Negewo said he was imprisoned until 1983. He said he then worked for several months for an organization calle Irish Aid to Ethiopia and then for a cement company. In August 1987, he came to Atlanta and attended classes for one semester at Morris Brown College. He said he then transferred his records to Georgia State University, and plans to start classes there when he earns enough money. He is supporting his three children, ages 15, 13 and 11. Negewo won't discuss his social or family life, except to say he is not married. Negewo said he has tried to bury thoughts of the past and never thought the Red Terror would haunt him again. ``I'm just a simple man all my life,'' he said. ``I don't have any money. I can't feed my children. I applied for a lawyer. What can I do then? I don't have any position.''

DOC.HEAD: Congress Moving To Protect Conservation Payments From Budget Cuts
With AM-Budget-Taxes, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Congress is moving to ensure that farmers won't have to worry that future disputes over the federal budget will jeopardize their monthly government checks for idled erodible land. Representatives of the House and the Senate have agreed to exclude the Conservation Reserve Program from any automatic spendingcuts that might take place over the next four years, congressional aides said Thursday. The program pays farmers to take environmentally sensitive acreage out of production for 10 years. The exemption was proposed by the House in its version of the 1990 farm bill. The Senate negotiators agreed late last week to the position, said Joe Duggan, a spokesman for the House Agriculture Committee. The presidential Office of Management and Budget had angered some farmers and lawmakers by insisting that CRP payments be subject to any across-the-board cuts made under the Gramm-Rudman deficit-reduction law. Those cuts are supposed to kick in if Congress doesn't take action on its own to shrink the budget deficit. Had the cuts taken effect this year, CRP payments could have been cut by 32 percent. ``This action by the conferees settles this issue once and for all,'' said Sen. Tom Daschle, D-S.D. ``OMB will no longer be able to hold CRP payments hostage to the fate of future budget negotiations.'' Daschle; Rep. Tim Johnson, D-S.D.;; and the North Dakota congressional delegation had written the farm-bill conferees urging them to agree to the exemption. The Agriculture Department paid farmers about $1 billion over the last year on 334,000 CRP contracts, according to the House committee. About $1.3 billion has been tentatively budgeted for the program for the fiscal year that began Oct. 1. The recent budget agreement that stopped the Gramm-Rudman cuts from taking effect will require the farm bill negotiators to reduce agricultural spending by $1 billion this year and $13.5 billion over the next five years. However, CRP payments will not be subject to any of that reduction, congressional aides said. All of the proposed cut must come out of Commodity Credit Corp. benefits.

DOC.HEAD: 40 Percent of Romania's Ethnic Germans Have Registered to Emigrate
DOC.TEXT: About 40 percent of Romania's ethnic Germans have registered to leave the country since dictator Nicolae Ceausescu fell last December, according to figures released Thursday. The Interior Ministry, in a statement carried by the state news agency Rompres, said 92,650 of Romania's ethnic Germans, estimated to be 220,000 at the time of the revolution, already had passports to leave the country. About 70,000 of them already have left, the ministry said. The ethnic Germans are among 120,603 people who have applied to leave since Ceausescu's ouster, the statement said. Independent sources say the real figure is much higher. Since the elimination of travel restrictions after the revolution, more than 10 million Romanians out of a population of 23 million have gone abroad as tourists. Diplomatic sources say millions would like to remain outside Romania. But because Romanians no longer qualify for the refugee status they had when the country was a dictatorship, Western countries have rejected most would-be emigres. The notable exception is Germany, which has accepted almost 100,000 immigrants, the overwhelming majority ethnic Germans. Another 10,000 Romanian citizens, mainly members of the 2-million-strong ethnic Hungarian community, have headed for Hungary, officials said. Florin Albulescu of German Forum, an organization for the ethnic minority, said most ethnic Germans leave because of poor standards of living in Romania and ``the temptation of the miraculous German economy.'' The country's ethnic Germans were once estimated at 500,000. But many left following a 1978 agreement between Bucharest and Bonn that allowed Germans to pay their way out of Romania for up to $8,000 each, said German Forum President Thomas Nagler.

DOC.HEAD: Orange Harvest Up Sharply, Agriculture Department Says
DOC.TEXT: The Agriculture Department said Thursday its initial forecast of the 1990-91 season indicates an orange harvest of 231 million boxes, up 24 percent from last season's freeze-damage yield. The Florida crop was estimated at 165 million boxes against 110.2 million in 1989-90. California production, forecast at 64 million boxes, is down 12 percent from last season. Arizona's crop, at 1.75 million boxes, would be up 11 percent from 1989-90. But the USDA said due to the severe freeze of last December, the Texas orange crop ``is virtually eliminated'' in 1990-91 and will not be forecast this season unless sufficient commercial supplies become available.

DOC.HEAD: Catholic School Pledge: `Liberty and Justice for the Unborn'
DOC.TEXT: A Roman Catholic school revised the Pledge of Allegiance to say ``with liberty and justice for the born and unborn,'' angering some students who said the issue has no place in a patriotic oath. ``It's like changing the Constitution,'' Angela Martinez, a Lorain Catholic High School junior, said Thursday. Robert Garcia, a senior, also said the change, which began this week, was a bad idea. ``I feel the `born and unborn' shouldn't be added. The pledge is a pledge to your country. ... The pledge deals with patriotism,'' he said. This week has been designated by U.S. Catholic schools as ``respect for life'' week, said Robert Kealey, executive director for the Washington, D.C.-based National Catholic Education Association. Students are being urged to reflect on the issues of abortion, euthanasia, the homeless and poverty. Kealey, whose association represents most Catholic secondary and elementary schools in the country, said he had not heard of any other school altering the Pledge of Allegiance. Jerry Lackamp, director of communications for the Cleveland Catholic Diocese, said references to the unborn in the pledge is not policy for Catholic schools in northeast Ohio. Principal Joanne Miller was said to be in a faculty meeting on Thursday and not available to comment. Reporters trying to interview students were told to leave school grounds. In an interview published Thursday with The (Lorain) Journal, Ms. Miller defended the change as appropriate. ``We are a Catholic school and therefore our philosophy is one of pro-life,'' she said. ``(The pledge change) was suggested to us. It does not go against our philosophy. ``I did not realize there was a difficulty with this until (Tuesday) morning. I was wondering if the students concerned would come talk with me. They have not,'' she said. The Chronicle Telegram in nearby Elyria reported Thursday the phrase was added at the request of the Knights of Columbus, a Catholic fraternal organization. Tom Laubenthal, a trustee with the Elyria K of C Council, said the organization regularly uses the phrase at its meetings ``just because of our stance on abortion.'' Some of the 400 students who attend the school in this Lake Erie port city about 35 miles west of Cleveland said they were not required to recite the added phrase. But several said they felt pressure to do so. ``A lot of students, when they say the pledge, say `justice for all' and then sit down, and you just hear the rest over the P.A. system,'' said Marcie Apont, an eighth-grader. Some students in the working class neighborhood had threatened to boycott classes Thursday morning to protest the pledge change. But students questioned after school said they had not skipped classes and did not know if others had. Senior Meghan Chapple said she supported the change. ``I believe it's OK for Catholic schools to do it, because that's our beliefs,'' she said. ``It has the same emphasis and values behind it that our prayers do. ... They're at a Catholic school and should be expected to (uphold) the Catholic values.''

DOC.HEAD: Tax Plan Would Hit Wealthiest, But Still Give Them $9,000 Tax Cuts
With AM-Budget-Taxes, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The wealthiest people in America would face higher tax rates but still collect tax cuts averaging more than $9,000 a year under a plan endorsed Thursday by President Bush. The plan, advanced by conservative Republicans in the House, would exclude more than half of capital gains from taxation and raise the 28 percent maximum income tax rate on the richest people to 31 percent. It would reduce the top rate affecting some upper-middle-income people from 33 percent to 31 percent. The Congressional Budget Office estimated people with incomes of $200,000 or more would realize tax cuts averaging $9,097 a year. That would represent a 6.2 percent reduction in their federal tax liabilities. Those with incomes between $100,000 and $200,000 would get a 4.4 percent tax cut, averaging $1,541 a year. Families with income between $40,000 and $50,000 would see tax cuts averaging $54, or 0.5 percent. Families with incomes under $10,000 would get nothing on average from the proposal, CBO said. Those making between $20,000 and $30,000 would get a $14 tax cut, an average reduction of 0.3 percent. The Republican proposal, which was rejected by Democratic negotiators last month, would reduce from 33 percent to 31 percent the marginal tax rate on couples with taxable income between $78,400 and $162,770 and single people between $47,050 and $97,620. The marginal rate applies to any additional income earned. Taxable income is after deductions and exemptions have been subtracted. In reducing the 33 percent rate, the GOP proposal also would eliminate a quirk in the law that allows people with the highest incomes to pay a 28 percent marginal rate while some upper-middle-income people pay a 33 percent rate. The bill, sponsored chiefly by Reps. John Kasich of Ohio and Carl Pursell of Michigan, would exempt from taxation 51.6 percent of long-term capital gains, which are profits from the sale of investments held a year or longer. Capital gains now are fully taxed at the same rates that apply to other income. The combination of the capital-gains exclusion and the new rate structure would have these effects: -Capital gains of people in the highest, 31 percent, tax bracket, would have an effective capital-gains rate of 15 percent. -People in the 28 percent bracket would pay an effective rate of 13.55 percent on capital gains. -Taxpayers in the lowest bracket, 15 percent, would pay an effective 7.26 percent rate on capital gains. -Couples with no children and filing a joint return would pay a 15 percent rate on their first $32,450 of taxable income; 28 percent on the next segment, between $32,450 and $78,400; and 31 percent on everything above $78,400. -A single person would pay 15 percent on the first $19,450; 28 percent on the next segment, between $19,450 and $47,050; and 31 percent on everything above $47,050.

DOC.HEAD: Most of Nation's 1990 Blood Pressure Goals Met, CDC Says
DOC.TEXT: Americans achieved most of the objectives aimed at lowering their blood pressures during the past decade, with one important exception: losing weight, the national Centers for Disease Control said Thursday. Seven of the nine U.S. health objectives relating to blood pressure have been met, including a reduction in the rate of high blood pressure nationwide, the CDC said. In 1979, when the federal Department of Health and Human Services prepared its 1990 health goals for the nation, hypertension - high blood pressure - was defined as a reading of 160-95 or higher. By this year, the government hoped to have at least 60 percent of Americans who met that definition to control their blood pressures with medication, diet and exercise. One recent survey indicated a level of 65 percent, the CDC said. However, the goal of reducing the overweight population to less than 10 percent of adult men and less than 17 percent of adult women was not reached, the CDC said. According to a 1988 federal survey, 27 percent of adult men and 26 percent of adult women were more than 20 percent above their recommended weight, it said. Being overweight increases the risk of high blood pressure, which is, in turn, a cause of heart disease and strokes. ``Improvements in blood pressure control ... have contributed to a 50 percent decrease in stroke and a 35 percent decrease in coronary heart disease since 1972,'' the Atlanta-based CDC said, citing a 1988 federal report. ``Despite this progress, 30 million persons in the United States still have inadequately controlled blood pressure.'' Although comprehensive studies are not complete, the goal of having at least 60 percent of the hypertensive population in control of their blood pressure ``has most likely been met,'' the CDC said, citing various studies over the past several years. However, in 1984, federal health officials revised the standard for hypertension to a reading of 140-90, and progress at that level is less certain, the CDC said. A study in South Carolina showed 38 percent of hypertensive people - as defined under the stricter standard - lowering their blood pressure with medication, diet and exercise, the CDC said. Progress toward the 1990 goals ``cannot be definitely determined'' until statistics from a new national survey are analyzed over the next several years, it said. Other blood-pressure goals which were met, include: - More than half of U.S. adults should know the principal risk factors for heart disease and stroke: high blood pressure, smoking, high cholesterol, diabetes. - More than 90 percent of adults should know whether they have high blood pressure. - At least half of processed food in grocery stores should be labeled with sodium and caloric content. Other goals, also met, targeted public health systems and research methodology. Progress is unknown toward one goal: reducing the average daily salt intake to less than .21 of an ounce. No studies have been done to provide such data, the CDC said. Sodium, a component of salt, contributes to high blood pressure.

DOC.HEAD: Lawn Mower Engine Maker Recalling 850,000 Fuel Tanks
DOC.TEXT: One of the country's leading makers of lawn mower engines is recalling 850,000 fuel tanks sold since July 1, 1989, because they may leak gasoline. The engines, made by Briggs & Stratton and installed on more than 100 brands of walk-behind mowers, have the name ``Quantum Power'' on top, said the Consumer Product Safety Commission. Sears, Snapper and Toro produced some mowers using those engines without the name. Owners of those machines, bought after July 1 last year, should check the engine model number on a plate just above the spark plug. If the first two digits are 12, the fuel tank is subject to recall. If a tank leaks, the CPSC said, the owner should arrange for a replacement at 16,000 Briggs & Stratton dealers at no charge. If it is not leaking, owners are advised to make an appointment for a replacement.

DOC.HEAD: Octavio Paz: A Writer Who Defined His Nation
With AM-Nobel Literature, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: In his sensuous poetry imbued with mythology and politics, Octavio Paz has helped shape Mexico's idea of itself and long served as interpreter of his nation's soul for the West. He finds company among the Latin American literary greats who have profoundly influenced the politics of their nations and channeled their cultures into the mainstream of world literature. Mexican novelist Carlos Fuentes has called Paz the ``greatest living Mexican writer, great renovator of the Spanish language, great universal poet and essayist.'' Peruvian writer Mario Vargas Llosa said Paz was ``one of the greatest poets that the Spanish-language world has produced and, at the same time, a great humanist.'' But the self-styled socialist and democrat has been heavily criticized by the Mexican left and virtually ostacized by his peers for his political views, which defy allegiance to either left or right. He has chosen the life of political dissident in his country. Paz resigned from a 25-year diplomatic career to protest the government's suppression of student demonstrations during the 1968 Olympic Games in Mexico City, and has since devoted himself to writing and lecturing. He received an honorary doctorate from Harvard University in 1980. The newest Nobel laureate is known in Mexico as a poet, essayist, diplomat, critic, professor, translator, polemicist and founder of literary journals. His poetry and essays cover concerns ranging from surrealism and socialism to archaeology and Oriental philosophy. But above all, Paz, 76, is immersed in his country's geography, climate and mythology. ``Our history,'' writes Paz, ``has been a discontinuous process of fits and starts: at times a dance, at others a lethargy interrupted by a sudden, violent awakening.'' ``Again and again, we Spanish and Spanish-Americans rub eyes and ask: What time is it in world history? Our time never coincides with other times. We are always either ahead or behind.'' Among his best-known works are ``The Labyrinth of Solitude'' - a classic analysis of the Mexican psyche - and his long, sensuous poems ``Sun Stone'' and ``Blanca.'' Critics have said his writing expresses Paz's sense of the deep loneliness of man, which can be transcended only through attempts at communion, sexual love, compassion and faith. Paz describes poetry as ``the memory of a country,'' and says poets must be critics of their times. And the giant of Mexican letters has never shunned controversy. His essays have angered both the left and the right. He miffed the leftist literati by equating President Fidel Castro of Cuba with former Chilean strongman Augusto Pinochet and dismissing the 1979 leftist revolution in Nicaragua as ``inconsequential.'' ``I am an interlocutor who is hated and read by the left,'' he once said. At the same time, he has frequently denounced the Institutional Revolutionary Party - which has ruled Mexico for 61 years - as corrupt and out of touch with the people it was formed to help. Paz was born in Mexico City on March 31, 1914 into what he has described as a ``typical Mexican family.'' His mother's relatives emigrated from Andalusia in Spain and his father's ancestors were Mexicans of Indian descent. His paternal grandfather was a writer, journalist and political activist who espoused the cause of the peasantry. It was in his vast private library that the young Paz first read extensively. His father, a lawyer, embraced the Mexican revolution of 1910 and was an ardent supporter of Mexican revolutionary Emiliano Zapata. The young writer was active in Marxist movements at the University of Mexico. But Paz's family was ruined during the upheavals of the civil war and he spent his boyhood in a suburb of Mexico City in a large house that was, he once said, ``crumbling to bits.'' ``As rooms collapsed,'' he recalled in Rita Guibert's 1973 book, ``Seven Voices,'' ``we moved the furniture into others.'' He lived for a time in a large room with only part of a wall. At 17, Paz founded the avant-garde literary journal, ``Barrandal,'' and at 19 published his first book of poetry, ``Forest Moon.'' He went to Spain for a year during the Spanish Civil War and took up the anti-Franco republican cause. He told Guibert that Spain ``taught me the meaning of the word `fraternity.''' Paz used such experiences and the insights they gave him to write the scores of essays and hundreds of poems that have helped shape Mexico's idea of itself and the way in which it is perceived abroad. For this work, he on Thursday won one of the world's top prizes for a writer, the Nobel Prize for literature.

DOC.HEAD: Mexican Author Was Awakened By News Of Nobel Prize
With AM-Nobel-Literature, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Octavio Paz said he would rather die than stop writing poetry, which has unlocked doors to travel and diplomacy and on Thursday brought him the Nobel Prize in literature. The 76-year-old Mexican author said he was in a Manhattan hotel room ``sleeping peacefully'' when the phone rang with the news from Sweden. ``I was very, very surprised,'' he told reporters. ``The prize means a great lot, not in the sense it's a passport to immortality. But it gives you the possibility of a wider audience. Even the most expert writer needs an audience.'' Paz, a former ambassador to India, is no stranger to praise. In 1981, he received the most important award in the Spanish-speaking world, the Cervantes prize. In 1982, he captured the prestigious American Neustadt Prize. ``Poetry is not a very popular art form these days, but it's an essential part of human life,'' Paz said. ``Poetry is the memory of a country, of language. Without poetry, people can't even talk well.'' ``I don't want to retire until I'm dead,'' he said. Paz, in New York for a Mexican art exhibit at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, answered questions in Spanish, French and English from journalists from around the world. He spoke energetically behind a podium, his thick eyebrows and full head of hair giving him a youthful presence. His blue eyes calmly moved about the room, settling on each person he answered. Reflecting on his 25 years as a diplomat, he said poets must be critics of society. He said the current century, with its two world wars, concentration camps and the atomic bomb, had been ``very cruel.'' Paz resigned his job as ambassador to protest his government's suppression of student demonstrations at the 1968 Olympic Games in Mexico City. ``It has been a terrble century,'' said Paz. ``But we have had great moments. Many poets have died in concentration camps. ``Now, we are seeing the coming back of freedom all over the world and that is important. Art and also the great change of the world has given me great pleasure,'' he said. He also reflected on years as a writer. ``We are born alone and the first thing is to be with others. I have to communicate this thirst of communion. Language is a common property. A writer is only the guardian of language, a collective wealth,'' said Paz. ``My only job,'' he said, ``was to write the best I could.''

DOC.HEAD: GOP Lawmakers Feel `Party of the Rich' Label in Tax Fight
DOC.TEXT: Congressional Republicans who vowed to fight any effort to raise income taxes are having second thoughts, fearing they're being tarred as the protectors of the rich. ``I think we made a mistake, this party made a mistake taking ... this blood oath'' against tax rate increases, said Fred Grandy, R-Iowa, who took it himself. ``I'm sick and tired of going home to rural Wisconsin and protecting a Republican image as the party of the rich,'' added Rep. Steve Gunderson, R-Wis. ``And I don't do it.'' Gunderson is among the majority of House Republicans who only a few months ago pledged in writing not to touch top tax rates. Now, in the 11th hour of crafting a five-year, $500 billion deficit reduction plan, those tax changes seem more acceptable than some alternatives such as a boost in the tax on gasoline. Rep. Duncan Hunter of California, the House Republican research chairman, took the House floor on Thursday to announce his view: ``Republicans stand for cutting the gas tax.'' One of the most vocal opponents of touching tax rates in the past, he repeated the gas tax assertion four times - and never once mentioned the income tax rate. Adding to the Republican problem is the confusion over just where President Bush and the congressional Republicans stand on the issue. Bush, famous for his ``read my lips'' pledge not to raise taxes, was out in front of most of his party's leaders in dropping that promise. And on Thursday the president said he could trade a modest increase in income taxes on the wealthiest Americans for a deep cut in capital gains rates. Republicans may have reason to worry about public perceptions. A recent national poll by the Times Mirror news organization indicated that since Bush took office more and more Americans consider the Republican party the party of the rich. Asked, ``What does it mean to be a Republican,'' 51 percent volunteered that Republicans were allied with ``rich, powerful moneyed interests.'' In 1987, only 21 percent gave that answer. Sen. Don Nickles, R-Okla., chairman of the GOP's Senate campaign effort this year, said the portrayal was unfair but he acknowledged the issue was hurting. ``I think so far the Democrats have been pretty successful in demagoguing the issue. They're taking advantage of it,'' he said. Nickles said Republicans now might support what he called ``making the tax rates more understandable,'' that is, making the marginal tax rates on the wealthy match those of the upper middle class, but without a net increase in revenue. House GOP leader Bob Michel, R-Ill., said he was struggling with other GOP lawmakers to come up with a Republican alternative budget. He said his ranks were divided on whether to exchange a rate increase on the wealthy for a capital gains tax cut in line with Bush's position. But the House Republican Policy Committee on Wednesday included in its budget proposal a plan to raise the top tax rate on the wealthy to 31 percent in exchange for cutting the rate on capital gains to 15 percent. ``Phony populism,'' is how House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., portrays the latest GOP effort. Democrats have insisted on rates of at least 20 percent on capital gains and 32 percent on the upper incomes in an effort to prevent what they call another tax break for the rich. ``Quite frankly, the price is still too high,'' Michel said. But for a growing number in his party, Michel said, raising taxes on the rich was an attractive alternative to raising gasoline taxes, cutting Medicare, or other features in the budget deal now working its way through Congress. ``There are some who are really worried about the rich man versus poor man argument (who would) without too much prodding go to 33 percent,'' he said. Rep. Mickey Edwards, R-Okla., the chairman of the policy committee, denied his group's plan was in reaction to the polls or Democratic rhetoric. ``We have never ... been a party that was sympathetic to the higher incomes,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Police Officer Says None of Air Crash Victims Survived Long
DOC.TEXT: A police officer on Thursday told a public inquiry into the terrorist bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 that none of the 270 victims survived for any length of time. Sgt. David Johnston made the comment during cross-examination as he continued the roll call of victims, detailing the cause of death and where their bodies were found, if they were found. Johnston told Brian Gill, attorney for the relatives of British victims, ``It soon became apparent that no person had survived for any length of time'' in the Dec. 21, 1988 crash. Later, Johnston continued a roll call on the victims that began on Wednesday. The occupation of one victim was listed in court papers as a ``Nazi hunter,'' but this description was not given in court. Attorney Michael Bernstein, 36, of Bethesda, Md., had been traveling from Vienna and London to New York on the night of the disaster. Johnston told the hearing the dead man was an employee of the U.S. Department of Justice, but gave no details. His body was found on open ground near Lockerbie. The inquiry also heard that the body of student Nicole Boulanger, 21, from Shrewsbury, Mass., was never found. But investigators identified her from personal belongings strewn around the area - her passport, found at Langholm, 18 miles away, and her London Transport photocard. A Pan Am stewardess, who one witness thought had briefly survived the crash, may have been Noelle Berti, 40, of Paris. Johnston told the hearing her body was found near the cockpit and was identified by fingerprints, dental records and jewelry. Mary Young, who trained as a nurse, said she found a pulse on a young woman near the cockpit wreckage shortly after the crash, but it was gone 10 minutes later. The inquiry is focusing on the causes of death and airport security, but not criminal responsibility. Scottish police say they are investigating several radical Palestinian groups. Police have said the bomb was planted in a radiocassette recorder placed in a suitcase. The flight originated in Frankfurt on a Boeing 727 and transferred to a larger 747 at London's Heathrow Airport.

DOC.HEAD: Pell `Out Of It,' Says Schneider
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Rep. Claudine Schneider says voters regard 71-year-old Sen. Claiborne Pell as being ``out of it.'' Pell's campaign manager said Miss Schneider was becoming ``desperate'' in her campaign against the senator, who is ahead in the polls. ``She sees him daily,'' said Mary Beth Cahill. ``She knows that's not true.'' Before a news conference, Miss Schneider, a 43-year-old Republican, said: ``People say to me they saw Claiborne out campaigning and they say, `I didn't realize ... he was so out of it.''' Democrat Pell declined comment on the matter.
DOC.HEAD: Lola Perpich Pounding Air Waves as Governor Pounds Grunseth's Personal Life
DOC.TEXT: Lola Perpich has taken an unusually high profile in her husband's Democratic gubernatorial re-election campaign, appearing in 30-second ads saying everything is rosy under the Perpich administration. The current ad shows a vase of white roses, with hands from an unseen person inserting a rose into the vase as a narrator tickets off awards and distinctions to Minnesota. The ad closes with a shot of Lola Perpich suggesting that Minnesota's high quality of life and well-managed government has come about because ``Rudy makes government work for you.'' There's a small picture of the governor in the corner. The ``Roses'' ads are part of a double-barrelled attack against Perpich's opponent, Jon Grunseth. While Lola appears on television, the governor has been dwelling on the details of Grunseth's divorce.
DOC.HEAD: In Texas Politics, The One With The `Famous' Name Has An Edge
DOC.TEXT: In previous races for the Texas Railroad Commission, John Sharp has beaten opponents Sam Ervin and Jack Daniel. Now in his bid for state comptroller, Democrat Sharp is being challenged by Republican Warren G. Harding Jr. That was the name of a former Texas treasurer as well as the late president. Sharp says he is worried about his latest campaign against yet another election-year rival with a celebrated name. ``Whenever a famous name is taken for granted, they win,'' Sharp told a news conference. The Ervin in Sharp's race was not the famous Watergate senator and Daniel had no connection to the Tennessee whiskey. Among the other names on the ballot in Texas this year. Gene Kelly is trying to win a seat on the Texas Supreme Court. Sam Houston Clinton is seeking re-election to the Texas Court of Criminal Appeals. Voters in San Antonio could elect Bart Simpson - a young businessman and not the sharp-tongued cartoon character - to the Texas Legislature. Two write-in candidates for governor hope to take advantage of their names. James ``Jim'' Wright is not the former U.S. House speaker. Writer Lloyd ``Alamo'' Scott hopes voters will Remember the Alamo when they cast their ballots.
DOC.HEAD: Poll Shows Kopetski Has Lead
DOC.TEXT: Democratic challenger Mike Kopetski has edged past U.S. Rep. Denny Smith in a hotly contested congressional race, according to a poll conducted for a Portland television station. The survey, conducted for KPTV, showed Kopetski favored by 49 percent, compared with 41 percent for Smith. Te percent were undecided. Of those who considered themselves most likely to vote, Kopetski was favored by 51 percent and Smith by 41 percent. The poll, by Bardsley & Neidhart Inc., has a margin of error of plus or minus 4.9 percent. The random telephone survey questioned 404 registered voters between Oct. 2 and 7.

DOC.HEAD: Spectators Demand `Unification' During First Inter-Korean Sports Match
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of spectators cheered wildly Thursday for North and South Korean soccer teams at the first inter-Korean sports match in more than four decades, news reports said. The crowd in North Korea's capital, Pyongyang, chanted ``unification!'' as the two teams entered the stadium holding hands, the South Korean news agency Yonhap reported. ``Waves of excitement and feelings of unity swept spectators,'' the agency said. The report said about 150,000 North Korean spectators waved flags and hoisted huge placards that read ``Korea is one.'' Many sang the ``Song of Unification,'' a sad and haunting melody known to all Koreans, as 200 musicians played. South Korea's sports minister, Chung Dong-sung, received seven standing ovations when he called for an exchange of civilians across the heavily armed border as a step toward uniting the two countries, Yonhap said. North and South Korea have been divided since 1945. ``I hope this game will be an event that heals the pains of the past and expedites unity and unification,'' Yonhap quoted Kim Yu Sun, chairman of the North Korean Olympic Committee, as saying. North Korea's team beat South Korea, 2-1. Rules had been changed to allow unlimited substitutions so that more players could participate. North Korea's official Korean Central News Agency, monitored in Tokyo, gave a similar account. At the end of the game, players on both sides bowed to cheering spectators and exchanged their sweat-soaked shirts as an electric scoreboard flashed ``Our country is one,'' the South Korean reports said. It was the first exchange of sports teams between North Korea and South Korea since partition, and was only the second civilian exchange between the two hostile Koreas. North Korean soccer players are to visit Seoul later this month. The exchanges are seen as an indication of increased dialogue between the two Koreas. More than 10 million Koreans were separated from their families by the division of the peninsula and by the three-year Korean War in the early 1950s. The border between the Koreas remains tightly sealed and guarded by more than 1.5 million troops. Next week, the prime ministers of the two nations are to meet in Pyongyang for a second round of talks on easing tensions.

DOC.HEAD: West African Task Force Wins Control of Monrovia
DOC.TEXT: West African soldiers using tanks and jet bombers have won control of the capital of Liberia from Charles Taylor's rebels, the army commander said Thursday. It cleared the way for an interim government and the arrival of desperately needed food supplies in Monrovia. The five-nation army sent on Aug. 5 to stop Liberia's civil war has forced the rebels back into Monrovia's eastern suburb of Paynesville in fighting this week, Brig. Gen. Joshua Dogonyaro of Nigeria said. Diplomats in Abidjan said reports reaching them by radio from Monrovia backed Dogonyaro's statement. Rival rebel leader Prince Johnson pulled his fighters from central Monrovia this week at Dogonyaro's request. A third force in Monrovia, the remnants of the army of slain President Samuel Doe, was holed up in and around the presidential mansion. Some Doe soldiers were fighting alongside the West Africans, diplomats in Abidjan reported Thursday. The war began with Taylor's rebel forces invading from Ivory Coast last December to oust a Doe government they called corrupt. In February, Johnson split from the Taylor forces and brought his fighters with him. The Economic Community of West African States, which sent the multinational army, renewed an appeal for emergency food for people starving in Monrovia, a city of 400,000. Executive Secretary Abbas Bundu said Dogonyaro assured him the port was safe for ships and that posts were set up for an orderly distribution of food. U.S. and other food aid has been held up in countries neighboring Liberia, a West African nation of 2.5 million people founded in 1847 by freed American slaves. The U.S. Ambassador in Monrovia, Peter de Vos, has said U.S. food would not be brought in until relief workers' safety was guaranteed and food could be distributed without causing a riot, as happened previously. Nigerian ships this week carried the first substantial food shipment to reach Monrovia in three months - 150 tons from the U.N. World Food Program. The diplomats in Abidjan confirmed that the West Africans captured Spriggs Payne Airfield, a few miles from downtown Monrovia, but said the airport could not be used safely unless the rebels are pushed back at least 10 miles. Diplomats said Ghanaian troops and some Liberian army soldiers went into the German Embassy neighboring Paynesville on Wednesday. They said they were conducting a house-to-house search for rebels, but the Liberians started looting, the diplomats said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The only German who remains there along with hundreds of refugees called diplomats by radio. They contacted the West African force headquarters, and officers were dispatched who ordered the troops from the embassy, the diplomats said. Other countries that have sent soldiers are Nigeria, Guinea, Gambia and Sierra Leone. West Africans sent the army to force a cease-fire to allow the installation of an interim government chosen by exiled Liberians. Elections will follow. Taylor has named his own government and says the temporary administration, presently based in neighbrring Sierra Leone, is a stooge of the West Africans. More than 5,000 civilians have been killed in the war, and half a million Liberians have fled to neighboring states or are displaced within the country. Task force nations said the impact of Liberia's civil war on surrounding nations made their action imperative.

DOC.HEAD: Bolivian Policeman Slain in Attack on U.S. Embassy
DOC.TEXT: Leftist guerrillas attacked a U.S. Marine residence, killing a Bolivian policeman, and set off a bomb that destroyed a monument to President John F. Kennedy, officials said Thursday. A group calling itself the Nestor Paz Zamora Commando claimed responsibility for Wednesday night's attacks in calls to a Roman Catholic radio station. Two men, one dressed in army fatigues, got out of a car in front of the Marine residence and opened fire with machine guns, said U.S. Embassy spokesman Bruce Wharton. The two police guarding the residence were injured, and one of them died on the way to the hospital, Wharton said. The gunmen tossed a package bomb at the door of the building, destroying the door and causing the front of the building to tilt. The three Marines inside were not hurt, Wharton said. ``We very much regret the death of the Bolivian police and are taking the attacks very seriously,'' Wharton said. At midnight, a powerful bomb went off at the Kennedy statue in central La Paz, a city 2{ miles high in the Andes in this landlocked South American country. Several people near the statue suffered slight injuries. The guerrillas said the attacks were ``a response to the violation of our territoral and political sovereignty by imperialists from the North.'' Their statement denied a link to drug smugglers. ``As revolutionaries, our struggle is based on the highest ethical standards. No more yankees, no more drugs.'' The group takes its name from the late brother of Bolivia's current president, Jaime Paz Zamora. Nestor Paz Zamora launched an unsuccessful guerrilla movement in Bolivia in 1970, the year before his brother founded the Revolutionary Left Movement, currently the governing party. Interior Minister Guillermo Capobianco said the attacks were ``attempting to bury a democratic process that cost the Bolivian people a great deal of sacrifice.'' Only last week Capobianco had called Bolivia ``an island of tranquility.'' Over the past decade Bolivia has been largely spared the violence of drug smugglers and political extremists that has wracked Peru and Colombia, fellow Andean nations. The attacks came a week after the government denounced an alleged plot by cocaine traffickers to assassinate U.S. Ambassador Robert S. Gelbard, President Paz Zamora and other officials. In May 1989, two Mormon missionaries were slain in La Paz by a leftist terrorist group called Zarate Wilka.
