Several members of the group are in jail awaiting trial, but the triggermen were believed still at large. Zarate Wilka also claimed responsibility for the August 1988 bombing near the motorcade of then-Secretary of State George P. Shultz. It caused no injuries.

DOC.HEAD: Tape Recorded Hunter's Horror Finding Out He Killed Woman
DOC.TEXT: The first testimony at a hunter's manslaughter trial Thursday was a tape recording of his horror at shooting a woman he said he thought was a deer. ``When I got there, she was laying on the ground and I lost it right there,'' Donald Rogerson told a game warden, who recorded their conversation about one hour after Karen Wood was killed Nov. 15, 1988. ``All I could think of was `I just don't want her to die,' '' Rogerson said on the tape, his voice trembling. Rogerson, 47, the manager of a supermarket produce section, is on trial in Penobscot County Superior Court. His case has touched off renewed debate about hunting safety and drawn national attention. Rogerson, who lives in Bangor, said he had been hunting in the woods behind Mrs. Wood's suburban Hermon home for some time the day of the killing and didn't realize how near he was to her home. ``I couldn't see the house at all,'' he said. ``At no time did I ever see a person.'' Rogerson said he had been following a deer, fired one and missed. Then, he said, he thought he saw ``two flags,'' the white underside of a deer's tail. He fired again. Rogerson said on the tape he was horrified when he found Mrs. Wood lying on the ground and realized he must have mistaken her white mittens for a deer's tail. After trying to carry Mrs. Wood to her home, he placed her on the ground. ``I just laid down on the ground next to her and kept her covered,'' Rogerson said on the tape. Before the taped conversation was played, the prosecution and defense attorneys offered conflicting assessments about the abundance of deer in the area where Rogerson shot the 37-year-old mother of twin year-old girls. Jeffrey Hjelm, the assistant attorney general prosecuting the case, said in his opening remarks that wardens examined the area of the shooting and found only one deer track. He said that track was behind where Rogerson fired the fatal shot. Defense attorney Lewis Vafiades countered that two other hunters who had been with Rogerson before the shooting had spotted several deer in that area earlier in the day. The prosecution contends Rogerson acted negligently or recklessly when he killed Mrs. Wood, who was about 130 feet behind her house. Mrs. Wood's husband, Kevin, who now lives in Bettendorf, Iowa, said he didn't think a conviction would help heal emotional scars because ``there are no winners in this situation.'' Hours after the shooting, Rogerson was charged with manslaughter. But the charge was dropped in December 1988 after a county grand jury concluded his actions were neither criminally negligent nor criminally reckless. The state attorney general's office reopened the case after a Portland television station reported that Vafiades' nephew had served on the first grand jury. A special grand jury indicted Rogerson on manslaughter charges in December 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Physicians Warn Adult Suicides Increase With Economic Downturn
DOC.TEXT: Physicians at a conference on suicide warned Thursday that an economic downturn could spark a dramatic increase in adult suicides. If recession is defined as nine months of rising unemployment, ``the correlation is extremely strong between the vicissitudes of the economy and actual suicide,'' said Dr. Andrew Slaby, president of the eastern division of the American Suicide Foundation. Slaby spoke at a news briefing before the foundation's one-day conference at a midtown hotel on preventing, evaluating and managing suicidal behavior. About 1,500 physicians, therapists, psychologists and social workers from a three-state area registered for the gathering, described by organizers as the largest of its kind in the United States. Slaby, psychiatrist in chief at The Regent Hospital in Manhattan, said studies on suicide rates during the Depression found suicides increased most ``among white, successful males and black women, the two that really suffered the most when they lost jobs.'' In times of economic hardship, he said, black women were often among the first to lose jobs. He noted that domestic workers relied for employment on affluent white men who had lost jobs themselves. Dr. Herbert Hendin, the American Suicide Foundation's executive director, said there are no figures measuring the effect of the current economic downturn on the suicide rate. But he said throughout the century, the suicide rate went up when the economy declined. In September, the nation's unemployment rose to 5.7 percent. It was the first time since the 1981-82 recession that the jobless rate increased three months in a row. Slaby also noted the suicide rate generally has declined during war times. The 19th century French sociologist Emile Durkheim found there were fewer suicides during the great wars in Europe in the 19th century. The U.S. suicide rate rose during World War I, World War II and the Korean War but not during the Vietnam War, Slaby said. People feel less desperation when they ``bond together and fight for a common cause,'' he said. The American Suicide Foundation said 30,796 people - 24,272 men and 6,524 women - committed suicide in the United States in 1987. Although more men commit suicide, more women attempt suicide, it said. Because men use ``more violent means'' to kill themselves than women, they are more likely to succeed, Slaby said. Women are more likely to seek counseling or help from peers, he said. But Slaby noted that the suicide rate among professional women is rapidly increasing. Among 15 to 24 year olds, suicide is the second leading cause of death after accidents, according to the foundation. The foundation was formed two years ago and funds research at major medical centers in the treatment and prevention of depression and suicide.

DOC.HEAD: Corn Crop To Hit Four-Year High
DOC.TEXT: Despite some losses to dry weather, farmers are still harvesting a bumper corn crop estimated at a four-year high of 8.02 billion bushels, up 7 percent from last year, the Agriculture Department said Thursday. However, the new estimate by the department's Agricultural Statistics Board was down 1 percent from last month's forecast of 8.12 billion bushels. ``Early in September, lack of moisture in the western Corn Belt caused deteriorating crop conditions,'' the board's report said. ``Crop conditions lagged furthest behind in Illinois, Indiana and Missouri.'' Farmers harvested 7.53 billion bushels in 1989, and the department in its initial 1990 forecast on Aug. 9 put this fall's harvest at 7.85 billion bushels before raising it last month. John A. Schnittker of Schnittker Associates, a Washington-based consulting firm, said the forecast is ``almost equal to the amount of corn we will need in the next 12 months'' to meet domestic and export demands now projected. But the bad news, he said, is that ``this corn crop coincides with a glut in wheat, especially.'' Big wheat producers, including the United States, are subsidizing exports in an effort to unload surpluses. ``The big wheat crop glutting the world market and the subsidization of wheat, pushing it below corn prices, is the real problem,'' Schnittker said. Based on Oct. 1 surveys, corn yields were estimated at a record 120.3 bushels per acre harvested, compared with 116.2 last year and 121.7 indicated last month. The old record was 119.4 bushels in 1987. As livestock feed, corn is the largest and most important U.S. farm crop and is essential for the production of meat, poultry and dairy products. Consumer food prices, which rose an average of 5.8 percent in 1989, the sharpest year-to-year increase since 1981, are expected to climb an additional 5 percent to 7 percent in 1990. Soybean production, a source of high-protein meal and vegetable oil, was estimated at 1.82 billion bushels, down 5 percent from last year's harvest of 1.93 billion bushels and 1 percent below the September forecast of 1.83 billion bushels. Cotton production was indicated at 14.5 million bales, up 19 percent from last year's output of 12.2 million bales but down 1 percent from the September forecast. The revised estimates showed total wheat production at 2.74 billion bushels, up 35 percent from the 1989 harvest but down slightly from last month. The department's all-crops production index was reported at 111 percent of its 1977 average used for comparison, down one percentage point from September but still the highest reading since the index averaged 116 percent in 1985. In a related report on supply and demand for major commodities, analysts said total corn use in the 1990-91 marketing year that began on Sept. 1 is expected to be about 8.095 billion bushels, including domestic and export requirements. With demand slightly exceeding 1990 corn production, that will mean a decrease in U.S. corn stockpiles to about 1.273 billion bushels left over by Sept. 1, 1991. But the downturn would be modest compared with 1989 when the corn stockpile plummeted from 4.26 billion bushels on Sept. 1, 1988 to 1.93 billion bushels on hand last Sept. 1. The report sid U.S. corn prices may average in the range of $2.20 to $2.60 per bushel in the 1990-91 marketing year, up 10 cents from the September projection. Corn prices at the farm averaged about $2.36 per bushel last season. No significant changes were reported in the U.S. wheat supply and demand situation, and prices at the farm are expected to average $2.55 to $2.85 per bushel this marketing year, down from $3.72 in 1989-90. Soybean prices at the farm were forecast at $5.70 to $7 per bushel in 1990-91, compared with $5.70 the past marketing year. That was up 20 cents on the lower end of the range in September. Other 1990 crop estimates based on Oct. 1 indications, compared with 1989 output, included: -Sorghum, 561.9 million bushels and an average yield of 60.7 bushels per acre, compared with 617.9 million and 55.4 in 1989. -Rice, 158 million hundredweight and a yield of 5,629 pounds per acre, compared with 154.5 million and 5,749. -Peanuts, 3.36 billion pounds and a yield of 1,917 pounds per acre, compared with 3.99 billion and 2,426. -Tobacco, 1.58 billion pounds and a yield of 2,166 pounds per acre, compared with 1.37 billion and 2,016. -Sugar beets, 27.1 million tons and a yield of 19.89 tons per acre, compared with 25.1 million and 19.4. -Sugar cane, 25.7 million tons and a yield of 35.7 tons per acre, compared with 29.4 million and 34.5.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Harvesting Near-Record Grain Crop, US Says
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union is harvesting a near-record grain crop estimated at 235 million metric tons, up 5 million tons from previous forecasts, the Agriculture Department said Thursday. Officials said the increase in grain prospects was based primarily on harvest reports from the Soviet Union. The estimate of wheat production was raised 4 million tons to 108 million tons, while coarse grains such as rye, barley, oats, corn, sorghum and millet, were increase by 1 million tons to 114 million tons. Production of pulses, rice, buckwheat and miscellaneous grains account for the remainder. The monthly report by the department's Foreign Agricultural Service said Soviet grain imports in the 1990-91 marketing year that began July 1 continue to be estimated at 30 million tons, down from 38 million last year. Moscow's grain buying ``continues relatively subdued,'' the report said. Prospects for this year's bumper grain crop and uncertainty caused by economic and political reforms were cited among the reasons.

The Persian Gulf crisis has unleashed forces seeking political reforms in the feudal gulf states, including an extraordinary effort to discuss the future of Kuwait if it is freed from Iraqi occupation. Kuwait's exiled rulers have invited 450 prominent citizens to a conference in Saudi Arabia this weekend to consider the future shape of a free Kuwait. The government is eagerly - and uncharacteristically - soliciting the attendance of the Western press at the event. Crown Prince Sheik Saad al Abdullah made it clear that the agenda will range from future defense arrangments to the rights of Kuwaiti citizens and foreign workers. ---= ROME (AP) - Every morning, 90 Iraqi sailors hoist the flag on their two Esmeraldas-class corvettes, rev their engines and swivel their 76-millimeter cannons menacingly along the horizon. It is a scene that would worry the U.S. military - if it were not taking place on the sunny Italian Riviera. The two corvettes, and eight other warships floating nearby, were ordered from Italy in 1980. They were to have formed the bulk of Iraq's most powerful naval fleet ever. But as Saddam Hussein's country prepares for war, its would-be navy is stranded at an Italian military base and a nearby shipbuilder's docks, a victim of delays and Italian government embargoes. ``It will be very difficult for these ships to ever arrive in Iraq,'' said Marco Maria Ferranti, spokesman for the Italian shipbuilder, Fincantieri. ---= JERUSALEM (AP) - Police fired tear gas in Jerusalem's Old City on Thursday to break up a march by about 150 Palestinians to the Temple Mount, where police killed 19 Arabs earlier this week. The government and Israel's chief rabbis called on Israelis to come to the Western Wall by the thousands Thursday night to reassert control over Judaism's holiest site. In New York City, the U.N. Security Council held consultations to end the stalemate over criticism of the violence in Jerusalem. But a vote was not expected Thursday. Thousands of fundamentalist Moslems demonstrated in neighboring Jordan and pledged to avenge Monday's killings, which occurred when police opened fire on rioters stoning Jews praying at the Western Wall below. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - The House moved toward a vote Thursday on a bill that would scrap explicit anti-obscenity curbs on the National Endowment for the Arts and instead penalize grant recipients later convicted of violating obscenity laws. Supporters predicted passage of the measure after months of controversy over public financing of art considered offensive by some. Conservatives led by Rep. Dana Rohrabacher, R-Calif., fought to muster opposition to the bipartisan compromise bill that would extend the NEA's statutory authority for three years, without any restrictions on the kinds of art eligible for federal subsidies. The Williams-Coleman bill would drop the detailed anti-obscenity restrictions that Congress imposed on the NEA a year ago at the urging of Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C.. The measure would shift from the endowment to the courts the burden of deciding whether NEA-supported works are obscene. ---= STOCKHOLM, Sweden (AP) - Octavio Paz, who explored the Mexican character and the universal themes of love, death and loneliness in lyrical poetry and impassioned essays, won the Nobel Prize in literature Thursday. The Swedish Academy awarded Paz the prize for his ``exquisite love poetry, at the same time sensuous and visual,'' and for his wide international perspective. It also cited Paz for his essays on Mexican society, calling him ``a lodestar in the tide of opinion.'' Paz's views have angered the left and the right in his homeland, and he was dumped by leftists who felt he turned on their cause. Paz, 76, said he was ``very, very surprised'' at being selected. ``Poetry is not a very popular art form these days, but it's an essential part of human life,'' Paz said in New York, where he is inaugurating a Mexican art exhibit at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. ``Poetry is the memory of a country, of language.'' ---= MOSCOW (AP) - The Soviet Union's most advanced booster rocket, which an American specialist believed was carrying a spy satellite, exploded seconds after liftoff last week. The blast nearly destroyed the launch pad and may complicate Soviet efforts to sell space hardware to the West. The official Soviet news agency Tass reported for the first time Thursday that a Zenit booster ``broke up'' at the Baikonur space port in the Central Asian republic of Kazakhstan on Oct. 4. Tass said no one was hurt and that a commission is investigating the accident. The three-sentence dispatch did not identify the payload or give any other details. It also did not say why the explosion was not reported for a week. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - A congressional report warns that shuttle flights and other space activity could become too risky within the next 20-30 years if nations continue to litter the most traveled paths. Already, the Hubble Space Telescope - which has enough problems of its own because of faulty optics - has been given a one-in-100 chance of being severely damaged by space debris during its 17-year lifetime, said the Office of Technology Assessment. `Even small debris particles can produce high levels of damage,'' said Ray Williamson, who directed the study. ``The average collision velocity in low earth orbit is about 10 kilometers (6.2 miles) a second.''

DOC.HEAD: Government Demands Expropriation of Communist Property
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th pvs, `Anger deepened...' to CORRECT that Communist official urges disbanded committees be re-established at work places, not that those committees control the work places. Pickup 12th pvs, `The comments...'
DOC.TEXT: The government on Thursday proposed seizing all Communist Party property without compensation, highlighting the growing anger at Czechoslovakia's former rulers during a time of economic hardship. The state news agency said the plan would be presented immediately to parliament for approval. About 60,000 people jammed the Old Town Square in Prague late Thursday in a show of support for the proposal. The CTK news agency said the expropriation plan would remove property the Communist Party had ``gained in unjust ways, giving it an advantage over other political parties and movements in contradiction to democratic principles.'' According to news reports, the Communist Party still controls property worth about $368 million. Government spokesman Zbynek Fiala said party assets totaled $793 million before Czechoslovakia's peaceful revolution late last year. But Communist Party secretary Jiri Machalik contested the figures, saying on Thursday that much of the party's property had already been handed over to the government. He said the remaining assets were worth about $145 million. Machalik added the Communists had proposed an alternate proposal that would allow the party to retain some property in Prague and elsewhere. Party property includes buildings, communications equipment, recreation centers, newspapers, and other assets. The government began a gradual transfer of property away from the Communists in May when it froze party assets. But as economic difficulties heighten in the central European country, many people now consider that insufficient. Anti-Communist sentiment has been growing steadily in Czechoslovakia. Government officials said last month the party had lost more than a million members, or about half its adherents, in the 10 months since the revolution. Anger deepened following reports Sunday that Communist Party leader Vasil Mohorita had criticized the country's economic reforms and urged disbanded Communist Party committees at work places be re-establishd. The comments were seen by many as a way of making political gains out of Czechoslovakia's economic troubles. The Soviet Union has fallen short of its targets for oil deliveries, and the government last week announced higher prices for heating oil and gasoline. The crowd jamming Prague's Old Town Square on Thursday warned they would not tolerate any attempt by the Communists to regain control of the country. ``We do not want political trials, we do not want to see Communists in jail, we just want them to go,'' said Milan Dolejsi, 63, of Czechoslovakia's confederation of political prisoners. But many of the younger participants were more radically inclined. Miroslav Kulhavy of the Greens Party demanded prosecution of former President Gustav Husak and other party leaders.

DOC.HEAD: Portugal, Indonesia Negotiate Portuguese Visit to East Timor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with human rights report from Jakarta, details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Portugal is negotiating the country's first official visit to the tiny island of East Timor since Indonesia annexed the territory in 1976, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said Thursday. The spokesman said Portugal and Indonesia held their fourth round of U.N.-sponsored talks in August. A new round of talks was expected before the end of the year, he said. Indonesian Foreign Minister Ali Alatas said the visit by Portuguese lawmakers could occur next year. Meanwhile, there were new reports of repression in the former Portuguese colony. According to Portuguese news reports, Indonesia reinforced security measures this week in East Timor's capital, Dili, after unidentified masked groups attacked students demonstrating in favor of independence. There were no reports of injuries or arrests. A human rights group in Jakarta has asked the military to explain the deaths of 22 people in the East Timor village of Poros Posparlos on Aug. 19. H.J.B. Princen, director of the Institute for the Defense of Human Rights, declined in an interview to discuss the specifics of the deaths. Diplomatic sources said there were riots in the area around that time. Brig. Gen. Nurhadi Purwosaputro, head of the Armed Forces Information Center, said Princen's claims were ``groundless.'' ``The Indonesian soldiers have moral sense that prevents them from doing such inhuman things,'' he said. Portugal has tried to enlist international support for its demand that East Timor be granted self-determination. The island 350 miles north of Australia was invaded by Indonesian troops in 1975 and annexed a year later. A guerrilla war has been going on since then. Rights groups estimate 100,000 Timorese have been killed or starved to death. Alatas, in Jakarta, said Wednesday that the Portuguese would be accompanied by a U.N. delegation ``to make sure that the evaluation is objective.'' A 1982 United Nations resolution empowers the U.N. Secretary General to mediate between Indonesia and Portugal over the East Timor question.

DOC.HEAD: Tandy, Cronyn Say They Need Apartment for Attendant
DOC.TEXT: Actor Hume Cronyn used a personal plea to convince zoning officials that he and his wife, actress Jessica Tandy, needed a waiver to build an apartment for an attendant. ``Old age is a hardship,'' Cronyn told the Zoning Board of Appeals. ``One that you'll be dealing with over the years.'' Miss Tandy, 81, and Cronyn, 79, had been denied a zoning waiver in August to build the apartment, which they said they might need for a driver or attendant. But the board approved the request Tuesday after Cronyn said the problem had become more urgent. Miss Tandy, who won an Oscar for her role as an elderly woman who needed a chauffeur in ``Driving Miss Daisy,'' recently was hospitalized for a heart condition following surgery, Cronyn said. He did not reveal the nature of her surgery.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Grounds Planes in Gulf; Hurd Warns of Anarchy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with oil, stock prices, State Department comment on freedom flight. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos DHA5,6
DOC.TEXT: Britain's foreign secretary warned Thursday the world will revert to anarchy if the international coalition against Iraq collapses, and said Saddam Hussein must be told force will be used if Iraq doesn't withdraw from Kuwait. The Air Force, meanwhile, grounded all training flights in the Persian Gulf region for 24 hours from midday Wednesday until midday Thursday to discuss air safety with pilots. The order followed separate accidents this week in which 12 U.S. servicemen died. A group of 321 Western evacuees from Iraq and Kuwait landed in Britain on Thursday in the first such flight in nearly three weeks. Most of the passengers were Americans and many were children. The Americans and Canadians on the flight were to leave Friday for Raleigh-Durham International Airport in North Carolina, said Andrew Varney, Gatwick airport's director of public affairs. While Westerners continued to flee occupied Kuwait with tales of low food supplies and looting by Iraqi troops, international pressure grew against Saddam to withdraw from the oil-rich emirate he invaded and annexed. Speaking at the annual conference of the governing Conservative Party in Bournemouth, England, British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd urged the world to remain united against iraq's occupation. ``If it does not (hold), then despite the coalition, despite the leadership of the United States, despite the cooperation of the Soviet Union - then we shall be back in a world of anarchy punctuated by explosions of force,'' Hurd said. ``The clouds would have extinguished the light. We cannot allow this to happen.'' Hurd also said Saddam should know that force will be used if Iraq does not pull out of Kuwait, which his troops invaded on Aug. 2. ``Day by day we must build in the minds of the Iraqis the certainty that they have to leave Kuwait - if not peacefully, then forced out by military action,'' Hurd said. Monday's killing by Israeli police of 19 Arabs during a riot in Jerusalem brought international outcry and united Arab nations against Israel, a close ally of the United States. There was concern that the israeli action might weaken Arab support for the multinational military presence in the gulf. The U.N. Security Council is considering means of censuring Israel that would satisfy outraged Arab nations and also Israel's allies. Oil prices rose $1.73 a barrel in New York Thursday to close at $40.43 on unfounded rumors that a Palestine terrorist group lobbed missiles into the Israeli-occupied West Bank, land taken from the Arabs in the 1967 war. Stocks in New York again fell, down 42.82 points to an 18-month low at 2,365.10. More than 170,000 U.S. troops are deployed in Saudi Arabia and on warships in the gulf region, backed by vessels and soldiers from other countries. Most nations, with few exceptions, have condemned Iraq's aggression. The Air Force announced it had halted all training flights in the gulf region but not reconnaissance missions and other ``operational patrols,'' said a second Pentagon spokesman, Col. Miguel Monteverde. There are an estimated 700 Air Force combat and support aircraft in the gulf region under Operation Desert Shield. ``The Air Force declared a flying standdown for one day to conduct safety awareness meetings with Air Force pilots,'' Williams said. He said the grounding was ``to get together with everybody and just sort of review what they need to do to fly more safely.'' The official death toll for Desert Shield rose to 24 on Wednesday, when an Air Force F-111 fighter-bomber crashed on a training mission in Saudi Arabia, killing both crew members. On Monday, two pilots were killed in the crash of an Air Force F-4 Phantom reconnaissance jet in Saudi Arabia. Hours earlier, two Marine Corps UH-1 Huey helicopters - each carrying four crew members - crashed over the Arabian Sea. The eight men are listed as missing. Williams said, however, that the military's safety record since troops began to be deployed two months ago remained good under the circumstances. ``Given the amount of flying that has to be done, given the extraordinary circumstances and given the higher than ordinary operating tempo in the area, I think our service people are doing very well,'' he said. The freedom flight from Iraq and Kuwait arriving in London on Thursday was the first since Sept. 22, and like previous flights, carried mostly women and children and Western men of Arab origin. In Washington, State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler described as ``simply outrageous'' Iraqi treatment of the 270 Americans and foreign-born family members aboard the flight. Ms. Tutwiler said Iraqi authorities interrogated and harassed the departing passengers forcing lengthy delays. Some evacuees said they were threatened with weapons and a dozen people were prevented from boarding the flight, she said. Until Thursday, freedom flights had transported about 1,900 Americans out of Iraq and Kuwait. Recent State Department estimates indicated more than 600 Americans were stranded in Kuwait and more than 300 in Iraq. American and other Western men are being held in Iraq and Kuwait, many at strategic Iraqi installations to deter against any possible attack.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Passes Drift Net Ban
DOC.TEXT: The Senate voted Thursday to ban the use of large-scale drift nets in U.S. waters up to 200 miles offshore as well as their use by domestic fishing fleets anywhere in the world. The nets - which can extend up to 40 miles - have been blamed for the deaths of thousands of dolphins, other sea mammals and birds caught in their paths as they float through the water to trap tuna and other commercial fish. The U.S. ban, as well as language directing the Bush administration to seek an international outlawing of drift net fishing, was included in a bill approved 98-0 extending the Magnuson Fishery and Conservation Act another five years. Named after the late Sen. Warren Magnuson, D-Wash., the 1976 law established exclusive U.S. economic control over commercial and sport fishing within 200 miles of the U.S. coastline. The bill extends that control to tuna, which had been exempted from it in the past because they migrate over international boundaries. Similar legislation was approved by the House last February. The legislation also includes a provision by Sen. Joseph Biden, D-Del., that would require the development of government standards that tuna canners would have to adopt in order to label their product ``dolphin-safe.'' In response to environmental campaigns and TV documentaries with dramatic footage of water-breathing dolphins suffocating in tuna drift nets when brought to the surface, Starkist last April began publicizing its use of ``dolphin-safe'' practices and labeling their cans as such. Biden said the labels have been ``abused and bastardized'' by other tuna canners whose practices continue to result in dolphin deaths in their fishing operations.

DOC.HEAD: BULLETIN ELIMINATION
Retransmitting with `a' category code.
DOC.TEXT: Eds: Eliminate the AM-Budget-Pizza story, filed as a0675. The pizza was for the press plane, not for Air Force One. No sub story will be filed.
DOC.HEAD: The AP
ANC Accuses De Klerk of Bad Faith
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to UPDATE with de Klerk's denial. Picks up 11th graf, `Gerrit Viljoen. . .
DOC.TEXT: The African National Congress accused President F.W. de Klerk of negotiating in bad faith Thursday and warned of a renewed armed struggle if peace talks break down. De Klerk later denied the allegation before leaving for a visit to Britain and Portugal. He said the ANC charge appeared timed to coincide with his trip. A government minister, meanwhile, criticized an ANC leader's statement that the organization was continuing to recruit fighters for its suspended armed struggle. ANC spokesman Sakkie Macozoma told a news conference the government reneged on an agreement to release only a joint statement after Monday's meeting between de Klerk and ANC deputy president Nelson Mandela. After the meeting, de Klerk also announced that ANC and other political exiles could begin applying for permission to return to South Africa. He said there were no guarantees indemnity from prosecution would be granted. His statement addressed a key ANC demand, that the estimated 20,000 ANC exiles be permitted to come home. Macozoma said de Klerk's announcement pre-empted further work by a government-ANC committee studying the issue. ``De Klerk and the government's undermining of efforts to achieve a genuine peace settlement places the whole negotiations process in jeopardy,'' Macozoma said. He distributed a document Mandela gave de Klerk at the meeting. In it, Mandela warned the ANC would have no choice but to resume its armed struggle if peace talks failed. The ANC suspended its armed struggle in August as a condition for the talks on ending apartheid and setting up negotiations on power-sharing between the white minority and black majority. ``It should be plainly understoood that if we ever, once again, face a situation in which all constitutional avenues for an advance to democracy are closed, we will have no option but to use other methods,'' the Mandela document said. ``If this is war talk, then I too plead guilty.'' De Klerk told a hastily arranged airport news conference the ANC statements would not derail negotiations. ``I hope that the leadership of the ANC will also refrain from any act or statement which will unnecessarily endanger this and will make sure of their facts before they make an attack on the integrity of the government,'' he said. Gerrit Viljoen, the minister of constitutional development, accused the ANC of violating its agreement to suspend the armed struggle by continuing to recruit fighters. He was referring to comments by Chris Hani, head of the ANC's armed wing, that recruitment continued. In suspending its armed struggle, the ANC agreed to halt ``related activities,'' Viljoen told a news briefing. `` `Related activities' surely must include the recruitment of people for training for armed action, and training and keeping them in camps and having ammunition stores and so on,'' he said. Relations between the white-led government and the ANC, the largest black opposition movement, have been strained by black faction fighting that has killed about 800 people in two months. The fighting in black townships around Johannesburg has pitted Xhosas and other blacks linked to the ANC against Zulu supporters of the conservative Inkatha movement. Mandela and other black leaders accuse security forces of instigating the clashes, perhaps at the behest of right-wing extremists opposed to the government-ANC talks. His statement to de Klerk called for an independent judicial inquiry into the violence and charges that Inkatha fighters were trained by government forces. ``A reluctance to subject such widespread allegations to impartial inquiry fuels a popular perception that there are forces close to you, Mr. President, with a double agenda,'' the document said. The government has denied the allegations and challenged the ANC to provide proof.

DOC.HEAD: Bomb by Separatist Group Kills 3, Injures 49
DOC.TEXT: A bomb in a crowded discoteque Thursday killed the Galician separatist who apparently brought it in and two other people, a government spokeswoman said. Forty-nine people were injured. The pre-dawn blast was one of six early Thursday in the northwestern region of Galicia. The disco bomb was the only fatal explosion and was apparently accidental, said spokeswoman Rosa Conde. The other bombings were aimed at property owned by or linked to cocaine smugglers, regional officials said. The separatists claimed responsibility for the non-lethal bombs, said Pontevedra province official Jorge Parada. Police found and defused a seventh bomb at a bank after receiving a telephoned bomb threat from the separatists, he said. More explosives were later found in a rented car parked near the disco. The explosion destroyed the Clangor dance club and killed Ignacio Villar Regueiro, the suspected member of the Exercito Guerrilleiro de Pobo Galego Ceibe (The Guerrilla Army of the Free Galician People), Conde said. Two women were killed. Eleven of those injured were hospitalized in serious condition late Thursday, hospital spokesmen said. About 5,000 University of Santiago students marched silently through the city, the capital of the region, to protest the disco bombing, which injured some of their classmates. The separatist group, seeking independence for the four-province region in northwest Spain, has claimed more than 50 attacks since its first action in March 1986. It is the weakest of the three major separatist movements in Spain - the others being the Basques in northeast Spain and the Catalonians in the southeast. Although Galicians speak a separate tongue, closer to Portuguese than Spanish, the notion of a separate state has attracted little voter sympathy. The bombings against the traffickers, whose influence in Galicia has grown notably in recent years, could be an attempt to rally support for the separatists' goals, Parada suggested. The bombs destroyed or damaged a clothing boutique, a car dealership, a canning factory, a bar and a bank branch, all in Pontevedra province, Parada said. The targeted cocaine traffickers were among more than 30 people jailed last June in a major anti-drug sweep, officials said. The smugglers have been adapting routes long used to move contraband tobacco along Galicia's jagged coast to become major distributors of cocaine in Europe. So far this year, narcotics agents have captured more than a ton of Colombian cocaine in Galicia, almost a third of all the cocaine seized last year in Spain.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Demands Correction On Sunscreen Label
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration has told a sunscreen maker to stop claiming its products protect against a broad spectrum of the sun's rays. In an Oct. 5 letter released Thursday, the FDA told Schering-Plough Corp. officials to correct the labeling on ``Shade'' and any of its other sunscreen products by removing references to protection against ultraviolet A rays. The UVA protection claim is unproven because there are no generally recognized testing procedures for determining UVA protection, the FDA said. Schering-Plough includes on the labels of its ``Shade'' products the designation ``APP,'' the company's UVA protection factor expressed as a percentage of the spectrum blocked by the sunscreens. UVA rays are longer, less intense rays that are believed to contribute to cancer, wrinkles and other skin damage. Ultraviolet B, or UVB, rays are the shorter, burning rays that cause sunburn and some skin cancers. These rays can be measured and are often expressed as a sun protection factor, or SPF. The agency gave the company 10 days after receipt of the letter to advise the FDA what corrective measure had been taken. Otherwise, the FDA said it was prepared to take the matter to court. Lewis Nolan, a spokesman for Schering-Plough HealthCare Products, said the company wants to meet with the FDA as soon as possible to discuss the issue. ``The company believes that FDA questions over the type of information communicated to consumers about UVA protection can be resolved to the satisfaction of all parties,'' he said. In letters to several companies last February, the FDA warned sunscreen makers that claims of UVA protection were ``unsubstantiated, and therefore, unacceptable.'' UVA protection claims can give consumers a false sense of security, the FDA said, because sunbathers who believe they are adequately protected may stay out in the sun longer. The only company the FDA allows to make UVA protection claims is Herbert Laboratories' Photoplex. The product contains a new ingredient, which required it to undergo a more intensive effectiveness review by the FDA.

DOC.HEAD: Officer Disguised as TV Cameraman Rescues Girl Held at Gunpoint
LaserPhoto SAO1
DOC.TEXT: A police sergeant disguised as a television cameraman rescued a 14-year-old salesgirl held hostage for three hours on Wednesday by a thief pointing a gun at her head, a police spokesman said. He gave this account: Marcelo de Jesus Bastos, 20, and a friend entered a downtown sportswear store to steal tennis shoes, shorts and T-shirts. They panicked when police patrolling the area entered the store. Bastos took salesgirl Luciana Silva Oliveira hostage and his friend fled. Holding a gun to Miss Oliveira's head, Bastos walked out of the store but was cornered by more than 50 police in front of a nearby Pentecostal church. Police Sgt. Claudio Manoel Falcao de Figueiredo, disguised as a TV cameraman, slowly approahed Bastos. Seeing that the gunman's weapon was not cocked, he hurled the camera at him and grabbed the pistol. Miss Oliveira was rescued unharmed. The spokesman spoke on condition of anonymity.

DOC.HEAD: Kessler of New York Tapped for FDA
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Thursday he will nominate David A. Kessler, a lawyer-physician from New York City, to be commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration. Kessler is medical director of the Albert Einstein medical school in New York and teaches food and drug law at Columbia School of Law. The top spot at FDA has been vacant since Frank Young resigned under pressure nearly a year ago. James Benson has been acting FDA commissioner. The FDA has the responsibility of regulating a wide range of foods, drugs and cosmetics that account for about 25 cents of every dollar spent on consumer products in the United States. Kessler was a consultant to Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, for several years in the early 1980s. He is a member of an advisory panel formed to study problems at the agency, which has been under scrutiny ince an investigation of its generic drug division uncovered evidence of fraud and bribery last year. Kessler, 39, earned an undergraduate degree from Amherst College in Massachusetts, a law degree from the University of Chicago and a medical degree from Harvard. This will be the first time the position of FDA commissioner requires Senate confirmation. Previous commissioners have been appointed by the secretary of health and human services. The FDA is a part of the Health and Human Services Department.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Endorses Tax Deal, but Casts Doubt on Its Chances
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with Democratic plan, subbing 3 grafs for 3rd graf pvs and inserting 2 grafs after 10th graf pvs, The White; cuts last 4 grafs to shorten
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Thursday he could trade a modest increase in taxes on affluent Americans for a deep cut in capital gains rates but that it was ``a waste of time'' to try to push such a deal through a divided Congress. Instead, Bush called on lawmakers to put aside that battle and come up with a $500-billion deficit-reduction plan that contains neither element. Within hours, Democrats on the House Ways and Means Committee said they were well into writing an alternative budget that would not only raise taxes on rich Americans but push them higher than Bush has said he can accept. The committee's chairman, Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, said the changes would ``restore fairness to our tax system.'' He said the Democrats would meet again Friday to decide whether the package will also reduce the capital gains tax rate, but if it does ``it'll be a lot less rich'' than the administration's version. Congressional committees are working toward the goal of finding a half-trillion dollars in spending cuts and tax increases before the Oct. 19 deadline when the latest emergency spending authorization expires. By most accounts, higher Medicare premiums and taxes on alcohol, cigarettes and gasoline are likely to be included. ``We believe we have made progress,'' Senate Democratic Leader George Mitchell said after a meeting with Republican Leader Bob Dole and members of the Finance Committee. Trying to end two days of confusion surrounding the president's position on taxes, the White House laid out - but said it wouldn't push - a plan that would combine higher taxes on the 500,000 or so wealthiest Americans with lower capital gains rates for people who profit from sales of stocks, real estate and other investments. Bush, trying to put the pressure on lawmakers, said, ``The meter is running, but look, I can't dictate to Congress.'' His hypothetical package would increase the top rate on the highest-income people from 28 percent to 31 percent, ease the top rate from 33 percent to 31 percent for some 4.5 million slightly less well-to-do taxpayers and chop the rate on capital gains from 28 percent to 15 percent. That would do away with the ``bubble'' in the tax code, under which some upper middle-income taxpayers now pay a higher rate than the wealthiest. The White House held out the proposal as the outer limit of Bush's willingness to compromise on taxes. Of some Democratic proposals to raise the top rate to a flat 33 percent, Bush said, ``I cannot accept that.'' Thursday's proposal by the Ways and Means Committee Democrats, which they plan to offer on the House floor next week, would indeed raise the top rate for the richest Americans to 33 percent. And people earning more than $1 million annually would also pay a 10 percent tax surcharge. In addition, cuts to Medicare beneficiaries would total $10 billion over the next five years, down from the $28 billion budget summit negotiators agreed to last month and $7 billion less than the full Ways and Means Committee agreed to Wednesday. Bush's budget director, Richard G. Darman, told a Senate panel that the administration had privately proposed coupling a 31 percent top tax rate with a capital-gains cut last month but had been turned down by Democrats. ``It's my personal opinion that it's not negotiable on satisfactory terms on both sides,'' Darman told the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee. ``There just isn't a deal there.'' The developments came in a day of damage control at the White House, as Bush and his lieutenants sought to counter an impression of presidential indecisiveness on the continuing budget impasse. The president presented his case in three separate White House meetings on Thursday with House Republicans. At a picture-taking session at the outset of one of them, Bush said he was open to suggestions but had little flexibility on the size of a tax increase he could tolerate. Thus, he said he wasn't eager to press Congress to accept a plan with a 31 percent top rate and a 15 percent capital gains rate. ``I think it's a waste of time because I just don't think it can get through both houses of Congress,'' Bush said. The White House efforts to clarify Bush's position did little to end the budget stalemate on Capitol Hill. And they were initially accompanied by more of the same confusion that has reigned for the past few days on the subject. Rep. Bill Archer, R-Texas, a senior Republican on the tax-writing House Ways and Means Committee, emerged from a White House meeting announcing that the president was ready to endorse the 31-percent top rate, 15-percent capital gains plan. ``He is willing, and I think he'll speak to you today about this, to equalize the level at 31 percent,'' Archer said. His comments were quickly followed by a statement from White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater seeming to rule out pushing any such plan. Fitzwater said Bush believed that ``pursuing it in the current context may not only fail; it may legitimize something farther to the left that we cannot accept.'' In other words, a top rate above 31 percent. Among details Congress is working on, the House Ways and Means Committee voted Wednesday night to eliminate a heating-oil tax that was included in the budget bill voted down last week and to reduce the proposed increase in premiums that retirees pay for Medicare coverage of doctors' bills. The Medicare premium, now $28.60 a month, would rise gradually to $46.50 under the Ways and Means version. The annual $75 deductible that beneficiaries pay for hospital care before Medicare starts paying would be raised to $100 next year and to $125 in 1992. In addition, many tourists entering the United States as well as railroads and ship lines would face higher costs under other parts of the giant deficit-reduction bill Congress is piecing together.

DOC.HEAD: Bolshoi Ballet Artistic Director Forms Self-Sustaining Troupe
DOC.TEXT: Soviet ballet is going capitalist. Yuri Grigorovich, artistic director of the Bolshoi Ballet in Moscow, on Thursday announced formation of a new dance company that will be self-sustaining, rather than rely on government subsidies. Grigorovich said he took out a bank loan to start the company of 60 dancers, ages 19 through 25. The new company, the Bolshoi Ballet Grigorovich Company, will perform for the first time, ``The Nutcracker,'' Nov. 2 at the Bolshoi Theater. Then it will tour five American cities with ``The Nutcracker,'' starting at Texas A&M University in College Station, Texas, 90 miles north of Houston. The company will begin rehearsing at Texas A&M on Nov. 19, give its Western premiere there Nov. 23 and perform through Dec. 2. He declined to name other cities in the U.S. tour. At a news conference here, Grigorovich said through an interpreter that a ballet competition for young Soviet dancers was held in June. Twenty-one chosen are from the Bolshoi Academy. Rehearsals started in August. And if he can't pay back the loan? ``We'll probably be put where Dickens spent time - debtors' jail,'' Grigorovich said with a smile. Later he said, ``If everything goes as we have planned, tours all over the world and performing at home, I think we will be able to pay the loan back within the next year and a half.'' He said that building ``The Nutcracker'' sets cost 250,000 rubles and added, ``Nobody knows how to put it into dollars. Until we switch to a convertible currency, if we do, it will be very difficult to understand what the actual rate of exchange is.'' The Entertainment Corp., a British company, will manage the Bolshoi Ballet Grigorovich Co. outside the Soviet Union. Charles Dillingham, Entertainment Corporation U.S.A. president, said it's hoped companies doing business in the Soviet Union will sponsor new ballet productions and tours to their countries. The second tour will be to Australia. There also will be performances in the Soviet Union. The Olympic Center in Moscow, built for the 1980 Olympics, has offered to build a stage for the new company, Grigorovich said. Grigorovich said he took out the loan after the Bolshoi Theater's general director and the minister of culture told him they liked his idea for a young company, but had no money to support it. ``I decided to take advantage of the new rights that we have been given in our country. The three directors borrowed money from the bank and set up a new company on the basis of total self-accountancy and being self-sustained.'' He said some heavy industry companies in the Soviet Union already have given some moderate-size donations. ``Naturally in order to survive we need money.''

DOC.HEAD: Latin Actor Carlos Thompson Dead at 67
DOC.TEXT: Carlos Thompson, an actor whose passionate roles in 1950s melodramas gained him an enthusiastic following throughout Latin America, has died, an apparent suicide. He was 67. Thompson's body was found Wednesday afternoon in his apartment in fashionable Barrio Norte neighborhood with a bullet wound to the head, said Judge Luis Cevasco. Foul play was not suspected. Two letters were found with the body - one to his agent, Roberto Fraga, and one to actress Chunchuna Villafane, his partner in the stage production ``Love Letters.'' Neither explained the suicide, officials said. He was married to German actress Lilli Palmer, with whom he lived in Switzerland. After her death several years ago, Thompson returned to Argentina for the first time in nearly four decades. Born Juan Carlos Mundin Shafter Thompson on June 7, 1923, he made his first film at age 16. In the 1950s, the tall, dark-haired Thompson was a leading actor in Argentine melodramas that played to packed houses up and down the continent. Along with countryman Fernando Lamas, he was the epitome of the Latin lover. His many film roles included a villain in the ``Valley of the Kings,'' starring Yvonne de Carlo, and ``Flame of Treason,'' in which he played opposite Lana Turner. He also starred in ``El Tunel,'' based on the novel by the noted Argentine writer Ernesto Sabato.

DOC.HEAD: Government Calls on Jews to Rally at Wailing Wall
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8grafs to UPDATE with speeches at Wall, crowd of 30,000, many with guns. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `In New...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos JRL1,2
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Jews, many carrying guns, danced at the Western Wall to end the Sukkot festival Thursday, answering a government call to assert control over Judaism's holiest site after bloody riots there. ``The large crowd gathered here today shows that nothing in the world can break us,'' Parliament Speaker Dov Shilansky told about 35,000 people squeezed into the cobblestone plaza in front of the wall, more commonly known in the West as the Wailing Wall. Ultra-orthodox Jews carrying sacred Torah scrolls stood side by side with less observant countrymen waving Israeli flags. Hundreds of riot police, backed by soldiers, were deployed at the Wall and the adjacent Temple Mount. On Monday, at least 19 Palestinians were killed and 140 wounded when police fired at rioters stoning Jewish worshipers at the site. Many Palestinians living in the nearby Moslem Quarter stayed indoors as policemen escorted singing and dancing Jews through the area's narrow alleys to the Wall. Police posted at the gates of the Old City frisked Palestinians, and many were turned away. ``We will prevent young inciters from reaching the area,'' said Jerusalem's police commander, Arieh Bibi. Many worshipers carried submachine guns slung over their shoulders or had pistols tucked into their belts. ``Thousands of people came in answer to those who stoned us. They should learn that Jerusalem is indivisible,'' Religious Affairs Minister Avner Shaki told the crowd. In New York City, meanwhile, the U.N. Security Council held consultations to end the stalemate over criticism of the violence in Jerusalem. But a vote was not expected Thursday. Earlier Thursday, police battled Palestinian protesters in several Jerusalem neighborhoods. Police fired tear gas and rubber bullets to disperse about 300 Palestinians who tried to march from the city's Shuafat refugee camp to a major thoroughfare used by many Israelis. Clashes were also reported in the Issawiyeh neighborhood in east Jerusalem. Police fired tear gas to break up a march by about 150 Palestinians to the Temple Mount. ``World, listen to us! We are people who will never submit!'' the marchers chanted before being blocked by police from entering the compound. Inside, several hundred Arabs marched around the Dome of the Rock mosque with outlawed Palestinian flags. They chanted the Moslem battle cry ``Allahu Akbar,'' or God is Great. Christian leaders, including the Greek Catholic patriarch of Jerusalem, Lufti Laham, marched from the Church of the Holy Sepulcher to the Temple Mount to join Moslem clerics in prayer. Israeli officials called for the Jewish rally at the Western Wall at the end of the eight-day Sukkot festival. On the final day, Jews carry Torah scrolls in a festival procession. Israel's two chief rabbis, Avraham Shapiro and Mordechai Eliyah, had urged Jews to stage the processions in Jerusalem instead of in their hometowns to erase what they called ``the great blasphemy'' of Jews being stoned at the wall. Full-page newspaper ads from the Religious Affairs Ministry called for mass participation ``in view of the wicked attempt to desecrate the joy of our holiday near the remains of our temple.'' The Western Wall is the last remnant of the Jewish Temple destroyed in 70 A.D. On Temple Mount stand two mosques that constitute Islam's third-holiest site. The Moslems say this is where the Prophet Mohammed ascended to heaven. More than 1 million of the 1.7 million Palestinians in the occupid West Bank and Gaza Strip remained under curfew for a third day. Palestinians are observing a weeklong strike ordered by underground leaders of the 34-month-old uprising to protest the killings. In Arab east Jerusalem, Palestinian doctors said medical evidence indicated that Israeli police fired wildly in Monday's riot. ``There was indiscriminate shooting. In one case, we found 14 bullets in one man,'' Dr. Mustafa Barghouti, a physician at east Jerusalem's Mukassed Hospital, told reporters. Barghouti said that most of the wounded were struck by live ammunition or plastic bullets, which are lethal at close range. He said that of the 120 people treated at Mukassed, 32 remained hospitalized. Of those, eight were in critical condition, including a 4-year-old boy with a rubber bullet lodged in his brain, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Investigation Begins in Peru of Former President's Finances
DOC.TEXT: Former President Alan Garcia appeared on Thursday before a congressional committee that will decide whether he should face criminal charges for his role in the 1986 massacre of about 250 rebel prisoners. As a former president and a lifetime member of the Senate, Garcia cannot be prosecuted in criminal court unless the committee decides to revoke his immunity. Upon leaving the hearing, Garcia said he would ask that his immunity be lifted. He said he hopes to ``submit myself like any other common, ordinary citizen to common justice.'' A second congressional panel is investigating charges that Garcia used government funds to buy houses. Most political analysts still regard Garcia as the favorite to be elected president in 1995. No other strong political figure is in sight, they say. As chief of the center-left Aprista Party government from 1985 to 1990, Garcia presided over Peru's worst economic crisis. His term in office was also marked by increased rebel violence. Under the constitution, Garcia was ineligible to run for re-election in this year's presidential elections, won by Alberto Fujimori. A number of congressmen, especially from leftist parties, say Garcia should share responsibility for the massacre in June 1986, when soldiers and police put down riots in three Lima prisons. Most of those killed were members of the Maoist-oriented Shining Path rebel movement. Garcia publicly criticized lower ranking members of the security forces for summarily executing dozens of prisoners after they surrendered. He says he and the military chiefs of staff at the time of the massacre are guiltless. Fujimori also had problems with Congress on Thursday. It prevented him from attending a summit of Latin American leaders in Caracas, Venezuela. Prime Minister Juan Hurtado Miller said Fujimori abandoned plans for the trip after the government was unable to convene a special session of Congress Thursday afternoon. The constitution says Congress must approve all foreign travel by a president. If a president leaves without such approval, he forfeits his office. Fujimori's wife Susana was to travel to Caracas instead, Hurtado said. He said Foreign Minister Luis Marchand Stens will represent Peru at the meetings.

DOC.HEAD: Klan Member Receives Order To Turn Over Tapes
DOC.TEXT: Mister Rogers won't allow racial hatred in his neighborhood. A temporary restraining order issued Wednesday against the Missouri Knights of the Ku Klux Klan prohibits the Klan and three of its alleged members from imitating the popular children's television show on a racist telephone recordings. On the recordings, a man imitating Rogers makes racist and threatening remarks against blacks. The order issued by U.S. District Judge Howard F. Sachs requires the Klan to turn over the racist recordings by Friday. Lawyers for Fred M. Rogers, host of ``Mister Rogers' Neighborhood,'' and Family Communications Inc. said the recordings infringed on trademarks and copyrights by imitating the sound effects and song of the television show and Rogers' voice and speech patterns. The order named the Klan and three alleged members, Adam Troy Mercer of Independence; Michael Brooks, also known as M.B. Madison; and Edward E. Stephens, both of Kansas City. A hearing on whether to make the order permanent was scheduled for Oct. 20. A group of civil rights, community and religious leaders said last week that the telephone number was widely circulated among school children in the Kansas City area. The same phone number was used earlier this year to promote the philosophy of the Missouri Knights of the Klan. Rogers' lawyers said his television show is broadcast on 600 Public Broadcasting Service stations and reaches 7 million people a day.

DOC.HEAD: Agencies Find Ozone Levels Near Record Low Over South Pole
DOC.TEXT: The ozone hole over the South Pole this year is almost as severe as the record levels recorded in 1987, two federal agencies announced Thursday. Scientists at both the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said that the depletion of ozone over the pole reached a low point for the year last Tuesday. NOAA measurements, taken by balloon released from a South Polar station, showed that ozone at 9 to 11 miles altitude dropped to 15 parts per billion, less than 1 percent of normal. Normal concentration is 2,000 parts per billion. For the atmosphere as a whole above the station, ozone concentration was 50 percent of normal, nearly equaling the lowest level previously recorded, on Oct. 9, 1987. A NASA satellite measurement made a similar finding, the space agency said. Ozone in the upper atmosphere is important because the compound acts as a shield against ultraviolet radiation from the sun. UV radiation can cause skin cancer and is harmful to some plants. Scientists believe the Earth's ozone belt is being erroded by the action of chlorine and some other molecules that come from industrial pollution. The ozone layer over the South Pole thins severely each September and October, creating what scientists called an ozone hole. NOAA scientists said that ozone in the air over the South Pole is normally at 260 Dobson Units, a measure used for ozone concentrations. Last Tuesday, the measurement dropped to 130 Dobson units. NOAA spokesman William J. Brennan said that the record low, recorded on Oct. 9, 1987, is 126 Dobson units. Sam Oltmans, a NOAA physicist in Boulder, Colo., said the ozone depletion over the south pole has been following a pattern of dipping more severely every other year, with the low points coming on the odd years. The low registered on Tuesday is a change in this pattern, but Oltmans said it is unclear if the ozone depletion is trending toward a new, permanently lower level or not. ``The pattern has changed for the first time, but this was predicted because of a circulation pattern in the air currents,'' said Oltmans. He said the ozone hole in 1991 may revert to the alternate-year pattern that has been observed since 1979.

DOC.HEAD: Heavy Rain in Southeast, Record Cold in Texas, Arkansas
DOC.TEXT: Tropical storm Marco and a slowly moving cold front crossing the eastern part of the nation combined Thursday to produce heavy rain from Florida to Pennsylvania, while record cold pushed deep into the south-central states. Thunderstorms over central Florida produced wind gusts to 62 mph at Tampa during the morning. Moisture flowing northward along the front from Marco hit hardest in Georgia and the Carolinas, causing low-land flooding and damaging some roads and bridges. Southeastern Georgia got 4 to 7 inches of rain Wednesday and Thursday, including 7.70 inches at Hinesville, 7.30 inches at Jesup, and 6.60 inches at Statesboro, the National Weather Service said. Heavier 24-hour rainfall for South Carolina included 9.50 inches at Honey Hill and Schulerville, and 6.50 inches at Cross and Bonneau. In North Carolina, a storm total of 5.70 inches was reported at Kannapolis. Wednesday rainfall total of 4.10 inches at Charlotte was a record for the date. Rainfall totals in Virginia for the 12 hours up to 6 a.m. EDT ranged up to 5.10 inches at Marrowbone Reservoir. Parts of Pennsylvania and New York state got 1 to 2 inches. Showers developed behind a cold front crossing the north-central states and were widely scattered from Minnesota to northeastern Colorado. Snow showers were reported in southeastern Wyoming. Showers during the morning produced just enough rain at Akron, Ohio, to push the city's precipitation total for the year past their record of 53.36 inches, set in 1890. Normal precipitation at Akron is 35.90 inches for the year. Afternoon temperatures warmed into the 60s and 70s in the southern Plains after record morning lows in the upper 30s and 40s. Record lows were 49 at Brownsville, Texas; 44 at College Station, Texas; 45 at Corpus Christi, Texas; 31 at Fayetteville, Ark.; 42, a tie, at Fort Worth, Texas; 55 at Galveston, Texas; 33 at Hot Springs, Ark.; 44, a tie, at Houston; 42 at Midland, Texas; 33 at Ozark, Ark.; 44, a tie, at Port Arthur, Texas; and 42 at Waco, Texas. Overnight lows also were in the 30s and 40s from the northern and central high Plains to northwestern Minnesota. Temperatures also hit record lows in the Northwest, including 22 at Boise, Idaho, and 25 at Klamath Falls, Ore., and Portland, Ore., tied its record at 37. Thursday's low for the Lower 48 states was 18 at Gunnison, Colo.; McCall, Idaho; and Baker, Ore.

DOC.HEAD: Syrian Troops Move against Rebel General's Enclave in Lebanon
DOC.TEXT: Tank-led Syrian troops closed in on major routes to rebel Gen. Michel Aoun's enclave on Thursday and police said an attack appeared imminent to evict Aoun from Lebanon's Christian heartland. Hours earlier, Aoun's command said his air defenses fired on an unidentified jet fighter that streaked over his headquarters at the presidential palace. Police said a dozen columns of Syrian T-62 tanks and thousands of soldiers moved up to combat positions to support President Elias Hrawi's army along a five-mile front from southern Beirut to the central mountains east of the capital. Most of the buildup was shaping up under parachute flares at the Tiro district in Beirut's Shiite Moslem southern slums and at the Druse-inhabited suburb of Kfarshima, four miles farther southeast. France was making an 11th-hour mediation bid to persuade Aoun to abandon the palace and leave for Paris to form a government-in-exile there, a Hrawi government source said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The source said French Ambassador Rene Ala was in radio contact with Aoun, urging him to ``leave and spare Lebanon another bloodbath.'' ``If and when Ambassador Ala tells us his effort failed, our forces, backed by the Syrian army, will attack,'' he said. He mentioned no deadline. Several Beirut radio stations announced they were extending their broadcast beyond the regular midnight closing hour to report developments. Aoun's radio station broadcast a communique instructing inhabitants of his enclave, home for 150,000 Christians, to ring church bells all night to ``protest what looks like an imminent military thrust.'' An earlier Aoun communique said ``a warplane flew through the free area over the presidential palace at midafternoon and was confronted by anti-aircraft fire.'' Radio stations of rival Christian warlord Samir Geagea's Lebanese Forces militia said two Syrian MiG-17 jets made two reconnaissance runs over the hilltop palace at suburban Baabda, east of Beirut, and then flew eastward toward neighboring Syria. The reported overflight heightened fears that Hrawi's mainly Moslem army was poised to attack with Syrian backing to dislodge Aoun. The Syrians maintain 40,000 troops in Lebanon under a 1976 Arab League mandate to end the 15-year-old civil war between Moslems and Christians. Syrian forces have rarely scrambled jets in Lebanon's airspace. They apparently fear a clash with the Israeli air force, which dominates and routinely patrols Lebanese skies to film guerrilla activities of Palestinian and pro-Iranian Shiite fundamentalist factions. For the last three weeks, 20,000 Hrawi troops and Syrian soldiers have ringed Aoun's 80-square-mile bastion in a bid to starve the maverick general into submission. Aoun has vowed to fight unto death if attacked. The Syrian-aligned Hrawi fired Aoun as army commander and interim prime minister last November, when Hrawi was elected president by Parliament to enforce a peace plan brokered by the Arab League to end the civil war. But Aoun rejected Hrawi's presidency. Aoun has been holding out with 15,000 troops - most of them Christians - in part of Christian east Beirut and the adjoining Metn mountains, including the traditional seat of power in Baabda. Hrawi, Aoun and Geagea are Maronite catholics, the largest Christian sect that held power in Lebanon after it gained independence from France in 1943.

DOC.HEAD: Mistrial Declared in Bensonhurst Trial After Juror's Outburst
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with mistrial declared. Picks up 4th graf pvs, `What are you...' ^By RONALD POWERS
DOC.TEXT: A mistrial was declared Thursday for a defendant in the Bensonhurst racial slaying after a juror was dismissed for screaming across the courtroom at the victim's father. State Supreme Court Justice Thaddeus Owens, the trial judge, said Charles Stressler's criminal trial could not continue without 12 jurors. The alternate jurors in the case had been dismissed Wednesday when deliberations began. ``The defendant cannot waive a constitutional right,'' Owens said. ``The only alternative I have is to declare a mistrial.'' Earlier, after juror Lydia Bermudez told the judge that she could not remain impartial and he dismissed her, both defense and prosecution lawyers agreed to proceed with deliberations and accept judgment from the remaining 11 jurors. However, late Thursday, Owens called the lawyers back to the courtroom and said he had learned state law prohibited fewer than 12 jurors in a criminal case. Stressler will go on trial again Jan. 17, when a co-defendant is scheduled to be tried on an assault charge, court officials said. Of those charged in the Bensonhurst attack, one has been convicted of murder and two of lesser charges, and four still face murder trials. Ms. Bermudez' outburst occurred shortly before noon, after the jury had heard about an hour's worth of readback of Stressler's trial testimony. She began screaming at Moses Stewart, the father of murder victim Yusuf Hawkins. ``What are you looking at?'' she yelled at Stewart, sitting in the second row of seats in the courtroom's spectator section. ``She's talking to me?'' he asked. ``You've been doing that to me every day. You know what I'm talking about. You've been doing it every ... day,'' she shouted back at Stewart. After a few moments of silence in the stunned courtroom, Owens called the lawyers and Ms. Bermudez into his chambers to discuss how to handle the problem. A pool of two reporters were allowed into the discussions. With the judge and lawyers out of the courtroom and the jurors watching, Stewart stood up and walked toward the door, mumbling angrily: ``If she can't stand the father of the victim looking at her, get her ... out of here. I look at everybody on the jury. I don't care who she is, I look at everybody on the jury.'' In chambers, Stressler's lawyer, Jacob B. Evseroff, moved for dismissal of the indictment, mistrial or Stewart's exclusion from the courtroom. Owens denied all three motions. Ms. Bermudez told Owens she felt intimidated by Stewart and asserted: ``I don't need this aggravation from this freaking low-life ...'' ``Yesterday, he had everybody staring at me .... I don't need this. I don't need nobody staring at me,'' she told the judge and lawyers. Owens sent Ms. Bermudez out to join the other jurors, and called in Stewart to hear his side. ``Yesterday, I felt the same way,'' he said. ``I felt she has been trying to get into a staring contest with me. I'm looking at everybody, not just her.'' He said that as thevictim's father he had a right to sit in on all of the proceedings. ``I can't exclude him from the courtroom,'' the judge said. ``His argument is as compelling as hers. We'll see which one stares the other one down.'' When the reading back of testimony resumed, Stewart returned to the courtroom for a few minutes, but quickly left. Ms. Bermudez slumped in her chair, one hand hiding her face. Outside the courtroom during the lunch recess, prosecutors refused to comment. ``I have never, in 42 years, ever seen anything like this,'' Evseroff said. The panel began deliberating the case late Wednesday. Stressler, 22, is accused of murder, manslaughter, riot and other crimes in the Aug. 23, 1989, slaying of Hawkins, a 16-year-old black shot through the chest when he and three friends crossed paths with a mob of young whites in Brooklyn's Bensonhurst section.

DOC.HEAD: Volunteers Speed Up Soviet Potato Harvest
DOC.TEXT: An offer of free potatoes for anyone who helps gather them has enticed thousands of city dwellers into the fields and reduced the chances of hunger this winter, Soviet officials said Thursday. Two weeks ago, newspapers and television broadcasts warned that the harvest was proceeding very slowly and Moscow had stockpiled only 7 percent of the potatoes it would need to get through the winter. Fear of hunger spread through the capital, and consumers emptied grocery shelves, stashing sacks of potatoes in closets and basements. Since then, emergency measures - including ordering soldiers into the fields and offering to let volunteers keep half the potatoes they dig up - has doubled and even tripled the rate of the harvest in many areas, according to official reports. ``True, the weather has brightened up a bit, but the main thing is the massive turnout of (voluntary) helpers,'' Gennady Kulik, deputy prime minister of the Russian republic, said on the main television news program, Vremya. Vremya reported 160,000 Moscow residents, including 40,000 soldiers, were working in the fields. It showed city dwellers pulling potatoes from the soil and placing them in buckets - one for the state, then one for themselves. The TV report appeared aimed at reducing the crisis atmosphere as the country heads into winter amid economic confusion and shortages of many essential goods, ranging from gasoline to sausage, tobacco and paper. After weeks of debate, the national legislature is still trying to reach consensus on a plan to switch from central planning to a market-based system. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev initially endorsed a radical 500-day plan, then hesitated on whether to allow private ownership of farms, which he said should be decided by a national referendum. Thursday's upbeat TV broadcast said 75 percent of the Soviet Union's potato plantations have been harvested, and 40-50 percent of the planned allocation has been sent to industrial centers. Kulik said several cities, including Chelyabinsk, Sverdlovsk and Perm, already have filled their vegetable storage facilities and are fully provisioned for winter. He said Moscow has nearly finished stockpiling beets and is likely to get more carrots than planned. The city also has received 50,000 of the 165,000 tons of cabbage it is expected to use during the winter, and the cabbage harvest ``is going well,'' he said. The TV report did not say what percentage of Moscow's potato allocation was in hand. But Kulik said deliveries were arriving from across Russia, the largest of the Soviet Union's 15 republics, and ``measures are being taken to fully provide the capital'' with potatoes. A bumper crop of wheat also is being harvested, but much of it is expected to rot or go to waste because of poor transportation and inefficient bakeries. Last month, bread was in short supply in Moscow for the first time since the early 1960s. A crash program to raise bakers' wages and put bakeries back in operation eliminated the bread lines within weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Appropriations Panel Endorses Defense Bill
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS grafs 7-8: ``The measure,'' with panel approving only research money for the V-22 Osprey and restrictive language on SDI.
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Appropriations Committee approved a $268 billion defense bill Thursday that leaves intact President Bush's 1991 budget request for the B-2 stealth bomber. By voice vote, the panel adopted the legislation after turning aside an attempt by Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., to stop production of the B-2 at six planes. ``The greatest threat to our national security is not the Soviet Union; it is our spiraling debt,'' Leahy told his colleagues. The lawmaker also pointed to an Air Force review that found widespread problems with the aircraft's manufacturer, the Northrop Corp. Sen. Daniel Inouye, D-Hawaii and chairman of the Appropriations subcommittee on defense, argued that the measure would result in the United States spending $3 billion on ``an unfinished science project.'' The bill largely tracks the steps taken in August by the Senate when it approved separate legislation that outlined ceilings on defense spending for the fiscal year that began Oct. 1. The committee bill, which would appropriate actual funds, trims about $1 billion from Bush's $4.7 billion budget request for the Strategic Defense Initiative, cuts troop strength by 100,000 and provides $5.1 billion for two B-2 bombers in 1991 and components for more bombers in 1992. The measure includes $238 million for the V-22 Osprey tilt-rotor aircraft but not the $165 million in procurement money the House included for the program Bush has proposed canceling. The committee also adopted by voice vote an amendment restricting the way the administration can spend money on specific programs within SDI, commonly known as Star Wars. Leahy is expected to bring up the B-2 amendment again when the full Senate takes up the defense spending plan, possibly as early as Friday. Nevertheless, the panel's action was welcome news to Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee and a B-2 proponent. ``That'll help; that'll help. We're hanging on by stealthy fingers,'' Nunn said of the vote. Earlier in the day, Air Force Secretary Donald Rice pleaded with Congress not to decide the fate of the B-2 based on the Air Force review. ``It would be both inappropriate and unwise to use the review,'' Rice told the Senate Armed Services Committee at a hastily-scheduled hearing. ``Weapon systems must continue to be judged on the basis of the threat.'' Seeking to repair the damage to the B-2 bomber program from Air Force testimony earlier this week on major problems at Northrop, Nunn summoned Rice before the panel to discuss the service's review. On Tuesday, Brig. Gen. Robert W. Drewes, who led the eight-man team that conducted the study, told a House panel that Northrop was beset by problems in nearly every aspect of its business. Drewes identified weaknesses in systems engineering, the transition from research and development to production, software management, subcontract management, organization and personnel and business systems, which includes cost and schedule estimates. The review did not delve into problems associated with ongoing federal probes of the Los Angeles-based company. Northrop pleaded guilty in February to 34 counts of fraud and was fined $17 million, the largest criminal fine ever imposed on a defense contractor. The plea stems from charges that Northrop falsified reports on the air-launched cruise missile and conducted improper tests on the Harrier AV-8B jet.

DOC.HEAD: Riegle Returns $5,000 to Troubled Thrift
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Donald Riegle's campaign committee paid a troubled California savings and loan $5,000 this year for catering services provided at a 1987 fund-raiser, an aide said Thursday. Federal law prohibits corporations from donating to candidates for federal offices. Services are considered ``in-kind,'' or non-monetary, donations. They also are required to be listed in campaign finance reports. Riegle's campaign did not report the catering services, paid for by Columbia Savings and Loan, until this year.
