David Krawitz, Riegle's administrative assistant, said the senator's political organization did not receive an invoice for the California fund-raiser until late in 1989. ``It was our understanding that the bills had been paid,'' Krawitz said. ``When we were informed otherwise, the reimbursement was made.'' Columbia Savings and Loan chairman Thomas Spiegel put the costs on his company expense account, the Detroit News reported. Spiegel resigned from Columbia last year in the wake of accusations that he used the thrift's money for personal expenses. He is a close associate of Michael Milken, the junk-bond pioneer who has pleaded guilty to securities fraud violations and is awaiting sentencing. A spokesman for the Federal Elections Commission said he could not comment on whether the Riegle fund-raiser was financed in violation of the law. The spokesman, Scott Moxley, also declined to say whether the FEC would investigate the matter. Krawitz said it was his understanding that Riegle's campaign complied with the law by paying the invoice promptly after receiving it. Riegle was not aware of who paid for the catering services and has done nothing to benefit Columbia, Krawitz said. The Banking Committee handles legislation affecting the thrift industry. The fund-raiser was hosted by the California League of Savings Insttutions, Krawitz said. Riegle, who became chairman of the Senate Banking Committee in 1989, collected $25,000 in donations for his 1988 re-election campaign at the fund-raiser. He is one of five senators whose ties to another thrift - Lincoln Savings and Loan of Irvine, Calif. - are the subject of an ethics committee investigation. That thrift's former chairman, Charles Keating Jr., faces 42 counts of defrauding investors in the nation's biggest S&L failure, expected to cost taxpayers $2 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Latest Breakdown on Foreigners in Iraq, Kuwait
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Following is the breakdown of the number of foreigners in Iraq and Kuwait as of Oct. 10. Most estimates are based on embassy registrations. An undetermined number of U.S., British, French and West German citizens are being held in Iraq and Kuwait as human shields around strategic targets. Others are believed hiding in Kuwait. Some foreigners, mostly women married to Iraqis or Kuwaitis, have elected to stay. According to U.S. State Department figures, more than 900,000 of the estimated 3 million foreigners in Kuwait and Iraq on Aug. 2, when Iraqi forces overran Kuwait, have left.
AUSTRALIA - Before the Iraqi invasion, there were 127 Australians in the two countries. There are now 44 in Iraq and 50 in Kuwait, including diplomats.
AUSTRIA - Before the invasion, there were 70 Austrians in Iran and the same number in Iraq. One remains in Kuwait and three or four in Iraq, all of Arab background.
BANGLADESH - About 110,000 Bangladeshis were in Kuwait and Iraq when the invasion occurred. About 15,000 remain.
BELGIUM - Before the crisis, there were 38 Belgians in Iraq and 21 in Kuwait. Now 38 remain in Iraq, 2 in Kuwait.
BRAZIL - There were 450 Brazilians in Iraq and Kuwait Aug.2. Eleven are in Iraq now. None are believed to be in Kuwait.
BRITAIN - Before the invasion, there were about 3,000 Britons in Kuwait and 1,000 in Iraq. There are now about 1,000 in Kuwait and 420 in Iraq.
CANADA - Of the approximately 600 Canadians in Kuwait and 200 in Iraq before the invasion, about 50 remain in Kuwait and 50 in Iraq.

CHINA - Virtually all the 5,000 Chinese in Kuwait before the invasion have been evacuated. About 4,800 Chinese remain in Kuwait. About 150 citizens of Hong Kong and Taiwan have been evacuated from Kuwait and Iraq.
CYPRUS - There were 35 Cypriots in Iraq and Kuwait before Aug. 2. Twenty remain.
CZECHOSLOVAKIA - Of the 470 Czechs in Iraq and Kuwait Aug. 2, only six women married to Kuwaitis remain in Kuwait. Eighty remain in Iraq.
DENMARK - Some 35 Danes remain in Kuwait, with 41 in Iraq, out of a pre-invasion total of 100.
EGYPT - Some 335,000 Egyptians have left Iraq and Kuwait, out of more than 1.3 million in Iraq and 300,000 in Kuwait before the invasion.
FINLAND - There are 21 Finns in Iraq and 4 in Kuwait, compared to a total of 46 before the invasion.
FRANCE - There are about 100 French citizens in Kuwait and about 230 in Iraq. Before the invasion, there were 270 in Kuwait and 290 in Iraq.

GERMANY - The German Foreign Ministry refuses to give specific figures on how many of the pre-invasion total of 1,000 remain in Iraq and Kuwait, apparently because of nationals hiding out there. Latest reports mention only 43 being held in Iraq, with 30 still in Kuwait.
GREECE - There were about 127 Greeks in Kuwait and Iraq before the invasion. Now, 24 remain in Iraq, with 29 in Kuwait.
HUNGARY - There were 178 Hungarians in Kuwait and Iraq before Aug. 2. Now, 32 remain in Iraq, with none in Kuwait.
INDIA - There were about 170,000 Indians in Kuwait and 20,000 in Iraq before the invasion. About 90,000 remain in Kuwait with 6,000 in Iraq.
IRELAND - Of the 380 Irish citizens in Iraq and Kuwait before the invasion, there are now 235 in Iraq and about 25 in Kuwait.
ITALY - Before the invasion there were 160 Italians in Kuwait and 380 in Iraq. About 300 remain in Iraq and 10 in Kuwait.
JAPAN - About 790 Japanese were in Kuwait and Iraq at the time of the invasion. Ten are still in Kuwait and 309, including journalists, in Iraq.
LEBANON - Of the estimated 50,000 Lebanese in pre-invasion Kuwait, about 5,000 have left. None of the aproximately 10,000 in Iraq have been reported leaving.
NETHERLANDS - There were 200 Dutch nationals in Iraq and Kuwait before the invasion. About 160 remain in Iraq, with 13 in Kuwait.
NEW ZEALAND - Seven New Zealanders remain in Iraq and 11 in Kuwait out of a combined pre-invasion total of 36.
NORWAY - One Norwegian remains in Kuwait and 26 in Iraq, out of a pre-invasion total of about 46.
PAKISTAN - A total of about 130,000 Pakistanis were in Kuwait and Iraq before the invasion, and more than 40,000 have left.
PHILIPPINES - About 90,000 Filipinos were in Kuwait and 3,000 in Iraq before the invasion. About 2,300 remain in Iraq, with estimates of the number in Kuwait ranging from 5,000 to 15,000.
POLAND - There were 3,123 Poles in Kuwait and Iraq before the invasion. Now there are 1,213 n Iraq, mainly workers fulfilling project contracts.
PORTUGAL - About 15 Portuguese have left Kuwait and Iraq, leaving about 40 in Iraq and 34 in Kuwait.
ROMANIA - There were 3,055 Romanians in Iraq before the invasion. About 640 remain.
SOUTH KOREA - About 1,327 South Koreans were in Kuwait and Iraq, with 184 left in Iraq and nine in Kuwait.

SOVIET UNION - Nearly 10,000 Soviets were in Kuwait and Iraq before the invasion. There are now less than 5,000 in Iraq, mostly oil workers and construction specialists and 93 military advisers. About 2,000 are expected to leave by late October. There are none in Kuwait.
SPAIN - Of about 150 Spaniards in Kuwait and Iraq before the invasion, 19 remain in Baghdad and five in Kuwait.
SRI LANKA - About 150,000 Sri Lankans were in Kuwait and Iraq. About 65,000 remain in Kuwait, with 125 in Iraq.
SWEDEN - Out of a pre-invasion total of about 200, only a handful remain in Kuwait, with about 80 in Iraq.
SWITZERLAND - Before the invasion, there were 97 Swiss nationals in Kuwait and 71 in Iraq. None remain in Kuwait and about 70 in Iraq.
THAILAND - There were 7,000 Thais in Kuwait and about 1,150 in Iraq before Aug.2, with 874 still in Iraq now and 20 in Kuwait.

TURKEY - There were 3,000 Turks in Iraq and 1,000 in Kuwait at the beginning of the gulf crisis. Almost all have returned home, leaving about 60 in Iraq and about 40 in Kuwait, mostly women married to Kuwaitis.

UNITED STATES - Of the pre-invasion total of 3,500 Americans in Iraq and Kuwait, about 700 remained in Kuwait and 300-350 in Iraq until the most recent evacuation flight, which carried 321 Westerners from Kuwait to Baghdad and on to London on Oct. 10. Most of them were Americans.
VIETNAM - There were an estimated 17,000 Vietnamese in Iraq before the invasion. Most are still there. There are no figures available for Kuwait.
YUGOSLAVIA - There were about 6,000 Yugoslavs in Iraq and 1,000 in Kuwait Aug. 2. About 300 remain in Kuwait and 1,000 in Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Resolution to Block Much of Sale Introduced
DOC.TEXT: Administration officials sought to reassure friends of Israel on Capitol Hill Thursday as a senator introduced a resolution to disallow most of a $7.5 billion package of new weapons for Saudi Arabia. ``We must not become the unwitting arms supplier for a new Arab war of annihilation against Israel,'' said Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif. Cranston introduced a bill that would forbid President Bush to sell advanced M-1A2 tanks, Apache attack helicopters, multiple-launch rocket systems and TOW 2 missile launchers to the Saudis. The sale of those items, as well as Bradley fighting vehicles, Patriot anti-missile missiles, tanker planes, trucks and communications gear was proposed last month to help counter the threat posed by Iraq, whose troops are dug in along the border with Saudi Arabia following their conquest of Kuwait. At the same time, administration officials briefed members of the House Foreign Affairs Committee on what the United States is prepared to do for Israel to counterbalance the Saudi sale. The administration already has said it will provide Patriot anti-missile batteries for Israel, and is believed ready to provide advanced aircraft as well. Officials are looking at ``creative financing'' to make it possible for Israel to get the new equipment without paying for it, said Rep. Mel Levine, D-Calif. ``I would prefer not to see us go down this path with either of them,'' Levine said. ``We should be pushing regional arms control. But if the president is determined to sell these weapons to the Saudis, and the Saudis are determined to have them, we must also provide Israel with items needed to maintain its qualitative (military) edge.'' Levine said he would withhold until next week a decision on whether to oppose the Saudi sale.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Approves Payment of Overdue United Nations Bills
DOC.TEXT: The Senate voted Thursday to begin paying nearly half a billion dollars in past dues to the United Nations withheld in recent years because of congressional opposition to its practices. Reflecting an about-face prompted by the U.N.'s sponsorhip of a trade embargo against Iraq, the measure was included as part of a $19.6 billion money bill approved by a 91-7 vote. President Bush last January had requested $93 million as a 20 percent first installment on a five-year plan to pay off the $464 million in U.S. dues arrearages. But lawmakers had shown no inclination to go along with it until the U.N.'s sharp response to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in August and subsequent taking of American and other foreign hostages. In addition to the $93 million in past dues, the bill includes $31 million to cover U.S. arrearages for supporting U.N. peacekeeping forces in addition to the $91 million as the American share for their support in the current fiscal year. Also to support the military effort against Iraqi President Suddam Hussein, the bill adds $79 million for activating another five ships in the U.S. Ready Reserve Force for deployment to the Persian Gulf. Already, 41 ships in the 96-ship fleet have been put on active duty and sent to the region. The bill, which finances the operation of the Justice, State and Commerce departments for the fiscal year that began Oct. 1, also triples, to $162.5 million, Bush's request for investigating and prosecuting savings and loan fraud. ``The president and the attorney general just don't place a priority ... on these S&L criminals,'' said Sen. Fritz Hollings, D-S.C. ``They spend a fortune arranging stings but they have been stung more than 1,300 times and don't do anything about it.'' The bill now goes to a conference committee to iron out differences with a version passed earlier by the House. Voting against the bill were Sens. Dan Coats, R-Ind.; Kent Conrad, D-N.D.; Alan Dixon, D-Ill.; Jesse Helms, R-N.C.; Gordon Humphrey, R-N.H.; Steve Symms, R-Idaho, and Malcolm Wallop, R-Wyo. Sens. Pete Wilson, R-Calif., and Mark Hatfield, R-Ore., did not vote.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Said To Bar American Males Over 55 From Leaving
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS grafs 4-6: ``In a,'' Voice of America message to Americans still in Iraq and Kuwait
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi authorities, in a further tightening of restrictions, apparently have ruled that no American men 55 years and older will be allowed to depart Iraqi-controlled territory, the State Department said Thursday. Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler also described as ``simply outrageous'' Iraqi treatment of Americans and foreign-born family members who left Iraq and Kuwait on Wednesday aboard a U.S.-chartered evacuation flight. Aboard the flight were 321 persons, including 270 U.S. citizens and their foreign-born family members. In a message to Americans still in Iraq and Kuwait broadcast over the Voice of America, the State Department said no more charter flights were scheduled. ``However, we will continue to assist with the travel arrangements for all U.S. citizens and thir foreign-born family members who want to depart and are allowed to do so,'' the broadcast said. The message again urged Americans to ``keep a low profile and exercise caution,'' and concluded, ``Your release is of the utmost importance. We will not stop our efforts to gain your freedom until the last American is home.'' Ms. Tutwiler said Iraqi authorities interrogated and harassed the departing passengers both at a Kuwait City hotel and at a checkpoint en route to the airport in Basra, forcing lengthy delays. Some evacuees said they were threatened with weapons. A dozen people who signed up for the flight were prevented by the Iraqis from leaving, she said. The delays forced a postponement from Thursday to Friday in the passengers' arrival at Raleigh-Durham airport in North Carolina. The passengers spent the day Thursday in London. Virtually all the departing Americans were women and children. Ms. Tutwiler said U.S. officials have received reports that men over age 55 are now being prevented from leaving. She said previous indications were that Americans males of that age were exempted by Iraqi authorities along with those under 18. She declined to give estimates of the number of Americans left in Iraq and Kuwait. Other officials said, however, there were somewhat more than 100 Americans on the flight, most from Kuwait. Based on department estimates dating back to last month, that would leave perhaps 775 to 925 in the two countries, taking into account Wednesday's departures. About 104 are being detained and the remainder are the targets of house-to-house searches by Iraqi soldiers.

DOC.HEAD: Tribe Can't Sue State for Past Damages, Judge Rules
DOC.TEXT: Wisconsin's Chippewa Indians cannot sue the state for an estimated $300 million in damages resulting from their being denied hunting and fishing rights for more than a century, a federal judge ruled Thursday. The tribe's only hope to collect damages rests in persuading the federal government to sue the state on behalf of the Chippewa, U.S. District Judge Barbara Crabb said, citing recent Supreme Court interpretations of the U.S. Constitution's 11th Amendment. The Supreme Court's analysis ``leaves the plaintiff tribes without an adequate remedy for the wrongs they have suffered,'' Crabb said. The 11th Amendment gives states ``sovereign immunity'' from lawsuits by tribes and other foreign nations. ``I find this wholly at odds with the principle ... that federal law operates to provide individuals with relief for deprivations of their `rights, privileges or immunities secured by the Constitution and laws' caused by state actors,'' she said. The federal government was unlikel to join the case, she said. The ruling reversed a 1984 District Court decision that the tribe could sue the state based on a federal law designed to help tribes resolve treaty disputes. The lawsuit was to have been tried last month but was postponed by Crabb. Her ruling dismisses the claims. Earl Charlton, an attorney for the Mole Lake Chippewa band, described the ruling as a minor setback and said the tribe would appeal 7th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Chicago. ``The state still has to resolve this matter. The decision certainly doesn't address the merits of the case,'' he said. ``This doesn't vindicate the past actions of the state of Wisconsin in violating tribal rights.'' Republican Gov. Tommy Thompson and other state officials were delighted with the decision. The ruling confirmed that ``Wisconsin is not responsible for any damages regarding the exercise of the Indian's treaty rights,'' Thompson said. Under 19th century treaties ceding Indian territory to the U.S. government, Wisconsin's six Chippewa bands retain the right to spear fish, hunt and cut timber off reservations on 23,929 square miles of public land in northern Wisconsin. Since a court affirmed those rights in 1983, the Chippewa have encountered huge and sometimes violent protests by non-Indians who claim the treaty rights give the state's 4,000 Chippewas an unfair edge and threaten to deplete fish and timber. Thursday's ruling is the second setback this year in the 16-year court battle with the state over treaty issues. In May, Crabb reversed another ruling that had allowed the tribe 100 percent of the safe allowable harvest of resources on ceded lands. She ruled that the resources be shared equally between the state and tribe. Efforts to negotiate settlements with two of the most active spearfishing bands of Chippewa were defeated by the tribe last year. Those agreements would have provided the tribes millions of dollars over 10 years if the tribes curtailed some of their treaty rights.

DOC.HEAD: Family Wins $850,000 in Fetal Injury Case
With AM-Pledge-Abortion, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A case that hinged on whether a 28-week-old fetus was covered by the mother's insurance has been settled by a $850,000 payment to the family. American Global Insurance Co. had appealed a $1 million judgment in favor of Sharon and Andre Bonte and their daughter, Stephanie, to the state Supreme Court. The case is believed to be only the second of its kind to have reached a state supreme court. In a similar case in 1981, the Alabama Supreme Court ruled that the phrase ``resident of the same household'' was ambiguous and ruled for the family. Sharon Bonte gave birth the day after she was struck by a car while walking in Manchester in June 1988. The Bontes said that as a result of the accident, Stephanie, now 2, was born with cerebral palsy, a nervous disorder usually caused by damage to the brain before or during birth. Andrew Dunn, American Global's lawyer, said the settlement, reached last week, averted two other lawsuits. One, on behalf of Stephanie, would have charged Sharon Bonte with negligence for crossing the street where there was no crosswalk, Dunn said. The other would have sued New Hampshire Insurance Co. - American Global's sister company and Sharon Bonte's employer - as a landowner, because the accident happened in front of its offices, he said. ``More than $850,000 was involved,'' Dunn said. ``The settlement in this case also dealt with some issues that may come up in connection with those two threatened claims.'' The Bontes' lawyer, Thomas Craig, did not immediately return calls Thursday, when the Supreme Court was to have heard oral arguments. In briefs filed with the high court, Craig had argued that the fetus was a member of the Bonte household and should have been covered under the policy, which covers relatives who are ``residents of the same household.'' But Dunn said the usual meaning of ``relative'' doesn't include a fetus in the womb. ``It's a contractual issue. It's not an issue of whether the fetus is a person, of whether the fetus is alive, of when life begins,'' he said. ``It's not an issue of any cosmic importance - it's not a philosophical issue.'' Lawyers agreed the case was unrelated to abortion because it did not consider whether a feuus has legal rights generally, only whether it qualified as a resident under the insurance company's definition.

DOC.HEAD: Civil Rights Sponsors Offer Last-Minute Concessions
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New throughout with conference committee revamps bill
DOC.HEAD: By MIKE ROBINSON
DOC.TEXT: Sponsors of a civil rights bill designed to combat job discrimination made last-minute concessions to the Bush administration Thursday in a move to save the measure from a threatened presidential veto. Critics said, however, President Bush still appeared poised to reject the bill on grounds that it would usher in minority hiring quotas. ``At least in my contacts with the administration, they think this so-called compromise does more harm than good,'' declared Rep. Harris Fawell, R-Ill., a leading critic, as sponsors overhauled the legislation. The bill would overturn six Supreme Court decisions last year and has been the top item on the civil rights movements priority list in recent months. Major provisions would reshape complex courtroom procedures in a way that would make it harder for employers to defend themselves in lawsuits alleging discrimination in the workplace. Other provisions range from a ban on racial harassment on the job to a obstacles to reopening court-approved minority hiring agreements. The Bush administration has been saying the bill would make it so hard for employers to win discrimination suits that they would turn to hiring quotas as a way of protecting themselves in advance from such charges. A House-Senate conference committee that had already produced a compromise version of the bill went back to work Thursday night and adopted a seven-point package of concessions designed to win Bush's backing. Even if Bush remains opposed, supporters said, the changes might attract enough support for the bill to override the threatened veto. The core of the concession package would offer employers greater leeway in defending against discrimination suits. It also would make clear that nothing in the bill was designed to encourage the use of hiring quotas. The package was adopted 11-8 by the conference committee. Rep. Craig Washington, D-Texas, who had supported earlier versions of the bill, voted with critics against it. He said the changes turned the measure into ``the hollow shell of a civil rights bill.'' He said long delays in sending the bill to the White House most likely will enable Bush to stop the bill with a pocket veto if he so desires. Under a pocket veto, a president is able to kill bills by simply refusing to sign them when Congress is not in session. Lawmakers are getting ready to leave Washington and get in a round of campaigning before November elections. ``I'm not criticizing them; they're senators and stuff,'' Washington said, nodding toward Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass. ``But we could have done this three weeks ago.'' Rep. Augustus F. Hawkins, D-Calif., also a supporter of earlier versions of the bill, said it was time to ``come up with something we hope is more in line with the president's views.'' Peter Lunnie, head of the Fair Employment Coalition, a business group critical of the bill, said after the conference committee met that it appeared Bush would not be swayed by the changes. He said there was a White House meeting last week at which ``Sen. (Orrin) Hatch (R-Utah) was told point blank the language was unacceptable to the president and they would recommend that he (Bush) veto this bill.'' Lunnie said Hatch received that message at the meeting from White House counsel Boyden Gray and Attorney General Dick Thornburgh. Civil rights advocate William Taylor said after the conference committee meeting, however, that it still was not fully clear that Bush would wield his veto pen when the bill reached his desk. ``Everybody has heard it from Boyden Gray, some people have heard it from Thornburgh, but nobody has heard it from Bush,'' Taylor said. Rep. Hamilton Fish, R-N.Y., said earlier it was unclear whether Bush would approve the fresh version. Fish said the decision to go ahead with the last-minute concessions represented a recognition by the civil rights movement that the choice now was between winning Bush's support or coming away empty-handed and refighting the battle next year. ``In a sense they have watered down their work product,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Currency Will Be Devalued, Official Says
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet ruble will be devalued by about 70 percent in relation to the dollar under Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's economic reform program, a Soviet economic official said Thursday. Ivan Ivanov, deputy chairman of the state Foreign Economic Commission, said the new exchange rate for international commercial transactions would be 1.8 rubles per $1, compared with the current .56 ruble to the dollar. The official news agency Tass quoted Ivanov as telling a legislative committee that the new rate would be introduced by presidential decree. Tass did not say when the devaluation would take effect. But it said the rate was calculated on the basis of new Soviet wholesale prices that are scheduled to become effective Jan. 1. The new rate will ``make exports more profitable for Soviet producers and facilitate the streamlining and restriction of imports, which have been growing rapidly since Soviet enterprises were granted the right of free access to the foreign market,'' Tass said. The chairman of the Soviet State Bank, Viktor Gerashchenko, had said this week a devaluation was likely. Gorbachev's economic plan, which envisions a gradual switch from central planning to a market-based economy, is under consideration by a committee of economists and politicians appointed by the Supreme Soviet. The committee is scheduled to issue a report by Oct. 15, after which the plan could be approved by the national legislature. Lawmakers already have voted to give Gorbachev emergency powers to make the transition to a market, and he has begun issuing decrees. Ivanov said the devaluation would not affect the exchange rate for tourists converting dollars to rubles at Soviet banks. That rate would remain at 6 rubles to the dollar, he said. Unlike most countries' currencies, whose exchange rates fluctuate with free trading on international markets, the ruble's rate is set artificially by the Soviet government. On the black market, a dollar can fetch 15 to 30 rubles.

DOC.HEAD: House Democrats Write Own Budget Plan Hitting Rich
DOC.NOTE: EDs:INSERTS new grafs 7-8: ``In the,'' with Bentsen proposals
DOC.TEXT: Democrats on the House Ways and Means Committee began writing their own budget plan Thursday, stuffing it with higher taxes for the rich and easing the burden other deficit-reduction proposals put on the poor and the middle class. The plan is the most liberal of the burgeoning number of budget proposals floating around Capitol Hill. Democrats insisted they wanted to reverse the trends of a decade in which they said the poor got poorer. ``Contrary to what you hear, doing something to reverse this deplorable trend is not preaching class warfare,'' said Ways and Means Chairman Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill. The new proposal would impose a top 33 percent income tax bracket on the wealthiest Americans, ending the current ``bubble'' in which the top bracket drops from 33 percent to 28 percent. The rich would have to pay a 10 percent surtax on any income surpassing $1 million. The minimum tax the wealthy pay after all exemptions and deductions, now 21 percent, would be increased to 25 percent. The full Ways and Means Committee adopted a separate plan on Wednesday containing none of those increases. That plan, the Democratic proposal and a Republican alternative are expected to be debated on the House floor next week. In the Senate Finance Committee, meanwhile, Chairman Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, continued reshaping his proposal in an effort to attract bipartisan support. For example, the latest version would limit itemized deductions of people with incomes over $100,000 a year; raise to $125,000 the maximum amount of annual wages subject to the tax that finances Medicare, and allow monthly premiums paid by Medicare beneficiaries to rise more slowly than negotiators had proposed. Rostenkowski said Democrats were still discussing whether to put a cut in the capital gains tax in the package. He said if it were included, it would be less generous than what the White House wants. Bush has said he wants the top rate on capital gains taxes - levied on profits from the sale of assets - dropped to 15 percent. Currently, capital gains are taxed at the same rate as ordinary income. Under the Democratic plan, the gasoline tax would be increased by 3 cents per gallon. That is 8 cents less than the full committee proposal and 9 cents less than President Bush and congressional leaders agreed to during their budget summit. The federal tax on gasoline is now 9 cents per gallon. The Democrats would limit cuts to Medicare beneficiaries to $10 billion over the next five year. That would be $7 billion less than the full committee's proposal and $18 billion below the budget summit agreement. As a result, the Democrats would boost the monthly premium Medicare beneficiaries pay for doctors' coverage - now $28.60 - to $29.90 next year and $46.20 in 1995. In addition, the Democratic proposal would increase the current $75 annual deductible beneficiaries pay for doctors' expenses to $100 - below the full committee and budget summit proposals. The Democratic proposal would also: -Increase from $51,300 to $100,000 the ceiling on annual earnings from which the 1.45 percent Medicare tax is deducted. The full committee raised the amount to $73,000. -Drop the 2 percent tax on petroleum fuels the budget summit had produced. -Include many elements of the full committee's plan, such as a 10 percent tax on private planes and other luxury items and a doubling of the 16-cent tax on six-packs of beer. The top income tax bracket now drops from 33 percent to 28 percent at $162,770 taxable income for a childless married couple filing a joint return and at $97,620 for a single taxpayer. The Democratic proposal would extend the 33 percent bracket to include all additional taxable income above these bracket points.

DOC.HEAD: House Votes to Scrap Anti-Obscenity Curbs on Arts Endowment
DOC.TEXT: The House on Thursday rebuffed conservative demands for strict new anti-obscenity curbs on the National Endowment for the Arts and voted overwhelmingly to let the courts decide whether federally subsidized arts projects are obscene. After an emotional five-hour debate, the House approved a bipartisan compromise sponsored by Reps. Pat Williams, D-Mont., and E. Thomas Coleman, R-Mo., that would penalize grant recipients if they are subsequently convicted of violating obscenity laws. Passage of the Williams-Coleman measure on a 382-42 roll call vote signaled a major reversal of congressional sentiment on the politically explosive issue of federal support for art that some lawmakers consider offensive. A year ago, in the heat of a controversy over support for exhibitions of works by photographer Robert Mapplethorpe and artist Andres Serrano, Congress approved explicit anti-obscenity restrictions on the endowment at the urging of Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C. On Thursday, the House rejected even more stringent curbs proposed by Rep. Dana Rohrabacher, R-Calif., and overwhelmingly defeated a separate proposal to abolish the $171 million federal arts agency altogether. Williams told reporters the House's resounding approval of the compromise bill was ``a bigger victory in favor of tolerance and freedom of expression than I had expected.'' He predicted it would make it easier for the Senate to resist pressure from Helms and his allies for new restrictions on the endowment. Like a similar measure awaiting Senate floor action, the House bill would scrap the current Helms restrictions on the endowment and rely on the courts to make determinations of obscenity. The House bill also would renew the endowment's statutory authority for three years and order reforms in its grant-making procedures with the aim of making the endowment's decisions more responsive to the interests of the taxpaying public. At the request of Republican negotiators, the bill provides an increase in the share of grants allocated to state arts agencies from 20 percent to 35 percent over three years. The House planned to vote Friday on a separate appropriations bill that would boost the endowment's budget from $171 million to $180 million in the current fiscal year. That bill, approved by the House Appropriations Committee, omits any content restrictions on works subsidized by the endowment. It also would order endowment chairman John E. Frohnmayer to scrap a controversial requirement that grant recipients sign an anti-obscenity pledge before they can receive federal money. Before it approved the compromise bill, the House voted 249-175 to defeat Rohrabacher's proposal to prohibit support for works that depict ``sexually explicit conduct'' or sexual exploitation of children, attack religion, defile the American flag or include ``an actual human embryo or fetus.'' House members also buried, 361-64, a proposal by Rep. Philip M. Crane, R-Ill., to abolish the agency because of its past support for what Crane called ``obnoxious, perverted and sick'' arts projects. Rohrabacher warned his colleagues that ``the American people are watching this debate'' on television, implying that House members who opposed his amendment would face the wrath of voters in the Nov. 6 congressional elections. He said the compromise bill was a fraudulent ``political fig leaf'' that would do nothing to halt the flow of offensive art allegedly subsidized by the arts endowment. Liberal lawmakers denounced Rohrabacher's tough proposed crackdown as a possibly unconstitutional attempt to intimidate artists and squelch freedom of expression. Williams said Rohrabacher's proposal was ``copper-riveted, iron-clad censorship of the first degree.'' Rep. James Scheuer, D-N.Y., called it ``an offensive and misguided measure.'' But Rohrabacher won support from several conservatives, including Rep. Ron Marlenee, R-Mont. ``It's a fix ... that allows the junkies to continue to peddle their depraved, sadistic wares with impunity,'' said Marlenee, who may be fighting the liberal Williams in 1992 for the single Montana House seat expected to emerge from redistricting based on the 1990 census. Under the compromise, a grant recipient convicted of violating obscenity statutes would be required to give the government its money back. The original bill would have barred a guilty artist from receiving further NEA grants for three years, but the House voted to allow the artist to apply for a new grant as soon as the NEA had been repaid. The bill says that obscenity ``shall not be funded'' by the endowment. The current ban forbids the NEA to support any works that ``may be considered obscene,'' including depictions of homosexual or sadomasochistic activities and the sexual exploitation of children. Before debate, Rohrabacher denounced the Williams-Coleman bill as a fraud that would ``open the door to federal subsidies for anything - no matter how freakish, pornographic or sacrilegious - that an NEA panel would approve.'' Rohrabacher announced the support of 20 conservative groups, including Phyllis Schlafly's Eagle Forum, Pat Robertson's Christian Coalition and the Rev. Donald Wildmon's American Family Association, for his amendment to impose specific anti-obscenity restrictions on the arts endowment. When the House takes up the money bill Friday, Rep. Ralph Regula, R-Ohio, plans to introduce a floor amendment that would forbid support for obscene or indecent works as defined by the Supreme Court and the Federal Communications Commission. Regula's proposal says the endowment chairman shall ensure that federal supported works are ``sensitive to the nature of public sponsorship,'' respect ``general standards of decency'' and are ``appropriate for a general audience.''

DOC.HEAD: Maharishi Says Meditation, not United Nations, Will Bring Peace
DOC.TEXT: The Maharishi Mahesh Yogi said Thursday his solution to the Persian Gulf crisis was to have hundreds of thousands of professional meditators mediate worldwide to try to harmonize world consciousness. The Maharishi, leader of the Transcendental Meditation Movement, told an internationally broadcast news conference in the Netherlands that the United Nations ``is like a dead body'' and only mass meditation can bring bliss. He said 7,000 skilled meditators in the gulf region could improve regional and international atmospheres and make peace inevitable. ``We cannot rely anymore on the political arena of the world,'' the Maharishi said from his European headquarters in the Dutch city of Vlodrop. ``Governments and political organizations are incompetent to bring about peace and are of no significance. ``What happened to Kuwait now can happen to any country or little emirate here and there. All the military might and efforts against terrorism are not succeeding.'' His meditation peace plan for the gulf was heard at the United Nations and in Washington; Austin, Texas; Cleveland; Boston; Kansas City; Chicago; Ottawa; Montreal and Toronto. Two days ago the United Nations was the site of an international TV hookup to commemorate what would have been the 50th birthday of the late John Lennon, one of the Beatles who were followers of the Maharishi. U.N. officials said they make U.N. conference rooms available to worthy organizations without any rental fee and bill them only for the cost of services and overtime. At the yogic hookup Thursday, only about 30 professional people in business suits and a few journalists gathered in a small basement conference room at U.N. headquarters and there was no transcendental meditation. After an opening statement, the Maharishi took questions. Asked about the United Nations that recently has had some peacekeeping success, he said: ``It is a nebulous organization. . . . The Security Council cannot guarantee security to any part of the world. . . . It's like a dead body.'' He said, in answer to a question, that U.N. peacekeepers with light sidearms should be replaced by professional, paid meditators. ``That would be more successful and productive,'' he said. ``U.N. efforts in the gulf have failed,'' the Maharishi said. ``That is why we appeal to the people of the world to be united now.'' His followers claim that 7,000 is a magic number for creating a powerful meditative consciousness that can affect urroundings and behavior. They say this has been proved in more than 500 scientific studies. The Maharishi said responsible governments should designate special groups of 7,000 people who then would be taught meditation and a form of levitation. ``We would train them to `fly' and that would be the end of all unfortunate evils in the world.'' The title maharishi signifies a Hindu teacher of mysticism.

DOC.HEAD: Ousted President Manigat Allowed Back in Haiti, to Run Again
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 10 `To ensure' to ADD elections set for Dec. 16. Picks up 11th graf, `At least...'
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) - Haiti's interim government said Thursday it would allow deposed civilian President Leslie Manigat to return from exile in the United States and run for president. ``I am returning to rally men of goodwill to see what can be done to save our critically ill country,'' Manigat said in a telephone interview from New York. He said he planned to come back next week. In July, the provisional government of Ertha Pascal-Trouillot refused Manigat entry for ``reasons of state,'' fearing he intended to return in his capacity as president. But in a communique released Thursday, Interior Minister Joseph Maxi said Manigat was free to come back. The government did not give a reason for changing its mind but the refusal to allow Manigat in had been widely criticized by political and human rights groups - particularly after two figures associated with brutal regimes were allowed to return this year. Manigat was deposed in a military coup on June 19, 1988, six months after he was elected in an election widely believed to have been rigged by the army. He was the army's choice in the January 1988 balloting, held after elections the previous November were canceled when ruffians supported by the army massacred 34 voters at the polls. Fearing for their lives, most Haitians stayed at home in the 1988 race, undermining the credibility of Manigat's presidency. A former history and political science professor, Manigat has been teaching in the United States, Geneva and Paris. He is president of the National Progressive Democratic Rally, a conservative Christian Democratic party. He has repeatedly stated his intention to run again for president. To ensure a free and fair vote, the Dec. 16 elections will be monitored by the United Nations, the Organization of American States and the Caribbean Economic Community. At least 20 other presidential candidates have said they would run for the presidency. The president-elect will take office Feb. 7, 1991, on the fifth anniversary of the overthrow of dictator Jean-Claude ``Baby Doc'' Duvalier. Duvalier fled to exile in France in 1986, ending 29 years of brutal Duvalier family rule. Political turmoil and violence have plagued this poor Caribbean nation since Duvalier's fall.

DOC.HEAD: CBS' New Late Show Yields Lower Ratings
DOC.TEXT: CBS' new late-nigt ``America Tonight'' news program was third in late-night ratings its first week and had a smaller audience than the entertainment shows it replaced, ratings figures showed Thursday. The half-hour series co-anchored by Charles Kuralt and Lesley Stahl averaged a 2.3 rating last week, two-tenths of a ratings point less than the preceding week's entertainment shows. ABC News' ``Nightline,'' the main competition of ``America Tonight,'' was well ahead of the latter, averaging a 4.7 rating. NBC's ``Tonight'' show was the ratings leader, averaging a 5.6. Each ratings point represents 931,000 homes. CBS research analyst Michael Eisenberg said the new show's first week wasn't typical because the show's 11:30 p.m. broadcast was delayed twice last week, the first time by a presidential speech, the second by a CBS telecast of the baseball playoffs. With the playoffs continuing this week and CBS televising the World Series next week, there'll be more delays of ``America Tonight,'' he said. He said it won't be until the week of Oct. 22-26 that the new show has what would resemble a typical week.

DOC.HEAD: Compromise Floated
DOC.TEXT: The two key adversaries blocking Senate action on a bill to re-regulate cable television reached a compromise Thursday that would allow cable companies to continue signing programming deals that freeze out satellite dish owners. Sens. Al Gore, D-Tenn., and Timothy Wirth, D-Colo., reached the accord after the bill's manager, Sen. Daniel Inouye, D-Hawaii, last month declared it ``dead and buried'' for the year because of threats of a filibuster by Wirth and a veto by President Bush. Bush's veto threat still stands, but Gore and Wirth agreed Thursday on ``exclusivity'' contracts that would require the Federal Communications Commission to determine their use illegal if abused. Gore, who wanted to give satellite dish owners and other cable competitors like so-called ``wireless cable'' operators better access to the programming produced by the cable industry, said he hoped the bill could be brought to the Senate floor early next week. ``To those who would continue to block its consideration on behalf of the cable industry or the White House, I would only say that such a move would backfire,'' he said, threatening to introduce a tougher bill on the industry next year. Both the Senate bill and a similar measure passed by the House last month would require cable operators to provide a ``basic tier'' of cable service - local and public TV stations plus government-access channels - at rates regulated by the FCC. Including converter boxes on TV sets and remote controls, the Consumer Federation of America, the major promoter of the legislation, estimates the basic service should cost a cable subscriber no more than $5 a month. The FCC also could adjust rates for some other cable channels such as Cable News Network, MTV and ESPN, but excluding the premium services like Home Box Office and Cinemax, in response to consumer complaints. The legislation is a response to a growing wave of consumer complaints about excessive rates and poor service in many areas after the industry was deregulated by Congress in 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Navajo Plant Not the Only Culprit
DOC.NOTE: EDs: ADDs two grafs reaction
DOC.TEXT: A major coal-burning power plant near the Grand Canyon contributes significantly to wintertime air pollution over the popular tourist attraction, but it is not the only culprit, the National Research Council said Thursday. The council's report is expected to be used by operators of the plant, the Navajo Generating Station, as an argument for not requiring expensive pollution controls. The Environmental Protection Agency last year proposed that the power plant 16 miles from Grand Canyon National Park be required to reduce sulfur dioxide emissions by 90 percent. To do so, the operators of the plant likely would have to install expensive ``scrubber'' technology. Critics of the EPA proposal say that the canyon's air pollution problems cannot be solved by just reducing emissions from the power plant. Sulfur dioxide can be converted in the atmosphere to sulfate compounds in the form of microscopic aprticles, which are an important contributor to haze in certain atmospheric conditions, particularly in air stagnation over the canyon and when in clouds. The issue of air pollution over national parks has been a thorny one for lawmakers trying to work out a new Clean Air Act. The House version of the bill calls for stricter pollution controls to protect parks but the Senate so far has agreed only to study the issue. The EPA proposal for tighter pollution controls at the Arizona power plant came after the National Park Service concluded a $2 million study that purported to tie extensive wintertime haze over the canyon to sulfur emissions from the plant. But Interior Secretary Manual Lujan dismissed the National Park Service study as inadequate and asked for a review by the National Research Council, an affiliate of the National Academy of Sciences. The Academy is a congressionally chartered body charged with giving the government scientific advice. The National Park Service is part of the Interior Department and a sister agency to Interior's Bureau of Reclamation, a part owner of the power plant. The council said it was clear that emissions from the power plant reached the Grand Canyon and that these emissions ``contributed significantly to haze'' over the canyon. Marker gases deliberately emitted by the plant were found at Grand Canyon, the council noted. The Park Service study said the power plant accounted for 40 percent to 60 percent of the loss of visibility in the park. But the council said it could not determine how much of the canyon's haze should be attributed to the power plant. Under some weather conditions the haze over the canyon might be attributed almost totally to emissions from the power plant, while under other weather conditions the pollution might contain almost no sulfur from the plant, but sulfur from other pollution sources, the panel said. The Park Service study did not make certain measurements which could have helped resolve the question, did not adequately treat the conversion of sulfur dioxide into sulfates, and did not adequately consider the background concentration of sulfates, the council said. Even with new pollution control equipment at Navajo, the wintertime haze problem at the canyon ``would likely be reduced, but not eliminated.'' The 14-member committee that studied the issue said its conclusions were not aimed at resolving the question of whether EPA should require additional pollution controls at the plant. ``These issues involve policy considerations outside the committee's purview,'' said the panel. According to the EPA, the plant burns 24,000 tons of coal daily. releasing an estimated 12 tons to 13 tons of sulfur dioxide per hour, 288 to 312 tons per day. However, the council said the plant burned about 19,000 tons of coal per day during the study period and emitted 163 tons of sulfur dioxide per day. D. Michael Rappaport, Salt River Project assistant general manager for governmental affairs, said, ``It's our conclusion that it would be imprudent for the EPA to base a regulatory decision on findings that have been called into serious question by a group of eminent scientists.'' Dave Ryan, an EPA spokesman, said the council's study ``supports our basic belief'' but said he could not say how it would affect an EPA proposal expected by early next year.

DOC.HEAD: Enthusiasm Muted at Mexican's Nobel Victory
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with additional quotes from Mexican writers and artists. Picks up 7th graf pvs, `In recent...
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Nobel-Literature
DOC.TEXT: From president to pushcart vendor, most Mexicans reacted with pride Thursday to Octavio Paz' achievement on being named the first Mexican Nobel Prize for literature. Among fellow writers, many of the congratulations were delivered with the air of disdain that characterizes the left-leaning intellectual community's attitude toward its senior defector. ``As a poet he has great respect, less as an essayist and none as a politician,'' fiction writer Paco Ignacio Taibo was quoted as saying by the Excelsior news service. ``I hope that Octavio Paz doesn't become a spokesman for the right.'' Among the more outrageous responses was that of filmmaker Rafael Corkidi, who charged the prize was the result of publicity that the television chain Televisa spends on Paz. Televisa, which owns the only private television channels in Mexico, frequently is criticized for leaning to the right in its news coverage and favoring middle-of-the-road talent in its programming. The giant network sends out photographs of Paz among its promotional materials. ``Paz' undeniable literary value is wasted with sad speeches he gives in favor of the company,'' Corkidi said at a poetry festival in Guadalajara. Paz' criticism of leftist intellectuals - and aside from Paz not many intellectuals in Mexico are anything but - long has estranged him from the country's literary mainstream, if such a thing exists. But Mexican writers who have worked with Paz, such as Salvador Elizondo, a collaborator on the magazine Vuelta, called the prize well-deserved. ``In the cultural order it gives distinction to one of the most important figures of the Spanish language,'' Elizondo said. ``Despite the controversy and disagreement that Paz' ideological position generates, his creative quality is indisputable,'' said Jaime Labastida, a poet who stands opposed to Paz on many political issues. In recent months, Paz has been criticized for traveling overseas in the retinue of President Carlos Salinas de Gortari. Salinas, attending meetings in Venezuela on Thursday, sent a congratulatory message to Paz. ``He is a poet and writer of whom we Mexicans feel proud. He has a universal stature,'' said the president, praising Paz for ``his deep Mexican and Latin American vision.'' Paz is already one of Mexico's best-selling writers. Many students are assigned in school his ``Labyrinth of Solitude,'' a pithy investigation of the Mexican national character. At the Alameda park in downtown Mexico City, the award generated excitement among a group of sidewalk booksellers. Rogelio Galindo of the Sotano bookshop said he had sold 250 copies of Paz' latest work, ``A Small Chronicle of Great Days,'' the past three months. ``For him it's good. For me, it's marvelous,'' said Manuel Marquez, as he rushed to rescue his books from an afternoon rain. Scooping them off a patch of cardboard on the sidewalk, Marquez stacked them onto a cart. ``We hope this will lead us to read more books and by all writers,'' said Ricardo Contreras Plata, who has sold books for 22 years on a busy streetcorner opposite Mexico's Palace of Fine Arts. Enrique Fuente, owner of the Madero Bookstore, said the award was ``practically a merchandizing device'' for selling Paz' books. ``It's good because he's a Mexican,'' said bookshop customer Roman Picazo. Salvador Diaz Contera, a professor of Greek literature who was shopping at the Madero, praised Paz as ``one of the best writers'' in Mexico, although he said this is not a great era for Mexican writers. He said Paz' image had suffered among intellectuals because he seemed to have abandoned his socialist ideals and had become friendly with the government. Paz won many fans among the young in 1968 when he resigned as ambassador to India in protest over the bloody army attack on student protesters. ``Now he has changed when he sees the retreat of the socialist ideology in a great part of the world,'' Diaz said. In fact Paz began criticizing Marxist governments in the 1970s, a period that might be construed as revolutionary Socialism's heyday.

DOC.HEAD: At the Movies: ``Welcome Home, Roxy Carmichael''
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs planned.
DOC.TEXT: The wrong version of ``Welcome Home, Roxy Carmichael'' must have been released, because this sloppy-looking film never should have been allowed into theaters. The small town of Clyde, Ohio, is the setting. Local kid Roxy Carmichael left there 15 years ago and found fame and fortune when she helped inspire the hit song, ``In Roxy's Eyes.'' Apparantly, the good people of Clyde have been thinking about nothing else since. Roxy is to return for a grand homecoming and the town has arranged a day in her honor, with a guided tour of her old house and a gala ``Roxy Ball'' no one would dare miss. Two residents are especially anxious to greet the guest of honor. Fifteen-year-old Dinky Bossetti (Winona Ryder) is a homely, eccentric tomboy convinced the departed heroine is her real mother. Denton Webb (Jeff Daniels) was Roxy's childhood sweetheart and still pines for her although he is now married with two kids. Other highlights include efforts by Dinky's stepparents to ship her to boarding school, a possible relationship between Dinky and the class hunk, a fleeting reference to Roxy's bisexuality and the breakdown of Daniel's marriage. None of it really matters. The film lasts just 97 minutes and by the end you won't really care what happens once Roxy arrives. ``Roxy Carmichael'' was originally scheduled to come out in late August, and the delay should have been used for a little fine-tuning. Ryder, given several scenes communing with animals, gets to play a suburban Elly Mae Clampett while Daniels looks appropriately bored. The supporting performances are embarrassingly flat, as if the actors were reading off cue cards. And the editing is choppy, with abrupt cuts and awkward transitions between scenes. Who's to blame? Perhaps Jim Abrahams, who directed the very funny ``Ruthless People,'' but shows no such skill here. Or perhaps one could fault Karen Leigh Hopkins, making her debut as a screenwriter and executive producer. For Ryder, this is the first of three films scheduled for release by the end of the year. She'll also be seen in ``Mermaids,'' co-starring Cher and Bob Hoskins, and ``Edward Scissorhands'' with off-screen boyfriend Johnny Depp. ``Roxy'' should be safely out of the way by the time the others arrive. The Paramount Pictures Release is rated PG-13. Running Time: 97 minutes. ---= Motion Picture Association of America rating definitions: G - General audiences. All ages admitted. PG - Parental guidance suggested. Some material may not be suitable for children. PG-13 - Special parental guidance strongly suggested for children under 13. Some material may be inappropriate for young children. R - Restricted. Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian. NC-17 - No one under 17 admitted.
