DOC.BYLINE: Brazil to U.S. Banks: Convert Debt Into Long-Term Bonds ^By JORGE MEDEROS
DOC.TEXT: The government proposed Thursday to convert $60 billion of its debt to private foreign creditors into medium- and long-term government bonds. The conversion scheme was announced simultaneously by Secretary of Economic Policy Antonio Kandir to U.S. bankers in New York and by Economy Minister Zelia Cardoso de Mello to ambassadors from creditor nations in this inland capital. The negotiations involve $60 billion owed to private lenders in the U.S., Japan and Europe. Brazil's total foreign debt is $114 billion, largest in the Third World. ``We want to prove that Brazil is a solvent country that only has occasional liquidity problems,'' Cardoso de Mello said after briefing ambassadors of the United States, Japan, Germany, France, Great Britain, Italy on the proposal. She said the repayment plan offered three options: -All debt would be converted into long-term ``zero coupon bonds'' paying annual interest. These bonds could be recovered when they mature, or beforehand, at government auctions held every three months. -Short-term exit bonds would be available for purchase at greatly reduced interest. -Medium-term bonds would be available at slightly reduced interest, according to the purchasing capacity of the buyer. Cardoso de Mello declined to give details of payment terms or interest rates, she said, ``because they form part of our negotiating strategy.'' Brazil has accumulated some $6 billion in arrears on interest payments of its debt to private banks, which it has been under pressure to repay. Cardoso de Mello said this amount would be included in the overall restructuring of Brazil's total debt. She also proposed separating debt owed by private Brazilian firms from money owed by the government, which would permit Brazil to immediately restart debt payments. Debt accumulated by private Brazilian firms would not be included in the bond conversion plan, she said. ``The private sector, if it has dollars available, can pay its debt when and how much it wants,'' said Cardoso de Mello.

DOC.HEAD: Investigators in Florida Student Killings Re-examine Louisiana Deaths
DOC.TEXT: The task force investigating the deaths of five Florida students is taking another look at an unsolved triple slaying in Louisiana because of striking similiarities in the crimes. The stabbing deaths in Shreveport, La., of Julie Grissom, her father and her nephew came to the attention of the Gainesville task force early in its investigation. Investigators at first disregarded similarities because Edward Humphrey was not in Shreveport at the time of the November 1989 slayings, sources told The Miami Herald in a story published Thursday. Now, physical evidence seems to be pointing away from Humphrey and investigators are again looking into the Grissom case, the Herald said. Humphrey, a 19-year-old University of Florida freshman, has been listed as a suspect in the slayings. He was convicted Wednesday of battery on an person over the age of 65 for the Aug. 30 beating of his grandmother, Elna Hlavaty. The beating occurred shortly after Humphrey returned home to Indialantic from Gainesville two days after the last two bodies were found in apartments near the university. Humphrey faces up to 22 months in prison when he is sentenced Nov. 8. He also faces an unrelated attempted sexual battery case in Indian River County and an assault charge in Gainesville. Last week, a Shreveport detective flew to Gainesville to help the task force. Shreveport police homicide Lt. Gary Pittman confirmed that one of his detectives spent several days in Florida with the task force. But he cautioned against concluding that one killer was responsible for all eight deaths. ``Right now, we're proceeding as if they're not related,'' he said. Authorities believe the intended victim in the Shreveport killings was 24-year-old Julie Grissom. Her father, William T. Grissom, and her nephew, 8-year-old Sean, also died in the Nov. 4, 1989, attack. Among the similarities in that case and the Florida murders, the Herald said: - Ms. Grissom was a petite brunette student at Louisiana State University. The four women killed in Gainesville were petite brunettes between the ages of 17 and 23 and attended the University of Florida or Santa Fe Community College in Gainesville. The young man killed was living with one of the women. - The killer posed Ms. Grissom's body to shock whoever found her. The Gainesville killer also posed the bodies of victims. Investigators in both states say the killer may have photographed the crime scenes. - In both states, the killer left behind little evidence. - The Shreveport killer used tape during the killings but removed it from the victims or took it with him. The Gainesville killer did the same thing. - Both killers used liquids (vinegar and household cleaner) to destroy evidence on the victims' bodies. Some of the Gainesville victims were mutilated, but Ms. Grissom was not. Serial killing experts, however, say it is not uncommon for a killer to become increasingly brutal.

DOC.HEAD: Experts Urge Caution on Taiwan
DOC.TEXT: Experts on China recommended Thursday that the U.S. Congress not provoke Beijing or raise disastrously false expectations in offshore Taiwan by suggesting a plebiscite on the island's future. Maryland University Law Professor Chiu Hungdah said mere use of the word plebiscite in a proposed resolution would be offensive to Chinese officials, especially on the mainland, because of the ``One China'' policy staunchly upheld by the United States as well as both the Beijing and Taiwan governments. That policy insists there is only one China and the offshore island of Taiwan is part of it. Brown University Political Science Professor Michael Kau said terms such as ``plebiscite'' or ``Taiwan independence'' were ``too emotionally charged'' for a congressional resolution. But, he added, ``I fully agree that the future of Taiwan should be determined in accordance with the opinion of the people of Taiwan and I think even the government in Beijing should not object to that kind of idea.'' Maysing Yang, director of the New York-based Asia-Pacific Council on Democracy, an private advocacy group, took issue with the two scholars at a hearing of the House subcommittee on Asian and Pacific Affairs. She testified that plebiscite is not an emotional word and Congress should freely vote its sentiments about democracy. Rep. Stephen Solarz, D-N.Y., the subcommittee chairman, was seeking opinions on his draft resolution about taking into account Taiwanese views on the island's future through ``democratic mechanisms such as a plebiscite.'' The draft said Beijing's 1989 crackdown against democracy ``seriously undermines the credibility of its pledges on any issue'' including peaceful union with Taiwan. While pressing for more democracy on Taiwan, the United States should avoid creating ``a false expectation'' of support for independence or self-determination, Chiu testified. This would encourage advocates of independence to move Taiwan ``on a course of military confrontation with the Chinese Communists which can only bring disaster to all the people of Taiwan,'' he added. A Taiwanese dissident recently freed after 11 years in prison apologized to the panel, saying that it would be inappropriate, for him, as a Taiwan citizen, to answer questions about the degree of democracy on the island. Shih Ming-deh noted, however, that many people have urged him to tell the U.S. lawmakers that ``there are those imprisoned because they dissent in word and thought; the civil rights and the right to work of those who have been imprisoned over these long four decades have not been restored ... those in Taiwan who are engaged in environmental, labor and farmer movements are targeted by the government to be treated as mobsters.'' Shih's American-born wife, Linda Gail Arrigo, interpreted for him as he added, ``other people requested me to tell the American Congress that Taiwan is not part of the Peoples Republic of China, and the people of Taiwan have the right to self-determination and independence.''

DOC.HEAD: Argentina Said To Be Interested in Joining OPEC
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, ``Although our . . . CORRECTING to make Menem president since last year, not last July. Picks up 4th graf, He said . . .
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Latin Summit
DOC.TEXT: Economically pressed Argentina wants to enter OPEC, according to a news report Thursday. Argentine President Carlos Menem was quoted by Venezuela's government news agency Venpres as saying Argentina plans to free its domestically controlled energy prices in January and to increase foreign oil sales so it can join the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. ``Although our oil exports are still small, we are slowly increasing them to reach our goals,'' Menem was quoted as saying. Menem has been president of Argentina, which has rich natural resources but has been debilitated by years of chronic economic and labor problems, since July 8, 1989. He said Argentine oil now earns nearly $400 million per year. ``Argentina is a country with oil, and it has the option of gradually increasing exports,'' Menem said. Venezuela and Ecuador are the only Latin American members of the 13-nation OPEC cartel. Mexico and Colombia also export oil. Menem spoke while attending a two-day summit of eight Latin American presidents that began Thursday in Caracas.

DOC.HEAD: Philippine Judge Suspends Enrile Trial
DOC.TEXT: A judge Friday suspended the rebellion trial of Sen. Juan Ponce Enrile and two others until the Court of Appeals rules on several petitions filed by the defendants. Enrile, Rebecco Panlilio and his wife Erlinda were to have been arraigned Friday on rebellion charges in connection with a failed coup attempt last December. But Judge Jaime Salazar noted the three defendants had filed petitions with the Court of Appeals to halt the case. Enrile and the others were indicted in February after witnesses claimed they saw coup leader Lt. Col. Gregorio ``Gringo'' Honasan at the opposition senator's home on the first day of the failed putsch. Enrile denies the charge. The Panlilios were attending a party at Enrile's home in Makati on the day of the coup attempt. Chief prosecutor Aurelio Trampe charged the defendants were using stall tactics. Salazar also expressed frustration over the delays. ``The case is hanging in the air,'' he said. ``I'm for speed. What is important is the trial on the merits.'' Enrile was first charged with rebellion and murder, but the latter charge was dropped. He could face up to 20 years in prison if convicted of rebellion. Enrile, defense minister under late President Ferdinand Marcos, led the Feb. 22, 1986 mutiny against Marcos that triggered the uprising that lifted Corazon Aquino into the presidency. Mrs. Aquino fired Enrile from the defense ministry in November 1986 after a failed coup by his followers. Enrile ran successfully for the Senate in 1987 and used his post there to lead opposition to Mrs. Aquino.

DOC.HEAD: Latin Summit with 8 Presidents Opens in Venezuela
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with Venezuelan President's remarks, Chile and Ecuador accepted, picks up 7th graf pvs, `Aylwin on ...' ^By EDUARDO GALLARDO
DOC.TEXT: Eight Latin American presidents opened a two-day summit Thursday with talks on the effect oil price hikes from the Persian Gulf crisis have had on the region and on President Bush's proposal to create a free trade zone in the Americas. The closed-door sessions were held without ceremony at a downtown Caracas hotel. Host President Carlos Andres Perez said a communique would be issued Friday describing ``the fundamental agreements that exist among us, and explaining how the political will to integrate our economies has strengthened.'' Nine presidents were to attend the conference, but Peruvian President Alberto Fujimori was prevented from leaving his country at the last minute because he lacked congressional authorization. First Lady Susana Higuchi de Fujimori was to arrive Thursday evening in his place. Presidents attending were Carlos Menem of Argentina, Fernando Collor de Mello of Brazil, Patricio Aylwin of Chile, Cesar Gaviria of Colombia, Rodrigo Borja of Ecuador, Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico, Luis Alberto Lacalle of Uruguay, and Venezuela's Perez. The so-called Group of Rio was founded with eight members, and Chile and Ecuador were accepted as members Thursday. Panama was suspended from the group during the government of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. The inclusion of Bolivia and Paraguay was expected to be announced Friday. Perez and Argentine Foreign Minister Domingo Cavallo said oil prices and what they called ``Latin American security on energy matters'' dominated most of Thursday's four-hour session. Aylwin on Wednesday suggested the region create a Latin American and Caribbean investment fund with windfall profits generated by high priced oil and sales of other raw materials. He said he would raise the idea at the summit. ``It would mean studying how nations of the continent can help each other reciprocally, taking advantage of the fortunes that some countries might have at certain times,'' Aylwin said. Conference sources said the Chilean leader's idea drew considerable interest. Borja, whose OPEC nation is one of four Latin American oil exporters, said the oil price hikes posed problems for producing as well as consuming nations. Mexico, Venezuela and Colombia also export oil. Although consuming countries face high and even devastating expenditures, producers risk runaway inflation through the injection of massive funds into their economies, the Ecuadoran leader said. Thus everyone should ``work to stabilize petroleum prices. The current increase doesn't favor anyone,'' he said. He called on multinational oil companies and countries with large strategic oil reserves, such as the United States, to put stored oil on the market to force prices down. Lacalle, whose nation imports all its oil, presented the other side of the coin. Uruguay's oil bill will jump at least 10 percent as a result of the crises, he said. On the Bush initiative, which proposes free enterprises zones in Latin America and forgiving some Latin debt to the U.S. government, Borja said it was the first time ``an American president is recognizing that the Latin American foreign debt is a political problem, not only an economic one.'' ``How can it not be political, if our democratic system depends on it?'' he asked rhetorically. Lacalle was more enthusiastic, saying that as soon as Bush presented his June 27 speech ``I called him up in the White House Oval Office to tell him I'm 1,000 percent behind his initiative.'' But Lacalle said the general proposal must quickly be made more concrete. The fight against drug traffic and environmental preservation are also important themes on the summit agenda.

DOC.HEAD: Former Spies Handed Over Information About German Fighter Jet
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with two new arrests; picks up 4th graf pvs, `The espionage...
DOC.TEXT: Former spies for East Germany have handed over information about top-secret military projects in West Germany, including the development of the Tornado fighter jet, officials said Thursday. The new disclosures followed the arrest Wednesday of eight alleged spies. For a people accustomed to wild tales of oold War espionage in their own backyards, the new reports are causing some extra head-shaking across the recently united Germany. The alleged Communist East German spies include a 63-year-old woman, her son and daughter-in-law. The ZDF television network said two more suspected spies were arrested on Thursday, but gave no details. The espionage activities stretch back to the 1960s and the era of highest tensions between East and West. Chancellor Helmut Kohl's government has appealed to former East German spies to come in from the cold, and it is speculated they could face lighter prison terms for doing so. Kohl, however, warned in an interview that the legacy of the East German spy service must not ``poison our nation's atmosphere.'' ``We must in no way open up a witch-hunt, but protect our capacity for reconciliation,'' the Sueddeutsche Zeitung newspaper quoted Kohl as saying. Earlier this week, Germans learned that the same top secret intelligence summaries that reached Kohl's desk each week wound up in Communist East Germany's spy headquarters. Klaus Kuron, a top spy, quickly started naming names after turning himself in to authorities Sunday. That led to the arrest of the eight spies whose crimes were outlined by the chief federal prosecutor's office Thursday. Late Thursday, the Cologne newspaper Express said Kuron's former East German control officer had also been arrested. There was no immediate confirmation from authorities. One of the group of eight arrested, identified only as Karlheinz S., allegedly passed on directly to the Soviet KGB information about a new tank under development, the chief federal prosecutor said. Another agent identified only as Franz M. passed on to the East Germans ``information and documents'' about military helicopters. The prosecutor said the agent obtained the information while working for Messerschmidt-Boelkow-Bloehm, the largest West German aerospace manufacturer. Two other people are accused of handing over to the East Germans information about the development of NATO's sophisticated Tornado fighter jet. They allegedly took pictures of the original top-secret documents and passed them on to the Soviet Bloc agents. All eight of those arrested come from West Germany, according to chief federal prosecutor Alexander von Stahl. The Associated Press called von Stahl's office to learn the last names of those arrested, but the spokesmen had already left for the day and were unreachable at home. Where the latest round of arrests and disclosures will stop no one knows. Von Stahl says more developments are expected, and he has a pool of 8,000 former East German spies to pick from in the coming months. Leaders of the former East German security service, known as the Stasi, are believed to have abetted some of international terrorists. News reports say the terrorists may still be lurking on German soil.

DOC.HEAD: Walgreen Orders `Slap Bracelets' Removed From Shelves
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Maryellen cq in 2nd graf
DOC.TEXT: Walgreen Co. said Thursday it had ordered its drug stores nationwide to remove ``slap bracelets'' from their shelves while the safety of the fad jewelry is investigated. The action was taken Wednesday in response to a complaint Tuesday that a Connecticut child received a minor cut while playing with a bracelet, said Maryellen Thielen, spokeswoman at Walgreen corporate headquarters in this Chicago suburb. ``We just want to make sure that if and when we do put them back on the shelves we know they are safe,'' Thielen said. ``And while we are investigating we have asked them to remove them.'' Also Thursday, Connecticut consumer protection officials ordered the recall of Taiwan-made imitations of the popular toys. The bracelet consists of a 9-inch strip of metal encased in brightly colored cloth. When the strip is slapped against the wrist, it wraps itself around the wearer's arm. The state Department of Consumer Protection issued the recall order after testing three versions of the bracelets for exposed sharp edges, which are prohibited on most toys under the state's Child Protection Act. Only one version passed the tests: ``The Original Slap Wrap'' bracelets made by Simsbury-based Main Street Toy, said Lois Bryant, director of the department's product safety division. Those that failed were labeled ``Made in Taiwan'' or lacked labels, she said. The slap bracelets sold by Walgreen are imitations. Main Street Toy maintains that its bracelets, made with stainless steel, are not dangerous, but that imitations are made from cheaper steel that will rust and snap. When 4-year-old Nicole Tomaso wrapped the bracelet she got at Walgreen in Wallingford, Conn., around her wrist Tuesday, a piece of metal protruded from the toy's sewn end and she cut her finger, her father said. The bracelet that caused the injury was an imitation. Slap Wraps sell for $2.49; the imitations cost less, usually 99 cents. Elementary school officials in Pelham, N.Y., banned the wraps last week after becoming concerned about children cutting themselves.

DOC.HEAD: Two Japanese Sailors Freed After 7 Years by North Korea
DOC.TEXT: Two Japanese sailors, held nearly seven years in North Korea, returned home Thursday after being released by the communist North in an apparent bid for closer relations with Japan. Isamu Beniko, 60, and Yoshio Kuriura, 59, looked healthy and relieved as they stepped off a chartered All Nippon Airways airplane into bright sunshine at Haneda Airport. In a scene televised live and nationwide, Beniko broke with customary Japanese reserve and waved vigorously toward the airport terminal. After a private reunion with their wives inside the plane, the two seamen were driven to a local hospital for medical checkups. ``He hasn't changed much. I was relieved,'' Beniko's wife, Maneko, said in a news conference. Returning on the same plane from Pyongyang, North Korea's capital, were top officials of Japan's two largest political parties, which had negotiated the men's release in a period of unprecedented contact between Japanese politicians and the North Korean government. Japan has no diplomatic relations with Pyongyang. It recognizes the North's archrival, South Korea. Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu told reporters at his official residence that he was happy about the seamen's return, Kyodo News Service reported. Pyongyang's official Korean Central News Agency, monitored in Tokyo, said they were given amnesties ``from a humanitarian stand.'' On Wednesday in Pyongyang, North Korean President Kim Il Sung and Ichiro Ozawa, secretary general of Japan's governing Liberal Democratic Party, agreed that the two Asian neighbors should begin talks to establish diplomatic relations quickly, the nationally circulated newspaper Asahi Shimbun reported. Ozawa and Takako Doi, chairman of the opposition Japan Socialist Party, had been invited to celebrations Wednesday of the 45th anniversary of North Korea's ruling communist party, called the Workers Party. Beniko, the captain, and Kuriura, the first mate, were seized in November 1983 on a return voyage to North Korea on the Japanese freighter Fujisan Maru No. 18, on which a North Korean soldier, Min Hong Gu, had stowed away to Japan. Japan rejected the North's demand that Min be sent home. In 1988, it granted him permission to live in Japan. Meanwhile, in December 1987, North Korea retaliated by sentencing the two seaman to 15 years in prison for alleged spying. Their release became a key hurdle to improved Japan-North Korea relations. Late month, a delegation from Japan's governing party met in Pyongyang with North Korean officials and the two sides agreed to open talks in November on establishing diplomatic relations between the two countries. Japan ruled the Korean peninsula as a colony from 1910 until its defeat in World War II in 1945. After the war, the peninsula was split into the Communist North and the capitalist South, and the two fought a bloody war in 1950-53. South Korea normalized relations with Japan in 1965. Min, 27, a former army sergeant who now lives north of Tokyo, was quoted as saying he was happy about the seamen's release. ``I would like to meet the two men, without much publicity, and apologize. I would like to do anything in my capacity. I could give them my kidney,'' Kyodo quoted him as saying.

DOC.HEAD: Egyptians Vote in Referendum Over Dissolution of Parliament
DOC.TEXT: Egyptians voted Thursday in a referendum to decide whether to give President Hosni Mubarak a mandate to dissolve Parliament. Security officials meanwhile remained on alert to terrorists threats spawned by the Persian Gulf crisis. Interior Minister Abdel-Halim Moussa, whose ministry handles internal security, said Arabs angered over Mubarak's anti-Iraq position are threatening Egypt with sabotage and assassination. Five Moslem fundamentalists were reported arrested in a southern city for distributing antigovernment leaflets. Otherwise, voting was reported occurring without incident. The voters had to answer ``yes'' or ``no'' to the question: ``Do you approve of the dissolution of the People's Assembly?'' Government officials expected a comfortable, probably overwhelming, affirmative vote. Under the constitution, that would allow Mubarak to disband the assembly, declared illegal by the country's highest constitutional court, and call new elections within two months. More than 23,000 polling stations nationwide opened in the morning Thursday for nine hours. The turnout in Cairo and major cities appeared low. Mubarak and his wife Suzanne voted at the northeastern Cairo suburb of Heliopolis, their official residence. In southern Egypt's Assiut, police armored cars and trucks were seen at key points, including squares and within the Assiut University compound. City and university have been for years centers of hard-line Moslem antigovernment agitation. Assiut police sources said five fundamentalist students were arrested on campus as they distributed leaflets. The sources said the leaflets opposed holding the referendum now and attacked the presence of American and other Western forces in the gulf region. Officials said security was tightened nationwide in preparation for the referendum. In the past week, authorities have reported the arrest of 35 Palestinians and Iraqis suspected of planning sabotage. Mubarak has led Arab opposition to Iraq's Aug. 2 conquest of Kuwait. ``In addition to Iraq, some Palestinian factions have threatened Egypt openly with sabotage and acts of terror,'' Interior Minister Moussa told a Cairo seminar. ``They said they will export terrorists to Egypt to assassinate public figures.'' Mubarak suspended the 458-member People's Assembly on Sept. 26 because of a May 19 ruling by the Supreme Constitutional Court that the assembly was elected under an illegal law. He also scheduled the referendum on dissolution as required by the constitution. The seven-judge court said provisions of the law violated the constitutional principle that all Egyptians must be given equal opportunity to be elected to public office. It let individuals run against each other alongside balloting for candidates on political party lists. Using his executive lawmaking powers in Parliament's absence, Mubarak promulgated an election law that appears to satisfy the court's objections. He canceled the party-list method and proportional representation and revived the system of voting among individual candidates that prevailed in Egypt under the monarchy ended by a coup in 1952. The president also redrew electoral districts, creating 222 constituencies instead of 48. The next parliament will have 444 elected members, two from each district, and 10 appointed by Mubarak. Egypt has an electorate of about 15 million from a population of 55 million. Everybody over 18 can vote, but political apathy causes some men and many women, particularly in rural areas, to neglect to register.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0480, fixing numbering.
DOC.TEXT: The House is being asked to approve the second-largest tax increase in history - a $144 billion plan to boost taxes on gasoline, tobacco, alcohol and higher-income Americans. ``I really think this plan could pass,'' Rep. Jim Moody, D-Wis., said after the House Ways and Means Committee approved the deficit-reduction plan by voice vote on Wednesday. A similar plan is in the making in the Senate Finance Committee. Either version could be amended to include President Bush's proposed capital gains tax cut. But prospects for such a change are clouded by doubts about whether the president would support raising tax rates on the rich as part of the bargain. ---= CONCORD, N.H. (AP) - White House chief of staff John Sununu's reputation as ``big, bad John'' on Capitol Hill comes as no surprise to former associates in New Hampshire who say his persistence as governor sometimes turned into belligerence. But even some bruised in the legislative give-and-take during his six years as the state's chief executive admire his ability to get things done. ``They're so used to being treated with such deference in Washington,'' House Democratic Leader Mary Chambers said Wednesday. ``They go home and everybody bows and scrapes and wants to shake their hand. They get pretty arrogant and self-satisfied. ``Someone like John Sununu comes along and doesn't care who they are. The mission of getting the job done, that's his driving thing. It amuses me to read what they say about him.'' ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - They are in their third month of holding out against all odds - 10 U.S. diplomats refusing to bow to Iraq's annexation of Kuwait or to leave other Americans in the terrorized Persian Gulf country without an official U.S. presence. Not that Ambassador W. Nathaniel Howell and his beleaguered staff can do much for their 500 or so countrymen, many of whom are in hiding and several of whom are desperately ill. Telephone conversations are intentionally brief, on the supposition that Iraqi eavesdroppers are listening for useful information about the whereabouts of the elusive Americans, their risk-taking Kuwaiti protectors or Washington's intentions. Through satellite communications, the embassy also is in touch with the State Department. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - More than 33,000 military reservists have been called to active duty in support of the U.S. buildup in the Persian Gulf area - nearly as many as were activated during crises in Vietnam and Korea in 1968. The Army today activated 12 National Guard and 24 Army Reserve units from 24 states and Puerto Rico, for a toal of 4,846 troops. Meanwhile, the Marine Corps said Wednesday it was calling up about 160 reservists. Those actions brought to 33,252 the number of reservists from all services activated since Aug. 22 when President Bush authorized their use in support of Operation Desert Shield. None of the reserves called so far are from combat units; all are performing combat support or combat service functions such as cargo handling, air, sea and ground transportation, water purification, intelligence and security. ---= SPACE CENTER, Houston (AP) - NASA pronounced an end to its losing streak after Discovery completed a nearly trouble-free mission that sent a probe speeding toward the sun. ``We showed the world that the shuttle and NASA is reliable and can meet their commitments,'' said Aaron Cohen, director of the Johnson Space Center. The shuttle and its five astronauts swooped out of orbit and glided to a landing at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif., on Wednesday after a four-day flight. It was NASA's first shuttle mission in six months. Only a few problems were reported from blastoff to touchdown, including a computer programming error discovered after takeoff that was considered serious but no threat to the shuttle or crew, said Milt Heflin, lead flight director. ---= BOSTON (AP) - Coffee drinkers, delight. A good cup of joe, or two, or three, won't hurt the heart, Harvard researchers reported today. In fact, coffee with caffeine, the often maligned chemical that gives the brew its kick, may turn out to be easier on the heart than the decaffeinated variety. ``It's amazing how coffee has a bad name, when the harder one looks at health hazards, the more difficult it is to find adverse effects,'' says Dr. Walter Willett of the Harvard School of Public Health. His research, part of a huge study of healthy people, shows that those who drink several cups of ordinary caffeinated coffee every day do not raise their risk of heart attacks.

DOC.HEAD: Inflation: A Daily Struggle for Brazilians
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: Marta de Teixeira Campos knew the price of a frozen chicken, but that was yesterday. It had risen 50 percent overnight. The rice, black beans, cooking oil and cheese in her cart were vital if her four children were to be fed, so Mrs. Campos reluctantly handed the chicken back to the supermarket cashier. She and most of the 150 million other Brazilians are feeling the bite of a resurgent inflation that makes survival a daily struggle. Wages don't go up to match prices, and the public is gradually losing confidence in the economic ``shock'' plan decreed by President Fernando Collor de Mello on Mar. 15. Inflation plunged from 84 percent in March to 3.3 percent in April and the poor, elated by their new buying power, gave Collor a 74 percent approval rating in May. Unfortunately, inflation didn't go away. Prices rose 9.6 percent in June, by August the monthly rate was up to 10.5 and in September nearly reached 13 percent. Helio Jaguaribe, a leading sociologist, said inflation had ``now reached the level where it is biting into basic needs.'' Brazilians shrugged off inflation for years because cost-of-living indexing protected wages and savings. The government had to print money to pay the bill, however, and that made inflation worse. In June, Collor did away with wage indexing and said workers must negotiate their own pay increases. In September, he abolished rent control to encourage construction and rents tripled overnight. A one-bedroom apartment in the affluent South Zone that rented for $500 a month last year now costs $1,700. People returning from winter vacations found the 800-cruzeiro ride from home to the airport cost 1,900 in the other direction. A movie ticket has tripled in two months to 300 cruzeiros, about $3.40. A month of lambada dance lessons doubled to 5,000 cruzeiros, or $56, and the cost of an international telephone call has tripled since June to about $5 a minute. Prices of auto parts inhabit an unreal world of their own. A Volkswagen distributor charges $95 for a headlight, enough to buy more than 26 pounds of prime beef. Newspapers are filled with announcements of price increases. Magazines offer advice on how to cope and invest money, and carry classified ads from people who want to pool stocks of food and household items. Prices vary wildly. A men's linen shirt costs the equivalent of $560 at a one shop in downtown Rio and a similar one goes for $80 at another. All prices may be going up, but they rise more rapidly in some stores than in others. In September, a government price supervision agency said a check of 325 shops turned up 300 different prices for the same brand of suntan lotion. Comparison shopping has become a national pastime. Marcia Sobreira Evangelista, a 29-year-old lawyer, said inflation forced her to atted the theater less often. So what does she do instead? ``I go to mall to see the prices.'' When Collor's austerity plan froze most bank accounts, barter became popular. Joao Alves do Brito, starting out as a dentist, traded his 1981 Volkswagen Beetle for dental equipment. ``I was lucky,'' said Brito, 32. ``I avoided a big hassle of getting cash, and who knows when the manufacturer would have delivered the materials?'' As inflation grows, so does the amount of time and energy spent in coping with it. Sandra Ippolito Brunoro, 34-year-old manager of a Sao Paulo office-lighting company, says she spends three hours a day reading journals and newspaper business sections in an effort to keep her money from losing value. ``You start thinking, `What'll be today - gold, dollars or putting it into the stock market?' '' she said. ``It's incredibly unproductive, but what choice do you have?'' Computer analyst Sebastiao Freitas Gomes, 27, tries to beat the system by shuffling money between bank and investment accounts. Every Friday afternoon, Gomes transfers money from his checking account into a short-term ``overnight'' money market that pays 10 percent a month. ``It's tricky,'' he said, ``because you have to get to the bank first thing on Monday to tranfer money back into your checking account to cover the checks you wrote over the weekend.'' Brazilians have turned to credit cards as a way to delay payment. There is no finance charge when the total balance is paid promptly, and using a card locks in prices that prevailed at the time of purchase. Some merchants will not accept credit cards. Others follow the illegal, but common, practice of charging credit customers 45 percent more than those who pay cash.

DOC.HEAD: Colombia Trying to Repair Battered Judicial System
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: Colombia is trying to repair a judicial system made powerless by drug traffickers, who often kill judges and court officials they cannot bribe or coerce. President Cesar Gaviria, inaugurated Aug. 7, plans ``fortress cities'' where judges can live and work free of intimidation that presents them with a choice of ``plata o plomo'' - money or lead. ``The country's powerful crime organizations are leaving the judicial system in complete impotence,'' said Fernando Carrillo, judicial adviser to Gaviria. An elite corps of ``untouchable'' - specialized judges, policemen and lawyers - is to be created and given constant military protection. Federal prosecutors, not judges, will investigate organized crime and the identities of judges hearing cases will be concealed. Judges now spend hundreds of hours gathering evidence. In nine years, 228 judges and other court officers have been murdered in Colombia, according to the Judges' Union. Judges who stand up to the Medellin cartel run the greatest risk. In July 1989, Judge Maria Helena Diaz and her two bodyguards were killed in Bogota. She had issued an arrest warrant for Pablo Escobar, head of the cocaine cartel. Twelve judicial workers were murdered in January 1989 while investigating massacres of peasants in northern Colombia. In both cases, the government blamed paramilitary death squads paid by the drug barons. Marta Restrepo, a regional attorney general, and her bodyguard were shot to death in July in Apartado, a northern banana-growing region. She was investigating the massacre of 42 peasants, in which suspicion also fell on the death squads. When the Medellin cartel declared war on the government in August 1989, then-President Virgilio Barco figured he had no choice but to resume extraditions to the United States. ``The cartel had the government against the wall,'' said Attorney General Alfonso Gomez. ``Magistrates were receiving coffins in their homes as death threats. There was no way they could have tried these cases freely in Colombia.'' Drug gangs have been blamed in the past year for the killings of 550 Colombians, but recently declared a unilateral cease-fire. President Gaviria revised the extradition policy with a decree Sept. 5 that drug traffickers who surrender can be tried in Colombia instead of being sent to the United States. He also announced the judicial reforms. In making the extradition offer and proposing reforms, Gaviria sought to show the Colombian people the government was strengthening its own institution rather than relying on foreign governments, a policy-making official told The Associated Press. ``We cannot construct an anti-terrorism policy based on the justice system of the United States,'' he said, on condition of anonymity. Extraditions are unpopular and many Colombians consider them an insult to the country. Colombia is unable to keep traffickers in jail, however, and extraditions are likely to continue until the courts can function properly. ``As long as no other clear alternative exists, we'll still have extraditions,'' said Jorge Orlando Melo, president of the Institute of Political Studies in Bogota. Barco asked the United States last year to help provide physical protection for judges. The Bush administration sent bulletproof vests and armored cars as part of a $65 million aid package for the drug war. A high judicial official said, also on condition of anonymity: ``A few vests and cars? With this you protect an entire institution from the most powerful mafia in the world?'' He said the United States should offer to train judicial workers, and added that Colombia needs money to build maximum-security prisons. On Sept. 18, a man accused of murdering a leading presidential candidate escaped from La Picota, the most heavily guarded prison in Bogota. Jaime Rueda, believed to be in charge of explosives for the Medellin cartel, was one of three suspects in the murder of Liberal Party candidate Luis Carlos Galan, whose death led to the year-old drug war. Four years ago, Honduran trafficker Juan Ramon Matta walked out of La Picota, passing through 17 doors that were supposed to be locked. Inefficiency plagues Colombia's judicial system. For example, the Supreme Court president must personally appoint drivers to take court officers to and from their homes. ``This is madness,'' said Carrillo, the presidential adviser. Under the Gaviria plan, the executive branch will coordinate the judicial system. Federal prosecutors, working with the police and attorney general, will collect evidence and press charges. Judges, who now gather evidence and act as prosecutors, will be limited to deciding guilt or innocence. Of Colombia's 5,000 judges, only 200 to 500 living in the ``fortress cities'' will hear cases related to drugs or terrorism, officials say. Computers and evidence-collecting techniques are to be modernized, and the government is may establish a special corps of the 100 top judicial police. Carrillo said the reforms will cost the equivalent of $190 million, about 3 percent of the national budget, and take 18 months. Some changes will require constitutional amendments and others will need congressional approval. Colombian governments have talked of reforming the judiciary since the 1970s, ``but only now does there exist the political will to do so,'' Carrillo said.

DOC.HEAD: `Nixon,' A PBS Biography, Falls Short of The Mark
DOC.TEXT: He telephoned the first men on the moon. He opened the door to China. And, in 1974, he became the only president to resign from office under the certainty of impeachment and the likelihood of conviction. It's 1990 now, and Richard M. Nixon is tanned, rested, ready and rehabilitated. And ``Nixon,'' a three-hour documentary, is opening the season Monday for ``The American Experience'' series on PBS. It's a comprehensive biography of the 37th U.S. president, even-handed, well-researched, full of good photographs and familiar footage. Unfortunately, Nixon and his immediate family did not cooperate in the making of the film. ``Nixon'' makes fine viewing for someone born since 1969, for whom Nixon is ancient history, but it won't satisfy those who lived during his prime. Nixon has been a national figure since 1948, when the young California congressman made headlines by bird-dogging Alger Hiss' alleged Communist ties before the House Un-American Activities Committee. ``Nixon'' fails to show how his character led to the ``high crimes and misdemeanors'' that toppled him for concealing his government's ties to the June 1972 botched break-in at Democratic offices in the Watergate complex. Interviews with Nixon historians and biographers cannot illuminate the labyrinth of Nixon's character. As historian James MacGregor Burns has noted elsewhere, ``Nixon was not merely complex, he was opaque.'' ``Nixon'' tells of a boy born to a lower middle-class family, with an unsuccessful father and a distant, dominating mother. Two brothers died at an early age. Richard was smart, serious, a gifted actor and debater. Whittier College, Duke University Law School and World War II service in the Navy followed. In 1946, Nixon ousted Rep. Jerry Voorhis, D-Calif., by claiming he was communist-supported. Anonymous phone calls said worse. In 1950, he beat Helen Gahagan Douglas for the U.S. Senate with an equally sleazy red-baiting campaign. There is a 1979 interview with Douglas, who died the next year. Her revenge was the nickname that haunts him still: ``Tricky Dick.'' His next political leap nearly undid him. Fresh on the 1952 GOP ticket as Dwight D. Eisenhower's vice president, he attacked Democratic corruption and immediately was accused of having a secret slush fund. He denied everything. He bypassed the press in the so-called ``Checkers speech'' televised to the nation. He spoke of his children, his wife, Pat, and her ``Republican cloth coat,'' and the family dog, Checkers. It saved his place on the ticket. ``Nixon'' uses footage from the Checkers speech and Nixon's first televised debate with John F. Kennedy in the 1960 presidential race. And it shows the embittered Nixon in 1962, after losing a bid for governor of California. ``You won't have Nixon to kick around any more,'' he told reporters, ``because, gentlemen, this is my last press conference.'' Six years later, ``the new Nixon'' won the presidency and inherited the divisive Vietnam war. His attempts to end the war - diplomatic initiatives, stepped-up bombing and ``Vietnamization'' of the ground war - divided the nation even further. The Watergate era is the best and final hour of ``Nixon.'' We get to see the brooding still photos of Nixon bunkered in the White House and the speech that claims the support of a ``great, silent majority.'' The film shows how the White House, perceiving political opposition to the war as subversion, compiled an ``enemies list,'' used by the FBI, CIA and IRS to attack its foes, and created an extralegal ``Plumbers'' unit to stop leaks. And then there was the Watergate break-in. But for Washington Post reporters Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein (uncredited by name in ``Nixon''), the president and his men might have gotten away with it. As it was, the reporters found a ``massive campaign of political spying and sabotage'' that led straight to the White House and triggered our nation's greatest constitutional crisis. There are excellent interviews with cheerful, expansive former aides, including John Ehrlichman, John Dean, and Charles Colson, who did time for Watergate crimes, and speechwriter Ray Price. ``Nixon'' ultimately fails because of its ending: There is the damaged man, ascending the helicopter steps, the sudden, agonized wave, the embarrassing, awkward V-signs. It's still painful to witness his departure into exile. But he didn't stay there. And the film neglects to mention his miraculous ``rehabilitation'' as elder statesman for the Republican Party. That omission only emphasizes the obvious: History is not yet done with Richard Nixon. --- Elsewhere in television ... Tonight's guest artist is David Crosby, who will discuss the National Rifle Association, alcoholism and substance abuse. Future guests will include Mick Fleetwood, Judy Collins, Gregg Allman, Herbie Hancock and Bob Geldof.

DOC.HEAD: Just Where Does That Bottled Water Come From?
With PM-Bottled Water
DOC.TEXT: Consumers who opt for bottled water over tap water might be surprised to learn that their preferred drink could be drawn from the source they want to avoid - their public water supply. Some water lovers may already know this, particularly those who live in a state like California that requires bottled water labels to disclose the source. But in areas that depend largely on federal regulations to ensure the quality of their bottled water, consumers may find little more than a brand name and a picture of a pristine mountain lake on the label. ``They're selling a lot of bottled water because it is believed to be better and purer and safer, but that's not necessarily so. All it has to be is as good as tap water,'' said Edward Zadjura, who is overseeing a General Accounting Office study on bottled water regulations. ``You can have the mountain in the background, but you just can't say it comes from a mountain or a lake if it doesn't,'' he said. ``You can let the public's mind and imagination wander where it wants.'' He also notes that ``people overlook the fact that springs can be as polluted as anything else.'' The GAO study was requested by Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., chairman of the House Energy and Commerce investigations subcommittee, after traces of benzene was found in Perrier bottled water. The bottled water industry, which favors source labeling, is careful not to make claims of the relative safety of bottled vs. tap water. ``The reason people buy bottled water is because of the taste,'' said William Deal, executive vice president of the International Bottled Water Association. But is it safer? ``The answer is sometimes it is, and sometimes it isn't,'' said Herbert Allen, an environmental engineer at the University of Delaware, who helped conduct a 1981 study of domestic and imported mineral waters. The study, the results of which were published last year, found that 24 of the 37 brands tested exceeded U.S. drinking water standards for at least one chemical. But a recent Food and Drug Administration sampling of 50 imported and 50 domestic brands of bottled water found ``very little reason for concern,'' said FDA spokesman Chris Lecos. The Environmental Protection Agency sets drinking water standards in the United States, and these must be followed by municipal water suppliers. Bottled water, however, is the responsibility of the FDA, which generally adopts the EPA standards. If there is a taste difference, the reason is chlorine: it's added to public water supplies to eliminate bacteria. Bottled water doesn't contain chlorine - either it wasn't added in the first place, or it was taken out. Often when the source of a bottled water is the public water supply, the chlorine and other possible organic and inorganic substances have been removed. Municipal water suppliers feel they've been taking unwarranted hits from the bottled water industry. ``If the consumer thinks they like the taste of bottled water, that's fine,'' said Jack Hoffbuhr, deputy executive director of the American Water Works Association. ``We just don't want them to be scared into buying it.'' ``We want the public to know the tap water is safe and they don't need to pay $1 a gallon or more for this product, unless they want to,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: The New, Unusual and Contradictory Economics
DOC.TEXT: The new economics now on display in Congress is confusing millions of Americans who were brought up on a more or less standard brand of the art that everyone understood. It included government actions to smooth wrinkles in the economic cycle - maintaining an equilibrium between supply and demand and avoiding inflation and recession. Economic growth was good, stagnation was to be avoided. Now they aren't sure. The new economics, they fear, belongs to no school at all, and, say the wags, isn't likely ever to gain admittance to a school. It appears instead to be a conglomeration of conflicts and contradictions. Those brought up in the practical school of economics over the past half century accepted the idea that government intervention was sometimes acceptable to control an economy from growing too weakly or too strongly. Booms and busts were to be avoided. You avoided booms by raising interest rates and maybe taxes, and by controlling federal spending; you averted recessions by lowering taxes and interest rates, and maybe by spending more. The new economics now on display in Washington seems to be a different and so far unidentifiable brand, since it would raise taxes and avowedly slow federal spending while the country heads toward recession. It is also accompanied by a monetary policy - a Federal Reserve policy - that appears to be more concerned with inflation than recession, and that has resisted pleas by businesses and investors for easier money. Yes, it's confusing, and it may be little solace to people to realize that many members of the professional economic fraternity are as confused as anyone. Negatives abound, they say, and more taxes might make them worse. Among the negatives: Economic expansion, if it still exists, has slowed to a crawl and may soon go into reverse. Consumer confidence is at its lowest since the 1982 recession. Unemployment is growing steadily. Manufacturing activity is stalling. Small businesses are complaining of a credit crunch. Bankruptcies are rising Banks are failing. Important insurers are endangered because their real estate portfolios have collapsed. Household, business and government debt is high. The securities markets are in serious trouble; junk bonds are defaulting and the stock market has plunged, erasing not just billions of dollars but literally trillions from portfolios around the world in August and September. Had such a situation occurred in the past it most likely would have been countered by calls for propping up the economy through tax relief, lower interest rates and conceivably some pump-priming by the federal government. Today, the economy seem to be caught in a vicious political debate that obscures the issues. It has no sponsor, no spokesman, no outspoken defender. Those who might have accepted the role are too busy with the budget. The Federal Reserve, which handles monetary policy, has indicated that interest-rate relief might be forthcoming if budget negotiators reach an acceptable agreement. But what if they don't? Meanwhile, government activity as a percentage of gross national product is likely to grow by default of the private sector. Taxes as a percent of gross national product could rise to 19.5 percent, close to a post-World War II high. The last two times that government revenues accounted for so much of GNP the economy fell into recession, and that is the expectation expressed today in a growing number of published forecasts.

DOC.HEAD: Wilder Agitating for Tougher Democratic Stand on Deficits
DOC.TEXT: Gov. L. Douglas Wilder has changed many things in more than two decades in politics. He was the first black elected to the Virginia Senate since Reconstruction. He became the nation's first elected black governor. Now the rising political star wants to change the national Democratic Party. He is chipping away at bedrock Democratic doctrine in a quest to redefine it in more fiscally conservative terms. Wilder fired a broadside at his own party that sounded almost Reaganesque in its denunciation of tax increases. ``A backroom tax deal'' stacked against the middle class, Wilder said of a quickly defeated federal deficit-reduction package. He criticized Democratic national chairman Ron Brown for endorsing it. In speeches and a recent interview, the governor describes himself as the personification of a ``new mainstream'' style of politics that blends fiscal conservativism with social activism. It helped get him elected governor, made him a hot commodity for speaking engagements around the country and - some say - could help put him on the national Democratic ticket in 1992. And now, he seems to be playing the role of outsider in a not-so-subtle campaign to gain an inside track on 1992. The next successful Democratic presidential candidate will be someone ``who can identify with the totality of the American public, and have shown soee degree of fiscal responsibility,'' says Wilder. He says he plans to serve his full term of governor, which ends in 1994. But others aren't so sure. Wilder ``knows he's got one shot at national office, and just about everything he does in the state is geared to that,'' says Larry Sabato, a University of Virginia political scientist. Wilder risks alienating many of his strongest supporters by trying to wipe out a $1.4 billion state deficit solely through spending cuts. Civil rights and labor groups have been somewhat disenchanted with his performance so far, he concedes. ``The only special interest that I recognize is the people of Virginia,'' he says in defending his approach. The political heat is likely to get worse when he discloses details of the planned cuts. Wilder concedes his record in Richmond will be ``like a fingerprint'' if he seeks national office, but he minimizes speculation that he's positioning himself for a place on the national party ticket. The governor said ``I didn't include myself'' when talking about the type of Democrat he believes can return the party to the White House. Still, in his first six months in office, he visited 11 states, including the early presidential sweepstakes states of New Hampshire and Iowa. He has injected himself on the national scene, asking President Bush to appoint an independent commission to investigate the savings and loan bailout and has expressed support for Israel. He also has gotten some unwanted publicity: Using a state helicopter to take personal trips with Patricia Kluge, estranged wife of America's richest man, John W. Kluge. At times, Wilder acts like a political outsider, raising eyebrows in the party establishment. He made waves with his blast at Brown on the deficit-reduction package. ``It is becoming more apparent than ever before that our two-party system is becoming a competition between the party inside Washington and that new party, the vast majority of Americans who live outside, who see the need to unite to protect their interests,'' Wilder wrote. He assailed both parties for ``fiscal irresponsibility,'' drawing criticism in return. Wilder ``would have been better off'' to be speaking in support of any Washington budget package that was intended to curb the huge deficit, responded former Democratic Party chairman Robert Strauss. ``I think people all over are looking for answers and solutions,'' said former chairman Paul Kirk, ``and they can ally with anyone who says something is wrong. But the toughest part is to say what the solution is.'' Wilder winces when asked whether he could be compared to House Republican Whip Newt Gingrich, who has established a record as a GOP maverick. Like Wilder, Gingrich loudly denounced higher taxes as a solution for federal deficits. ``I'm not familiar with Newt Gingrich's politics,'' Wilder said. ``One of the things I think differs is that I've shown I can work with people from both sides, with all segments. There isn't the schism that follows me, that follows him.'' Former Democratic Party chairman Charles Manatt says the next presidential candidate must be a fiscal moderate because Americans, ``be they black, white or brown,'' aren't going to step up ``in favor of higher taxes.'' According to political scientist Sabato, Wilder ``understands that a conservative, white Democrat would not be nominated by a party where the selection process is dominated by liberals. ``But he also knows that a black conservative could not be opposed by liberals. It wouldn't be in their constitution to be against that,'' Sabato concludes. Wilder has a point in suggesting that the Democratic Party must nominate a fiscal moderate or conservative next time around, Strauss says. ``But it isn't just Doug Wilder saying it,'' Strauss said. ``Stu Eizenstat, a liberal, has been saying it. I've been saying it. (Georgia Sen.) Sam Nunn has been saying it. I think we're all singing from the same hymn book.'' Kirk said: ``I don't disagree at all with what he's suggesting as the type of candidate the party needs. It's just easier said than done.'' Wilder's ``new mainstream'' style follows two decades in which he adhered to liberal principles while climbing the ladder of Virginia politics. His father was a clerk at a black insurance company. His mother cared for the eight children. The family was poor enough that they had to stuff their shoes with newspaper. Wilder was elected to the Virginia Senate nearly 21 years ago, the first black since Reconstruction. He promptly asked for replacement of the official state song, noting that its lyrics extol plantation life under ``old Massa.'' He became one of the most influential senators in the Legislature, shepherding an array of anti-discrimination laws and winning a long battle to declare a holiday honoring Martin Luther King. He won the lieutenant governorship in 1985, after rejecting the pleas of white party leaders to pull out. They feared he would sink the ticket headed by Gerald Baliles. He won the governorship in 1989 by emphasizing his pro-choice stand on abortion. Wilder prizes political experience. It would be ``awfully difficult'' for someone like Jesse Jackson to get on the ticket without ``some prior life'' in high public office, Wilder says. He did not support Jackson's bid for the Democratic presidential nomination in 1984 or 1988. A pragmatist, Wilder says unsuccessful Democratic presidential candidates, starting with Hubert Humphrey, couldn't win in today's atmosphere of soaring budget deficits. He says: - George McGovern's positions on foreign policy and defense likely would be considered too soft. - Walter F. Mondale is ``eminently qualified to be president'' but was perceived as too beholden to Democratic Party constituent groups. - Michael Dukakis didn't react aggressively to Bush's negative advertising, and probably lost the 1988 presidential election because of it. Wilder has said he foresees a black president in the ``not too distant'' future. Many people think he has himself in mind.

DOC.TEXT: One candidate awaits a verdict on excommunication. Another fights to stay in a religious group she helped found. Four find themselves out of work, rejected by voters. All of them are Roman Catholic and all of them are paying a price for their positions on abortion - no matter which side they're on. Hold to the church teaching that abortion is murder, and a candidate risks learning the hard way that many voters think otherwise. Support a woman's right to an abortion, and the politician may become a pariah in his or her own parish. Several recent incidents illustrate the clash between religion and politics: - Jim Moran, the mayor of Alexandria, Va., and a pro-choice Democratic candidate for Congress, skipped communion three times. ``I didn't want to challenge my pastor and members of the church who would feel upset if a confrontation developed,'' he explained. The local bishop is weighing a request to excommunicate Moran. - Catholic abortion rights supporters defeated anti-abortion Catholics in four Maryland state Senate primaries. Veteran state Sen. Frank Shore, an ardent abortion foe, said the voters disappointed him. ``I thought if they knew my opponent was a Catholic for death and I was a Catholic for life, they would respond,'' he said. ``Nobody responded.'' - State Rep. Mary Boergers, who defeated Shore in the Democratic primary, has stopped speaking at Catholic high schools and keeps a low profile to protect her pastor. She's being thrown out of a Catholic scientists' group she helped found. ``You can say you are where the voters are, but you pay a personal price,'' Boergers says. The price for Catholics, both personal and political, has risen since the Supreme Court's 1989 decision giving states more latitude to restrict abortion. The ruling turned abortion rights into a winning issue in some races and, at the same time, put increased pressure on Catholic public officials. Last October, Rep. Bob Dornan, R-Calif., had the names of all Catholic members of Congress with pro-choice voting records published in the Congressional Record. ``They never have to pay any price,'' Dornan declared on the House floor. ``There are 352 active bishops and they never lean on the self-proclaimed Catholics in this House who say, `I personally believe it is a human being with an immortal soul, a child in the womb, but go ahead and kill it and I'll help you pay for it.' '' Just days later, bishops meeting in Baltimore declared abortion ``the fundamental human rights issue.'' The bishops said no responsible Catholic could be pro-choice, and urged all public officials - ``especially Catholics'' - to seek laws limiting abortions. And last June, Cardinal John O'Connor in New York warned that Catholics who promote pro-choice legislation or make public funds available for abortion are at risk of excommunication. It is ``the only option'' if such actions persist, he said. Richard Doerflinger, associate director of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops' anti-abortion office, disagrees there has been any escalation of pressure on Catholics in public life since the Baltimore meeting. ``I don't know of any Catholic politician who's been criticized for failure to toe the line with an absolute position on this,'' he said. However, Catholics for a Free Choice cites dozens of incidents over the past year. Among the group's examples: - Montana bishops confronted four state officials over their pro-choice stands. - A diocesan newspaper in Providence, R.I., banned the publication of Christmas greetings from politicians who had not signed a statement saying abortion should be constitutionally banned. - Two candidates for the Pennsylvania Legislature were dismissed from church positions because they favored abortion rights. - Pro-choice legislators were forbidden to talk to parochial school students in South Kingston, R.I., and Yonkers, N.Y. In one of the best known cases, a California bishop denied communion to state Senate candidate Lucy Killea because she supported abortion rights. Killea went on to win a special election and tip the chamber to a pro-choice majority. Her opponent blamed the church, saying Killea had been elevated to martyr and celebrity status. The Killea case was by no means an isolated case of backlash against the church, and the David-vs.-Goliath phenomenon has not been lost on church elders. ``The bishops are becoming more aware of that,'' said Doerflinger. ``It's an additional reason to be very, very cautious about anything that seems to be a church penalty against a public figure.'' Doerflinger said some campaign consultants actually advise pro-choice candidates to try to provoke a negative reaction from the church. Shore, the Maryland loser, takes a similarly cynical view of his pro-choice brethren. ``At candidate forums the first thing they holler is `I'm choice, I'm choice.' I think they're trying to read the tea leaves,'' Shore said. ``I was willing to take that chance in defense of the unborn. . . . I would do exactly the same thing today if I had it to do over again.'' Some observers believe the church may be creating a problem that transcends individual victories or losses. ``There is a fear that the bishops could actually create an anti-Catholic climate in the electorate,'' said Frances Kissling, president of Catholics for a Free Choice. She said voters could come to view Catholic politicians as puppets of the church and distrust their ability to put broader interests first. That raises an issue many Catholics thought had been laid to rest 30 years ago, when John F. Kennedy won the presidency. One candidate even paraphrased Kennedy to demonstrate his independence. ``I am not the Catholic candidate for Congress,'' Rhode Island Democrat John Reed said earlier this month. ``I am a candidate for Congress who happens to be Catholic.''

DOC.SECOND: AM-AP Arts: Barnes Foundation, Adv18, 1st-Ld Writethru b0329,1111
DOC.NOTE: $Adv18
For release Thurs AMs, Oct. 18, and thereafter
Eds: Recasts lead. ^Legendary Collection Becoming More Accessible
DOC.TEXT: It may be the greatest art museum you never heard of. There is no sign outside the Barnes Foundation, just a small framed notice on a gate to a Main Line mansion that is hidden behind towering trees and dense rhododendron. Those who sign in at the gatehouse and pay $1 inside the door step into a world of Renoir, Cezanne and Matisse that makes art lovers weak in the knees. ``It's a staggering collection,'' says New York art collector and dealer Richard L. Feigan. ``It's one of the legendary repositories of masterpieces of post-impressionists in the world.'' ``They have more Cezannes than the Met, the National Gallery and Chicago combined, and they're all very high quality,'' says Gary Tinterow, associate curator of European painting at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York. ``The collection is unrivaled,'' adds Charles E. Stuckey, modern art curator at the Art Institute of Chicago. That collection - including 171 Renoirs, 57 Cezannes, 54 Matisses, 19 Picassos and several paintings by van Gogh, Seurat, Degas and Rousseau - is probably worth more than $1 billion. ``There's an embarrassment of choice, there are so many great things,'' said Marco Grassi, a curator in New York. ``It should be one of the musts on everyone's tour of great things to see in America.'' But the foundation is open just 2{ days a week - all day Friday and Saturday and Sunday afternoon - and is closed most of the summer. Paintings are not sold or lent out, and color reproductions - slides or prints - are forbidden. The collection and the restrictions are the legacy of scientist and inventor Dr. Albert C. Barnes, who established the foundation in 1922. According to a plan he laid out shortly before his death at 79 in 1951, control of the foundation has shifted to Lincoln University, a largely black college in the Chester County town of Lincoln University. The change has art scholars hoping for a more open policy at the foundation. ``It's phenomenal and wonderful and we all like it,'' said Tom Freudenheim, assistant secretary for museums at the Smithsonian Institution. ``But it's idiosyncratic.'' That's why so many outside the art world haven't heard of the Barnes Foundation, which is not, as Barnes stressed, a museum, but an educational institution, offering classes in art appreciation. Barnes was an eccentric, brilliant scientist who invented an antiseptic, Argyrol, a mild silver protein that fights infection, made a fortune and bought art - great art - in bunches in the early 20th century, sometimes an entire studio-full at once. Among the treasures: ``Les Grandes Poseuses'' by Seurat; ``Le Bonheur de Vivre'' by Matisse; and ``The Card Players and Girl'' by Cezanne. Barnes feuded with the art establishment, barring critics, art historians and museum officials and most of the general public from his galleries. After his death, members of the public were allowed to enter - if they made a reservation. Slowly, things are changing. The reservations-only restriction was lifted a few years ago, as was a limit of 450 visitors a day. And foundation officials have been talking with museums about modern gallery practices - something Barnes avoided. ``Prior to this, the Barnes Foundation was considered nearly an eccentricity and made no attempt to become part of the art world,'' said Feigan, who is on the Lincoln University board of trustees. Barnes put the paintings on the walls of the mansion in crowded symmetrical arrangements. One wall holds 24 canvases - Picassos and Matisses surrounding a Modigliani. A single small room contains more than 30 Renoirs. ``Museums tend to be carbon copies,'' said Freudenheim of the Smithsonian. ``It's nice to have a place with real personality. I think the idea of a collector's personality shining through is a nice thing. It's full of masterpieces. It's extraordinary.'' The arrangements - as well as the pieces of decorative iron hardware stuck on the walls and the antique furniture in the rooms - are essential elements in Barnes' art education program. That program teaches the scientific analysis of painting, what Barnes felt was an objective way to judge composition, color and, in the end, quality. ``Art appreciation can no more be absorbed by aimless wandering in galleries than can surgery be learned by casual visits to a hospital,'' a foundation pamphlet says. A host of publications are available at the foundation, explaining the Barnes way of looking at things and reflecting his quirks. One pamphlet by Violette de Mazia, education director until her death in September at the age of 89, was titled: ``The Lure and Trap of Color Slides in Art Education,'' and subtitled, ``The Time-Released Venom of Their Make-Believe.'' ``He acted more crazy than he was,'' Feigan said. ``If you look at it, the man was brilliant. The kind of masterpieces he bought could only be bought by someone with an acute eye and brilliant judgment.'' That judgment wasn't infallible. Experts say numerous paintings that Barnes bought as old masters are merely copies. Barnes was long interested in African art - he amassed an impressive collection - and friendly with Lincoln University's president. He amended a trust indenture nine months before his death to allow the school to select foundation trustees as the original trustees retired or died. By 1988, Lincoln-named trustees were in the majority. Don't expect things to change. ``First and foremost, we intend to be very faithful to the indenture and we intend to ensure that the foundation is able to carry out its mission as envisioned by Dr. Barnes,'' said Richard Glanton, president of the foundation. ``I'd like to emphasize that no quick changes will be implemented, if any at all, simply because the character and personality of the institution is a very delicate thing.'' However, Stuckey of Chicago's Art Institute, thinks hours should be lengthened and catalogs published with color reproductions. ``If someone called me up today and offered a decent salary to do a catalog, I'd be packing my bags today,'' he said. Said the Met's Tinterow, who was consulted by the trustees, ``They are very well equipped to usher the Barnes into the next century and maintain it as it is, which is jewel of a collection which represents the ideals and tastes of a remarkable man.''

DOC.HEAD: Country's Richest Man: Gambler, Intellectual
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on financial wires.
DOC.HEAD: Laserphoto RM1 of Oct. 11
DOC.TEXT: Metromedia Co. founder John W. Kluge, the wealthiest man in America, credits much of his success to plain old gambling and good luck. ``The greatest factor in my life - and I know entrepreneurial people don't want to express it, they think it diminishes them - but luck plays a large part,'' Kluge told Forbes magazine in a rare, recent interview. The 76-year-old Kluge (pronounced kloogy) is worth an estimated $5.6 billion, making him the richest man in the country, according to Forbes. The Forbes 400 ranking released last Monday marked the second straight year Kluge topped the list. Last year, the magazine estimated his worth at $5.2 billion. While many successful men are driven by money, Kluge is not, said his estranged wife, Patricia. ``John was a pioneer - he wasn't particularly a man who wanted to be rich or enjoy a grand life,'' Mrs. Kluge, 41, told The Washingtonian magazine in an interview published in August. ``He was more an intellectual businessman than a money-making businessman,'' she said. ``He was more challenged by the creation of new ideas and new markets against all odds . . . He took a small idea and turned it into something grand.'' Friends and colleagues also describe the stocky, balding Kluge as friendly and down-to-earth. ``He's just a regular guy,'' said Alson H. Smith, who has known the Kluges since they moved to Virginia in 1982. ``He'll talk about anything you want to talk about.'' Kluge, born in Germany, came to the United States in 1922 at age 8. The son of an engineer, he and his family settled in Detroit, and for a time he worked on a Ford assembly line. During the Depression, Kluge enrolled in Columbia University and earned an economics degree in 1937. He worked in Army intelligence during World War II. At Columbia, Kluge told Forbes, he was a gambler, often playing cards well into the night to help earn money for school. ``I came out of college with $7,000,'' he said. Kluge got into broadcasting after the war, buying his first radio station in 1946. Later he expanded into television, and his holdings, Metromedia Broadcasting, eventually grew into seven TV stations and 14 radio stations. The TV stations eventually became the foundation of Fox Television. Business wasn't always smooth. In the early 1980s, Metromedia was taking a beating on Wall Street. Kluge, convinced his properties were worth much more, decided to go private by buying out public shares. He warned his wife of tight financial times ahead, but by her own account, she wasn't sympathetic. ``There was no buildup for this thing. I was stunned, as any wife would be,'' she said. ``And I said: `Why don't you have a fortune? All those people lesser than you certainly don't have your brain and your vision, but they have fortunes.' '' When he told her it had never been important for him to become rich, she shot back, ``Damn it, it is now!'' The Kluges had just adopted a son, John W. Kluge II. ``Go out and become a billionaire, and don't come back until you are,'' she said she told her husband. ``And he did.'' Kluge had met Patricia Rose, the Baghdad-born daughter of a British father and Scottish-Iraqi mother, at a dinner party in 1976. She was divorced from Russell Gay, publisher of the British men's magazine Knave, which had run nude photographs of her. She and Kluge were married in 1981, he for the third time. ``What attracted me was his brilliance,'' she said. ``I was absolutely knocked out by his ability to achieve whatever he wanted to achieve.'' The reclusive Kluge declined to be interviewed by The Associated Press. After the highly leveraged buyout that gave him all of Metromedia, Kluge sold off the pieces for $4.65 billion, according to Forbes, and personally netted more than $1.6 billion. ``I felt that television was going to change,'' Kluge told Forbes of the selloff. ``I just thought that it was going to get more competitive.'' Since then, Kluge has invested his profits in other interests, including cellular telephones and restaurants. He owns the Ponderosa Steak House, Bonanza and Steak & Ale chains. He recently sold his New York cellular operations for more than $1 billion in cash and $850 million in stock. Kluge plays his business deals as close to the vest as he plays his cards. ``Whenever I have a plan, I keep it really very much to myself, because I make changes in my own mind,'' he said. ``It's been a habit of mine to do that, not because I don't want to look like I don't make mistakes - I make mistakes all the time - but rather so that people around me don't feel that every five minutes I'm changing my mind. ``I have to work things out, and I sometimes change in the middle of the course,'' he said. ``I think the ability to gauge risks is crucial. I never ordinarily take on things that I can't see some end to, where you pile risks on risks,'' he said. One of Kluge's lesser-known business ventures is cattle breeding on his 10,000-acre Albemarle Farms estate in the shadow of Monticello, Thomas Jefferson's home near Charlottesville, Va. Before the Kluges separated this spring, he balanced the week between Virginia and his New York office, but now spends more time in New York. In a 1986 broadcast interview, he said he moved to the pastoral county near the Blue Ridge Mountains ``because it's a place where the urban centers like Washington don't encroach.'' He also owns 70,000 acres in Scotland. Mrs. Kluge will keep the 45-room Albemarle House mansion the couple built on the Virginia estate plus a reported $1.5 million weekly allowance. She serves on the governing board of nearby University of Virginia. She and Kluge contributed $200,000 to Virginia Gov. L. Douglas Wilder's campaign for election last November, and both served as chairmen of Wilder's inauguration festivities in January. Since the separation, which by all accounts was amicable, Mrs. Kluge has been romantically linked to the 59-year-old Democrat. Wilder says only that he is friends with the Kluges.
