DOC.HEAD: Rhymin' Simon Goes to Brazil
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: There is reason to believe the new Paul Simon album won't be received as well as the double Grammy-winning ``Graceland.'' Still, ``Rhythm of the Saints,'' where South Africa meets Brazil meets the U.S.A., was the next logical step. ``I think it's inevitable that people will compare this to `Graceland.' You can make the comparison, but . . . It's relevant in terms of what I took from `Graceland' and continued with in this,'' the singer-songwriter said of his new release. ``In terms of do you like it more or less, that's up to people's taste or opinion. Is it better? Is it worse? Time will tell. It's really not my job to be deciding that, which is a break for me, because I'm very critical.'' ``Rhythm of the Saints,'' which will be in record stores on Monday, is not the accessible, up-tempo romp of its predecessor. A cultural melange that unites Brazilian drummers with African musicians with American session players, ``Rhythm'' is a darker, denser work than ``Graceland.'' Simon said he enjoyed the project as much as the ``Graceland'' sessions, although he doesn't expect the response the previous album generated. ``Phenomenons don't occur every time. I don't expect that this is going to be a phenomenon,'' Simon said during an interview in his Brill Building office. ``You don't set out to create a phenomenon, you set out to create a piece of music.'' Simon's immediate post-Graceland music had a different focus. He recorded a duet with Brazilian singer Milton Nascimiento and started work on an as yet unfinished Broadway musical (``It's not pop music. It's a different kind of music, different periods of time,'' he said of that project). There were other things to keep Simon busy - back-to-back Grammys for ``Graceland,'' and his induction with old friend Art Garfunkel into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame. ``Rhythm of the Saints'' began when Simon set off for Brazil in March 1988, following the advice of Quincy Jones and Nascimiento that he should check out the great drummers from around the world. Simon was immediately swept up in the sounds and began recording drum tracks, including one done on an eight-track recorder in the town square of a Brazilian village. Several trips south ensued, with Simon finally getting to work full time on the record in May 1989. ``I thought I would be finished by fall '89. But, you know, typically, I missed my deadline,'' said Simon, who was remixing and resequencing the album up until two weeks ago. The album features the drum tracks mixed with some South African players (Ladysmith Black Mambazo makes an appearance) and some top-notch help from the United States: horn player Michael Brecker, drummer Steve Gadd, guitarist J.J. Cale and accordionist C.J. Chenier. Cajun veteran Chenier fit right in with the eclectic mix of players, Simon said. ``I go back to the premise that the West African and Brazilian cultures are connected, and likewise into Caribbean and into Louisiana in the United States,'' said Simon. ``So you bring C.J. Chenier, and you let him play, he finds a pocket. ``It's a little Louisiana groove, but it fits, because there are those elements. I was dealing with a big arc of culture that spanned thee different continents, so a lot of the stuff worked.'' Brecker and Gadd will tour with Simon's 14-piece band later this year - a group that will include four Brazilian percussionists. ``I was dealing with really extraordinary musicians. . . . It's a privilege to get them,'' said Simon. While ``Graceland'' followed Simon's commercially disappointing ``Hearts and Bones,'' this album follows a certified smash. Simon said he's not concerned about following up a multi-platinum effort. ``It's not the first big hit that I've had. It's not even the first phenomenon that's occurred to me. I mean, `The Graduate' was a big thing. `Bridge Over Troubled Water' sold twice as much as `Graceland,' '' said Simon. `` `Still Crazy After All These Years' was the album of the year. The concert in Central Park - about a half a million people. So I've had big successes before, and I've had flops.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, Oct. 14

DOC.HEAD: Children Fare Worst in Nicaraguan Health Crisis
An AP Photo Package by John Gaps III
LaserPhotos NY350-356
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds publishable ed's note with address for contributions.
DOC.TEXT: Nicaragua's health system is crumbling under a load of economic chaos, shortages, corruption and epidemics. Those who suffer most are the children. Diseases that were under control are returning. A measles epidemic has killed hundreds of children this year. The rainy season brings the annual diarrhea epidemic and a host of respiratory problems. Puddles of rainwater breed flies that contaminate uncovered food. People have to drink unsafe water. Poverty deepens in range and scope. Malnutrition ravages small bodies. Conditions are desperate at La Mascota Children's Hospital, which has 240 beds and was built eight years ago. Dr. Adolfo Galan Ruiz, head of the emergency room, asked the mother of a 9-year-old boy: ``Do you know how to pray?'' She nodded, and he said: ``Then start praying.'' The youngster had a leg infection and fever that began with an insect bite. Because he was malnourished, the infection developed into gangrene that threatened his life. Galan said malnutrition was the direct or indirect cause of more than 40 percent of the deaths at La Mascota. Fifty-four children died there in September, 67 in August and 118 in July. ``We have done what we can,'' Galan told the mother. ``The rest is up to God.'' Asked later whether he believed in God, he shrugged and said: ``No.'' In three days, the boy was dead. --- EDITOR'S NOTE: Those who want to help can send contributions to Dr. Enrique Alvarado, Director, Hospital Infantil La Mascota, Apartado Postal C-199, Managua, Nicaragua. Checks should be made payable to the hospital.

DOC.HEAD: Bush to Voters: You're Sick and Tired of Washington Goings-On
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: The voters, President Bush was telling a group of them, are frustrated, outraged by what's going on in Washington, sick and tired of smoke and mirrors that hide congressional spending habits. It sounded like an often tested, seldom successful Republican formula: campaign against Congress, where the Democratic majorities are. This would seem to be a promising season for that message, with signs of rising wrath about the government's inability to manage its own budget. But the Bush message is tempered this time, with good reason. He'd like more Republicans elected to Congress on Nov. 6, but he also needs Democratic support there, before election day, to get the government out of its tax, spending and budget maze. ``Believe me, when you don't control either house of the United States Congress, it ain't easy,'' the president told a Republican fund-raising reception in Atlanta Wednesday night. And it gets worse for a White House that can't hold the Republican minority together for a tax and spending settlement to cut the deficit. Bush held a White House reception Thursday night for ``select Republican House members,'' meaning the 71 who stuck with him on a budget settlement. They were a minority of the House minority - 105 Republicans bolted and helped kill the budget Bush favored. No reception for them. ``It is an outrage what's happening up there,'' Bush said. ``Sucking up tax dollars on one end and turning them into spending programs without end. And frankly, if we had more Republicans in Congress, we wouldn't be in this mess. ``But I've got to work with the Democrats in Congress because I was sent there to govern, not to give speeches about it . . . ,'' he said. ``We're outnumbered. We've got to get the Democrats to come with us . . . .'' In Bush's limited political warfare, he tells his off-year campaign crowds that Congress is responsible for solving the problem, and ought to get on with it to ``bring this ghastly federal budget deficit to its knees.'' ``I didn't come down here to assign blame,'' he said in St. Petersburg, Fla., ``but you know . . . the American people are pretty smart. They know where the action is. And they know that Congress has the responsibility to pass a budget. And it's about time that they met that responsibility.'' That's tame stuff, matched against the traditions of presidential campaigns against Congress. The classic was Harry S. Truman's daily denunciation of ``the do-nothing 80th Congress'' in 1948, when Republicans were in control. Every Republican president since his time has had occasion to campaign against Democratic Congresses, interrupted only by GOP majorities in the Senate during Ronald Reagan's first six years. Dwight D. Eisenhower said congressional Democrats were gloom merchants, ``men of little faith,'' bent on obstruction of programs the people wanted. Reagan said if he couldn't make liberal Democrats in Congress see the light, he would make them feel the heat from the voters. ``Here's a flash from the Gipper - they're not going to win,'' he said. Bush came to office pledging bipartisanship, saying he and Congress weren't elected to bicker. That's still part of his message, even at campaign rallies, and despite the confrontation that is built into divided government. Bush has vetoed 14 bills this year, and hasn't been overridden once. He's threatened a budget veto if he doesn't get satisfactory terms by Friday, a move that could lead to a government shutdown. ``I have tried to negotiate in good faith with the liberals in the Congress,'' he said at one southern campaign stop. ``And I believe the American people didn't send me as president to play cheap politics. They sent me up there to govern.'' --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Walter R. Mears, vice president and columnist for The Associated Press, has reported on Washington and national politics for more than 25 years.

DOC.HEAD: Army Engineers Set To Fill Canal and Rebuild River
DOC.TEXT: In 1984, the cameras rolled as Gov. Bob Graham hefted the first shovelful of dirt in a historic project to fill a canal and rebuild the river it replaced. The $340 million Kissimmee River restoration project is crucial to the survival of the Everglades. If it succeeds, it will serve as the model for similar projects around the country, authorities say. ``This is the headwaters of the Everglades system, and the Everglades is probably the most endangered national park, closest to the brink of environmental collapse,'' said Brien Culhane of the Wilderness Society, who is chairman of the Everglades Coalition, a network of 25 environmental groups. ``This is going to be the most ambitious riverine restoration project ever attempted.'' Graham's shovelful of dirt remains the only dirt moved so far. But Congress is nearing final action on legislation to authorize the project and appropriate $2 million to $6 million for the first year of the decade-long project. After two decades of debate, final design work on the project could begin next year. ``We've overcome the major hurdles,'' said Estus Whitfield, environmental adviser to Graham and the present governor, Bob Martinez. The aim is to undo a U.S. Army Corps of Engineers flood-control project, a segmented canal that brought howls from environmentalists even before it was completed in 1971. About half the 56 miles of canals will be filled to force water back into the old river run and on to the surrounding flood plain. The project has forced state and federal officials to drop rhetoric about saving the Everglades and to confront tough questions: How much is ecological restoration worth? Is restoring the Kissimmee River worth $340 million? So far, the answer has been yes. But the money hasn't yet been spent, and the bills haven't come due. ``I think it's going to be a good test case as to whether society is going to pay for these things,'' said Kent Loftin, director of the Kissimmee River restoration project for the South Florida Water Management District. ``And for whether technology is going to be successful at modifying some of our past work more in line with the way we'd like to have things today.'' The Kissimmee River lies at the headwaters of the Everglades system covering the southern third of Florida. The entire system is a shallow sieve, filtering fresh water that bubbles southward from the river through Lake Okeechobee and the Everglades wetlands to the sea. Lake Okeechobee, the largest fresh-water lake in the United States after the Great Lakes, covers 730 square miles but is only 12 feet deep. South of the lake, water moves through the Everglades in a river 50 miles wide and six inches deep. Its chronicler, the writer Marjorie Stoneman Douglas, called it a ``river of grass.'' Before the Corps o Engineers bulldozed a channel through the Kissimmee, it was a delicate, braided network of oxbows and meandering tributaries that stretched about 100 miles from Lake Kissimmee to Lake Okeechobee. The canals were intended to ease flooding along the river. And they succeeded. But that was not all they accomplished. The Kissimmee's braided course is bordered by a flood plain that was periodically inundated with water before the canal was completed. ``That's what made the system so productive,'' said John Wullschleger, a fisheries biologist with the Florida Game and Freshwater Fish Commission in Okeechobee. ``It was almost like a factory that produced birds and fish.'' With the canal completed, the fish spawning grounds disappeared. ``Most of the year, the water sits in the canal,'' Wullschleger said. ``People are encroaching into flood plain. Once they're there, there's nothing you can do. A lot of the flood plain has been turned into pasture rather than wetlands.'' The 30-foot-deep canals are stagnant much of the year. The water is poor in oxygen and can't support plants. Florida fish, adapted to shallow water and aquatic plants, have declined dramatically. Without the gentle flow and filtering action of the wetlands, agricultural pollutants that enter the river are eventually deposited in Lake Okeechobee, the primary water source for Florida's southeastern coast. In 1983, Graham, now a U.S. senator, inaugurated a save-the-Everglades program that included a provision to somehow restore the environmental values of the Kissimmee River. In 1985, the Corps of Engineers completed a report outlining options for restoring the river, but under Reagan administration policy, the economic benefits of the project had to outweigh the costs. ``There were no quantifiable economic benefits,'' Lewis Hornung, director of central and southern Florida projects for the corps, said. ``So we concluded that there was no federal interest in proceeding with the restoration project.'' Meanwhile, the South Florida Water Management District had begun its own research, including the construction of several weirs, or dams, as part of a demonstration project to determine whether river channels would recover if water were forced back into them. ``What we saw was good response from the old river channel to having flow restored,'' Loftin said. ``We saw good response from the flood plain from having it flooded seasonally.'' By 1989, the water management district had decided to recommend the most expensive restoration option. It provides for the complete filling of 25 to 30 miles of the 56-mile canal and partial filling of much of the remainder. The canals can't be entirely filled, because people have moved into the flood plain along the upstream portion of the canal, Loftin said. In January, Martinez endorsed that recommendation. The Corps of Engineers has so far received $6.3 million for work on the Kissimmee River. The first part of the project will cost $80 million, $30 million in construction costs and $50 million to buy land in the flood plain. Florida will be responsible for most of the land costs. It hopes Congress will pay for most of the construction. Loftin said $9 million or $10 million is likely to be spent during the next two or three years, depending upon the size of congressional appropriations. The next step is approval of the overall plan by the Corps of Engineers, expected early next year. ``If we got a project commitment at about that point in time, we have all the necessary steps identified to begin the final round of detail work that needs to be done,'' Loftin said. ``The major work we feel could begin sometime in the middle of 1992.'' Land acquisition has already begun. ``The Corps of Engineers has been touting that they're the new environmental engineers of the 1990s. The Kissimmee project should be their flagship,'' Culhane of the Everglades Coalition said. ``This will be looked at internationally as a model of ecosystem restoration - that we can look at our past mistakes, that we have the will, and wherewithal, to begin restoring natural systems where we can.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday, Oct. 15

DOC.TEXT: Oil prices seesawed wildly in the futures market, first jumping into record territory above $41 a barrel then tumbling on a vague rumor that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein had been killed. Light sweet crude closed $1.71 lower Wednesday at $38.69 per barrel for November delivery contracts on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Later delivery months were all down by more than $1 a barrel. --- MOSCOW (AP) - Wall Street executives teaching the Soviets about financial markets said they told their hosts to start by selling shares in the profitable state airline, tourist agency and petroleum businesses. The U.S. delegation led by New York Stock Exchange Chairman John J. Phelan Jr. also met for 90 minutes Wednesday with President Mikhail Gorbacev and signed a formal cooperation agreement with finance officials to exchange information. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - New projections by the Bush administration show the fund insuring bank deposits shrinking to less than half its current size within three years, a senior House Banking Committee member said. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corp.'s fund for commercial banks will lose $6.1 billion through fiscal 1993 even if the fees banks pay for deposit insurance are increased, Rep. Frank Annunzio, D-Ill., citing projections by the Office of Management and Budget said Wednesday. The new estimates are sharply more pessimistic than the budget office's previous projections. In June, the budget office had estimated the FDIC would show a profit of $600 million over the three-year period, Annunzio said. --- BRUSSELS, Belgium (AP) - Unemployment in the European Community rose 0.1 percent to 8.4 percent in August - 15.8 percent for people under 25 - the EC Commission said in a statement. The rise is the first in the 12-nation trade bloc since February and prompted Commission Vice President Henning Christophersen to call for the speeding up of economic and monetary union within the EC. But he said observers shouldn't ``over- interpret'' the increase. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Federal regulators voted to explore ways to make it easier for Canadian companies to sell securities in the United States and their U.S. counterparts to market them north of the border. The Securities and Exchange Commission voted unanimously to seek public comment on rules changes that would allow Canadian companies to use forms and documents from their home country to satisfy U.S. disclosure requirements. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Buyout strategist Theodore Forstmann is seeking investors for a $1.5 billion fund that would finance acquisitions of companies by using debt, a source knowledgable about the proposal said. The venture is likely to be watched by Wall Street as a barometer of the market for debt-financed buyouts. Since the collapse of the junk bond market a year ago, many investors have shunned the idea of funding acquisitions primarily with debt. The source said Wednesday that Forstmann is planning to offer investors in his fund yields 1 percent above the interest rate on five-year Treasury bonds, which now yield about 8.5 percent. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Three of the Supreme Court's nine justices gave a chilly reception to an employer's ``fetal protection'' policy that excludes women of childbearing age from some hazardous jobs. In a case that could affect millions of working women, Justices John Paul Stevens, Sandra Day O'Connor and Antonin Scalia voiced doubts about the wisdom and legality of such a policy. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Saks Fifth Avenue will lay off 700 workers as it undergoes a streamlining following its purchase by an investor group earlier this year, officials of the upscale fashion retailer said. Most of the layoffs will made among Saks' corporate staff, with some job cuts being made immediately and the rest expected by the middle of 1991, said Saks Chairman Melvin Jacobs. Saks, which has 47 stores in 22 states, has an overall workforce of about 12,000. James Martinez, a Saks vice chairman, said sales were running ``nicely ahead of last year.'' --- SOFIA, Bulgaria (AP) - The government on submitted to Parliament sweeping plans to change the command economy left behind by four decades of communism into a free-market system along Western lines. The economic program presented by Premier Andrei Lukanov places emphasis on denationalization, privatization, demonopolization, competition and a new monetary, credit and banking system, the state BTA news agency reported. President Zhelyu Zhelev, a leading opposition figure before his appointment, said rival parties in Parliament were prepared to support the legislation. BTA said small-scale enterprises would be the first to be denationalized, probably beginning in December. ---
DOC.HEAD: By The Associated Press
DOC.TEXT: Stocks fell sharply Wednesday for the second day in a row. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials fell 37.62 to 2,407.92, its lowest close since it stood at 2,382.88 on May 11 of last year. Silver prices fell to the lowest point in 13 years. The dollar was mixed in world trading. Gold prices fell. Grain and soybean futures prices closed mostly lower on the Chicago Board of Trade. Livestock and pork futures were lower. Profit-taking fueled a selloff of energy futures. Bond prices fell sharply.

DOC.HEAD: Despite Turmoil, Pacific Routes Help United Fly Past Competitors
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Epic takeover battles and soaring operating costs might sound like a formula for failure but they haven't downed United Airlines. But the carrier is beating the flaps off its competition and many observers sum up United's success in two words: Pacific expansion. Earlier this year it became the biggest carrier across the Pacific Ocean, surpassing Japan Air Lines and Northwest Airlines. United's success comes despite two leadership changes and four buyout bids in the last four years as well as an industry-wide domestic business slump and a sharp increase in fuel prices. Parent company UAL Corp. rejected the latest employee acquisition offer Tuesday, ending more than a year of constant pressure on the company's board and management. But the stress never showed in the airline's performance. ``We all suspect it's been distracting but anybody who makes that assertion is hard-pressed to support it,'' said Robert Decker, an airline analyst with Duff & Phelps Inc. UAL had not yet resumed contract negotiations Wednesday with its flight attendants, pilots and mechanics, said company spokeswoman Sara Dornacker. The unions, which all are working under expired contracts, pledged on Tuesday to ``pursue all means necessary'' to get substantial improvements in wages and benefits. But United's revenues, market share and on-time performance have actually improved since last year while passenger complaints and mishandled-baggage reports are down. Profits have slipped - parent UAL Corp. reported net income of $112 million for the first six months of 1990 compared with $207 million for the same period last year. And UAL earned $324 million for all of 1989 after posting record profits of $1.1 billion in 1988. But analysts say the decline reflects the condition of the entire U.S. airline industry. For the first nine months of this year, United's trans-Pacific revenue passenger miles - the number of miles flown by paying customers - totaled 15.3 billion, a 32 percent increase over the same period last year. The surge in Pacific business compares with a 3.4 percent increase in United's North American business for the first nine months of 1990. Pacific travel now accounts for 24 percent of United's business. That share is likely to grow as the airline adds to the 755 flights it now makes each week across the ocean, said United spokesman Joe Hopkins. Chicago-based United has been taking delivery of one new plane per week in recent months, mostly to replace aging aircraft in its domestic fleet. But the airline also has received six long-range Boeing 747-400s in the past year to expand its trans-Pacific fleet, and will soon announce a large order for wide-bodied jetliners for international travel, Hopkins said. The Pacific expansion, directed by UAL Chairman Stephen Wolf, has given United a slight edge over arch-rival American Airlines in monthly revenue passenger miles since June. As of September, United still trailed American in year-to-date business but appeared likely to become the undisputed largest U.S. airline by year-end. Trans-Pacific business also has been a boon to United's bottom line because long-distance routes are the most profitable an airline can fly. A long flight allows an airline to spread fixed costs such as food and labor over a greater number of miles, reducing the cost per mile. And the laws of supply and demand allow airlines to increase profit margins for flights across the Pacific. ``In the United States you've got six or seven carriers flying into London six times a day but if you want to go to Tokyo you've got maybe four carriers, each having one flight a day,'' said analyst Stephen Dexter of Kemper Financial Services Inc. ``A lot of people want to go to Tokyo and they'll pay a premium price to get there.''

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Nations Put on Brave Face in Uncertain Economy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Gulf nations hit hard economically by Saddam Hussein's invasion of Kuwait are putting on brave faces despite big cash crunches, paralyzed stock markets, drooping trade and bolting expatriates. Gulf banks squeezed of their liquidity by the mass scramble for dollars in August have been releasing statements saying the situation has normalized. Abdullah Saif, governor of the Bahrain Monetary Agency, recently told the Arabic-language daily Al-Ayam that ``the public has already started to return some of those funds to the banking system. Stability is quickly returning to Bahrain's banking sector.'' But neutral observers say the oil-rich region is in a state of limbo. ``The sooner the state of no-war no-peace is over, the better,'' said a Western businessman who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``Normality has returned to some extent, but unless it's a matter of quick profit, no one's going to risk anything for the moment.'' Deposits in Bahrain's commercial banks declined by 12 percent during the panic that gripped the region in the first weeks after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion. Some 1.9 billion riyals, about $5 billion, were pulled out of Qatar by the end of August. In the United Arab Emirates, Central Bank Governor Abdul-Malik al-Hamar estimated that in the first two weeks of August, deposits including those by the government dropped by 5.9 percent. Private-sector deposits declined by 9.8 percent, he said. Bahrain, Qatar, the U.A.E., Oman, Saudi Arabia and Kuwait are grouped in the GCC economic and security alliance. Together with Iraq and Iran, the Gulf states sit on two-thirds of the world's proven oil reserves. GCC assistant secretary-general for economic affairs Abdullah al-Quwaiz told the Saudi Press Agency in Riyadh this week that ``ministers of finance and economy and central bank governors in the Gulf Cooperation Council are confident about the solidity of the economic, fiscal and banking conditions of the member states,'' Fawzi Behzad, director of Bahrain's Stock Exchange, also dismissed his market's tumbling as a normal reaction to the situation. ``Bahrain's stock market was strong enough to absorb what happened in the Gulf,'' he said. ``Just like any market, prices go up when there is good news, and they go down when the news is bad.'' But observers say some uncertainty remains. Exchange houses throughout the region have been among the busiest centers as expatriate workers diligently remit their salaries back home in greater volume than before. The profile of Gulf foreign trade has changed considerably. A businessman in the U.A.E., who asked to not be named, said local banks were asking for 100 percent cash coverage for letters of credit, which is not possible for most medium-sized companies. Nervous shippers are also asking for cash down payments before sailing. Five major lines serving the Gulf announced rate hikes due to additional fuel charges and currency adjustment rates. Property values have decreased across the Gulf, and the departure of an estimated 10 percent of expatriates has affected trading, said Abdul-Nebi al-Sho'ala, a member of Bahrain's Chamber of Commerce. ``The purchasing of luxury items and durables has decreased,'' he said. Recruitment agencies also say there will be fewer Westerners working in the region. ``Now it is really difficult to get new recruits from Europe to convince them to work in the Gulf, and those who accept would like to impose their own conditions, including astronomical salaries,'' said Christine Bond, managing director of the ABC Agency in Abu Dhabi.

DOC.HEAD: Knight-Ridder Reinvents a Community Newspaper
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Knight-Ridder Inc. unveils a redesigned newspaper Thursday that seeks a share of quality time in this baby-boomer rich suburb. The News, a reconstituted 35-year-old daily, takes its visual cues from USA Today with heavy use of color, maps and indexes, eye-catching graphics and clean lines. In content, short, trendy stories will be the norm. Broadsheet sections have been reserved for the top news, local developments, business and sports. Feature articles are offered in a tabloid magazine called Essentials. ``What we did was to take a very specific community and say, `If we were reinventing the newspaper, if a newspaper didn't exist in this place, and we were trying to create a newspaper that we thought would have the greatest appeal to the people in this community, what would it be?' '' said James Batten, Knight-Ridder chairman and chief executive officer. While many newspapers have evolved along similar lines in recent years, this is one of the most thoroughly researched projects aimed at baby boomers. The population bulge between ages 25 and 43 also has among it many infrequent newspaper readers. ``People were skeptical at first because they were afraid we were trying to reinvent USA Today for the local area,'' said Lou Heldman, the project's corporate coordinator. ``It is meant to have all of the traditional journalistic components: to do investigative reporting, to be a watchdog over government and institutions, to run stories with an edge when that's called for and to not homogenize the writing style.'' Nearly two years of research went into a prototype intended as a model for the company, which produces 29 dailies, including The Miami Herald, The Philadelphia Inquirer and the Detroit Free Press. ``There are 77 million people in the baby boom generation. They will be the primary customers for news for about the next 40 years,'' Heldman said. ``No one can afford to forget them if they want to be in business 20 years from now.'' But for decades, many newspapers stayed the same staid gray shade while everything from television to working women were remaking American society. ``We don't spend much time in the business asking ourselves what our readers are interested in,'' News editor Wayne Ezell conceded. ``We tend to engage people who read newspapers. We need to talk to the people who don't read newspapers.'' Miami-based Knight-Ridder has done that and thinks it has produced a product busy boomers will want. ``This one has the cosmetic element to it, but the cosmetics are not what is important here,'' Ezell said. ``We are trying to write more about things that people are talking about.'' The newspaper, whose circulation is estimated at 40,000, has been tailored specifically for Boca Raton, a community of 67,000 people between Fort Lauderdale and West Palm Beach. Its image is that of an upscale retirement haven, but 30 percent of the population is in the baby boomer pool, half of whom have arrived in the past five years. Loyal, older readers haven't been left out. A focus group study of readers over age 45 showed that ``it's a bigger hit frankly with the older readers than the younger readers,'' he said. Batten regards The News as a laboratory testing potential applications for other Knight-Ridder papers. The changes are welcomed by industry analysts watching a company whose strength has been its prize-winning editorial content. ``I think in today's busy world, people will appreciate this and find the papers more readable,'' said investment analyst Susan Putnam of Moran Asset Management in Greenwich, Conn. ``It'll be interesting to see how it develops.''

DOC.HEAD: Insurance Giant Battered by Real Estate Slump
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The nation's shaky real estate market has become a nightmare for Travelers Corp., driving away investors and sending the insurance giant's stock into a downward spiral. The slide accelerated last Friday when Travelers announced it was cutting its dividend, putting aside $650 million in reserves against future real estate losses, would report a third-quarter loss of about $500 million, and would post a yearly loss for the first time in its history. The company's stock, which sold for $49 per share in January 1987 and $25 per share in early September, tumbled from $20.75 Friday to $13.625 by the end of trading Wednesday. Analysts say Travelers' woes have deepened investors' fears about insurance companies. Many, like banks and other financial institutions, have extensive investments in real estate and mortgages. A Standard & Poor's Corp. index tracking stock prices of multi-service insurance companies has dropped 28 percent since the beginning of the year. Aetna Life & Casualty Co. stock closed Wednesday at $29.875, off 50 cents from Tuesday, and down from a 1990 high of $57 per share. Analysts caution, however, that Travelers' problems don't necessarily foreshadow serious troubles for other insurance giants. They say Travelers has been an aggressive investor in real estate and is saddled with a relatively high level of bad loans. ``In general, insurance companies do have exposure to real estate problems, and some of those problems have yet to be recognized,'' said Gloria Vogel, an analyst for Bear, Stearns & Co. ``The question becomes, `How far ahead of the pack is Travelers in recognizing problems? Or is Travelers just in a worse situation?'' ``By the company's own acknowledgement, they made some errors,'' said Herbert Goodfriend, an analyst at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. ``They were very aggressive in the early 1980s, with an overindulgence in the Southwest.'' Of its $57.3 billion in total assets, $17.3 billion is invested in real estate, mostly in mortgage loans on commercial properties such as hotels, office buildings and shopping centers. Travelers estimated Friday that $3.5 billion of its mortgage loans are problems - either foreclosed, in the process of foreclosure, or restructured to be repaid over a longer period. That news was not completely unexpected - the company was forced to set aside $415 million in reserves in 1988. But the company also announced it was reducing dividends to stockholders for the first time, from 60 cents to 40 cents for the third quarter. It was that announcement, Goodfriend said, that scared off investors and raised questions about Travelers' future. ``It destroyed investor confidence,'' he said. ``And it raises the question of whether the company will stick to the new dividend schedule.'' Without the $650 million real estate charge, Travelers Chairman Edward H. Budd pointed out, the company's operating income for 1990 was expected to exceed 1989 earnings of $319 million by as much as 25 percent. In an attempt to calm investors, Travelers executives met with analysts and investors Monday in New York, spelling out a plan to boost the company's capital by selling some assets. By cutting the dividend, the executives explained, they hoped to save about $100 million and use it to expand the company's money-making lines of property-casualty insurance and managed health-care group insurance. But both of those lines face uncertain futures. Property-casualty insurance tends to be a cyclical market, and most analysts agree the cycle is slumping. And many analysts, including Goodfriend, believe the growth of managed health-care group insurance peaked in the 1980s and that Travelers may be arriving in that market too late.

DOC.HEAD: Saks Laying Off 700, Looking to Expand Business
DOC.TEXT: Saks Fifth Avenue will lay off nearly 6 percent of its workforce and plans to boost investment to renovate stores, open specialty shops and expand its mail-order business. Some of the 700 job cuts are to be made immediately and the rest are expected by the middle of next year, Saks Chairman Melvin Jacobs said Wednesday. Most of the layoffs will be from Saks' corporate staff. Saks, which has 47 stores in 22 states, has an overall workforce of about 12,000. Jacobs said that while the retailer is looking for ways to cut costs, it also plans a ``significant capital investment'' for store renovations and improvements. Saks also aims at doubling its $55 million mail order business over the next five years, and is considering opening specialty stores and expanding overseas, said Philip Miller, a Saks vice chairman. There was no indication that Saks, which has been one of the most profitable U.S. retailers, was running in the red. As a private company, it is not required to disclose its sales or profit figures, but James Martinez, a Saks vice chairman, said sales were running ``nicely ahead of last year.'' Saks was bought last April by Investcorp, a Middle East-based company that also has large stakes in other upscale retailers, including Tiffany & Co. and Gucci. When BAT Industries PLC put it on the market a year ago, Saks was sought by a number of investor groups. Investcorp won the bidding with a $1.5 billion offer. Jacobs said top Saks management holds an 8 percent stake in the company. He described the retailer as now taking an entrepreneurial approach, with executives being given the opportunity to also acquire equity in the firm.

DOC.HEAD: Instant ``Cuppas'' For Tea-loving Britain
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: In a country where tea is not just a beverage but a social event, two companies are betting consumers will drop the messy ritual of brewing leaves or bags and go for granules. But are Britons ready to have their favorite drink - or ``cuppa'' - any other way? Nestle failed to woo tea drinkers with an instant version more than a decade ago, and many Britons are still horrified by office instant tea made by machines. A spot check on a London street found Britons unenthusiastic about the idea of tea granules, which Brooke Bond and Premier Beverage Products said Wednesday they will begin distributing nationwide. ``That would be dreadful,'' said Garnham Trotter, a 48-year-old electrical engineer. ``We have instant tea in machines in the office and it's really dreadful.'' Susan Essex, a 26-year-old secretary, said: ``I think part of the pleasure of tea is the brewing of it.'' In the United States, instant iced tea is popular but the hot version never caught on. Tea is the favorite drink in Britain; 80 percent of the population over age 10 drinks tea every day and the average person drinks three to four cups a day, the Tea Council says. Successful test runs in the Midlands in central England over the past few months have convinced the two companies that their instant tea is the biggest development in the $1.2 billion tea market since tea bags hit Britain 37 years ago. Tea bags make four-fifths of all cups brewed, loose tea the rest. The Tea Council's executive director, Illtyd Lewis, said there's bound to be a market for instant tea. Still, he said, ``I don't see it turning the tea world on its head. People will continue to brew the product in the traditional ways as they have done for hundreds of years.'' The two companies are spending $18 million marketing the granules, and Premier Beverage Products even plans to distribute free samples to half of Britain's homes. ``It's a natural progression,'' said Premier spokesman Tony Camp. ``This is what coffee has done.'' Camp conceded that making a traditional cup of tea is not so difficult, or time-consuming - wet leftover bags aside. But ``if you can put convenience and taste together, it seems to be a winner,'' he said. Nestle sold Nestea as an instant hot tea in Britain in the 1960s and 1970s, but it was not a success, said Nestle spokesman Allan Allbeury. ``It was probably before its time,'' Allbeury said. ``People would brew their tea very much to their particular tastes. Nestea was a very standardized flavor.''

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Plunge, Dollar Unchanged
DOC.NOTE: Eds: version on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Share prices in Tokyo plunged today as Wall Street's steep decline discouraged investors. The dollar closed unchanged against the Japanese yen. The Nikkei 225-share index lost 909.48 points, or 3.87 percent, closing at 22,585.63. That added to a 135-point drop on Tuesday. Markets were closed Wednesday for a national holiday. Investors were discouraged by the 111-point decline in the Dow Jones industrial average over the past two sessions. ``With investors almost shocked by the New York market's declines, there were very few buy orders,'' said Masashi Wakabayashi, a trader with Yamaichi Securities Co. Traders also linked the decline to rising oil prices and the weakening Tokyo bond market. In currency dealings, the dollar traded as low as 129.45 yen before closing at 129.95 yen, matching its closing level on Tuesday. The dollar opened lower after an overnight drop in New York, but heavy profit-taking on the yen checked the dollar's slide, traders said. Fears of possible interest rate cuts in Japan also supported the dollar. Bank of Japan Governor Yasushi Mieno told a news conference today that the dollar is falling too quickly against the yen, despite basic factors in the market that support its decline. The market is still striving to adjust to prospects of lower interest rates and weakening business conditions in the United States, he said. Mieno added that the U.S. Federal Reserve is likely to ease monetary policy soon, leading to lower interest rates. Expectations of lower U.S. interest rates are encouraging foreign exchange traders to sell the dollar as the value of dollar-denominated securities declines. In bond dealings, the price of benchmark No. 119 10-year government bonds fell to 82.74 points from Tuesday's 83.48-point close. Their yield climbed to 8.210 percent from 8.035 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Government Sees $6.1 Billion Drop in Bank Insurance Fund
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration predicts that bank failures will reduce the government insurance fund protecting deposits by $6.1 billion over three years, a House subcommittee chairman says. The commercial bank fund of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. will decline from $11.4 billion at the end of June to $5.3 billion by Sept. 30, 1993, which would mark its sixth consecutive annual loss, Rep. Frank Annunzio, D-Ill., said Wednesday. The shrinkage to less than half the fund's current size will come even if regulators continue to raise insurance premiums charged to banks, said Annunzio, chairman of the House Banking subcommittee on financial institutions. He cited projections by the administration's Office of Management and Budget contained in the budget agreement reached by White House negotiators and congressional leaders on Sept. 30. The new estimates are far more pessimistic than the budget office's previous projections. In June, it had estimated the FDIC would show a profit of $600 million over the three-year period. Roger Watson, FDIC director of research, said the figures as described by Annunzio ``certainly are pessimistic.'' ``They are possible, but not likely,' he said. They show the fund reserves falling to only 22 cents for every $100 in deposits by the end of the 1993 fiscal year. That is less than one-fifth the $1.25 minimum considered safe and less than half the 60-cent level in the fund at the end of June. ``These OMB projections are doubly alarming when you realize that they are based on economic assumptions that do not include a recession,'' Annunzio said. ``The taxpayer is in serious jeopardy of being asked to bail out the banks.'' Annual losses in the fund, by fiscal year, are projected at $3.7 billion in 1991, $2.3 billion in 1992 and $100 million in 1993. The latest forecast is being made despite an assumption that insurance premiums paid by banks will continue to rise. The fee already is set to increase from 12 cents per $100 of deposits this year to 19.5 cents next year. The budget office assumed it would go to 23 cents in 1992 and 1993. The FDIC itself has not made projections for its fund beyond the end of this calendar year. The bank fund lost $1.8 billion in the first six months of this year and will lose an additional $1 billion by Dec. 31, the agency has said. FDIC Chairman L. William Seidman said last summer the fund was ``under stress'' but would be adequate to handle foreseeable bank failures, which are expected to total around 200 in 1990 for the fourth consecutive year. Nevertheless, Seidman is asking Congress to lift legal caps on how high his agency may raise its insurance premiums. Legislation to do that has passed the House and is scheduled for action by the Senate Banking Committee on Friday. The General Accounting Office, Congress's auditing arm, and the Congressional Budget Office have issued warnings about the condition of the bank insurance fund.

DOC.HEAD: Veto Override Attempt Falls Just Short
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Advocates of toughened import restrictions intended to protect the jobs of American textile, clothing and shoe workers will have to wait for another day. For the third time in five years, supporters of tighter quotas failed Wednesday night to muster a required two-thirds majority in the House to override President Bush's veto of a quota bill. The 275-152 roll call fell only 10 votes short of the needed margin of approval, however, and opponents predicted the issue will be back when a new Congress convenes in January. ``Three strikes and you're out may be the rule in baseball, but not necessarily on Capitol Hill,'' said Rep. Philip Crane, R-Ill. In vetoing the measure last Friday, Bush said the measure would ``pick the pockets of U.S. consumers'' at an average cost of $100 a year in higher clothing prices for a typical family of four and undermine efforts to get other countries to lower their barriers to American exports. Over the past decade, the United States has lost some 400,000 textile and apparel jobs - 66,000 in the last year alone - to a tripling of imports from low-wage trading partners. ``For all the rhetoric and theory about free trade, the real issue is American jobs - of people we were elected to represent, who pay taxes to keep this government going,'' Rep. Helen Bentley, R-Md., said in urging an override. The Senate passed the bill in July by a potentially veto-proof margin of 68-32. The House approved it last month, 271-149, despite Bush's repeated vows to that he would veto it. Wednesday's vote maintained Bush's perfect veto record since taking office 20 months ago. He has disapproved 15 bills, and all 10 override attempts in Congress have failed. The bill would have imposed new quotas on a product-by-product and country-by-country basis to limit the annual growth of U.S. imports in textiles and textile products to 1 percent a year. Imports of non-rubber footwear - leather, vinyl and plastic shoes - would have been frozen at 1989 levels. None of the provisions would have applied to Canada and Israel, which have free-trade agreements with the United States. Congress passed nearly identical bills in 1985 and 1988 but, then as now, was unable to muster the two-thirds majorities needed in both the House and Senate to override vetoes by former President Reagan. This year, supporters were able to pick off opposition from some farm-state lawmakers who feared trading partners would retaliate by limiting their imports of U.S. agriculture products. Sen. Thomas Daschle, D-S.D., sponsored a provision to permit textile, clothing and shoe imports above the quotas from any country that increases its purchases of U.S. farm exports. However, many U.S. apparel manufacturers who had supported the bill in the past abandoned it this time after relocating their factories to Mexico and the Caribbean to employ low-wage workers to cut and sew clothing from American-made fabric.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Higher in Europe, Gold Lower
DOC.NOTE: Eds: version on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar rose in light European trading late this morning. Gold prices were down but off the lows reached earlier in Asia and late Wednesday in New York. Traders were unwilling to push the dollar lower amid the ongoing political and military tension in the Persian Gulf. At the same time, however, dealers tempered their dollar purchases because of the weak U.S. economy and widespread expectations that the Federal Reserve will ease U.S. interest rates soon. One currency analyst in Frankfurt said the dollar appears to be pausing at present after its declines over the past few days and is likely to continue downward soon given the ongoing economic problems in the United States. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 129.95, unchanged from Tuesday. Japanese markets were closed on Wednesday for a holiday. In London late this morning, it was quoted at a higher rate of 130.55 yen. In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.9676, cheaper for buyers than $1.9755 late Wednesday. Other dollar rates at midmorning in Europe, compared with late Wednesday's rates included: 1.5315 German marks, up from 1.5285; 1.2845 Swiss francs, up from 1.2785; 5.1260 French francs, up from 5.1160; 1.7245 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7225; 1,147.00 Italian lire, up from 1,143.25, and 1.1507 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1495. London's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended gold price of $389.60 per ounce at midmorning, down from $390.25 bid late Wednesday. In Zurich, the bid price was $388.50, down from $390.75. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold fell $2.56 to close at a bid $389.71. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $4.37 a troy ounce, down from Wednesday's $4.53.

DOC.HEAD: Opening a Stock Exchange Easy: Hard Part Is Finding Buyers And Sellers ^Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Opening a stock exchange 70 years after Lenin outlawed trading is the easy part. Getting Soviets to invest savings long hidden under mattresses will be the bigger hurdle. Aspiring Soviet investors and their New York Stock Exchange mentors agreed during a seminar this week that a limited stock exchange could be revived in the Soviet Union as early as next year. But a full-fledged market will require both large-scale privatization of state enterprises and widespread public education, they said. ``People in this country, perhaps they could be persuaded to buy something intangible,'' said Dmitri Tulin of the state bank, known as Gosbank. ``They prefer to buy something substantial.'' Soviets have accumulated a vast horde of paper rubles over the years because high state subsidies and barren store shelves left them little to spend their money on. Soviet economists estimate the so-called ruble overhang at about 250 billion rubles ($440 billion at the official exchange rate), although U.S. experts say it is twice that. A recent survey by the ``Nedelya'' weekly publication found only half of the 6,000 people it questioned had a bank account, and only 13 percent of them kept more than 1,000 rubles in it. The Wall Street experts said that if the Soviet government wants to soak up those excess rubles and create tradeable shares, it should begin selling off its wealth of state enterprises. First on to the auction block should be profitable companies or those with good profit potential such as the Aeroflot state airline, the Intourist travel agency or parts of the oil industry, the Americans said. However, Finance Minister Valentin Pavlov told a concluding news conference on Wednesday that the government has no firm timetable for setting up a stock exchange or for widescale privatization. Like many government officials attending the three-day seminar, he tried to put the brakes on the participants' enthusiasm, urging the 400 business people, bankers, researchers and academics to go slow and start small. Pavlov recommended that any new Soviet stock exchange start trading in bonds, rather than shares. John Chalsty, who becomes NYSE chairman next year, said that was a logical first step until private companies can be formed. ``It was my sense that a securities exchange can in fact be established in relatively short order, that it can start trading securities, mostly fixed income, but that it will be a much slower process before you actually get stocks, shares of ownership, traded on that exchange,'' Chalsty said. ``That will depend on the progress of privatization. You've got to have something to trade before you can trade it and before you can have something to trade you've got to have an entity that's tradeable.'' The Soviet Cabinet, or Council of Ministers, said in June that certain state enterprises could become joint stock companies and issue shares to individuals and institutions. More than 400 companies, mostly commercial banks, already have seized the offer although in most cases the government has retained a majority interest. Without brokers, a stock market or even facilities to print share certificates, they haven't even begun to trade over the counter. A stock market flourished in St. Petersburg - now Leningrad - for more than 200 years until it was closed by World War I. Stocks were outlawed after the Bolshevik Revolution. A smaller Moscow stock exchange existed near Red Square in a building now occupied by the Chamber of Commerce, and there were more than 100 commodities exchanges in czarist Russia. Hungary has the only functioning stock exchange in Eastern Europe, but trading has been light since it opened in Budapest in June after a lapse of 42 years. The Polish government has prepared a draft law on securities and hopes to open a stock exchange next year.

DOC.HEAD: Convenience Foods Gaining Popularity in Asia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: If it can be stir-fried or microwaved, a food item stands a better chance of getting attention from importers in prosperous Asian countries, says an Agriculture Department report. Consumer tastes are changing in the Orient. Fast foods, Western-style meals and a growing interest in healthful diets are making an impact. ``Asian consumers are also returning to their culinary roots, seeking out traditional foods, but with a new twist - convenience,'' said Violet Oon, a food editor in Singapore. ``The result is a desire for tradition in a packet that can be defrosted or microwaved.'' Oon, writing in the November issue of AgExporter magazine, said the new trends of Asian eating didn't develop overnight. Basically, she said, the changes in consumer tastes are linked to rising disposable income, openness to imports, a receptive news media and growth of the middle class. Singapore is ``on the leading edge in consumer tastes'' among the countries of Southeast Asia, Oon said. As countries develop economically, more and more consumers eat out as women join the work force. And domestic help is hard to come by. ``This has meant that home cooking is not what it once was,'' Oon said. ``Traditional cooking methods have been forgotten, and cooking has gone instant.'' For example: freshly squeezed coconut milk in bottles, deep-fried shallots and pre-peeled and pre-cut onions for the preparation of traditional meals, whether they are Malay, Indonesian or Singaporean. ``Anything traditional that can be pre-packaged or pre-mixed has a ready market,'' Oon said. There is still another trendy wave among Asians, she said. This is an obsession with health and nutrition, particularly the use of cooking fats and their relationship to cholesterol. ``Even China has not been immune to this trend,'' Oon said. ``Representatives of the international edible oils industry report that the Chinese have switched from lard to vegetable oil.'' Despite the emphasis on healthful eating habits, Oon said restaurants report that low-calorie menus are generally shunned by Asian customers. Yet, the health-food shops are doing well. ``What this means is that when it comes to eating out, the Asian consumer still wants to eat sinfully,'' she said. ``It's only when eating in the privacy of the home that the Asian consumer is really concerned about health.'' --- WASHINGTON (AP) - A recent big sale of cigarettes to the Soviet Union was good news for U.S. tobacco farmers and served further notice of a growing dependence on overseas markets, according to an Agriculture Department report. Two companies are selling 34 billion cigarettes to the Soviets over the next two years, the department's Economic Research Service said in the October issue of Agricultural Outlook magazine. ``The Soviet deal is equal to nearly 25 percent of U.S. cigarette exports in 1989 and appears to be only a forerunner of U.S. cigarette trade with Eastern European and newly industrialized countries,'' the report said. Cigarette use in the United States declined 18 percent between 1981 and 1990, due mainly to health concerns, slipping social acceptance and rising prices. Meanwhile, exports jumped from 83 billion cigarettes in 1981 to 142 billion last year. The export growth reflects lower trade barriers in Japan, Taiwan and South Korea. Other contributing factors were said to be the high quality of U.S. cigarettes, rising incomes in importing countries and the decline of the dollar against foreign currencies. Easter European countries also are showing more interest in U.S. cigarettes, the report said. And the Soviet sale is probably ``only the beginning of an important trade with the former Communist bloc countries,'' it said. The sales to the Soviet Union may take 3 percent to 5 percent of U.S. cigarette production within two years, the report predicted. ``This, combined with potential sales to other East European countries such as Czechoslovakia, Bulgaria and formerly East Germany, means that export sales stand to more than offset the steadily declining domestic market,'' it said. The net result, it added, could be that U.S. cigarette and tobacco leaf production may stabilize or increase, even with the big declines in domestic cigarette consumption. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Farmers have reduced acreages of fresh market vegetable for harvest this fall by about 3 percent from a year ago, the Agriculture Department said. A report Wednesday showed reductions for carrots, sweet corn, head lettuce and tomatoes. Only broccoli, cauliflower and celery showed increases from a year ago. In all, farmers expect to have 157,900 acres for the fall harvest, down from 163,500 a year ago, the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Debt Swap Approved
DOC.TEXT: The government has approved a series of debt-for-equity swaps that will cancel $1.8 billion of Mexico's debt over the next 18 months. The Treasury Department said Wednesday that it approved 29 private bidders for the swaps. The bids will lighten Mexico's approximately $92 billion foreign debt load. The investment will go toward projects in agriculture, tourism, communications, transportation and industry, the government said. The announcement marked the close of the second and final round of debt-swap bidding, part of Mexico's foreign debt renegotiation accords. The first round ended July 18.

DOC.HEAD: Amoco Offers Top Bid
DOC.TEXT: Amoco Oil Co. offered the highest bids and bought the most oil in the first sale from the U.S. Strategic Petroleum Reserve. Chicago-based Amoco offered $39.06 a barrel for 200,000 barrels of the sweet crude oil and submitted the winning bids averaging $38.60 on a total of 1.12 million barrels of sweet crude . President Bush on Sept. 26 ordered the sale of oil from the reserves stored in underground salt domes in Louisiana and Texas, saying he wanted to try hold down the oil prices that soared since the start of the Middle East crisis. Except for a brief test, the oil had not been put to use since the reserve was created in 1975. The department asked for bids on five million of the 590 million barrels in the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, and received bids for 10.4 million barrels. The Energy Department said the remaining bids were too low because they didn't meet the congressional mandate that all bids be at least 90 percent of the market value of a barrel of crude. All of the sweet crude that was offered was sold.

DOC.HEAD: Longshoremen Walk Out After California Union Officer Arrested
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The arrest of a local union officer instigated a walkout by hundreds of longshoremen, effectively shutting down cargo handling at one of the nation's busiest ports today. About 300 dockworkers stopped work at the Port of Los Angeles on Wednesday night after investigators came seeking a man for alleged non-payment of child support. A union official was arrested for investigation of inciting a riot. Mike Puliselich, a union member and cargo dispatcher, said it would be ``business as usual at the ports'' when day shift workers reported to their jobs at 8 a.m. PDT. He declined to comment on the walkout. The International Brotherhood of Longshoremen and Warehousemen Local 13 said it would issue a statement later today. The wildcat strike affected 33 ships, including at least one carrying U.S. military supplies to the Middle East, said Los Angeles Port Police Sgt. Martin Renteria. The action has had little immediate impact on ship traffic or other port operations because few ships are loaded or unloaded at night. ``It's not like being on the interstate with an accident backing everything up,'' Coast Guard Lt. Bob Shields said. On Wednesday, investigators from the district attorney's office went to the union hall in Wilmington to serve an arrest warrant on Roy Neal for allegedly failing to pay child support, district attorney's spokeswoman Sandi Gibbons said. The investigators, Jeff Oh and Ron Hobson, were admitted to the union hall and sat on a back bench. The union sergeant-at-arms, John Louis Nappi, then announced that non-union members must leave the hall and added, according to Ms. Gibbons, ``You two cops sitting on the back bench, get out now.'' The crowd in the hall advanced on the investigators, she said. Oh drew his gun, and the investigators ducked into a nearby office and locked the door, she said. The investigators called for help. Twenty Los Angeles police officers arrived and quelled the crowd. Nappi was arrested for investigation of inciting a riot, Ms. Gibbons said. He was released on $500 bail. The man sought by the investigators was not arrested.

DOC.HEAD: Chemical Giant Cuts Brazil Workforce by 3,500
DOC.TEXT: The French chemical and pharmaceutical giant Rhone-Poulenc SA said Thursday it will slash 3,500 jobs from its Brazilian workforce due to government austerity measures that are crimping business activity there. Voluntary layoffs are being conducted at the Sao Paolo-based Rhodia SA, which makes chemicals, fibers and medical products, a company spokeswoman said. ``People that leave simply won't be replaced,'' she said. About 2,000 workers have already left since Brazilian President Fernando Collor de Mello instituted his anti-inflation austerity program last year. Another 1,500 are expected to go over the next two years, the spokeswoman said. Rhone-Poulenc's first-half profits were off 13 percent from a year ago, partly due to a $58.7 million loss at Rhodia. It was the first loss recorded by the Brazilian division, which had been a jewel in Rhone-Poulenc's crown during the 1980s. Rhodia once accounted for 10 percent of revenue and an impressive 25 percent of profits. Other French firms have suffered in Brazil due to the stiff measures, including eyeglass specialist Essilor International SA and auto parts producer Valeo SA. The Rhone-Poulenc spokeswoman noted that the situation in Brazil has improved since midsummer but said it would be three years before the company regained lost ground. The job cuts at Rhodia - from 14,000 to 10,500 - will free up funds that cash-strapped Rhone-Poulenc can use to offset its $2 billion acquisition cost of U.S.-based Rorer Group Inc. An economic slowdown in the United States has cast doubt on the profit-making potential of the new unit, Rhone-Poulenc Rorer SA. As part of its cash-raising strategy, the company recently sold its Paris headquarters to a group of French banks, while its Spanish polyvinyl chloride business went to a unit of Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Awards $1 Million in Stray Voltage Damages to Dairy Farmers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A jury has awarded $1 million to dairy farmers who claimed a stray electrical current substantially cut their cows' milk production. The damages were awarded late Tuesday to Dale and Gloria ZumBerge and their son, Steven, following a 2{-week trial in Sibley County District Court. The three had sued Northern States Power Co., claiming the utility failed to warn them about stray voltage - errant electricity that enters the ground from grounded electrical distribution systems. The three also said NSP failed to bring it under control once it was discovered. ``It took a tremendous load off our shoulders,'' Dale ZumBerge, 51, said of the verdict. He said he pressed the case partly out of pride, to prove that his cows' problems were not the result of poor management. Sam Macalus, NSP spokesman, said the company was ``extremely disappointed'' with the verdict and may appeal. He said NSP's position ``is that the evidence in the case doesn't demonstrate the reduction in dairy production was due to stray voltage.'' The problem of stray voltage was recognized by researchers in several nations as early as the 1940s. They cited health dangers from current that flowed through the ground, into barns and into the bodies of cows and dairy farmers. The ZumBerges' lawyer, Jim Kaster, said the family began automating its Green Isle farm in the late 1970s and early 1980s. In 1984, after three years of declining milk production, the ZumBerges read about stray voltage in a dairy magazine. They called their milking company, which did some tests. NSP was called, and the utility found 1.9 volts of electricity outside the barn. Other tests found 3 volts inside the barn. Kaster and experts testifying in behalf of the Zumberges contended that the resulting irritation to the cows affected their ability to give milk. In 1984, NSP put up a blocking device at the primary pole where electrical service arrives at the farm, and that successfully halted the problem. But Kaster contended that when NSP put in a new transformer on that pole a few months later, the blocking device was reinstalled incorrectly. That problem was corrected last February, with a dramatic increase in production the next month, according to ZumBerge. The ZumBerge will use the money to pay off creditors who accumulated as the milk production dropped, Kaster said.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler Opens Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf to CORRECT 'pleading' to 'pledging'; uppicks 7th graf pvs: Also, the . . .
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. Chairman Lee Iacocca said he neither bemoaned money troubles nor tried to bargain with United Auto Workers leaders this morning as talks reopened between the union and automaker. ``We had a nice hour's discussion. I gave them a state-of-the-union, state-of-the company message,'' Iacocca said. ``I didn't plead poverty. I didn't bargain. That's not my role.'' Iacocca said he told about 40 UAW leaders at the meeting in Highland Park that some parts of the agreement reached with General Motors Corp. and Ford Motor Co. won't work for Chrysler, and he said the sides agreed to discuss them. He refused to be specific. Chrysler and the UAW had suspended talks begun in mid-July while the UAW negotiated a contract with GM. That pact was used as a pattern for an agreement reached with Ford. Chrysler and the UAW resumed talks today. UAW spokesman Bob Barbee said Iacocca got a positive reception. ``You didn't see him come down here with a bloody nose or anything, did you?'' Barbee said. Meanwhile, GM reached agreement late Wednesday on a contract covering 22,500 members of the International Union of Electronic Workers, pledging $250 million to guarantee job security. Also, the union for 36,500 Canadian GM workers called off a strike 20 minutes before a midnight Wednesday deadline, citing progress in contract talks in Toronto. In Detroit, GM and union negotiators reached the tentative, three-year national contract at 8:30 p.m. Wednesday, hours ahead of a midnight strike deadline. The union had been working under a contract that expired last month, but told GM on Sunday that it would cancel the pact and strike Wednesday at midnight. ``This is one of the best contracts we have ever negotiated,'' IUE negotiator Frank Sollitto said. Sollitto said the new pact guarantees job security for the IUE's 22,500 workers in Ohio, New York, New Jersey and Mississippi through a $250 million fund. ``It provides greater job security than ever before, excellent improvements in our pension plan, improved wages, full protection against inflation, a $600 Christmas bonus every year of the contract and a fairer profit sharing formula,'' Sollitto said. GM officials also praised the pact. ``For these past three months, bargainers from the company and the IUE had to face a number of difficult and complex issues,'' said Alfred S. Warren Jr., GM vice president of industrial relations. ``However, the dedication and efforts of both sides of the bargaining table has resulted in an agreement that benefits both the corporation and the GM employees that are represented by the IUE,'' he said. While the IUE's contract with GM, which expired Sept. 14, was similar to the automaker's pact with the United Auto Workers union, the IUE and UAW bargain separately. Last month, GM reached a contract agreement with the UAW. The GM-IUE agreement also includes: - Across the board wage increases of 3 percent, retroactive to Sept. 17. - Special 30-cents-per-hour increases for skilled trades workers, retroactive to Sept. 17. - Performance wage bonuses of 3 percent in the second and third years of the contract. ``There were no concessions in this contract - none,'' Sollitto said. ``And we won the best job security protection anywhere in the industry.'' Workers at IUE plants supply suspension systems, electrical parts, motors, batteries, windshield wipers and air conditioner compressors. The last IUE walkout against GM occurred in 1976 and lasted 10 hours. In Toronto, the Canadian Auto Workers union said it was close to an agreement late Wednesday with GM and hoped to settle early today. The basis for the talks has been a contract the union reached with Ford Motor Co. of Canada last month after a nine-day strike.

DOC.HEAD: For Those Willing To Pay, Home Delivery Booming
DOC.TEXT: Water is supposed to be cool, clear, healthy, refreshing and if not free, at least cheap. But more and more people are paying serious money to have bottles of water delivered to thei homes, saying they wonder about the safety of what flows out of the pipe or just don't like the taste. Lisa Ehrlich, for example, says she pays $140 a month to have bottles of spring water home delivered in suburban Bethesda, Md., where she lives with her husband and their two children. The Ehrlichs go through a half-dozen five-gallon bottles every two weeks. ``For our budget it's a lot to pay, but our water is important to us,'' Mrs. Ehrlich said. ``It makes me nervous to drink city water. Plus it tastes great.'' Industry statistics show home delivery to be the fastest-growing segment of a booming business, outpacing water sales in restaurants and grocery stores as well as office deliveries. A total of 424.8 million gallons of water was delivered to American homes in 1989, an increase of 70 percent from the 1985 figure of 248.7 million gallons. Jane Lazgin, spokeswoman for the Perrier Group of America Inc. in Greenwich, Conn., said there are indications home delivery of water is more than a passing fad. ``We find interest from kitchen designers, who are building kitchens leaving space for the bottled water dispenser,'' she said. ``There's a certain novelty attached to it, but it's becoming more of a refreshment beverage choice.'' The Perrier Group, the biggest U.S. bottled water company, has three major domestic water brands - Great Bear, Poland Spring and Arrowhead - all available for home delivery. Its flagship Perrier brand, like other carbonated waters, is not generally home delivered. The average price for home-delivered water is $4.91 for a five-gallon bottle, according to the International Bottled Water Association, the industry's trade association based in Arlington, Va. About 60 percent of bottled water buyers say they're interested mainly in better taste, the association said. Other reasons cited are safety and, more specifically, worries about chemicals in tap water. ``The area where I live I'm not sure of the water supply,'' said Robert Sims, who has a five-gallon bottle of water delivered to the door of his one-bedroom apartment in Dallas every three weeks. Sims said he liked the taste of the bottled water, but was motivated more by safety concerns. ``There'll be some brownish orangy color'' sometimes when he turns on the water, Sims said in a telephone interview. ``I've been told that it's absolutely safe, but I'd rather not be drinking something that came out of those pipes.'' Federal regulations on public water systems set strict purity standards for dangerous chemicals and disease-causing germs. When the rules were tightened last year, the Environmental Protection Agency said the action could prevent up to 90,000 water-borne diseases each year. Health issues, however, are dealt with carefully in bottled water advertisements and promotions. ``IBWA members do not, according to law, make health claims about bottled water,'' a statement from the association said. ``However, all bottled water must come from a government-approved source. In addition, because bottled water is a `food' product, it must meet more stringent andadditional regulations than tap water.'' Critics of the industry contend that regulations are not tight enough to ensure that bottled water is free of contamination. The Environmental Policy Institute in Washington issued a report last year concluding that there was a ``widespread misconception that the separate packaging and higher cost of bottled water guarantees a product substantially safer and healthier than ordinary tap water.'' The report, ``Bottled Water: Sparkling Hype at a Premium Price,'' urged consumers to ask for information about their normal water supply or have a sample tested before jumping to the conclusion that bottled water would be better. Mrs. Ehrlich said she was aware that contaminants had been found in some bottled waters. She said her family was considering switching to a system that would distribute pure distilled water throughout the house. ``Who knows for sure if what you're getting is so great,'' she said. ``We're trying to do the best, but who knows? The best might not be so good nowadays.''

DOC.HEAD: GM Takes Wraps Off Import-Fighting Saturn

DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY20, Graphic of Oct. 10
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. unveiled its new Saturn line today, but don't look for showroom floors to be filled with the import-fighting car in the next two weeks. There won't be as many new models on showroom floors as Saturn officials would like. There will, however, be enough to sell, Saturn Vice President Don Hudler said today. ``We're not going to be judged by the number of cars in the showroom on day one,'' Hudler said. ``We want to be judged on quality and customer satisfaction.'' Gov. Ned McWherter drove the first Saturn destined for a dealer showroom out of the $1.9 billion plant today. With him were Saturn President Richard G. ``Skip'' LeFauve, United Auto Workers official Dick Hoalcraft and UAW regional executive Bobby Lee Thompson. With the Saturn project, GM has promised an American model that looks and drives like an import. GM has committed $3 billion to the Saturn project - the automaker's first new division in 58 years - as it tries to regain some of the market share lost to imports. Officials at Saturn Corp., created by GM as a subsidiary to show its distinction from the rest of the company, wants 80 percent of the car's buyers to come from import shoppers, LeFauve said. Scott Merlis, an auto analyst with Morgan, Stanley & Co. in New York, called the target a pipe dream. ``There will be cannibalization'' as Saturn takes sales from other GM divisions, Merlis said. GM now offers the Geo Prizm and the Chevrolet Cavalier in the same price range as Saturn. The car's introduction will get plenty of free publicitiy. News media from around the world planned to cover the event. CBS planned a live spot from the plant 40 miles south of Nashville during today's ``This Morning'' show. NBC is scheduled to air a live segment from the Saturn plant during Friday morning's ``Today'' show. Early reviews of the high-tech Saturn praised its price ($7,995 for the base model) and fuel economy (27-37 mpg). But they rapped the car's engine rumble. Saturn officials will not discuss reports that the $1.9 billion plant is behind its production schedule. The plant, designed to produce 250,000 cars a year, is on a ``planned acceleration curve,'' and there will be plenty of cars for sale beginning Oct. 25, Ms. Schettler said. GM has lined up 116 Saturn dealers around the country, but only about 30 dealers in the South, West and Southwest will start selling the cars in free-standing dealerships later this month. It will take at least six months before Saturn cars are available in most major U.S. markets. Fifty dealers - Saturn calls them retailers - arrived in Spring Hill last week to undergo the company's sales training course, LeFauve said. ``Those folks are so enthusiastic about what we're doing. They're absolutely turned on about our product and say that we can't make enough of them,'' LeFauve said.
