DOC.TEXT: manufacturer, American Motors Corp., withheld documents from the government in a deliberate cover-up, Curry said. Chrysler Corp. acquired AMC in 1987. The safety probe was requested by Public Citizen, the Center for Auto Safety and the Institute for Injury Reduction. Such investigations can lead to recalls. They asked the agency to investigate what their petition described as ``the undue, unnecessary and defective propensity of the CJ vehicles to roll over.'' The groups accused AMC of knowing the vehicles' suspension system was defective and their roll bar assembly inadequate. Curry said an exhaustive inquiry showed the Jeep CJ's likelihood to roll over was ``slightly higher'' than the average for all utility vehicles. But the CJ ``does not stand out from its peers to an extent that warrants further investigation,'' he said. Deaths in CJ rollover accidents totaled 116 in 1989, said Michael Brownlee, the agency's associate administrator for enforcement. AMC sold 609,356 CJ-5 and CJ-7 vehicles between 1972 and 1986, when production was stopped. An estimated 420,000 are still registered for highway use. The utility vehicle in general is less stable and more likely to roll over than a passenger car, Curry said. It is narrow and has a short wheel base and high axles and suspension system. For that reason, the government requires manufacturers to attach a sticker to utility vehicles warning drivers to use extra caution. But Curry said people should be allowed to drive the vehicles if they wish.

The Limited dropped } to 11} in active trading. The company said its margins were somewhat lower in the third quarter than they had been in the corresponding period last year. Losers among the blue-chip industrials included Aluminum Co. of America, down 2] at 54[; Philip Morris, down ~ at 44[; General Electric, down | at 51], and International Business Machines, down 3[ at 100]. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell 2.75 to 162.22. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down 5.44 at 293.82. Volume on the Big Board came to 132.10 million shares with two hours to go.

DOC.HEAD: Reports: Trump Book Sales Flagging, Forced To Restructure More Debt
DOC.TEXT: Donald Trump may be struggling to survive at the top, but his second book seems to have lost the fight. The New York Times reported Thursday that the book, ``Surviving at the Top,'' has tumbled off its best-seller list after only seven weeks. The book, which expounds upon his self-proclaimed triumphs and was published by Random House, is a sequel to ``The Art of the Deal,'' which remained on the best-seller list for 48 weeks after its publication in 1987. According to the Times, some booksellers believe far too many copies of the sequel were printed. A Random House spokesman said the publisher printed 500,000 copies and sales have been very good. Still, sales remain beneath ``The Art of the Deal,'' of which nearly one million copies were sold. Perhaps the public has had its fill of the musings of the 44-year-old entrepreneur, who has come to symbolize the image of the brash 1980s by surrounding himself with luxury and building an empire of real estate, casinos and an airline on borrowed money. All three of his businesses have slumped sharply because of a slowing economy. Trump's financial problems have been the object of repeated speculation in recent months, including recurrent rumors that he will be forced to seek bankruptcy protection. But Trump's aides and some of his creditors have said they believe negotiations to stretch out his debt payments will succeed. Still more bad news surfaced Thursday, when the Wall Street Journal reported Trump will have to restructure more loans for his Atlantic City gambling empire. The negative account comes just days after Forbes magazine bumped Trump off its exclusive 400 Richest Americans list, estimating his net worth to possibly be within ``hailing distance of zero.'' The Journal said Trump has been forced to restructure $100 million in bank loans to the Trump Castle and Trump Taj Mahal casinos because they aren't generating enough cash to repay that debt. Trump already is in negotations with bondholder groups to restructure $675 million in Taj Mahal debt. Two months ago he negotiated a $65 million bank bailout that was supposed to give him breathing room to repay his loans, which together are believed to total more than $3 billion. The Journal quoted unidentified people close to Trump's lenders as saying representatives of National Westminster Bank USA and Midlantic National Bank have been meeting with Trump aides to restructure loans for the two Atlantic City casinos and technically could foreclose on them if the debts aren't paid. Each bank is owed approximately $50 million. Bank officials declined to comment. Trump's chief financial officer, Stephen Bollenbach, confirmed that talks are under way but disagreed with the characterization that the negotiations are a sign the developer's operations have deteriorated further. ``The way to look at this is we've got some very good business in Atlantic City holding up very well in difficult times, and they just aren't quite good enough to cover currently all their debt service,'' he said in a telephone interview. ``I think everybody understands that,'' Bollenbach said. ``It's a temporary problem. This is unlike other situations you read about, where you have a basically flawed business.'' Takevover investor Carl Icahn declined to comment Thursday on the Journal's account that he was believed to have bought Trump's casino bonds as a long-term investment. Bollenbach said he had heard rumors of an Icahn purchase but it didn't concern him. ``I know Mr. Icahn is a sophisticated bond investor. I assume he bought them at a discount,'' Bollenbach said. ``I suppose he sees value in them.''

DOC.HEAD: Grain Futures End Lower Ahead of Crop Report
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed mostly lower Thursday on the Chicago Board of Trade, reflecting bearish export signals in the wheat market and position-evening ahead of a government crop report. Wheat futures fell sharply early in the afternoon amid rumors that Jordan was seeking non-U.S. wheat after the Agriculture Department rejected wheat bids from Jordan on Tuesday and Wednesday. Most corn and soybean futures also retreated, partly in sympathy with wheat and partly in preparation for the USDA's revised corn and soybean crop estimates, which were released after the close. In the report, the government projected the 1990 U.S. corn harvest at 8.02 billion bushels compared with its September estimate of 8.12 billion and market expectations averaging 8.06 billion. The USDA projected soybean production of 1.82 billion bushels compared with the September estimate of 1.84 billion and market expectations averaging 1.83 billion. At the close, wheat futures were 2{ cents to 5\ cents lower with the contract for delivery in December at $2.71 a bushel; corn was 2} cents to 4 cents lower with December at $2.32} a bushel; oats were 2 cents to 3\ cents lower with December at $1.19} a bushel; soybeans were 4} cents lower to 5 cents higher with November at $6.20\ a bushel.

The stock market took another drubbing today, extending the decline that has driven it down to its lowest levels in nearly a year and a half. The Dow Jones average, off nearly 116 points over the last two sessions, fell another 45.54 to 2,362.38 by 3 p.m. today on Wall Street. Losers outnumbered gainers by more than 4 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 289 up, 1,269 down and 409 unchanged. Analysts said there was little in the news to relieve the gloom that has gripped the market since midsummer. The price of crude-oil for November delivery climbed about $1 a barrel, to just under $40 a barrel, in early trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Recession worries have kept mounting of late as investors await the peak flow of corporate earnings reports for the third quarter, due over the next couple of weeks. But economic weakness hasn't so far brought any downward pressure on long-term interest rates. Brokers also said market participants were frustrated by the slow progress and many twists and turns of efforts in Washington toward a plan to narrow the federal budget deficit. DOC.HEAD: Production Goes Up-Down This Week
DOC.TEXT: Domestic automakers were scheduled to produce 225,037 cars and light trucks this week, up from last week's 221,359, Ward's Automotive Reports said Thursday. This week's production is higher than the same week a year ago, in which 204,115 cars and light trucks were produced, the trade journal said. U.S. automakers were scheduled to make 142,411 cars this week, compared with 143,757 a week ago and 142,117 in the same week in 1989. Light truck production for the week was scheduled at 82,626, compared with last week's 77,602 and last year's 61,998. Canadian automakers were to build 21,972 cars this week, down from 27,360 a week ago and up from last year's 20,121. Canadian light truck production was scheduled at 14,936, compared with 16,288 a week ago and 15,993 in the same week last year.

DOC.HEAD: A Dismal September For Retailers Amid Fears of Recession, War
With BC-Retail Sales-Table
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: The news from the nation's biggest retailers Thursday was pretty grim: Worries about recession and a possible war in the Persian Gulf kept consumers on the sidelines in September, giving many storeowners a dismal September. The retailers' monthly sales reports - some of which showed a decline from September 1989 levels - did not augur well for a robust Christmas shopping season. ``I don't see anything to suggest an improvement,'' said Jeffrey Edelman, a retail industry analyst with Barclays de Zoete Wedd. Jeffrey Feiner, an analyst with Merrill Lynch & Co., warned, ``It could get worse. ... We believe that for the first time in a long time, we will have two very poor Christmases back to back.'' Many retailers were forced to slash prices - and consequently, their profit margins - to bring in sales last Christmas. Feiner predicted earnings would decline again in the fourth quarter although many companies are being very cautious and preparing for the worst - another bleak holiday season. A slump in profits in the final quarter could be devastating for retailers, who depend on this period for about 50 percent of their full-year earnings. September's results came as no surprise. August sales, which normally are boosted by back-to-school shopping, showed signs of a spending slowdown. Consumers were already nervous about the economy and the security of their own jobs when the Persian Gulf crisis and rising oil prices exacerbated recession fears and gave them less money to spend on so-called discretionary items such as clothes and furniture. Edelman called the Middle East tensions ``the straw that broke the camel's back.'' The weather also affected sales, as temperatures ran above the norm, and few consumers were in the mood to shop for winter clothing. Feiner summed up the confluence of factors as ``a multi-faceted barrage on the consumer.'' The nation's largest retailer, Sears, Roebuck & Co., said sales at stores open at least a year rose 4.4 percent for the five weeks ended Oct. 6, while sales from all of its stores rose 4.2 percent. Analysts believe sales from stores open at least a year - also known as same-store or comparable store sales - provide a truer picture of a retailer's performance than overall sales do. Newer stores tend to have extraordinarily robust sales that can skew a retailer's results. K mart Corp. said its same-store sales inched up 0.7 percent although overall sales rose 10.2 percent. Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the discount retailer that consistently outperforms the rest of the industry, reported a same-store sales gain of 9 percent and a 24 percent rise overall. J.C. Penney Co. Inc. said its same-store sales fell 3.4 percent, while overall sales were off 2.3 percent. Dayton Hudson Corp. reported a 2 percent decline in same-store sales, although overall sales were up 11.3 percent. Limited Inc., the nation's largest specialty apparel retailer, said its same-store sales dropped 3 percent, while overall sales rose 10 percent. Thursday's reports also came as bad news for the economy, as consumer spending accounts for about two-thirds of the gross national product. A drop-off in spending adversely affects other economic sectors, including manufacturers who sell merchandise to retailers. ``Retailers are playing a totally defensive ball game,'' reducing their orders to suppliers, said Feiner. The results announced Thursday differ from the monthly retail sales report from the government. The Commerce Department includes sales from supermarkets, restaurants and car dealerships in its figures, which are scheduled to be released Friday morning. In other reports from retailers Thursday: - Woolworth Corp. reported a 2.1 percent gain in same-store sales, and a 6.2 percent rise overall. - May Department Stores Co. said its same-store sales fell 1.8 percent, while overall sales picked up 3.5 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Diaper Plant Closes But Town Optimistic
DOC.TEXT: A tissue paper factory that prospered on the business of disposable diapers will close Friday, giving way to other factories that can make the same product more cheaply. Procter & Gamble's Paper Products Co. has been phasing down the Cheboygan tissue paper plant since May 1989. At that time, the company announced it would buy instead of make the absorbent paper that goes into its Pampers diapers and Always adult panty liners. The tissue was one of the main production lines at the Cheboygan plant. Plant Manager Phil Baker said Thursday five other companies expressed an interest in buying the plant and two still are talking. ``It's not possible for us to be too optimistic yet. They've visited the plant. They've looked at the equipment. But they are trying to sort through what products they would make on this equipment,'' Baker said. In 1989, Procter & Gamble had 300 people working at the Cheboygan factory. By Thursday, 130 of them had transferred to other Procter & Gamble operations around the country. Another 75 as of Friday will be retired, Baker said. The closing of the 86-year-old plant robs Cheboygan of its biggest employer.

DOC.HEAD: AFL-CIO Lobbies for National Health Insurance
DOC.TEXT: Labor leaders rallied Thursday in support of establishing a national health insurance program to provide health care for working people and others who cannot afford to pay for it. ``Unions are calling for national health insurance as the best way to control health care costs, improve the quality of care and make health care universally accessible,'' said Daniel Radford, executive secretary-treasurer of the Cincinnati AFL-CIO Labor Council. The Cincinnati rally was intended as part of a national AFL-CIO campaign begun this month, which includes television advertisements, to promote a national health insurance program. The AFL-CIO says 37 million Americans have no health care coverage, and three-quarters of those are working people and their families. The National Association of Working Americans, an affiliate of the Cincinnati AFL-CIO Labor Council, said it also intended the rally as a show of support for proposed Ohio legislation to create ``universal health care programs.'' The proposal by state Rep. Robert Hagan, D-Youngstown, would phase out private insurance and replace it with a comprehensive plan for all citizens, with no co-payments or deductibles, said Sally Krisel, director of the association. She said that as envisioned, the proposed plan would cover everyone, reduce the required insurance paperwork and allow participants their choice of doctors to perform the services. The plan would be funded by taxes on payroll from employers and employees, on interest and dividends, and on alcohol and tobacco products. Hagan is redrafting his proposal and expects to formally introduce it before the Ohio General Assembly in January, Ms. Krisel said.

Analysts said there was little in the news to relieve the gloom that has gripped the market since midsummer. DOC.HEAD: CPC International Earnings Up in Third Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Food giant CPC International said Thursday its third-quarter net income rose by 13 percent, an increase it attributed to growth in CPC's European and Latin American corn refining operations. Net income for the quarter ended Sept. 30 was $98.6 million, compared to $87.2 million in the 1989 period, the company reported. Earnings per common share of $1.27 were up 12.4 percent from $1.13. Among the company's products are Hellman's mayonnaise and Thomas' English muffins. ``Since 1986, our strategy has been to focus on our consumer foods business for growth and to fuel that growth with strong cash flow from corn refining operations,'' said CPC president C.R. Shoemate. ``That strategy has resulted in three straight years of significant earnings growth, and to that we will add another year of good earnings improvement when final results for 1990 are reported.'' Con refining is a chemical process that separates corn into various components used to make starches, sweeteners and corn oils, said CPC spokesman William Parker. Worldwide sales in the quarter were also 13 percent higher than a year ago, at $1.45 billion from $1.29 billion in 1989. Operating income increased 16 percent, from $173.8 million to $201.3 million. Net income for the first nine months of 1990 amounted to $272.5 million, or $3.51 per share, compared to $238 million, or $3.05 per share in 1989, according to company reports. Sales for the first nine months came to $4.26 billion, up 12 percent from $3.8 billion in the 1989 period. CPC, based in Englewood Cliffs, has operations in 47 countries and 32,500 employees. About 80 percent of its 1989 sales, totalling about $5.1 billion, came from consumer foods accounts in North America, Europe, Latin America and Asia.

DOC.HEAD: Ratings Short of Expectations, Fox Forced to Give Sponsors Free Ad Time
DOC.TEXT: Fox Broadcasting Co. has been forced to give free advertising to dissatisfied sponsors because ratings have fallen short of expectations, industry executives report. The network stopped selling advertising time for the fourth quarter in order to use what was left for ``make-goods,'' the bonus spots given away when shows fail to attract enough viewers, the Los Angeles Times reported Thursday. ``The numbers have fallen so dramatically that they are using most if not all of the available inventory for make-goods,'' the Times quoted Richard Kostyra of the J. Walter Thompson ad agency in New York as saying. The network's performance was ``considerably below what people had estimated,'' he said. Fox attracted 5.7 percent of the national TV audience in the first three weeks of the new fall season, well below the average 7 percent industry executives said it promised to advertisers. ``It will be extremely difficult for Fox to hold their guarantees,'' said Steve Grubbs of BBDO Worldwide, another New York ad agency. Fox said it would make good on guarantees, noting the network had not yet run new episodes for all of its shows. ``We are capable of making good on our guarantees,'' said Fox president Jamie Kellner. ``Historically, Fox takes a dip in September and October while the networks are promoting their new shows, but we build after that. ``We're comfortable where we are right now.'' Fox, the newspaper said, was counting heavily on Thursday night's premiere of ``The Simpsons,'' hoping high ratings would have a ``halo effect'' on the shows that follow it. The network promised ``The Simpsons'' sponsors, who paid up to $400,000 for a half-minute commercial, that new episodes will attract at least 27 percent of the TV audience, advertising executives said. Reruns of ``The Simpsons'' in its new Thursday night time slot against new episodes of NBC-TV's ``The Cosby Show'' haven't fared well. Since August ``The Simpsons'' has averaged only 15 percent compared to 35 percent for ``Cosby.''

DOC.HEAD: Drop in Gambling Revenues, Sluggish Economy Contribute to Hilton Losses
DOC.TEXT: Hilton Hotels Corp. said Thursday a sluggish economy and a drop in casino gambling revenues caused its third-quarter profit to drop 49 percent. For the three months ended Sept. 30, net income before property transactions amounted to $15.4 million, or 32 cents per share. Including property transactions, net income for the quarter ending Sept. 30 totaled $21.9 million, or 45 cents per share, compared to $28.1 million, or 58 cents per share, for the same period last year. The company had $260 million in revenues, compared to $248.5 million a year ago. Competition has kept gamblers away from the Las Vegas Hilton. The recently opened Excalibur and Mirage hotels have lured foot traffic away from other Las Vegas hotels. ``The gaming division experienced a difficult quarter,'' said Barron Hilton, chairman and president of Hilton. ``The hotel industry continues to contend with a sluggish economy and excess capacity in many major markets. Results from out hotels mirrored these conditions,'' he said. For the nine months ending Sept. 30, including property transactions, net income was $85.2 million, or $1.76 per share, compared to $83.2 million, or $1.72 per share, last year. Revenues came to $799.2 million, compared to $738.6 million last year.

DOC.HEAD: Rose $1.48 Billion in Latest Week
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Interest rate figures reported by Donoghue's Money Fund Report are for week ended Tuesday. All other figures are for the week ended Wednesday.
DOC.TEXT: Assets of the nation's 519 money market mutual funds rose $1.48 billion in the latest week to a record $411.35 billion, the Investment Company Institute said Thursday. The rise in the seven-day period ended Wednesday broke the record set a week earlier, when fund assets increased to $409.87 billion. The earlier record originally was reported as $409.96 billion but the Washington-based mutual fund trade group revised it. The institute said that in the latest week, assets of 255 general purpose funds rose $353.8 million to $146.15 billion, assets of 105 broker-dealer funds increased $163.6 million to $165.35 billion, and assets of 159 institutional funds rose $967.4 million to $99.85 billion. The seven-day average yield on money market mutual funds in the week ended Tuesday was 7.48 percent, unchanged from the previous week, said Donoghue's Money Fund Report, a trade journal based in Holliston, Mass. The 30-day average yield remained unchanged at 7.47 percent, Donoghue's said. The average maturity of the portfolios held by money funds was 45 days, down from 47 days, Donoghue's said. The newsletter Bank Rate Monitor said its survey of 100 leading commercial banks, savings and loan associations and savings banks in the nation's 10 largest markets showed the effective annual yield available on money market accounts fell to 6.02 percent as of Wednesday from 6.05 percent a week earlier. The North Palm Beach, Fla.-based newsletter said the effective annual yield available on special savings accounts, called Super NOW accounts, fell to 5.00 percent from 5.02 percent. Bank Rate Monitor said the effective annual yield was 7.68 percent on six-month certificates of deposit, unchanged from the previous week. Yields were 7.81 percent on 1-year CDs, down from 7.82 percent; 7.91 percent on 2{-year CDs, down from 7.92 percent; and 8.06 percent on 5-year CDs, unchanged from a week earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Refcorp Sells Bonds
DOC.TEXT: The government sold $5 billion in 30-year bonds Thursday to help finance the disposal of failed savings and loans. The bonds were sold at an average yield of 9.33 percent and will carry a coupon interest rate of 9] percent, with a $10,000 bond selling for $10,045. The Resolution Funding Corp., or Refcorp, received bids totaling $10.85 billion. In previous auctions this year, Refcorp received bids totaling $15.5 billion for a $5 billion issue in July, bids of $8.9 billion for a $3.5 billion issue in April and bids of $8.2 billion for a $5 billion issue in January. The July issue had a 30-year maturity while the April and January issues had 40-year maturities. The July bonds were sold at an average yield of 8.93 percent, the April issue at 8.89 percent and the January issue at 8.60 percent. In Refcorp's first auction, in October 1989, $4.5 billion in 30-year bonds were sold at an average yield of 8.15 percent. The agency, created to keep S&L bailout financing from showing up in the budget deficit, has so far sold $23 billion of $30 billion authorized.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Oil Tycoon Bids For Hunt's Ranch
DOC.TEXT: An Israeli oil tycoon has made the latest offer for the Circle T Ranch, the one-time haven of fallen Texas oil baron Nelson Bunker Hunt. Gad Zeevi has offered between $33.5 and $35 million for the 2,000-acre ranch, considered by real estate experts to be the last big chunk of prime undeveloped property in the Dallas-Fort Worth area, The Fort Worth Star-Telegram reported Thursday. Zeevi, who has homes and real estate holdings across the globe, has no plans to develop the property, unnamed sources told the newspaper. The ranch is controlled by the NBH Liquidating Trust, an estate set up to sell all of Hunt's assets in one of the largest personal bankruptcies in history. Most of the proceeds from the liquidation will go to pay off Hunt's $1.5 billion debt with the Internal Revenue Service. Trustee Carter Pate said in a statement three weeks ago that an agreement had been entered into with SC Investment, Inc. a Houston firm. Lawyer Jack Lapin, listed in state records as the corporation's agent, declined to confirm or deny that Zeevi is behind the investment firm. ``I'm not allowed to release any information,'' Lapin said. Pate did not immediately return telephone calls Thursday from The Associated Press. Zeevi is an international developer and aeronautical engineer with business interests in Kenya and Puerto Rico, according to published reports. He is also a major partner in Israel's largest oil company and owns a commodities trading company in London. Zeevi has indicated to several people involved in the negotiations that he may use the ranch as Hunt did - as a weekend retreat near the financial center of Texas' oil business.

DOC.HEAD: Brewer to Announce Plans for Opening Ohio Plant
DOC.TEXT: The Miller Brewing Co. is expected to announce Friday whether it will open a 7-year-old brewery that had received tax abatement and state assistance. Politician, irked that Miller has never delivered the promised jobs, have threatened to revoke the tax benefits. Miller spokeswoman Helen Dennison declined Thursday to reveal plans for the $411 million brewery, located near Trenton in Butler County. Miller completed the brewery in 1983 and produced beer in a 1984 test run, but the plant been idle since then. One critic, state Rep. Michael Fox, R-Hamilton, said Miller has received $11.5 million in tax reductions so far and stands to receive $10.1 million in future tax breaks, under a 1979 agreement to provide 1,500 jobs and a $30 million payroll by 1982 at the 1,070-acre site. Dennison said the brewery could begin producing beer within six months of an announcement to open the facility. Miller said it has never opened the Trenton brewery because beer demand flattened out nationally and the plant's production has not been needed. But sales figures have perked up in recent months, company officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Fannie Mae Income Up 41 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Fannie Mae, a secondary mortgage-market company, said Thursday that earnings rose 41 percent in the July-September quarter, in part because of declining home foreclosures. The Federal National Mortgage Association, as the company is more formally known, reported net income of $299.5 million in the third quarter, or $1.15 per share, up from $211.9 million, or 80 cents a share a year earlier. It was the 11th consecutive increase in quarterly profits. Earnings were $289.6 million in the second quarter and for the first nine months of the year were $865.7 million, the company said. ``We are encouraged that our acquisitions of foreclosed properties are down by 15 percent compared with the third quarter of last year, while our inventory of foreclosed properties has declined by more than 30 percent from its year-ago level,'' Fannie Mae chairman David O. Maxwell said in a statement. Fannie Mae, which finances about one in every eight of the nation's single-family home sales, purchases mortgages from lenders. It holds some and packages others into securities for resale to investors. Although it was chartered by Congress, it is shareholder-owned. The company also attributed the latest rise in profits to a $9.6 million increase in guaranty fees and to an $8.6 million gain in the difference between the interest it pays investors and the interest it receives from mortgage payers.

DOC.HEAD: One-Third of Saturn Buyers Seen Coming from GM
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. rolled out its new Saturn cars Thursday, predicting they will lure more buyers from the competition than from other GM divisions. GM created the Saturn to compete with Japanese imports that have stolen a large part of the market from the Big Three automakers. The car has a price tag and fuel efficiency rating that's competitive with Japanese models. Don Hudler, Saturn Corp.'s vice president for sales and marketing, said he expected 65 percent of the GM subsidiary's first-year sales will be new business to GM. The rest would come from current GM owners, probably owners of Chevrolets. But by the third year Saturn is on the market, 80 percent of its sales will come from would-be buyers of imports or cars made by domestic rivals Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. ``We'll do better as our perception gets out there,'' Hudler said after the official unveiling of Saturn's two- and four-door cars. The ceremony took place in Spring Hill, Tenn., where the new cars are made. Auto analysts long have questioned Saturn's lofty expectations that a large number of its sales would come from import buyers. Saturn's price range of $7,995 to $11,775 puts it in the same ball park as a host of imports, as well as the Geo Prizm and the Chevrolet Cavalier, both sold and serviced by Chevrolet dealers. Snatching a sale from Chevrolet may help Saturn, but does nothing for GM's profits overall. Saturn was set up as a separate corporation within GM in January 1985 and since then, the new company's officials have been trying to distance themselves, the Saturn plant and the cars from the parent corporation. No GM corporate officials were at Thursday's official unveiling. The ceremony, which took place at the end of the assembly line at Saturn's plant 35 miles south of Nashville, appeared like a pep rally for the company's 3,350 employees, or ``team members,'' as workers refer to themselves. As a trio of new cars were driven off the line and into a shipping area, hundreds of workers cheered. About 1,000 cars will be in dealerships or on their way when Saturn officially goes on sale Oct. 25 in 30 retailers, mostly in the South and West. The company expects nationwide availability through about 130 dealerships a year from now. Three to four weeks before the cars arrive in each of the markets, Saturn will begin a print and broadcast advertising campaign featuring testimonials from company workers and an appearance by Emmett, a small blond dog belonging to one of Saturn's transplanted workers. The television ads have a moody, slightly sentimental air. Not all show the cars, but the ads are designed to increase awareness of the Saturn brand, said Luana Floccuzio, the company's advertising manager. ``It's getting into the hearts,'' she said. Saturn has set an ambitious goal for itself. When production is fully operational, in about a year, the company expects sales to reach about 250,000 a year. That's slightly less than the 255,159 Honda Civics that Americans bought in the 1990 model year that ended last month. In price, the Saturn also is positioned against the Ford Escort, Mazda Protege, Nissan Sentra, Toyota Corolla, Dodge Shadow and Plymouth Sundance. Saturn is including a roadside assistance plan and a buy-back program for owners. Hudler said the cars will carry no incentives. The company already is working on new Saturns, perhaps including a station wagon and a convertible.

DOC.HEAD: `Pretty' Car Displayed at Saturn's Unveiling
With AM-Saturn, Bjt
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Nissan executive Jerry Benefield was among the crowd Thursday as Gov. Ned McWherter drove the first Saturn out of the $1.9 billion General Motors Corp. plant. ``It's pretty,'' said the president of Nissan Motor Manufacturing Corp. U.S.A., whose company makes Sentras and pickup trucks 40 miles away. Not that Benefield wishes well to his new competitor. The Saturn, GM's first new division in 58 years, produces an American-made car that looks and drives like it's Japanese, and is designed to compete with such companies as Nissan that have stolen market share from the nation's No. 1 automaker. Saturn workers took a 45-minute break from the line on Thursday for a ceremony to unveil the car. At an event that took on tones of a pep rally, Saturn Corp. executives drove out of the plant in three new cars destined for dealer showrooms for an Oct. 25 launch date. The executives were joined by United Auto Workers officials at the ceremony. Bobby Lee Thompson, assistant director of UAW Region 8, drew applause when he said he expects Saturn to ``surprise'' the imports. ``I happen to believe in the Saturn team to get the job done. But more important, I believe in you, the American public,'' Thompson said to more cheers. McWherter, who was state House speaker when GM announced in 1985 that Saturn was coming to Spring Hill 35 miles south of Nashville, recalled that his father moved their family from Tennessee to Michigan in search of work in the auto industry. ``I want to acknowledge the thousands and thousands of GM stockholders for their commitment to Tennessee,'' he said. McWherter drove the first Saturn, a silver four-door sedan, out of the plant to a waiting transport truck. With him were LeFauve, Thompson and Dick Hoalcraft, the Saturn-UAW coordinator who participates in decisions at the plant. Only 1,000 cars will be available for 30 dealers in the Southeast and West to sell in two weeks, Saturn President Richard G. ``Skip'' LeFauve said later. He would not give production figures but said the plant should reach capacity of 250,000 cars a year by end of 1991. ``We're not going to be judged by the number of cars in the showroom on Day One,'' said Don Hudler, Saturn's vice president for sales, service and marketing. ``We want to be judged on quality and customer satisfaction.''

DOC.HEAD: Macy Selling Credit Operations to GE Capital
DOC.TEXT: R.H. Macy & Co. Inc., in a move to reduce its $4.8 billion debt load, said Thursday it is selling its credit operations to GE Capital Corp. The step will lower the retailer's debt by $1.5 billion, Macy said in a statement. The credit operations include Macy Credit Corp. and Macy Receivables Funding Corp., which together have an asset value of $100 million, Macy said. Macy was expected to take some kind of step toward reducing its liabilities since it told its stockholders in July it was exploring ways to lower or refinance its debt. The company, which went private in a $3.74 billion leveraged buyout in 1986, suffered a disastrous Christmas last year and, along with the rest of the retail industry, faces another bleak holiday season. All retailers are dependent on Christmas sales for about half their annual profits, but highly leveraged companies such as Macy are particularly vulnerable when sales fall short of expectations. Macy is also reducing its debts by repurchasing its outstanding bonds. Last month, the company said it planned to buy back substantial amounts of its $1.6 billion in junk bonds, and would consider selling a 20 percent equity stake to help finance the repurchase. The retailer has already repurchased several other bond issues. By reducing its debt, Macy is also cutting its annual interest bill of $595 million. Thursday's announcement came as welcome news to the junk bond market, which bid up the price of Macy issues. GE Capital Corp. is a subsidiary of General Electric Co., which is among Macy's stockholders. One of GE Capital's divisions is GE Capital Retailer Financial Services, which handles credit operations for more than 200 retailers.

DOC.HEAD: Money Supply Rises
DOC.TEXT: The two broadest measures of the nation's money supply rose in the week ended Oct. 1, the Federal Reserve Board reported Thursday. The Fed said the measure known as M2 rose to a seasonally adjusted $3,324.2 billion from $3,315.7 billion the previous week. An even broader measure, M3, rose to a seasonally adjusted $4,087.7 billion from $4,085.4 billion. The narrowest measure of the money supply, M1, rose to a seasonally adjusted $829.3 billion from $821.6 billion. M1 includes cash in circulation, deposits in checking accounts and non-bank travelers checks. M2 is M1 plus accounts like savings deposits and money-market mutual funds. M3 is M2 plus less-liquid accounts, such as certificates of deposit in minimum denominations of $100,000. In judging its monetary policy, the Fed has indicated it is monitoring the value of the dollar, commodity prices and the difference between short- and long-term interest rates. It also has shifted its attention from M1 to the two broader money supply measures. The growth rate in M2 in the last 52 weeks was 4.9 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 3 percent to 7 percent. The growth rate in M3 over the past year was 1.8 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 1 percent to 5 percent. The Fed has not set a target for M1 growth since early 1987. For the latest 13 weeks, M2 averaged $3,301.6 billion, a 3.1 percent seasonally adjusted annual rate of gain from the previous 13 weeks. M3 averaged $4,084.9 billion, up 1.6 percent, while M1 rose 4.3 percent to an average of $816.1 billion. In other reports: - The Federal Reserve said bank borrowings from the Federal Reserve System at the discount window, excluding extended credit, averaged $399 million a day in the week ended Wednesday, down from $502 million the previous week. - The Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis reported that the monetary base, the seasonally adjusted total of member bank reserves held at Federal Reserve banks and cash in bank vaults and in circulation, was $317.6 billion in the two-week period ended Oct. 3, down from $318.8 billion two weeks earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Large Kentucky Coal Operator Announces Mass Layoffs
DOC.TEXT: South East Coal Co. announced Thursday it will permanently lay off about 400 workers in three eastern Kentucky counties because a 6{-year legal battle has ``bled this company white.'' The layoffs at Kentucky's third-largest independent coal producer were among the largest to jolt the eastern Kentucky coalfields in years, said Bill Weinberg, chairman of the East Kentucky Economic Development and Jobs Creation Corp. ``It's going to make hard times even harder for the short haul,'' said Weinberg. South East President Harry LaViers Jr. announced the layoffs in a prepared statement. He and other company officials did not return repeated telephone calls for comment. On Aug. 10, South East warned its 830 workers they could be laid off because of severe financial problems brought on by a legal battle with Kentucky Utilities Co., its largest customer. In 1984, Kentucky Utilities won a $79 million judgment against South East in a coal contract dispute. A Fayette Circuit judge ordered South East to place $36 million in an escrow account until appeals are resolved. ``This is a continuing tragedy for our workers, and for eastern Kentucky, but our difficulties with Kentucky Utilities have bled this company white,'' LaViers' statement said. The layoffs would be distributed among South East's four underground mines in Knott and Letcher counties and a coal preparation plant in Estill County. David Maggard of Millstone, a repairman in Letcher County, said many workers with seniority were dismissed over lesser experienced employees. ``It just looks like to me they picked on a lot of the union people,'' said Maggard, a negotiating team member of United Mine Workers Local No. 3007. After a bitter campaign, the UMW in July won the right to represent South East's workers in bargaining talks. Contract talks have been stalled because South East has challenged the union vote. LaViers' statement said some of the layoffs ``were made necessary by an exchange, presently being negotiated, of some of its assets in return for the assumption of part of its bank debt.'' The exchange was an attempt to avert bankruptcy, he said. The statement didn't identify the other party involved in the exchange. ``We are trying to preserve part of the company and some of the jobs. Our creditor banks insist that something must be done to pay them, now. We are trying to achieve that,'' LaViers said. No further layoffs are planned, he said. Statements of dire economic hardship puzzled several workers. South East has been spending large amounts of money improving its mines and facilities, they said. ``If they're hurting for money, they're certainly not showing it in Irvine,'' said Earl Howell, president of UMW Local No. 3008 in Estill County.

DOC.HEAD: MCI Offers Plan to Stop Unauthorized Switching of Long-Distance Service
DOC.TEXT: MCI Communications Corp. offered the federal government a plan Thursday to put a hold on telemarketers who switch phone customers' long-distance service without their permission. This customer switching, known as ``slamming,'' has generated tens of thousands of complaints to state and federal telephone regulators, particularly in the wake of recent advertising wars between MCI, US Sprint and American Telephone & Telegraph Co. With all three leading long-distance carriers now offering about the same prices, they are spending hundreds of millions of dollars on advertising and telemarketing trying to lure customers from their rivals. AT&T has about 65 percent of the market, MCI about 14 percent and Sprint about 10 percent, with the remainder taken by several hundred smaller companies. AT&T had about 90 percent of the market when it was broken up in 1984. MCI called on the Federal Communications Commission to establish uniform, minimum disclosures in all telephone sales solicitations; monitor procedures for phone solicitors; independently verify sales to insure the customer has authorized a change in service; conduct independent audits; and ensure ``free and convenient return to the original long-distance carrier in the case of unauthorized service conversion.'' Customers typically pay $5 to change services now. Eugene Eidenberg, MCI executive vice president, said the plan ``will create a national standard to protect consumers while still preserving the competition that has brought them better service in the long-distance industry at lower prices.'' MCI said its proposal should supersede a rival AT&T proposal to the FCC that would require each customer to sign a form prior to being switched to a new long-distance carrier. AT&T in January sued MCI and MCI's telemarketing agent, Pioneer Teletechnologies of Sergeant Bluff, Iowa, over slamming, claiming the companies had used misleading or false information to persuade AT&T customers to switch to MCI. MCI and Pioneer both denied any wrongdoing, and the suit is pending in U.S. District Court in Washington. When the lawsuit was filed, MCI said 100,000 AT&T customers a week were switching to MCI because it offered better service. But AT&T's suit said MCI agents were telling AT&T customers that MCI was merging with AT&T or that AT&T was going out of business. Telemarketers, according to industry analysts, often prey on the elderly, the hard of hearing or those who don't speak English well. FCC rules now require only that long-distance carriers provide local phone companies with written verification from customers, if the local phone company asks for proof. The House Government Operations subcommittee on government information, justice and agriculture will hold hearings on slamming next Wednesday, according to aides to the subcommittee's chairman, Rep. Bob Wise, D-W.Va.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Weaker, Gold Rises, Silver Falls
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell against most major currencies on concern about the health of U.S. banks and the belief among foreign traders that the United States is headed for a sharp recession. Gold finished mixed in world trading, while silver continued its slide to levels not seen in 13 years. The dollar fared well in European trading on increased anxieties over the Persian Gulf crisis. But it dropped in New York as concerns about U.S. banks intensified on Chemical Bank's move to cut its common stock dividend to 25 cents a share after posting a third-quarter loss of $43.7 million. ``It's down hard today,'' Marc Chandler, senior strategist with the consulting firm IDEA in New York, said of the dollar. He said other factors influencing its drop included a general bearishness in the market, continued confusion in federal budget negotiations and tensions in the Middle East. ``We also continue to hear talk of Japanese life insurance companies raising their dollar hedge ratios,'' Chandler said. ``That means they're selling more dollars to reduce their currency risk.'' In New York, the dollar closed at 129.47 yen, down from Wednesday's 129.48. Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar closed at 129.95 Japanese yen, unchanged from its closing rate on Tuesday before Wednesday's Sports Day national holiday. In London late Thursday the dollar closed at the same rate. In London, one British pound cost $1.9640 late Thursday, cheaper for buyers than Wednesday's late $1.9755. But in New York, it cost $1.9775 to buy one pound, up from $1.9694 late Wednesday. Other selected late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday rates included: 1.5138 German marks, down from 1.5278; 1.2730 Swiss francs, down from 1.2810; 5.0705 French francs, down from 5.1145; 1,134.75 Italian lire, down from 1,145.00; and 1.1468 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1491. Late dollar rates in Europe compared with late Wednesday included: 1.5330 German marks, up from 1.5285; 1.2910 Swiss francs, up from 1.2785; 5.1292 French francs, up from 5.1160; 1.7280 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7225; 1,147.25 Italian lire, up from 1,143.25; 1.1512 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1495. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery rose $1.60 to settle at $389.70 a troy ounce. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $391.00, up $2.75 an ounce from late Wednesday. Gold closed in London at a bid $389.75 a troy ounce, down from $390.25 late Wednesday. The late bid price in Zurich was $389.60, down from $390.75. Earlier in Hong Kong gold closed at $390.05, down from $392.15. Silver continued its slide on the Comex. Silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.235 a troy ounce, down further from Wednesday's sharp drop to $4.409 - its lowest level since August 1977. Silver traded late in London at a bid $4.28 a troy ounce, down from $4.53 Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Reaches $40.42, New Record
DOC.TEXT: Dwindling U.S. stockpiles, looming cold weather and a British warning of a Persian Gulf conflagration combined to drive oil prices back over $40 a barrel Thursday to a new record close in hectic futures trading. ``It's a market that reacts emotionally,'' said Bob Baker, an oil-trading specialist at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. in New York. ``It's going to stay that way as long as we have 200,000-plus troops out there.'' On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the November-delivery price of light sweet crude, the benchmark grade of oil, jumped $1.73 a barrel to close at $40.42, eclipsing the previous record of $40.40 set Tuesday. Later-delivery months also advanced strongly. The rise erased the decline a day earlier when traders dumped oil contracts on an unfounded rumor about the death of Saddam Hussein. The Iraqi leader's seizure of neighboring Kuwait more than two months ago led to an unprecedented U.S. military buildup in the petroleum-rich region and has doubled the price of oil since midsummer. Refined products traded on the exchange also surged Thursday. The most notable increase was in wholesale home heating oil for November delivery, which jumped 3.80 cents a gallon to $1.0485. Wholesale unleaded gasoline for November delivery jumped 2.4 cents a gallon to close at 96 cents, and natural gas rose 2 cents per 1,000 cubic feet to $1.96. Oil-market strategists said buyers plunged in at the opening of trading, motivated partly by a report from the American Petroleum Institute released after the close of trading Wednesday. API, an industry trade group, said its weekly tally of domestic supplies showed a 4.2 million barrel drop in crude stockpiles and a 1.5 million barrel drop in distillates, which includes heating oil. The declines were considered unusually steep, particularly at a time when seasonal demand for energy to heat homes is increasing. The report aggravated fears that the United States, which imports half its oil, was growing more vulnerable to shortages as the chances of a Persian Gulf war increased, which could cut off oil supplies completely from that area. Britain's Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd heightened war fears in the oil pits by telling fellow politicians in Britain that force would be used to evict the Iraqis from Kuwait if they didn't leave voluntarily. Hurd said that without a united front against Iraq, ``then we shall be back in a world of anarchy punctuated by explosions of force.'' Thomas Blakeslee, an energy analyst at the Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J., said the rhetoric unnerved professional traders, even though Hurd's remarks were basically no different than warnings the United States has issued to Iraq. ``Traders don't sit down and think about that type of thing,'' Blakeslee said. ``They don't have time.''

DOC.HEAD: Silver Plummets to Lowest Level in 14 Years
DOC.TEXT: Recession fears have sent silver and platinum plummeting in the last two days, and analysts say silver isn't looking quite like the precious metal it used to be. The spot price of silver fell 25.5 cents, or 5.6 percent, to $4.28 a troy ounce on Thursday from a late bid of $4.535 in London Wednesday. Thursday's late price was the lowest for silver since 1976, when the metal dipped as low as $3.82, according to Shearson Lehman Brothers Ltd. ``It's no longer a precious metal, it's an industrial metal,'' said Nick Hatch, a mining analyst at the London investment firm James Capel and Co. ``Both silver and platinum are suffering from mounting fears of an economic downturn,'' added Thomas Butler, a precious metals analyst at the London investment firm Samuel Montagu and Co. ``Both these metals have very strong industrial bases and fears that a recession may emerge soon are obviously undermining prices,'' he said. The spot price of platinum fell $23.50, or 5.3 percent, to $418.75 an ounce in London from $442.25 an ounce late Wednesday. That was its lowest since 1985, when the price reached $244, Shearson said. Silver rose as high at $35 an ounce in 1980 when the Hunt brothers of Texas tried to corner the silver market, Hatch said. It has fallen fairly steadily since. Analysts said silver is hurting lately because of the economic downturn that's affecting consumers to manufacturers. Silver is most widely used in the photographic industry, where demand is down, Hatch said. Silverware is a luxury item that's also coming under pressure from the economic slowdown, he said. There's also an abundance of silver. About 70 percent is produced as a byproduct of gold and other mining, Butler said. That means supply doesn't respond to changes in demand. Silver mines in Chile, Alaska and Nevada also are increasing production, and there's a lot of scrap being recovered, Hatch said. This year's total demand will come to 14,850 tons, surpassing expected supply of 14,400 tons, Hatch said. But he said there's a stockpile of roughly 10,000 tons. In the past, investors tended to snap up oversupply, Butler said. But that's no longer the case, he said. ``The long-term love affair with silver seems to be over,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Plastics Industry Looks To Recycling
LaserPhoto CX5
DOC.TEXT: As public concern mounts over the volume of packing materials, sandwich boxes and yogurt containers en route to landfills, plastic industry leaders have been thinking more about recycling to make the industry's outlook a little greener. In a recent survey, nearly 20 percent of Midwestern plastic industry leaders ranked environmental issues as having the greatest future impact on manufacturing. The survey - conducted by the Chicago-based Gary Siegel Organization for the investment firm of Berger, Goldstein Capital Group Inc. - found that the 6,500 industry executives polled cited solid waste disposal, ecological concerns and biodegradable products as top concerns. ``I think it's a combination of the industry being responsible and realizing that consumers are looking for these kind of recyclable products,'' said Bailey Condrey Jr., spokesman for the Council for Solid Waste Solutions. ``The companies want to maintain their market share by providing what customers want,'' said Condrey, whose Washington-based council consists of 26 plastic-producing companies. But some environmentalists say the solution is cutting the initial use of plastics, not reusing them. ``I don't think recycling plastics is the total answer to the waste disposal problem,'' said Kevin Greene, a researcher with the Chicago-based Citizens for a Better Environment. ``First we must cut down on the excessive use of packaging, plastic or otherwise.'' Plastic recycling today involves mostly food service and packaging products made of polystyrene plastic, said James Schneiders, president of National Polystyrene Recycling Co. In the late 1980s, his company opened one of the nation's first polystyrene recycling plants, in Leominster, Mass. In recycling, the materials are cleaned and ground into resin pellets, which then are used alone or in combination with virgin materials to produce plastic products. ``We're really benefiting society in two ways - by reusing materials that still have life in them and by cutting the use of primary material,'' Schneiders said. Environmentalists still have doubts. Because plastic products are so bulky they are difficult to collect and transport for recycling, Greene said. He also said Food and Drug Administration regulation prohibits the use of recycled products in most food packaging. ``We still favor the use of glass and aluminum,'' Greene said. ``Those products can be recycled into the same food and beverage containers. Some waste disposal experts say plastics in landfills aren't that big a problem, however. ``Plastics are among the most innocuous materials in landfills,'' said Allen Blakey, spokesman for the National Solid Waste Management Association. ``In many ways they're the perfect item to put into landfill because they don't decay'' and produce toxic byproducts. Blakey said about 20 percent, or 14.4 million tons, of the waste put in landfills in 1988 came from plastics. Paper products were the largest contributor with 34 percent, he said.

DOC.HEAD: OJ Price Plunge Likely After Bumper Crop Forecast
DOC.TEXT: Orange juice futures traders braced for a price collapse after the government on Thursday projected a 50 percent increase in Florida orange production this season, barring another significant freeze. Consumers should see lower prices in grocery store freezer cases within weeks as retailers try to reduce their inventories of frozen concentrate, analysts said. Orange juice futures fell sharply on the New York Cotton Exchange ahead of the report and analysts predicted the near-term contract, for delivery in November, would plunge Friday its permitted daily limit of 10 cents. On other commodity markets Thursday, oil futures surged; silver futures continued to plummet; gold rose slightly; grains and soybeans retreated; cattle futures fell; and pork futures were mixed. Futures prices for wholesale frozen concentrated orange juice settled .85 cent to 2.55 cents lower in New York with November at $1.299 a pound. Several analysts said orange juice futures likely will keep falling to less than $1 a pound, a four-year low, in reaction to the Agriculture Department's projection for a Florida orange harvest of 165 million 90-pound boxes. Florida growers harvested 110.2 million boxes last season after a severe Christmastime freeze. Most analysts had expected the USDA projection, which was the first government estimate of the new season, to be around 132 million boxes. ``No one anticipated this figure,'' said analyst Celeste Georkakis of Cargill Investor Services Inc. The government projected a total U.S. orange harvest of 231 million boxes. The USDA projected an increase in Florida orange juice yield to 1.52 gallons of juice per box compared with 1.23 gallons per box last year. Judith Ganes, orange juice analyst for Merrill Lynch & Co., said retailers will be forced to drop proces to stimulate demand. ``They're going to have to move the product,'' she said. Retail prices may not drop sharply until late winter, after the threat of frost damage is past, but moderate price reductions are likely ``almost immediately,'' said analyst Sandra Kaul of Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. Elsewhere, oil prices soared on the New York Mercantile Exchange, reflecting fears of war in the Middle East and a trade group report that showed an unexpected decline in U.S. supplies of crude oil. Light sweet crude oil settled 52 cents to $1.73 higher with November at $40.42 a barrel; heating oil was 1.05 cents to 3.8 cents higher with November at $1.0485 a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .10 cent to 2.4 cents higher with Noember at 96 cents a gallon. Inflation jitters helped pull gold futures higher on New York's Commodity Exchange but silver tumbled to a 14-year low, reflecting burdensome supplies and slack demand for the metal. Gold finished $1.40 to $1.60 higher with October at $389.70 a troy ounce; silver was 17.4 cents to 19.2 cents lower with October at $4.235 a troy ounce. Most grain and soybean futures prices fell on the Chicago Board of Trade, reflecting bearish export signals in the wheat market and position-evening ahead of a government crop report. In the report, the USDA projected the 1990 U.S. corn harvst at 8.02 billion bushels compared with its September estimate of 8.12 billion and market expectations averaging 8.06 billion. The USDA projected soybean production of 1.82 billion bushels compared with the September estimate of 1.84 billion and market expectations averaging 1.83 billion. Analysts predicted a slight opening drop in corn and bean futures Friday in reaction to the report. Wheat futures settled 2{ cents to 5 cents lower with December at $2.71\ a bushel; corn was 2} cents to 4\ cents lower with December at $2.32} a bushel; oats were 2{ cents to 3\ cents lower with December at $1.19} a bushel; soybeans were 4{ cents lower to 5 cents higher with November at $6.20{ a bushel. On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, live cattle finished .20 cent lower to .68 cent higher with October at 78.52 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .33 cent to .80 cent lower with October at 87.37 cents a pound; live hogs were .17 cent lower to .28 cent higher with October at 56.52 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1 cent to 1.25 cents higher with February at 64.40 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Chemical Bank Loses $43.7 Million, Cuts Dividend
DOC.TEXT: Chemical Banking Corp. reporeed a $43.7 million third-quarter loss Thursday and cut its dividend by more than half, another sign of painful times in the domestic banking business. The loss by the nation's 6th-largest banking company was an improvement over a year earlier but still reflected the rise in shaky loans and a softening economy that have afflicted several leading U.S. banks in recent months. ``Chemical Bank is struggling, as are other banks, with a deteriorating operating environment and the declining real estate market in the Northeast,'' said James McDermott, a banking analyst at Keefe Bruyette & Woods, a New York investment firm. Chemical said the results stemmed primarily from a $250 million increase in its reserves for loan losses and a $18.8 million accounting charge to cover the cost of shutting down its securities trading business in Switzerland and Japan, a move that had been announced previously. It also reported an improvement in the Texas Commerce Bancshares subsidiary, which earned $22.9 million. By contrast, Texas Commerce lost $372.4 million in the year-earlier quarter, which contributed to a loss of $824.6 million by the parent company during that period. Chemical said it dropped the quarterly dividend from 68 cents a share to 25 cents to ``retain a higher level of common equity to support consistent growth in its profitable core businesses.'' The dividend cut had not been unexpected. Several leading banks, notably No. 2 Chase Manhattan, have taken the painful step of cutting dividends recently to help strengthen their financial structures. For the first nine months of 1990, Chemical said it earned $221.1 million or $1.83 a share, vs. a loss of $578.1 million in the year-earlier period. The Bank of New York, meanwhile, said it earned $71 million or 90 cents a share in the third quarter ended Sept. 30, vs. a $271 million loss a year earlier. The 11th-largest U.S. banking company said it attributed the performance partly to an improvement in efficiency stemming from its acquisition of Irving Bank Corp. in 1989. Still, the bank said earnings were hurt by shaky real estate loans and Latin American debt, which led the company to increase its loan-loss provision by $113 million. For the nine months ended Sept. 30, net income was $243 million, compared with a loss of $56 million for the same period last year.

DOC.HEAD: Keating Lawyers, Rejected in State Court, Ask Federal Court to Lower Bail
DOC.TEXT: Rejected three times in state courts, lawyers for Charles H. Keating Jr. asked a federal court judge Thursday to reduce the jailed financier's $5 million bail. ``The district attorney's office did not offer a shred of evidence to support a finding that Keating is a flight risk,'' the U.S. District Court petition said. Keating's attorneys said the $5 million bail set by Superior Court Judge Gary Klausner was excessive and unconstitutional, and argued Keating couldn't adequately defend himself against fraud charges as long as he was in jail. On Wednesday, the California Supreme Court refused to consider lowering bail for the key figure in the Lincoln Savings & Loan collapse. Keating, a 66-year-old Arizona developer, has remained at a Los Angeles jail since his indictment last month on charges of misleading investors about the security of junk bonds sold at the failed Lincoln Savings. Keating was chairman of American Continental Corp., Lincoln's Phoenix-based parent company. Federal regulators took over the Irvine-based thrift last year, in a bailout expected to cost taxpayers $2 billion. Keating pleaded innocent to the charges at a hearing last week. A pretrial hearing was scheduled Monday.

DOC.HEAD: AT&T Microelectronics Introduces `Multimedia' Chip
DOC.TEXT: AT&T Microelectronics on Thursday unveiled a high-performance, low-cost computer chip for personal computers and workstations that combines voice, audio, graphics and modem functions. The DSP3210 chip, said to be compatible with Intel and Motorola 32-bit microprocessors that power IBM-compatible and Apple PCs, allows computer users to work with video images and compact disk-quality sound at the same time. ``The DSP3210 is designed for the emerging market in PCs and workstations that let users escape the limitations of low-resolution images and beep-quality sounds,'' said Kreg Ulery, AT&T's multimedia marketing manager. ``In fact, we expect the DSP3210 to become the worldwide standard architecture for multimedia applications,'' he said. AT&T plans to start producting the chip in the fourth quarter of 1991. It is expected to cost less than $50 in quantities of 100,000. The announcement, made at the Microprocessor Forum West seminar, is the latest indication that the industry is preparing a push into multimedia computing devices. The industry, including IBM and Apple Computer, is working to incorporate multimedia functions into the PCs and workstations they are developing. Next Computer Inc. already sells a computer with some multimedia capability using a Motorola Inc. digital signal processor. Motorola said its chip, the $200 96002, is more powerful than AT&T's. Industry observers called AT&T's new product significant. ``The PC industry hasn't had a high-powered digital signal processor that can integrate all these functions at the motherboard level,'' said Tim Bajarin, executive vice president of Creative Strategies, a Santa Clara research firm. Although there are other digital signal processors on the market, AT&T's new chip brings ``a fairly high level of performance at a price that makes it economically feasible to include it as a standard device in a PC,'' said Michael Slater, editor of Microprocessor report.

DOC.TEXT: The stock market dropped sharply for the third straight session Thursday, hitting a new 18-month low in an atmosphere of dismay about the outlook for business and the government's finances. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials fell 42.82 to 2,365.10, bringing its loss over the past three days to 158.66 points. That marked the lowest close for the average since it stood at 2,337.79 on April 17, 1989. Declining issues outnumbered advances by more than 4 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 301 up, 1,290 down and 416 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 180.06 million shares, against 167.89 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 219.03 million shares. Analysts said there was little in the news to relieve the gloom that has gripped the market since midsummer. The price of crude-oil for November delivery climbed $1.73 a barrel, to $40.42 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Recession worries have kept mounting of late as investors await the peak flow of corporate earnings reports for the third quarter, due over the next couple of weeks. But economic weakness hasn't so far brought any downward pressure on long-term interest rates. Brokers also said market participants were frustrated by the slow progress and many twists and turns of efforts in Washington toward a plan to narrow the federal budget deficit. Meanwhile, fresh evidence emerged of the troubles afflicting the banking industry. Chemical Banking of New York posted a $43.7 million loss for the third quarter and cut its quarterly dividend from 68 cents a share to 25 cents a share. Chemical's stock fell \ to 14}. Among other prominent money-center banking issues, Citicorp dropped { to 13|; Chase Manhattan ] to 12; J.P. Morgan } to 32[, and Manufacturers Hanover 1~ to 20. Losers among the blue-chip industrials included Aluminum Co. of America, down 2 at 54{; Philip Morris, down } at 44\; General Electric, down } at 51\, and International Business Machines, down 2{ at 101. Golden Valley Microwave Foods, which said it expected to report flat earnings and lower sales for the third quarter, slumped 2 to 8{ The Limited dropped { to 12 in active trading. The company said its margins were somewhat lower in the third quarter than they had been in the corresponding period last year. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $51.40 billion, or 1.82 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell 2.77 to 162.20. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell 6.25 to 346.86, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was down 4.93 at 295.46. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market dropped 7.64 to 325.61. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 293.71, down 5.55.

DOC.HEAD: UAL Offers Employees New Stock Ownership Plan
DOC.TEXT: UAL Corp. on Thursday offered employees a discount stock-purchase program that union officials said could give workers a 20 percent stake in the airline company. The board of directors earlier this week rebuffed the unions' bid for full employee ownership. UAL spokesman Joe Hopkins said he did not know if the 20 percent limit to the stock ownership cited by the unions is correct. Nor did he know how much stock employees now own. The company made a brief reference to the stock plan in a letter to employees on Wednesday, then added a few details in a bulletin board announcement on Thursday. It said that shortly after the first of the year, employees will be offered UAL stock at a 15 percent discount from the market price. In addition, the company will offer expanded stock-purchase rights to salaried and management employees. ``We believe these changes will be attractive for employees who wish to acquire United stock and share in the future successes of United through ownership,'' said Paul George, senior vice president for human resources. The three principal unions representing United Airlines employees expressed reservations about the plan. ``It is ironic that UAL proposes to sell 20 percent of its stock to its employees at a discount only two days after rejecting our offer to buy all of the stock at a significant premium above the current market price,'' heads of the pilots, machinists and flight attendants unions said in a statement. They said that while they favor employee ownership of stock, ``management's proposal for limited stock ownership raises numerous issues which must be addressed in negotiations.'' Tuesday's rejection of a bid for full employee ownership marked the fourth failed take-over attempt in 3{ years. The employee group was unable to arrange financing by the Tuesday deadline for the $201-a-share, $4.38 billion, offer the board accepted in principle in April. Despite the lack of bank financing, the buyout group presented the board with two other offers, both of which were rejected.

DOC.HEAD: Both Sides Claim Victory in Intel-Advanced Micro Devices Dispute
DOC.TEXT: An arbitrator Thursday ruled Intel Corp. did not act in good faith in a dispute with Advanced Micro Devices over the rights to Intel's highly profitable 386 microprocessor. The arbitrator, retired Superior Court Judge J. Barton Phelps, however, stopped short of ordering Intel to transfer the chip's rights to AMD. Phelps said remedies will be considered in a hearing to begin Nov. 15. Both sides claimed victory in the dispute over a 1982 contract under which the companies were to trade technology. Advanced Micro initiated the arbitration, seeking to require Intel to transfer products including the 386 chip rights to AMD, and also asked for $1 billion in damages. Intel has contended that AMD failed to develop acceptable products under the agreement and, therefore, is not entitled to take any Intel products. Phelps decided that Intel had provided ``a classic example of a breach of the covenant of good faith and fair dealing, preaching good faith but practicing duplicity.'' W.J. Sanders III, chairman and chief executive officer of AMD, said he was confident the company will get monetary damages as well as rights to the 386 chip durin the remedies hearing. F. Thomas Dunlap Jr., Intel general counsel, said the company was pleased the decision did not order the microprocessor's transfer. ``Although the decision does not completely foreclose the possibility of future product transfers, the concept of product-for-product exchange still applies. Intel continues to believe that the contract specifically limits remedies which can be awarded and that Intel's position on both damages and product transfers will prevail,'' Dunlap said. The 1982 exchange agreement was amended in 1984 and terminated in 1987. In the remedies hearing, AMD will ask for more than $500 million in damages and rights to the microprocessor, the company said.

DOC.HEAD: EAST MEETS HIGH-TECH:
Computer Makers Eye Potentially Huge Eastern European Market
DOC.TEXT: UNDATED - The return of capitalism to Eastern Europe presents a potentially vast new market for Western computer makers, a development that could boost a vital U.S. export industry. Computer and software companies could be among the early beneficiaries of modernization drives in these formerly communist nations since computers are a crucial ingredient in banking, telephone and transportation systems - all targets for major investment. ``You can't have a modern economy without massive infusions of information technology,'' says one executive. Slug BC-Computers-Eastern Europe. By Business Writer Bart Ziegler. Moved Monday on FFF-level news wires for Sunday, Oct. 14.
DOC.BYLINE: Hungary Serves As IBM's Eastern Model
DOC.TEXT: BUDAPEST, Hungary - IBM Hungary is the giant computer company's window on the East. The subsidiary was one of the few Western companies to weather more than four decades of communism in Hungary. Now it is serving as IBM's model for expansion in the rest of Eastern Europe. Slug BC-IBM-Hungary. By Business Writer Bart Ziegler. Moved Monday on FFF-level news wires for Sunday, Oct. 14. With LaserPhoto NY300 of Oct. 9.
DOC.BYLINE: PLASTIC PARADISE: States Lure Banks With Card Deregulation
DOC.TEXT: ATLANTA - In the great chase to attract jobs, state after state banked on deregulation during the 1980s to bring credit card issuers to their doors. South Dakota acted first, attracting the plum of the industry, Citibank, in 1980. Delaware followed quickly, and 18 other states have since deregulated credit card rates and fees in varying fashion, scrambling to create cozy environments for credit card issuers. Slug BC-Credit Card Banks. By Business Writer Marc Rice. Moved Wednesday on FFF-level news wires for Sunday, Oct. 14.
With BC-Credit Card Banks-List, BC-Credit Card Banks-States.
DOC.BYLINE: DADDY BIG BUCKS: Richest American Credits Success To Gambling And Luck
DOC.TEXT: RICHMOND, Va. - Metromedia Co. founder John W. Kluge, the wealthiest man in America, was taking a beating on Wall Street in the early 1980s when he got some financial advice from his wife, Patricia. `` `Go out and become a billionaire, and don't come back until you are,' '' Mrs. Kluge, now separated from her 76-year-old husband, said she told him then. ``And he did.'' Slug BC-Personal File-Kluge. By Business Writer Joe Taylor. Moved Wednesday on FFF-level news wires for Sunday, Oct. 14. With LaserPhoto RM1 of Oct. 11
DOC.BYLINE: TROUBLED CITY: Motor City Hasn't Run Out Of Gas Despite Decay
DOC.TEXT: DETROIT - Detroit was a legend of the manufacturing world, the Motor City that spawned wealthy suburbs. But today its decrepit center decays under the blows of poverty and crime. At least a third of the city's population has left since 1960 and a third of those who remain are on welfare. Yet there is fight left in this Great Lakes City which may become the free-trade link to Canada. Slug BC-Detroit Profile. Two takes. By A.J. Dickerson. Moved Monday on FFF-level news wires for Sunday, Oct. 14. Also moved on AP Newsfeatures. Three mailed photos, one graphic, one ColorFoto.
DOC.BYLINE: COSTLY SCRIPTS: Hollywood Screenwriters Starting To Command Spectacular Fees
DOC.TEXT: LOS ANGELES - What's more important to a movie, the story or the star? The men and women behind the scenes who write words that actors mouth have been grossly underpaid, compared with the people in front of the camera. But that is changing now, with major studios shelling out millions of dollars for scripts. BC-Script Costs, Two takes. By John Horn. Moved Monday on FFF-news wires for Sunday, Oct. 14. Also moved on AP Newsfeatures. One mailed graphic.
DOC.BYLINE: FIRST BUSINESS: Company Founded by Bush Struggles To Stay Afloat
DOC.TEXT: HOUSTON - Zapata Corp. helped make a future president wealthy. But the company founded by George Bush is now struggling to avoid bankruptcy by shedding the oil drilling business that was its foundation. Saddled with $560 million in debt from overexpansion, Zapata plans a realignment that includes selling its fleet of rigs and restructuring debt. Slug BC-Bush's Old Business. By Wendy Benjaminson. Moved Tuesday on FFF-level news wires for Monday, Oct. 15. With LaserPhoto.
DOC.BYLINE: MIDWESTERN STANDOFF: Striking Miners Dig In For Long Winter
DOC.TEXT: NEGUANEE, Mich. - The autumn-blazed hills of Marquette County are hushed with the silence of two foes trying to outlast each other. The largest iron ore range in North America is idle. Almost 2,000 United Steelworkers have been on strike against Cleveland Cliffs Inc. since Aug. 1. The two sides haven't talked in more than a month, and no further negotiations are planned. Picketers, bracing for a long strike, already have the snowblowers out and are building a winterized shelter. Slug BC-Waiting Game. By Paige St. John. Moved Tuesday for FFF-level news wires for Monday, Oct. 15. With LaserPhoto DT6 of Oct. 10.
DOC.BYLINE: DOLLARS WELCOME: Argentina Keeps Austral But People Prefer `Greenback'
DOC.TEXT: BUENOS AIRES, Argentina - The government insists it will not change the austral as Argentina's officials currency - it's fifth in 20 years. But many Argentines already have. Most every good and service in this Latin nation now is priced in U.S. dollars, or ``greenbacks'' as they're known here, as well as the devalued austral, making Argentina one of the few countries in the world with two working currencies. Slug BC-Argentina-Two Currencies. By Vicente L. Panetta. Moved Wednesday on FFF-level news wires for Monday, Oct. 15. With LaserPhoto BAI3 of Oct. 9.
DOC.BYLINE: LATIN WOES: South Americans Embattled by Recession
DOC.TEXT: LIMA, Peru - Record numbers of Argentines are unemployed. Brazil's economy has shrunk almost 10 percent in a year and millions of Peruvians go hungry. A deep recession is spreading through many of the countries that stretch south from the Caribbean to Tierra del Fuego. The free-market economic ``shock'' programs adopted in the past several years have conquered hyperinflation, but at the brutal cost of making most Latin Americans desperately poor. BC-Latin Austerity. By Barry Lynn. Moved Tuesday on FFF-level news wires for Wednesday, Oct. 17. With LaserPhoto. Also moved on general news wires.
